('83', 0, 1, 2, 42) 1. KHADI IN KATHIAWAD
('83', 0, 2, 3, 64) Readers must be aware that in order to make the khadi activity more extensive and more popular a Committee has been set up.
('83', 0, 2, 4, 188) Shri Nanabhai has been appointed its President and Shri Nagardas Doshi is its Secretary.
('83', 0, 2, 5, 277) The money which was collected on the occasion of the Rentia Jayanti 1 and which I had deposited with Shri Narandas Gandhi has been given to the Committee.
('83', 0, 2, 6, 432) 2 I have received a report of this khadi activity for the period 1938 to 1941 entitled Kathiawadna Khadikamno Heval, published by Pandya Khadi Karyalaya, Chalala.
('83', 0, 2, 7, 595) The following paragraphs 3 from that will give some idea of the khadi activity.
('83', 0, 2, 8, 675) The number of spinners in 1938 was 150 which rose to 600 in 1941. In 1941 there were 500 caste Hindus, 18 Muslims and 12 Harijan spinners.
('83', 0, 2, 9, 814) In 1938 the wages given came to Rs. 3,481 while in 1941 the amount was Rs. 18,948. The monthly income of a spinner in 1938 was Rs. 4 12 while in 1941 it rose to Rs. 10. The weavers’ wages increased from Rs. 12 to Rs. 30 and that of carders to Rs. 18 from Rs. 7. The report is good.
('83', 0, 2, 10, 1096) There is scope for raising the figures.
('83', 0, 2, 11, 1136) The progress of the work is satisfactory.
('83', 0, 2, 12, 1178) We can easily gauge the efforts of Shri Nagardas.
('83', 0, 2, 13, 1228) But Kathiawad is a small province with a population of 26 lakhs.
('83', 0, 2, 14, 1293) There is scope for much work.
('83', 0, 2, 15, 1323) How can we increase the number of workers?
('83', 0, 2, 16, 1366) In other words how can we make the work more interesting and attractive?
('83', 0, 3, 17, 1439) [From Gujarati]
('83', 0, 4, 18, 1455) Harijanbandhu, 7 6 1942
('83', 0, 5, 19, 1479) 1 Gandhiji’s birthday according to the Vikram Calendar 2 Vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 30 6 1942. 3 Not translated here.
('83', 0, 5, 20, 1604) The report stated that the Chalala Khadi Karyalaya had become the headquarters for khadi production and sales centres in Kathiawar.
('83', 0, 5, 21, 1736) There was no paid worker to carry On the routine office work, which was done by workers over and above their other activities.
('83', 1, 0, 1, 1863) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 1, 1, 2, 1903) 2. RAJAJI
('83', 1, 2, 3, 1913) Although I retain the opinion I have expressed about my differences with Rajaji, and although I adhere to every word I have said and he has quoted, and although I reaffirm my opinion that my language taken in its context does not bear the interpretation Rajaji puts upon it.
('83', 1, 2, 4, 2188) I do not propose henceforth to enter into any public controversy with him.
('83', 1, 2, 5, 2263) I join him in hoping that some day I shall see the error of my views which he sees so clearly.
('83', 1, 2, 6, 2358) But public controversy with close companions like Rajaji repels me.
('83', 1, 2, 7, 2426) He has a new mission and he has need to speak.
('83', 1, 2, 8, 2473) SEVAGRAM, June 7, 1942
('83', 1, 3, 9, 2496) Harijan, 14 6 1942

('83', 1, 9, 23, 3014) 4. NO SALVATION WITHOUT SACRIFICE
('83', 1, 10, 24, 3048) Accounts pour in upon me from all quarters about the action of the authorities demanding evacuation without notice.
('83', 1, 10, 25, 3164) Sometimes it is a zamindar who is to surrender his bungalow and sometimes it is a middle class man who has to surrender his house with fans and
('83', 1, 11, 26, 3308) 1Vide the preceding item
('83', 2, 0, 1, 3333) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 3
('83', 2, 1, 2, 3375) furniture for the use of the military.
('83', 2, 1, 3, 3414) More often it is villagers or labourers who are called upon under promise of compensation to vacate their quarters.
('83', 2, 1, 4, 3530) The condition of these people is piteous.
('83', 2, 1, 5, 3572) They do not know where to go.
('83', 2, 1, 6, 3602) To these I can only say, ‘Do not move— and take the consequences.
('83', 2, 1, 7, 3668) They cannot be forcibly ejected.
('83', 2, 1, 8, 3701) Even if they are, their cry will be heard whereas newspaper articles will be of little avail.
('83', 2, 1, 9, 3795) SEVAGRAM, June 8, 1942

('83', 3, 6, 13, 4979) 7. LETTER TO VALLABHRAM VAIDYA
('83', 3, 7, 14, 5010) SEVAGRAM, June 8 1, 1942
('83', 3, 8, 15, 5035) BHAI VALLABHRAM,
('83', 3, 9, 16, 5052) I could read the whole of your letter only today.
('83', 3, 9, 17, 5102) It did help me to understand your mind but it did not satisfy me.
('83', 3, 9, 18, 5168) That is because the task which you seek to accomplish cannot be accomplished with what you intend doing.
('83', 3, 9, 19, 5273) Many vaidyas have raised farms of the kind you want.
('83', 3, 9, 20, 5326) No doubt you can improve upon them, but you cannot reform the vaidyas.
('83', 3, 9, 21, 5397) I offered to entrust my entire treatment to the vaidyas but I was disappointed.
('83', 3, 9, 22, 5477) Lakshmipati wanted to settle here and made all the preparations but never turned up.
('83', 3, 9, 23, 5562) I sent a patient to him whom he dismissed telling him that he was all right.
('83', 3, 9, 24, 5639) The patient came back as ill as ever.
('83', 3, 9, 25, 5677) I tried to lure you to come and settle down here and conduct experiments but there were difficulties in your way.
('83', 3, 10, 26, 5791) 1 Pyarelal Papers has “9”.
('83', 4, 0, 1, 5818) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 5
('83', 4, 1, 2, 5860) Although I have said all this my blessings are with you.
('83', 4, 1, 3, 5917) Your intentions are pure; may they bear fruit.
('83', 4, 1, 4, 5964) At present it is allopathy that commands enterprise, industry and knowledge.
('83', 4, 1, 5, 6041) It is a developing science.
('83', 4, 1, 6, 6069) It has many defects.
('83', 4, 1, 7, 6090) Its pharmacopoeia is vast and yet very restricted.
('83', 4, 1, 8, 6141) But it is systematic and so can draw upon whatever is special in Ayurveda.
('83', 4, 1, 9, 6216) However, it is worth reflecting upon that if Ayurveda were to take what is special in allopathy the latter would be left with nothing but a few drugs.
('83', 4, 2, 10, 6367) Blessings from BAPU SHRI VALLABHRAM VAIDYA 23 SAURASHTRA SOCIETY AHMEDABAD

('83', 9, 4, 9, 13069) 18. INTERVIEW TO PRESTON GROVER 1
('83', 9, 5, 10, 13103) WARDHA, [June 10, 1942] 2
('83', 9, 6, 11, 13129) Q. There has been a great deal of questioning in America and India to as to the nature of your activities during the balance of the War.
('83', 9, 6, 12, 13266) I should like to know what it will be like.
('83', 9, 7, 13, 13310) GANDHIJI: But can you tell me when the War will end?
('83', 9, 8, 14, 13363) Q. There is a good deal of speculation that you are planning some new movement.
('83', 9, 8, 15, 13443) What is the nature of it?
('83', 9, 9, 16, 13469) A. It depends on the response made by the Government and the people.
('83', 9, 9, 17, 13538) I am trying to find out public opinion here and also the reaction on the world outside.
('83', 9, 10, 18, 13626) Q. When you speak of the response, you mean response to your new proposal?
('83', 9, 11, 19, 13701) A. Oh yes, I mean response to the proposal that the British Government in India should end today.
('83', 9, 11, 20, 13799) Are you startled?
('83', 9, 12, 21, 13817) Q. I am not.
('83', 9, 12, 22, 13830) You have been asking for it and working for it.
('83', 9, 13, 23, 13878) A. That’s right.
('83', 9, 13, 24, 13895) I have been working for it for years.
('83', 9, 13, 25, 13933) But now it has taken definite shape and I say that the British power in India should go today for the world peace, for China, for Russia and for the Allied cause.
('83', 9, 13, 26, 14096) I shall explain to you how it advances the Allied cause.
('83', 9, 13, 27, 14153) Complete independence frees India’s energies, frees her to make her contribution to the world crisis.
('83', 9, 13, 28, 14255) Today the Allies are carrying the burden of a huge corpse—a huge nation lying prostrate at the feet of Britain, I would even say at the feet of the Allies.
('83', 9, 13, 29, 14411) For America is the predominant partner, financing the war, giving her mechanical ability
('83', 9, 14, 30, 14500) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Throw Away the Carcass”.
('83', 9, 14, 31, 14559) Preston Grover of the Associated Press of America had especially come over from New Delhi for the interview.
('83', 9, 14, 32, 14668) 2 From Gandhi—1915 1948
('83', 10, 0, 1, 14692) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 11
('83', 10, 1, 2, 14735) and her resources which are inexhaustible.
('83', 10, 1, 3, 14778) America is thus a partner in the guilt.
('83', 10, 2, 4, 14818) Q. Do you see a situation when after full independence is granted American and Allied troops can operate from India?
('83', 10, 2, 5, 14935) A. I do.
('83', 10, 2, 6, 14944) It will be only then that you will see real co operation.
('83', 10, 2, 7, 15002) Otherwise all the effort you put up may fail.
('83', 10, 2, 8, 15048) Just now Britain is having India’s resources because India is her possession.
('83', 10, 2, 9, 15126) Tomorrow whatever the help, it will be real help from a free India.
('83', 10, 3, 10, 15194) Q. You think India in control interferes with Allied action to meet Japan’s aggression?
('83', 10, 4, 11, 15282) A. It does.
('83', 10, 5, 12, 15294) Q. When I mentioned Allied troops operating I wanted to know whether you contemplated complete shifting of the present troops from India?
('83', 10, 6, 13, 15432) A. Not necessarily.
('83', 10, 7, 14, 15452) Q. It is on this that there is a lot of misconception.
('83', 10, 8, 15, 15507) A. You have to study all I am writing.
('83', 10, 8, 16, 15546) I have discussed the whole question in the current issue of Harijan.
('83', 10, 8, 17, 15615) 1 I do not want them to go, on condition that India becomes entirely free.
('83', 10, 8, 18, 15690) I cannot then insist on their withdrawal, because I want to resist with all my might the charge of inviting Japan to India.
('83', 10, 9, 19, 15814) Q. But suppose your proposal is rejected, what will be your next move?
('83', 10, 10, 20, 15885) A. It will be a move which will be felt by the whole world.
('83', 10, 10, 21, 15945) It may not interfere with the movement of British troops, but it is sure to engage British attention.
('83', 10, 10, 22, 16047) It would be wrong of them to reject my proposal and say India should remain a slave in order that Britain may win or be able to defend China.
('83', 10, 10, 23, 16189) I cannot accept that degrading position.
('83', 10, 10, 24, 16230) India free and independent will play a prominent part in defending China.
('83', 10, 10, 25, 16304) Today I do not think she is rendering any real help to China.
('83', 10, 10, 26, 16366) We have followed the non embarrassment policy so far.
('83', 10, 10, 27, 16420) We will follow it even now.
('83', 10, 10, 28, 16448) But we cannot allow the British Government to exploit it in order to strengthen the stranglehold on India.
('83', 10, 10, 29, 16555) And today it amounts to that.
('83', 10, 10, 30, 16585) The way, for instance, in which thousands are being asked to vacate their homes with nowhere to go to, no land to cultivate, no resources to fall back upon, is the reward of our non embarrassment.
('83', 10, 10, 31, 16782) This should be impossible in any free country.
('83', 10, 10, 32, 16829) I cannot tolerate India submitting to this kind of treatment.
('83', 10, 10, 33, 16891) It means greater degradation and servility, and when a whole nation accepts
('83', 10, 11, 34, 16967) 1Vide “Question Box”, 12 6 1942.
('83', 11, 0, 1, 17000) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 11, 1, 2, 17041) servility it means good bye for ever to freedom.
('83', 11, 2, 3, 17090) Q. All you want is the civil grip relaxed.
('83', 11, 2, 4, 17133) You won’t then hinder military activity?
('83', 11, 2, 5, 17174) A. I do not know.
('83', 11, 2, 6, 17192) I want unadulterated independence.
('83', 11, 2, 7, 17227) If the military activity serves but to strengthen the stranglehold, I must resist that too.
('83', 11, 2, 8, 17319) I am no philanthropist to go on helping at the expense of my freedom.
('83', 11, 2, 9, 17389) And what I want you to see is that a corpse cannot give any help to a living body.
('83', 11, 2, 10, 17472) The Allies have no moral cause for which they are fighting, so long as they are carrying this double sin on their shoulders, the sin of India’s subjection and the subjection of the Negroes and African races.
('83', 11, 3, 11, 17680) Mr. Grover tried to draw a picture of a free India after an Allied victory.
('83', 11, 3, 12, 17756) Why not wait for the boons of victory?
('83', 11, 3, 13, 17795) Gandhiji mentioned as the boons of the last World War the Rowlatt Act and martial law and Amritsar.
('83', 11, 3, 14, 17895) Mr. Grover mentioned more economic and industrial prosperity—by no means due to the grace of the Government, but by the force of circumstances, and economic prosperity was a step further forward to swaraj.
('83', 11, 3, 15, 18101) Gandhiji said the few industrial gains were wrung out of unwilling hands, he set no store by such gains after this war, those gains may be further shackles, and it was a doubtful proposition whether there would be any gains—when one had in mind the industrial policy that was being followed during the war.
('83', 11, 3, 16, 18408) Mr. Grover did not seriously press the point.
('83', 11, 4, 17, 18454) Q. You don’t expect any assistance from America in persuading Britain to relinquish her hold on India.
('83', 11, 5, 18, 18557) A. I do indeed.
('83', 11, 6, 19, 18573) Q. With any possibility of success?
('83', 11, 7, 20, 18609) A. There is every possibility, I should think.
('83', 11, 7, 21, 18656) I have every right to expect America to throw her full weight on the side of justice, if she is convinced of the justice of the Indian cause.
('83', 11, 8, 22, 18798) Q. You don’t think the American Government is committed to the British remaining in India?
('83', 11, 9, 23, 18889) A. I hope not.
('83', 11, 9, 24, 18904) But British diplomacy is so clever that America, even though it may not be committed, and in spite of the desire of President Roosevelt and the people to help India, it may not succeed.
('83', 11, 9, 25, 19090) British propaganda is so well organized in America against the Indian cause that the few friends India has there have no chance of being effectively heard.
('83', 11, 9, 26, 19246) And the political system is so rigid that public opinion does not affect the administration.
('83', 11, 10, 27, 19339) Q. It may, slowly.
('83', 12, 0, 1, 19358) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 13
('83', 12, 1, 2, 19401) A. Slowly?
('83', 12, 1, 3, 19412) I have waited long, and I can wait no longer.
('83', 12, 1, 4, 19458) It is a terrible tragedy that 40 crores of people should have no say in this war.
('83', 12, 1, 5, 19540) If we have the freedom to play our part we can arrest the march of Japan and save China.
('83', 12, 2, 6, 19629) Mr. Grover, having made himself sure that Gandhiji did not insist on the literal withdrawal of either the British or the troops, now placing himself in the position of the Allies, began to calculate the gains of the bargain.
('83', 12, 2, 7, 19854) Gandhiji of course does not want independence as a reward of any services, but as a right and in discharge of a debt long overdue.
('83', 12, 3, 8, 19985) Q. What specific things would be done by India to save China, if India is declared independent?
('83', 12, 4, 9, 20081) A. Great things, I can say at once, though I may not be able to specify them today.
('83', 12, 4, 10, 20165) For I do not know what government we shall have.
('83', 12, 4, 11, 20214) We have various political organizations here which I expect would be able to work out a proper national solution.
('83', 12, 4, 12, 20328) Just now they are not solid parties, they are often acted upon by the British power, they look up to it and its frown or favour means much to them.
('83', 12, 4, 13, 20476) The whole atmosphere is corrupt and rotten.
('83', 12, 4, 14, 20520) Who can foresee the possibilities of a corpse coming to life?
('83', 12, 4, 15, 20582) At present India is a dead weight to the Allies.
('83', 12, 5, 16, 20631) Q. By dead weight you mean a menace to Britain and to American interests here?
('83', 12, 6, 17, 20710) A. I do.
('83', 12, 6, 18, 20719) It is a menace in that you never know what sullen India will do at a given moment.
('83', 12, 7, 19, 20802) Q. No, but I want to make myself sure that if genuine pressure was brought to bear on Britain by America, there would be solid support from yourself?
('83', 12, 8, 20, 20952) A. Myself?
('83', 12, 8, 21, 20963) I do not count—with the weight of 73 years on my shoulders.
('83', 12, 8, 22, 21023) But you get the co operation—whatever it can give willingly—of a free and mighty nation.
('83', 12, 8, 23, 21112) My co operation is of course there.
('83', 12, 8, 24, 21148) I exercise what influence I can by my writings from week to week.
('83', 12, 8, 25, 21214) But India’s is an infinitely greater influence.
('83', 12, 8, 26, 21262) Today because of widespread discontent there is not that active hostility to Japanese advance.
('83', 12, 8, 27, 21357) The moment we are free, we are transformed into a nation prizing its liberty and defending it with all its might and therefore helping the Allied cause.
('83', 12, 9, 28, 21510) Q. May I concretely ask—will the difference be the difference that there is between what Burma did and what, say, Russia is doing?
('83', 12, 10, 29, 21641) A. You might put it that way.
('83', 12, 10, 30, 21671) They might have given Burma independence after separating it from India.
('83', 12, 10, 31, 21744) But they did nothing of
('83', 13, 0, 1, 21768) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 13, 1, 2, 21809) the kind.
('83', 13, 1, 3, 21819) They stuck to the same old policy of exploiting her.
('83', 13, 1, 4, 21872) There was little co operation from Burmans; on the contrary there was hostility or inertia.
('83', 13, 1, 5, 21964) They fought neither for their own cause nor for the Allied cause.
('83', 13, 1, 6, 22030) Now take a possible contingency.
('83', 13, 1, 7, 22063) If the Japanese compel the Allies to retire from India to a safer base, I cannot say today that the whole of India will be up in arms against the Japanese.
('83', 13, 1, 8, 22219) I have a fear that they may degrade themselves as some Burmans did.
('83', 13, 1, 9, 22287) I want India to oppose Japan to a man.
('83', 13, 1, 10, 22326) If India was free she would do it, it would be a new experience to her, in twenty four hours her mind would be changed.
('83', 13, 1, 11, 22446) All parties would then act as one man.
('83', 13, 1, 12, 22485) If this live independence is declared today I have no doubt India becomes a powerful ally.
('83', 13, 2, 13, 22576) Mr. Grover raised the question of communal disunion as a handicap, and himself added that before the American Independence there was not much unity in the States.
('83', 13, 3, 14, 22739) G. I can only say that as soon as the vicious influence of the third party is withdrawn, the parties will be face to face with reality and close up ranks.
('83', 13, 3, 15, 22894) Ten to one my conviction is that the communal quarrels will disappear as soon as the British power that keeps us apart disappears.
('83', 13, 4, 16, 23025) Q. Would not Dominion Status declared today do equally well?
('83', 13, 5, 17, 23086) A. No good.
('83', 13, 5, 18, 23098) We will have no half measures, no tinkering with independence.
('83', 13, 5, 19, 23161) It is not independence that they will give to this party or that party, but to an indefinable India.
('83', 13, 5, 20, 23262) It was wrong, I say, to possess India.
('83', 13, 5, 21, 23301) The wrong should be righted by leaving India to herself.
('83', 13, 6, 22, 23358) Q. May I finally ask you about your attitude to Rajaji’s move?
('83', 13, 7, 23, 23421) A. I have declared that I will not discuss Rajaji in public.
('83', 13, 7, 24, 23482) It is ugly to be talking at valued colleagues.
('83', 13, 7, 25, 23529) My differences with him stand, but there are some things which are too sacred to be discussed in public.
('83', 13, 8, 26, 23634) But Mr. Grover had not so much in mind the Pakistan controversy as C.R.’s crusade for the formation of a national government.
('83', 13, 8, 27, 23760) Mr. Grover had the discernment to make it clear that C. R. “could not be motivated by British Government.
('83', 13, 8, 28, 23866) His position happens to harmoizne with them”.
('83', 13, 9, 29, 23912) G. You are right.
('83', 13, 9, 30, 23930) It is fear of the Japanese that makes him tolerate the British rule.
('83', 13, 9, 31, 23999) He would postpone the question of freedom until after the war.
('83', 13, 9, 32, 24062) On the contrary I say that if the war is to be decisively won, India must be freed to play her part today.
('83', 13, 9, 33, 24169) I find no
('83', 14, 0, 1, 24179) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 15
('83', 14, 1, 2, 24222) flaw in my position.
('83', 14, 1, 3, 24243) I have arrived at it after considerable debating within myself; I am doing nothing in hurry or anger.
('83', 14, 1, 4, 24345) There is not the slightest room in me for accommodating the Japanese.
('83', 14, 1, 5, 24415) No, I am sure that India’s independence is not only essential for India, but for China and the Allied cause.
('83', 14, 2, 6, 24524) Q. What are the exact steps by which you will save China?
('83', 14, 3, 7, 24582) A. The whole of India’s mind would be turned away from Japan.
('83', 14, 3, 8, 24644) Today it is not.
('83', 14, 3, 9, 24661) C. R. knows it, and it worries him as it should worry any sane patriot.
('83', 14, 3, 10, 24733) It worried me no less, but it drives me to a contrary conclusion.
('83', 14, 3, 11, 24799) India lying at the feet of Great Britain may mean China lying at the feet of Japan.
('83', 14, 3, 12, 24883) I cannot help using this language.
('83', 14, 3, 13, 24918) I feel it.
('83', 14, 3, 14, 24929) You may think it startling and big.
('83', 14, 3, 15, 24965) But why should it be startling?
('83', 14, 3, 16, 24997) Think of 400 million people hungering for freedom.
('83', 14, 3, 17, 25048) They want to be left alone.
('83', 14, 3, 18, 25076) They are not savages.
('83', 14, 3, 19, 25098) They have an ancient culture, ancient civilization, such variety and richness of languages.
('83', 14, 3, 20, 25190) Britain should be ashamed of holding these people as slaves.
('83', 14, 3, 21, 25251) You may say: ‘You deserve it!’ If you do, I will simply say it is not right for any nation to hold another in bondage.
('83', 14, 4, 22, 25370) P. G. I agree.
('83', 14, 5, 23, 25385) G. I say even if a nation should want to be in bondage it should be derogatory to one’s dignity to keep it in bondage.
('83', 14, 5, 24, 25504) But you have your own difficulties.
('83', 14, 5, 25, 25540) You have yet to abolish slavery !
('83', 14, 6, 26, 25574) Q. In United States, you mean?
('83', 14, 7, 27, 25605) A. Yes, your racial discrimination, your lynch law and so on.
('83', 14, 7, 28, 25667) But you don’t want me to remind you of these things.
('83', 14, 8, 29, 25720) Harijan, 21 6 1942
('83', 14, 9, 30, 25739) 19. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU’’ 1
('83', 14, 10, 31, 25771) [Before June 11, 1942] 2
('83', 14, 11, 32, 25796) Q. Till the last day you said there can be no swaraj without Hindu Muslim unity.
('83', 14, 11, 33, 25877) Now why is it that you say that there will be no unity until India has achieved independence?
('83', 14, 12, 34, 25971) A. Time is a merciless enemy, if it is also a merciful friend and healer.
('83', 14, 12, 35, 26045) I claim to be amongst the oldest lovers of Hindu Muslim unity and I remain one even today.
('83', 14, 12, 36, 26136) I have been asking myself why every
('83', 14, 13, 37, 26172) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Only If They Withdraw”, 11 6 1942 2 ibid
('83', 15, 0, 1, 26247) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 15, 1, 2, 26288) whole hearted attempt made by all including myself to reach unity has failed, and failed so completely that I have entirely fallen from grace and am described by some Muslim papers as the greatest enemy of Islam in India.
('83', 15, 1, 3, 26510) It is a phenomenon I can only account for by the fact that the third power, even without deliberately wishing it, will not allow real unity to take place.
('83', 15, 1, 4, 26665) Therefore I have come to the reluctant conclusion that the two communities will come together almost immediately after the British power comes to a final end in India.
('83', 15, 1, 5, 26833) If independence is the immediate goal of the Congress and the League then, without needing to come to any terms, all will fight together to be free from bondage.
('83', 15, 1, 6, 26995) When the bondage is done with, not merely the two organizations but all parties will find it to their interest to come together and make the fullest use of the liberty in order to evolve a national government suited to the genius of India.
('83', 15, 1, 7, 27235) I do not care what it is called.
('83', 15, 1, 8, 27268) Whatever it is, in order to be stable, it has to represent the masses in the fullest sense of the term.
('83', 15, 1, 9, 27372) And, if it is to be broad based upon the will of the people, it must be predominently non violent.
('83', 15, 1, 10, 27471) Anyway, up to my last breath, I hope I shall be found working to that end, for I see no hope for humanity without the acceptance of non violence.
('83', 15, 1, 11, 27617) We are witnessing the bankruptcy of violence from day to day.
('83', 15, 1, 12, 27679) There is no hope for humanity if the senseless fierce mutual slaughter is to continue.

('83', 15, 6, 20, 28288) Here we give a brief summary of the principal facts for all who are

('83', 16, 1, 2, 28524) interested in the progress of basic education.

('83', 16, 3, 10, 30058) 21. QUESTION BOX
('83', 16, 4, 11, 30075) ITS MEANING
('83', 16, 5, 12, 30087) Q. What is the meaning of your appeal to the British power to withdraw from India?
('83', 16, 5, 13, 30170) You have written much recently on the subject.
('83', 16, 5, 14, 30217) But there seems to be confusion in the public mind about your meaning.
('83', 16, 6, 15, 30288) A. So far as my own opinion is concerned, British authority should end completely irrespective of the wishes or demand of various parties.
('83', 16, 6, 16, 30427) But I would recognize their own military necessity.
('83', 16, 6, 17, 30479) They may need to remain in India for preventing Japanese occupation.
('83', 16, 6, 18, 30548) That prevention is common cause between them and us.
('83', 16, 6, 19, 30601) It may be necessary for the sake also of China.
('83', 16, 6, 20, 30649) Therefore I would tolerate their presence in India not in any sense as rulers but as allies of free India.
('83', 16, 6, 21, 30756) This of course assumes that after the British declaration of withdrawal there will be a stable government established in India.
('83', 17, 0, 1, 30884) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 17, 1, 2, 30925) Immediately the hindrance in the shape of a foreign power is altogether removed the union of parties should be an easy matter.
('83', 17, 1, 3, 31052) The terms on which the Allied powers may operate will be purely for the Government of the free State to determine.
('83', 17, 1, 4, 31167) The existing parties will have dissolved into the National Government.
('83', 17, 1, 5, 31238) If they survive they will do so for party purposes and not for dealings with the external world.
('83', 17, 2, 6, 31335) WHAT ABOUT NON VIOLENCE?
('83', 17, 3, 7, 31360) Q. But what about your non violence?
('83', 17, 3, 8, 31397) To what extent will you carry out your policy after freedom is gained?
('83', 17, 4, 9, 31468) A. The question hardly arises.
('83', 17, 4, 10, 31499) I am using the first personal pronoun for brevity, but I am trying to represent the spirit of India as I conceive it.
('83', 17, 4, 11, 31617) It is and will be a mixture.
('83', 17, 4, 12, 31646) What policy the National Government will adopt I cannot say.
('83', 17, 4, 13, 31707) I may not even survive it much as I would love to.
('83', 17, 4, 14, 31758) If I do, I would advise the adoption of non violence to the utmost extent possible and that will be India’s great contribution to the peace of the world and the establishment of a new world order.
('83', 17, 4, 15, 31955) I expect that with the existence of so many martial races in India, all of whom will have a voice in the government of the day, the national policy will incline towards militarism of a modified character.
('83', 17, 4, 16, 32160) I shall certainly hope that all the effort for the last twenty two years to show the efficiency of non violence as a political force will not have gone in vain and a strong party representing true non violence will exist in the country.
('83', 17, 4, 17, 32397) In every case a free India in alliance with the Allied powers must be of great help to their cause, whereas India held in bondage as she is today must be a drag upon the war chariot and may prove a source of real danger at the most critical moment.
('83', 17, 5, 18, 32646) WHAT ABOUT RADIO MESSAGES?
('83', 17, 6, 19, 32673) Q. You do not hear the radio messages.
('83', 17, 6, 20, 32712) I do most assiduously.
('83', 17, 6, 21, 32735) They interpret your writings as if your leanings were in favour of the Axis powers and you had now veered round to Subhas Babu’s views about receiving outside help to overthrow the British rule.
('83', 17, 6, 22, 32930) I would like you to clear your position in this matter.
('83', 17, 6, 23, 32986) Misinterpretation of your known views has reached a dangerous point.
('83', 17, 6, 24, 33055) A. I am glad you have asked the question.
('83', 17, 6, 25, 33097) I have no desire whatsoever to woo any power to help India in her endeavour to free herself from the foreign yoke.
('83', 17, 6, 26, 33212) I have no desire to exchange the British for any other rule.
('83', 17, 6, 27, 33273) Better the enemy I know than the one I do not.
('83', 17, 6, 28, 33320) I have never attached the slightest importance or weight to the friendly professions of the Axis powers.
('83', 17, 6, 29, 33425) If they come to India they
('83', 18, 0, 1, 33452) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 19
('83', 18, 1, 2, 33495) will come not as deliverers but as sharers in the spoil.
('83', 18, 1, 3, 33552) There can therefore be no question of my approval of Subhas Babu’s policy.
('83', 18, 1, 4, 33627) The old difference of opinion between us persists.
('83', 18, 1, 5, 33678) This does not mean that I doubt his sacrifice or his patriotism.
('83', 18, 1, 6, 33743) But my appreciation of his patriotism and sacrifice cannot blind me to the fact that he is misguided and that his way can never lead to India’s deliverance.
('83', 18, 1, 7, 33900) If I am impatient of the British yoke I am so because India’s sullenness and suppressed delight of the man in the street over British reverses are dangerous symptoms which may lead to the success of Japanese designs upon India, if they are not dealt with in the proper manner; whereas India finding herself in possession of complete freedom will never want the Japanese to enter India.
('83', 18, 1, 8, 34286) India’s sullenness and discontent will be changed as if by magic into joyful and hearty co operation with the Allies in consolidating and preserving her liberty from any and every evil design.
('83', 18, 1, 9, 34479) SEVAGRAM, June 12, 1942

('83', 21, 0, 1, 37562) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 21, 1, 2, 37603) 28. QUESTION BOX
('83', 21, 2, 3, 37620) WHAT WILL YOU DO?
('83', 21, 3, 4, 37638) Q. What will you do if in response to your invitation the British Government withdraws from India and as you predict there is chaos in the country?
('83', 21, 3, 5, 37786) What advice will you give to the workers who follow you?
('83', 21, 3, 6, 37843) What non violent steps will you take to put an end to the chaos?
('83', 21, 4, 7, 37908) A. If such a situation arises I myself and my co workers will take such steps as are necessary to overcome the chaos.
('83', 21, 4, 8, 38026) That is to say, we shall plead with those who are responsible for creating the chaos and dissuade them.
('83', 21, 4, 9, 38130) If in doing so we have to die we shall die.
('83', 21, 4, 10, 38174) If we have enough co workers with the spirit of non violence in them the chaos will soon come to an end.
('83', 21, 4, 11, 38279) Here one must bear in mind that there is no place for the non violence of the weak once the British Government withdraws.
('83', 21, 4, 12, 38401) Those who want to plunder and loot are neither going to arrest anyone nor show mercy to anyone.
('83', 21, 4, 13, 38497) Because they themselves are weak they will not have any other slogan except “kill, kill” and it will not be easy to arouse in them feelings of kindness or to appeal to their reason.
('83', 21, 4, 14, 38679) In other words we shall have to sacrifice many lives to awaken the humanity of such men.
('83', 21, 4, 15, 38768) I am afraid when there is chaos non violence alone will not operate.
('83', 21, 4, 16, 38837) Some other agencies will have appeared which will be engaging themselves in subduing by force those who indulge in looting and plundering.
('83', 21, 4, 17, 38976) When there is chaos it will be a test for everyone.
('83', 21, 5, 18, 39028) IF YOU ARE ARRESTED
('83', 21, 6, 19, 39048) Q. What will you do if the Government arrests you because of your strong writings appearing in the Harijan?
('83', 21, 6, 20, 39156) And what will happen if all the other leading Congressmen are also arrested?
('83', 21, 7, 21, 39233) A. I can’t say at the moment what we shall do in the jail if the Government arrests me and others because I myself do not know.
('83', 21, 7, 22, 39361) I shall have to do what occurs to me at the time.
('83', 21, 7, 23, 39411) What is more important is what those who stay behind will do.
('83', 21, 7, 24, 39473) The conditions which are imposed every time will not be there this time.
('83', 21, 7, 25, 39546) There will be only one condition, that of ahimsa, and that is indispensable.
('83', 21, 7, 26, 39623) This should not be interpreted to mean that people will be exempted from constructive work.
('83', 21, 7, 27, 39715) Those who know its value will never give it up.
('83', 21, 7, 28, 39763) But when masses are called upon to sacrifice themselves on the altar of independence some specified conditions will be relaxed as had been done in the
('83', 22, 0, 1, 39914) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 23
('83', 22, 1, 2, 39957) earlier mass movements.
('83', 22, 1, 3, 39981) So when the leaders are arrested every Indian will consider himself a leader and will sacrifice himself, and will not worry if his action results in anarchy.
('83', 22, 1, 4, 40139) The blame for the anarchy will go to the Government which under the pretext of anarchy or under some other pretext goes on consolidating its own anarchy.
('83', 22, 1, 5, 40293) Our ahimsa will remain lame as long as we do not get rid of the fear of anarchy.
('83', 22, 1, 6, 40374) This is the time to prove that there is no power stronger than ahimsa in this world.
('83', 22, 2, 7, 40459) [From Hindi]
('83', 22, 3, 8, 40472) Harijanbandhu, 14 6 1942
('83', 22, 4, 9, 40497) 29. JODHPUR TRAGEDY
('83', 22, 5, 10, 40517) As I had feared, Jodhpur satyagraha has taken a serious and ugly turn.
('83', 22, 5, 11, 40588) Heaps of papers have come in.
('83', 22, 5, 12, 40618) From these I gather that arrests are multiplying.
('83', 22, 5, 13, 40668) Lathi charges are a daily occurrence.
('83', 22, 5, 14, 40706) Official circulars have been issued prohibiting the use of private premises by satyagrahis.
('83', 22, 5, 15, 40798) In fact all the worst things that were experienced during the satyagraha campaigns in British India are being repeated in Jodhpur.
('83', 22, 5, 16, 40929) Only in Jodhpur they are being done far from the public gaze and a first class tragedy may pass unnoticed and may be buried like many such that have been buried and are being buried even today.
('83', 22, 5, 17, 41123) The cause of all these troubles is one and so is the remedy.
('83', 22, 5, 18, 41184) Till it is successfully applied, the painful drama will continue in some shape or form.
('83', 22, 5, 19, 41272) The British Government cannot escape blame and responsibility for every such happening in the States.
('83', 22, 5, 20, 41374) It is bound by treaty obligation to protect the people of the States from inhumanities such as those going on in Jodhpur in the name of law and order.
('83', 22, 5, 21, 41525) The prisoners have no respite even behind the prison bars.
('83', 22, 5, 22, 41584) The food is bad, usual facilities are denied to them.
('83', 22, 5, 23, 41638) By way of protest Shri Jai Narayan Vyas has undertaken hunger strike till the grievances are redressed or unto death.
('83', 22, 5, 24, 41756) If he has to die, the death will be upon those who are primarily responsible for the grievances which compel hunger strikes unto death.
('83', 22, 5, 25, 41892) Dr. Dwarkanath Kachru 1 has sent an instructive note on Jodhpur from which I take the following for public information:
('83', 22, 6, 26, 42012) The direct authority of the Jodhpur Government extends over 17% of the total area of the State; the remaining area—about 83% —is owned by the
('83', 22, 7, 27, 42154) 1 He was not a “Dr.”; vide “Jodhpur”, 29 6 1942.
('83', 23, 0, 1, 42203) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 23, 1, 2, 42244) Jagirdars, about 1,300 in number.
('83', 23, 1, 3, 42278) These Jagirdars are mostly autonomous internally and pay fixed tributes to the Maharaja .
('83', 23, 2, 4, 42368) For a long time now the Political Department has been controlling the affairs in Jodhpur.
('83', 23, 2, 5, 42458) Thrice during this century the State passed under the direct control and supervision of the Political Department.
('83', 23, 2, 6, 42572) At present Englishmen—a large number of them—occupy prominent positions in the State.
('83', 23, 2, 7, 42658) The Prime Minister is also a retired British official.
('83', 23, 3, 8, 42713) Apart from the British officials, other non State subject elements also predominate in the State administration.
('83', 23, 3, 9, 42826) There is thus a “Mulki Movement” which is becoming stronger day by day.
('83', 23, 3, 10, 42898) There is also a very strong rivalry between the different castes, Rajputs, Brahmins, etc., which is very often exploited by the government to play one against the other or to prevent the Lok Parishad from growing stronger.
('83', 23, 4, 11, 43121) The Marwar Lok Parishad, formed in 1938, became, during the course of these four years, a tremendous force in Jodhpur.
('83', 23, 4, 12, 43240) Because of the general political backwardness of the Rajputana States, a more advanced mass movement in Jodhpur was destined to lead the vanguard of the popular movement in the whole of Rajputana.
('83', 23, 4, 13, 43437) An All Rajputana Political Conference was also announced to be held in Jodhpur in March 1940. The mass awakening in Rajputana caused grave anxiety to the Political Department and the Jodhpur Government was instructed to act promptly.
('83', 23, 4, 14, 43671) The Jodhpur Government therefore declared the Lok Parishad illegal and put all its prominent men in jails.
('83', 23, 4, 15, 43778) Mass arrests, followed by terrible repression, ended in a compromise with the Government.
('83', 23, 4, 16, 43868) Marwar Lok Parishad began its constructive work once again and soon came to be recognized by all the people in Marwar, both in the khalsa and jagiri territories.
('83', 23, 4, 17, 44030) The Parishad contested the Municipal elections and emerged as the majority party in the Board.
('83', 23, 4, 18, 44125) Its leader became the chairman.
('83', 23, 5, 19, 44157) Since the war began the governments of Indian States have changed their attitude towards popular movements.
('83', 23, 5, 20, 44265) The war had in fact provided an excuse to suppress civil liberties and check the growth of popular forces.
('83', 23, 5, 21, 44372) In Jodhpur, where the Political Department has a hand in shaping the policy of the government, Prime Minister Sir Donald Field set to work according to the instructions from above.
('83', 23, 5, 22, 44553) Funds had to be procured for war and the whole State had to be put on war footing.
('83', 23, 5, 23, 44636) Money had largely to be procured from the Jagirdars, who must in turn be protected against the popular movement in the Jagirs led by the Lok Parishad.
('83', 23, 5, 24, 44787) The State Government thus assumed an attitude of neutrality towards the Jagirs and allowed the Jagirdars to squeeze even the last drop of blood from their subjects.
('83', 24, 0, 1, 44952) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 25
('83', 24, 1, 2, 44995) But the Lok Parishad could not ignore the grievances and demands of the masses of Marwar living in Jagirs.
('83', 24, 1, 3, 45102) The Parishad did not want the abolition of the Jagirs, but it certainly wanted the betterment of the people of Jagirs.
('83', 24, 1, 4, 45221) Repeated requests were made to the Government to intervene and secure a just and a humane treatment for the tenants in Jagirs, but unfortunately the Government chose to act differently.
('83', 24, 1, 5, 45407) They encouraged the Jagirdars and suppressed the Lok Parishad workers.
('83', 24, 1, 6, 45478) Briefly stated the conditions in Jagirs are: (a) the tenants demand regular latai (allocation of the shares of the Jagirdars and their tenants).
('83', 24, 1, 7, 45623) But the Jagirdars would not arrange to do it regularly and often evaded with the result that the tenants suffered, (b) the tenants also want the abolition of such cesses which have been declared illegal in the courts of the States.
('83', 24, 2, 8, 45855) The Government of Jodhpur repeatedly refused to come to the help of the tenants and even refused to stop the exaction of such cesses which were declared illegal in their own courts of law.
('83', 24, 2, 9, 46044) The Government went a step further and encouraged the Jagirdars themselves to take up cudgels against the Lok Parishad.
('83', 24, 2, 10, 46164) Thus when the Jagirdars beat and victimized and even burnt the houses of the Parishad workers the government refused to intervene.
('83', 24, 3, 11, 46295) SEVAGRAM, June 14, 1942 Harijan, 21 6 1942
('83', 24, 4, 12, 46338) 30. LETTER TO CHIANG KAI SHEK
('83', 24, 5, 13, 46368) SEVAGRAM, June 14, 1942
('83', 24, 6, 14, 46392) DEAR GENERALISSIMO, I can never forget the five hours’ close contact I had with you and your noble wife in Calcutta.
('83', 24, 6, 15, 46509) 1 I had always felt drawn towards you in your fight for freedom, and that contact and our conversation brought China and her problems still nearer to me.
('83', 24, 6, 16, 46663) Long ago, between 1905 and 1913, when I was in South Africa, I was in constant touch with the small Chinese colony in Johannesburg.
('83', 24, 6, 17, 46795) I knew them first as clients and then as comrades in the Indian passive resistance struggle in South Africa.
('83', 24, 6, 18, 46904) I came in touch with them in Mauritius also.
('83', 24, 6, 19, 46949) I learnt then to admire their thrift, industry, resourcefulness and internal unity.
('83', 24, 6, 20, 47033) Later in India I had a very fine Chinese friend living with me for a few years and we all learnt to like him.
('83', 24, 7, 21, 47143) 1Vide “Discussion with Chiang Kai Shek and Wife”, 18 2 1942.
('83', 25, 0, 1, 47204) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 25, 1, 2, 47245) I have thus felt greatly attracted towards your great country and, in common with my countrymen, our sympathy has gone out to you in your terrible struggle.
('83', 25, 1, 3, 47402) Our mutual friend, Jawaharlal Nehru, whose love of China is only excelled, if at all, by his love of his own country, has kept us in intimate touch with the developments of the Chinese struggle.
('83', 25, 1, 4, 47597) Because of this feeling I have towards China and my earnest desire that our two great countries should come closer to one another and co operate to their mutual advantage, I am anxious to explain to you that my appeal to the British power to withdraw from India is not meant in any shape or form to weaken India’s defence against the Japanese or embarrass you in your struggle.
('83', 25, 1, 5, 47975) India must not submit to any aggressor or invader and must resist him.
('83', 25, 1, 6, 48046) I would not be guilty of purchasing the freedom of my country at the cost of your country’s freedom.
('83', 25, 1, 7, 48147) That problem does not arise before me as I am clear that India cannot gain her freedom in this way, and a Japanese domination of either India or China would be equally injurious to the other country and to world peace.
('83', 25, 1, 8, 48366) That domination must therefore be prevented and I should like India to play her natural and rightful part in this.
('83', 25, 1, 9, 48481) I feel India cannot do so while she is in bondage.
('83', 25, 1, 10, 48532) India has been a helpless witness of the withdrawals from Malaya, Singapore and Burma.
('83', 25, 1, 11, 48619) We must learn the lesson from these tragic events and prevent by all means at our disposal a repetition of what befell these unfortunate countries.
('83', 25, 1, 12, 48767) But unless we are free we can do nothing to prevent it, and the same process might well occur again, crippling India and China disastrously.
('83', 25, 1, 13, 48908) I do not want a repetition of this tragic tale of woe.
('83', 25, 1, 14, 48963) Our proferred help has repeatedly been rejected by the British Government and the recent failure of the Cripps Mission has left a deep wound which is still running.
('83', 25, 1, 15, 49128) Out of that anguish has come the cry for immediate withdrawal of British power so that India can look after herself and help China to the best of her ability.
('83', 25, 1, 16, 49287) I have told you of my faith in non violence and of my belief in the effectiveness of this method if the whole nation could turn to it.
('83', 25, 1, 17, 49422) That faith in it is as firm as ever.
('83', 25, 1, 18, 49459) But I realize that India today as a whole has not that faith and belief, and the Government in free India would be formed from the various elements composing the nation.
('83', 25, 1, 19, 49629) Today the whole of India is impotent and feels frustrated.
('83', 26, 0, 1, 49688) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 27
('83', 26, 1, 2, 49731) Indian Army consists largely of people who have joined up because of economic pressure.
('83', 26, 1, 3, 49819) They have no feeling of a cause to fight for, and in no sense are they a national army.
('83', 26, 1, 4, 49907) Those of us who would fight for a cause, for India and China, with armed forces or with non violence, cannot under the foreign heel, function as they want to.
('83', 26, 1, 5, 50066) And yet our people know for certain that India free can play even a decisive part not only on her own behalf, but also on behalf of China and world peace.
('83', 26, 1, 6, 50221) Many like me feel that it is not proper or manly to remain in this helpless state and allow events to overwhelm us when a way to effective action can be opened to us.
('83', 26, 1, 7, 50388) They feel, therefore, that every possible effort should be made to ensure independence and that freedom of action which is so urgently needed.
('83', 26, 1, 8, 50531) This is the origin of my appeal to the British power to end immediately the unnatural connection between Britain and India.
('83', 26, 1, 9, 50655) Unless we make the effort there is a grave danger of public feeling in India going into wrong and harmful channels.
('83', 26, 1, 10, 50771) There is every likelihood of subterranean sympathy for Japan growing simply in order to weaken and oust British authority in India.
('83', 26, 1, 11, 50903) This feeling may take the place of robust confidence in our ability never to look to outsiders for help in winning our freedom.
('83', 26, 1, 12, 51031) We have to learn self reliance and develop the strength to work out our own salvation.
('83', 26, 1, 13, 51118) This is only possible if we make a determined effort to free ourselves from bondage.
('83', 26, 1, 14, 51203) That freedom has become a present necessity to enable us to take our due place among the free nations of the world.
('83', 26, 1, 15, 51319) To make it perfectly clear that we want to prevent in every way Japanese aggression, I would personally agree that the Allied Powers might, under treaty with us, keep their armed forces in India and use the country as a base for operations against the threatened Japanese attack.
('83', 26, 1, 16, 51599) I need hardly give you my assurance that, as the author of the new move in India, I shall take no hasty action.
('83', 26, 1, 17, 51711) And whatever action I may recommend will be governed by the consideration that it should not injure China, or encourage Japanese aggression in India or China.
('83', 26, 1, 18, 51870) I am trying to enlist world opinion in favour of a proposition which to me appears self proved and which must lead to the strengthening of India’s and China’s defence.
('83', 26, 1, 19, 52038) I am also educating public opinion in India and conferring with my colleagues.
('83', 26, 1, 20, 52117) Needless to say, any movement against the British Government with which I may be connected will be essentially non violent.
('83', 26, 1, 21, 52241) I am straining every nerve to avoid a conflict with British authority.
('83', 26, 1, 22, 52312) But if in the vindication of the freedom which has become an immediate desideratum, this becomes
('83', 27, 0, 1, 52409) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 27, 1, 2, 52450) inevitable, I shall not hesitate to run any risk however great.
('83', 27, 1, 3, 52514) Very soon you will have completed five years of war against Japanese aggression and invasion and all the sorrow and misery that these have brought to China.
('83', 27, 1, 4, 52671) My heart goes out to the people of China in deep sympathy and in admiration for their heroic struggle and endless sacrifices in the cause of their country’s freedom and integrity against tremendous odds.
('83', 27, 1, 5, 52875) I am convinced that this heroism and sacrifice cannot be in vain; they must bear fruit.
('83', 27, 1, 6, 52963) To you, to Madame Chiang and to the great people of China, I send my earnest and sincere wishes for your success.
('83', 27, 1, 7, 53077) I look forward to the day when a free India and a free China will co operate together in friendship and brotherhood for their own good and for the good of Asia and the world.
('83', 27, 1, 8, 53252) In anticipation of your permission, I am taking liberty of publishing this letter in Harijan.
('83', 27, 2, 9, 53346) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('83', 27, 3, 10, 53376) Non violence in Peace and War, Vol. I, Also C.W. 10367. Courtesy: India Office Library, London.

('83', 29, 1, 2, 55452) 34. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('83', 29, 2, 3, 55477) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, June 15, 1942
('83', 29, 3, 4, 55509) AMRIT, I was unable to send you anything yesterday.
('83', 29, 3, 5, 55561) M. 1 left this morning and J. L. will leave for Bombay this evening.
('83', 29, 3, 6, 55630) He is passing the day here and dining with Mahadeo.
('83', 29, 3, 7, 55682) In one sentence, M. is not satisfied with my demand or the manner of enforcement; he needs time for thought.

('83', 32, 4, 7, 59397) 40. A CHALLENGE
('83', 32, 5, 8, 59413) I have before me three letters rebuking me for not going to Sind to face the Hurs personally.
('83', 32, 5, 9, 59507) Two are friendly.
('83', 32, 5, 10, 59525) The third comes from a critic who has no faith in non violence.
('83', 32, 5, 11, 59589) His letter demands an answer.
('83', 32, 5, 12, 59619) Its main part runs as follows:
('83', 32, 6, 13, 59650) I am deeply interested in your writings and in the effect that they make upon the minds of the ignorant masses and your blind followers.
('83', 32, 6, 14, 59787) I would therefore feel obliged if you enlighten me on the following points, especially because points nos.
('83', 32, 6, 15, 59894) 3 & 4 raise novel and fundamental issues about non violence.
('83', 32, 6, 16, 59955) You have been training a number of satyagrahis in your Ashram and they must have had the advantage of your supervision and instruction.
('83', 32, 6, 17, 60091) You have been proclaiming that violence could be effectively met by non violent means.
('83', 32, 6, 18, 60178) Japan is now attacking India in the East and Hurs are creating trouble in the West.
('83', 32, 6, 19, 60262) Is this not then the long awaited opportunity when you can practise what you have so long preached?
('83', 32, 6, 20, 60362) Instead of doing that, you are contenting yourself by writing articles in the Harijan.
('83', 32, 6, 21, 60449) Imagine Hitler or Stalin, without sending their armies to the front line, writing such articles in Pravda or such other paper.
('83', 32, 6, 22, 60576) Instead of asking the Sind M.L.A.s to resign and go to Hurs, why should you not send a ‘company’ of your trained satyagrahis and try the luck of your doctrine?
('83', 32, 6, 23, 60736) Is it not the duty and business of a satyagrahi to go and meet the danger where it exists and threatens the country?
('83', 32, 6, 24, 60853) Or is it your case that your satyagrahis will meet it only when it reaches the Ashram and not before?
('83', 32, 6, 25, 60955) If so, is not your doctrine a doctrine of inaction?
('83', 32, 6, 26, 61007) I have no doubt that if I could have gone to Sind, I might have been able to do something.
('83', 32, 6, 27, 61098) I have done such things before, not without success.
('83', 32, 6, 28, 61151) But I am too old for such missions.
('83', 32, 6, 29, 61187) What little energy I have, I am storing up for what promises to be the last fight of my life.
('83', 32, 6, 30, 61281) I have not conceived my mission to be that of a knight errant
('83', 33, 0, 1, 61343) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 33, 1, 2, 61384) wandering everywhere to deliver people from difficult situations.
('83', 33, 1, 3, 61450) My humble occupation has been to show people how they can solve their own difficulties.
('83', 33, 1, 4, 61538) So far as Sind is concerned, I mainiain that my advice was perfect.
('83', 33, 1, 5, 61606) It was clearly Congressmen’s duty to proceed to the infested areas and spend themselves in the effort to convert the Hurs to the way of peace.
('83', 33, 1, 6, 61749) Indeed they could have used arms if they had no faith in non violence.
('83', 33, 1, 7, 61820) They should have resigned from the Congress to free themselves from the obligation to observe non violence.
('83', 33, 1, 8, 61928) If we are to be fit for independence, we have to learn the art of self defence either non violently or violently.
('83', 33, 1, 9, 62042) Every citizen should consider himself liable to render help to his neighbour in distress.
('83', 33, 1, 10, 62132) If I had adopted the role my critic has suggested, I would have helped people to become parasites.
('83', 33, 1, 11, 62231) Therefore it is well that I have not trained myself to defend others.
('83', 33, 1, 12, 62301) I shall be satisfied if at my death it could be said of me that I had devoted the best part of my life to showing the way to become self reliant and cultivate the capacity to defend oneself under every conceivable circumstance.
('83', 33, 1, 13, 62529) My correspondent has committed the grave error of thinking that my mission is to deliver people from calamities.
('83', 33, 1, 14, 62642) That is an arrogation only claimed by dictators.
('83', 33, 1, 15, 62691) But no dictator has ever succeeded in proving the claim.
('83', 33, 1, 16, 62748) Indeed if I could say, as the correspondent thinks I could, that if the menaces of the kind described by him face the Ashram, it will give a good account of itself, I should be quite content and feel that my mission was wholly successful.
('83', 33, 1, 17, 62987) But I can lay no such claim.
('83', 33, 1, 18, 63016) The Ashram at Sevagram is only so called.
('83', 33, 1, 19, 63058) The visitors gave it the name and it has passed current.
('83', 33, 1, 20, 63115) The Ashram is a medley of people come together for different purposes.
('83', 33, 1, 21, 63186) There are hardly half a dozen permanent residents having a common ideal.
('83', 33, 1, 22, 63259) How these few will discharge themselves when the test comes remains to be seen.
('83', 33, 1, 23, 63339) The fact is that non violence does not work in the same way as violence.
('83', 33, 1, 24, 63412) It works in the opposite way.
('83', 33, 1, 25, 63442) An armed man naturally relies upon his arms.
('83', 33, 1, 26, 63487) A man who is intentionally unarmed relies upon the unseen force called God by poets, but called the unknown by scientists.
('83', 33, 1, 27, 63610) But that which is unknown is not necessarily non existent.
('83', 33, 1, 28, 63669) God is the Force among all forces known and unknown.
('83', 33, 1, 29, 63722) Non violence without reliance upon that Force is poor stuff to be thrown in the dust.
('83', 33, 1, 30, 63808) I hope now my critic realizes the error underlying his question and that he sees also that the doctrine that has guided my life is not
('83', 34, 0, 1, 63943) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 35
('83', 34, 1, 2, 63986) one of inaction but of the highest action.
('83', 34, 1, 3, 64029) His question should really have been put thus: How is it that, in spite of your work in India for over 22 years, there are not sufficient satyagrahis who can cope with external and internal menaces?
('83', 34, 1, 4, 64228) My answer then would be that twenty two years are nothing in the training of a nation for the development of non violent strength.
('83', 34, 1, 5, 64359) That is not to say that a large number of persons will not show that strength on due occasion.
('83', 34, 1, 6, 64454) That occasion seems to have come now.
('83', 34, 1, 7, 64492) This war puts the civilian on his mettle no less than the military man, non violent no less than the violent.
('83', 34, 2, 8, 64602) SEVAGRAM, June 18, 1942
('83', 34, 3, 9, 64626) Harijan, 28 6 1942

('83', 36, 9, 19, 67334) 46. INTERVIEW TO THE UNITED PRESS
('83', 36, 10, 20, 67368) June 19, 1942
('83', 36, 11, 21, 67382) In an interview by the representative of the United Press of London regarding Sir Stafford Cripps’ statement 1 published in the Press Gandhiji said: I have read Sir Stafford Cripps’ statement to the United Press representative in London.
('83', 36, 11, 22, 67620) It is not conducive to the proper understan ding between different parties, if ascertainable facts are not admitted by all.
('83', 36, 11, 23, 67744) Sir Stafford knows that I was disinclined to proceed to New Delhi.
('83', 36, 11, 24, 67811) Having gone there, I intended to return the same day that I reached there.
('83', 36, 11, 25, 67886) But Maulana Saheb would not let me go.
('83', 36, 11, 26, 67925) I wish that I could have induced the Working Committee to take up its stand on pure non violence.
('83', 36, 11, 27, 68023) But it did not and could not.
('83', 36, 11, 28, 68053) With it, rightly,
('83', 36, 12, 29, 68071) 1 On June 16, 1942, Sir Stafford Cripps referring to Gandhiji’s repeated demand for British withdrawal from India had observed: “We are not going to walk out of India right in the middle of the war though we have no wish to remain there for any imperialistic reasons.”
('83', 37, 0, 1, 68340) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 37, 1, 2, 68381) politics were all important and it could not, not having the conviction, allow its deliberations to be affected by the issue of non violence.
('83', 37, 1, 3, 68523) The deliberations, therefore, of the Working Committee at New Delhi were carried on without any interference or guidance on my part.
('83', 37, 1, 4, 68656) Therefore, the negotiations had nothing to do at any stage with the question of non violence.
('83', 37, 1, 5, 68750) I would not have brought out thisfact, if it was not relevant to a calm consideration of the situation that faces British and Indian statesmen.
('83', 37, 1, 6, 68894) Nor do I like Sir Stafford’s description of my appeal for withdrawal of the British power as a walk out.
('83', 37, 1, 7, 68999) The appeal has been made in no offensive mood.
('83', 37, 1, 8, 69046) It is the friendliest thing that I could do.
('83', 37, 1, 9, 69091) It is conceived in the interest of the Allied cause.
('83', 37, 1, 10, 69144) I have made it in a purely non violent spirit and as a non violent step.
('83', 37, 1, 11, 69217) But this is merely personal to me.
('83', 37, 1, 12, 69252) It is necessary to remember in considering my proposal that it is essentially a non violent gesture.
('83', 37, 1, 13, 69353) Such non violence as India has or may have becomes impotent without the Withdrawal of the British power—even as that part of India which will put up an armed fight becomes impotent.
('83', 37, 1, 14, 69535) The step that I have conceived overcomes all difficulties, shuts all controversy about violence and non violence and immediately frees India to offer her best help to the Allied cause and more especially to China which is in imminent danger.
('83', 37, 1, 15, 69777) I am convinced that the independence of India, which the withdrawal of the British power involves, would ensure China’s freedom and put the Allied cause on an unassailable basis.
('83', 37, 2, 16, 69956) Harijan, 28 6 1942
('83', 37, 3, 17, 69975) 47. INTERVIEW TO REUTER 1
('83', 37, 4, 18, 70001) [Before June 21, 1942]
('83', 37, 5, 19, 70024) Asked by Reuter’s London representative to amplify his statement about the possibility of Free India entering into a treaty with the United Nations, Gandhiji said: There can be no limit to what friendly Independent India can do.
('83', 37, 5, 20, 70253) I had in mind a treaty between United Nations and India for
('83', 37, 6, 21, 70313) 1 This appeared under the heading “Notes”, dated Sevagram May 21, 1942. The source does not mention where and when Reuter interviewed Gandhiji, but May 21 could be a misprint for June 21 for it is unlikely that the item would have been kept for five weeks before it was published.
('83', 37, 6, 22, 70594) Besides, Gandhiji first mentions a treaty with the United Nations in answer to a question on June 6; vide “Important Question”, 6 6 1942.
('83', 38, 0, 1, 70732) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 39
('83', 38, 1, 2, 70775) defence of China against Japanese aggression.
('83', 38, 1, 3, 70821) But given mutual goodwill and trust, the treaty should cover protection of human dignity and rights by means other than resort to armament.
('83', 38, 1, 4, 70961) For this involves competition in capacity for greatest slaughter.
('83', 38, 1, 5, 71027) I wish British opinion could realize that Independence of India changes character of Allied cause and ensures speedier victory.
('83', 38, 2, 6, 71155) Replying to the criticism of the London Times on his latest proposal Gandhiji said: Every time nationalists have suggested solutions, however sound intrinsically, there has been distortion of their speeches and writings, followed later by persecution.
('83', 38, 2, 7, 71407) My latest proposal, conceived in the friendliest spirit and in my opinion intrinsically sound, has already begun to be distorted.
('83', 38, 2, 8, 71537) I regard my proposal as foolproof.
('83', 38, 2, 9, 71572) The operations of the Allied forces against Japanese aggression have been left intact under my proposal which amounts to this that Britain should become true to her declaration, withdraw from India as conqueror and therefore controller of her destiny, and leave India to shape her own destiny without the slightest interference.
('83', 38, 2, 10, 71901) This, as I can see, puts her case on a moral basis and gives her in India a great ally not in the cause of Imperialism but in the cause of human freedom.
('83', 38, 2, 11, 72055) If there is anarchy in India, Britain alone will be responsible, not I. What I have said is that I would prefer anarchy to the present slavery and consequent impotence of India.
('83', 38, 2, 12, 72233) Any person, however great he may be, who distorts the proposals I have made will be condemned by history as an enemy of the Allied cause.
('83', 38, 2, 13, 72371) Sir Stafford Cripps’ proposals have been weighed by India and after great deliberation rejected by all parties.
('83', 38, 2, 14, 72483) It is an insult to India to repeat those proposals as the final word of British statesmanship.
('83', 38, 3, 15, 72578) Harijan, 28 6 1942
