('83', 39, 4, 7, 73120) 49. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('83', 39, 5, 8, 73154) June 21, 1942
('83', 39, 6, 9, 73168) CHI, MATHURADAS, I have not been writing to you because I believe that you are out of danger.
('83', 39, 6, 10, 73262) Your postcard today has startled me.
('83', 39, 6, 11, 73299) Whatever is to happen, let it happen.
('83', 39, 6, 12, 73337) Even while striving to live, does not man keep himself ready for death ?
('83', 39, 6, 13, 73410) What is the advantage of going to Poona?
('83', 39, 6, 14, 73451) I for one feel that you should go to Bombay.
('83', 39, 6, 15, 73496) You can certainly get medical treatment there.
('83', 39, 6, 16, 73543) In Poona there was only Trivedi 1 who could have given you any help you needed.
('83', 39, 6, 17, 73623) But he is no more.
('83', 39, 7, 18, 73642) Blessings from BAPU
('83', 39, 8, 19, 73662) From the Gujarati original: Pyarelal Papers.
('83', 39, 8, 20, 73707) Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.
('83', 39, 8, 21, 73742) Courtesy: Beladevi Nayyar and Dr. Sushila Nayyar
('83', 39, 9, 22, 73791) 50. A POSER
('83', 39, 10, 23, 73803) A correspondent writes to Mahadev Desai:
('83', 39, 11, 24, 73844) Referring to Gandhiji’s demand for an orderly withdrawal of the British from India or for a complete and immediate ending of the British rule in this country, some friends here want to clearly understand the implications of the suggestion that on free India becoming an ally of the United Nations, British and American troops may remain on Indian soil and operate from here under a treaty with free India, because defence of India will be then our ‘common cause’.
('83', 39, 11, 25, 74308) Theoretically from the standpoint of India’s independence the position is no doubt quite clear.
('83', 39, 11, 26, 74404) But some questions arise as to its practical implications.
('83', 39, 11, 27, 74463) It is of course understood that Gandhiji here is not stating his personal non violent position but is visualizing one of the possibilities,
('83', 39, 12, 28, 74603) 1 J. P. Trivedi
('83', 40, 0, 1, 74619) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 41
('83', 40, 1, 2, 74662) namely, that of a free nationalist India going in for a policy of armed resistance or of collaboration of some kind with foreign troops in armed resistance, to aggression.
('83', 40, 1, 3, 74834) But what about the British position?
('83', 40, 1, 4, 74871) A cordial acceptance of Gandhiji’s demand by the British will not only completely change the moral basis of the war but will in fact negative, for them, its political and economic sine que non.
('83', 40, 1, 5, 75065) If the British are not driven out of India by force of circumstances, but they give up their hold on India as a voluntary repayment of a debt long overdue, this moral act cannot, by its very nature, be an isolated one, but should fundamentally affect Britain’s relations with her other Asiatic and African possessions also.
('83', 40, 1, 6, 75389) If Britain is forced to leave India to God or to the Japanese she will go on fighting to save her other possessions on Asia and Africa and to regain those already lost; but if she voluntarily dispossesses herself of her ill gotten properties, her material reasons for prosecuting the war will practically vanish.
('83', 40, 1, 7, 75702) From the economic point of view, Britiain could never inflict upon herself this terrible costly war if she did not hope afterwards to reimburse herself somehow out of the possessions she was fighting to retain.
('83', 40, 1, 8, 75913) It will be absolutely beyond the resources of Britain, divested of her foreign possessions, to carry on the war on anything like its present scale.
('83', 40, 1, 9, 76061) To try to do that would be a most senseless and inhuman infliction on the British people themselves.
('83', 40, 2, 10, 76162) As regards ideal reasons, these have no substance now, because so long as Britain is holding millions upon millions of human beings in subjugation she has no right to speak for democracy, etc.
('83', 40, 2, 11, 76355) But the ideal reasons will gain substantiality on Britain responding to Gandhiji’s appeal.
('83', 40, 2, 12, 76446) And then it is true Britain may look forward to the sympathy and co operation of the peoples she will have freed and may to some extent rely on their resources too.
('83', 40, 2, 13, 76611) But just here we are brought face to face with the old question of means and ends, namely, whether war can be a proper and effective instrument of policy for the attainment of the democratic ends of justice and human freedom.
('83', 40, 2, 14, 76837) It would be a disaster if anything were said or done that would give rise to a misunderstanding on this issue so as to jeopardize or prejudice the historic lead which Gandhiji has given in this matter to the world at this unprecedented crisis in human affairs.
('83', 40, 2, 15, 77098) On no account can that moral world leadership be endangered.
('83', 40, 2, 16, 77159) Why does not Gandhiji persist in the line which he enunciated sometime ago, namely, that the voluntary abdication of the British power in respect of her imperial possessions is sure to bring about a moral situation in the world that will baffle Hitler and Mussolini and their war machines?
('83', 40, 2, 17, 77449) The voluntary liquidation of British Imperialism in India, if it comes about, will be a tremendous act of non violence on the part of the British.
('83', 40, 2, 18, 77596) When we are visualizing its effect, why should we not think in terms of non violence also?
('83', 41, 0, 1, 77687) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 41, 1, 2, 77728) If the tree is non violence the fruit also should be non violence
('83', 41, 2, 3, 77794) There are so many side issues arising from the question of allowing foreign troops on Indian soil.
('83', 41, 2, 4, 77893) Foreign troops cannot at all function in this part of the world without India being made a vast arsenal and supply base for the United Nations.
('83', 41, 2, 5, 78037) Any suggestion, however tentative and hypothetical, in this direction is frought with danger.
('83', 41, 3, 6, 78131) While Gandhiji is desperately anxious to prove his bona fides as to his determination to keep the Japanese out, his utterances regarding the future position of foreign troops in India are likely to be misunderstood by the other party who may be already seeking an opening for bargaining.
('83', 41, 3, 7, 78419) Not that negotiations as such are objectionable, but if the other party’s approach is vitiated by the spirit of bargaining, that will not only detract from the value of the British action, if any, but will also introduce unwanted complications on the Indian side.
('83', 41, 3, 8, 78683) The effect on the mind of the Indian masses has to be taken into consideration.
('83', 41, 3, 9, 78763) At this stage of the new movement it is most essential to attune the public mind to the thought and conviction that India must get ready to fall back exclusively upon her own resources, moral and material.
('83', 41, 3, 10, 78969) Can we at this psychological moment emphasize a possibility which will suggest to the man in the street that ‘after all they will be here’?
('83', 41, 3, 11, 79109) The mind of the man in the street will hardly be able to juxtapose national freedom and the presence of thousands and thousands of foreign troops in the country.
('83', 41, 3, 12, 79271) This letter demands an answer.
('83', 41, 3, 13, 79302) The difficulty about the confu sion in the public mind by the contemplated stay of the Allied troops in the country is very real.
('83', 41, 3, 14, 79432) Neither the masses nor even the classes will appreciate the necessity of the military operations of the Allied powers after the declaration of withdrawal.
('83', 41, 3, 15, 79587) But if the necessity is proved, the public may be expected to reconcile themselves to the inevitable.
('83', 41, 3, 16, 79689) There was obviously a gap in my first writing.
('83', 41, 3, 17, 79736) I filled it in as soon as it was discovered by one of my numerous interviewers.
('83', 41, 3, 18, 79816) Non violence demands the strictest honesty, cost what it may.
('83', 41, 3, 19, 79878) The public have therefore to suffer my weakness, if weakness it may be called.
('83', 41, 3, 20, 79957) I could not be guilty of asking the Allies to take a step which would involve certain defeat.
('83', 41, 3, 21, 80051) I could not guarantee foolproof non violent action to keep the Japanese at bay.
('83', 41, 3, 22, 80131) Abrupt withdrawal of the Allied troops might result in Japan’s occupation of India and China’s sure fall.
('83', 41, 3, 23, 80237) I had not the remotest idea of any such catastrophe resulting from my action.
('83', 41, 3, 24, 80315) Therefore I feel that if in spite of the acceptance of my proposal, it is deemed necessary by the Allies to
('83', 42, 0, 1, 80423) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 43
('83', 42, 1, 2, 80466) remain in India to prevent Japanese occupation, they should do so, subject to such conditions as may be prescribed by the national government that may be set up after the British withdrawal.
('83', 42, 1, 3, 80657) The writer’s argument about Britain having no cause left for pursuing the war, if she accepts my proposal and logically follows it in Africa, is sound.
('83', 42, 1, 4, 80809) But that is the acid test proposed.
('83', 42, 1, 5, 80845) India has every right to examine the implications of high sounding declarations about justice, preservation of democracy and freedom of speech and individual liberty.
('83', 42, 1, 6, 81012) If a band of robbers have among themselves a democratic constitution in order to enable them to carry on their robbing operations more effectively, they do not deserve to be called a democracy.
('83', 42, 1, 7, 81206) Is India a democracy?
('83', 42, 1, 8, 81228) Are the States a democracy?
('83', 42, 1, 9, 81256) Britain does not deserve to win the war on the ground of justice if she is fighting to keep her Asiatic and African possessions.
('83', 42, 1, 10, 81385) I am not unaware of the tremendous change in Britain’s economic policy that the acceptance of my proposal involves.
('83', 42, 1, 11, 81501) But that change is a vital necessity if this war is to have a satisfactory ending.
('83', 42, 1, 12, 81584) Who knows if Britain’s acceptance of my proposal will not by itself mean an honourable end of the war resulting in a change even in the mentality of the Axis powers?
('83', 42, 1, 13, 81750) The writer is afraid that my reconciliation to the presence of the British troops would mean a descent on my part from my non violent position.
('83', 42, 1, 14, 81894) I hold that my non violence dictates a recognition of the vital necessity.
('83', 42, 1, 15, 81969) Neither Britain nor America share my faith in non violence.
('83', 42, 1, 16, 82029) I am unable to state that the non violent effort will make India proof against Japanese or any other aggression.
('83', 42, 1, 17, 82142) I am not able even to claim that the whole of India is non violent in the sense required.
('83', 42, 1, 18, 82232) In the circumstances it would be hypocritical on my part to insist on the immediate withdrawal of the Allied troops as an indispensable part of my proposal.
('83', 42, 1, 19, 82389) It is sufficient for me to declare that so far as India is concerned, she does not need troops to defend herself, having no quarrel with Japan.
('83', 42, 1, 20, 82533) But India must not by any act of hers short of national suicide let China down or put the Allied powers in jeopardy.
('83', 42, 1, 21, 82650) So long therefore as India lacks faith in the capacity of non violence to protect her against aggression from without, the demand for the withdrawal of the Allied troops during the pendency of the war would itself be an act of violence, if the
('83', 43, 0, 1, 82894) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 43, 1, 2, 82935) controllers of the troops hold it to be necessary for their defence to keep them in India for that purpose and that alone.
('83', 43, 2, 3, 83058) SEVAGRAM, June 22, 1942
('83', 43, 3, 4, 83082) Harijan, 28 6 1942
('83', 43, 4, 5, 83101) 51. TWO ACTIONS
('83', 43, 5, 6, 83117) My proposal for the withdrawal of the British power involves two actions.
('83', 43, 5, 7, 83191) One is to deal with the present emergency, and the other to secure freedom from British supremacy.
('83', 43, 5, 8, 83290) The second admits of delay.
('83', 43, 5, 9, 83318) There is a lot of confusion about its implications.
('83', 43, 5, 10, 83370) I am trying to the best of my ability to deal with the questions as they arise from time to time.
('83', 43, 5, 11, 83468) The first admits of no delay and demands specific action irrespective of the proposal for British withdrawal.
('83', 43, 5, 12, 83578) This is in connection with (1) the behaviour of troops, (2) the impending salt famine, (3) control of food grains, (4) evacuation for the sake of the military, (5) discrimination between Europeans and Anglo Indians and Anglo Burmans on the one hand and Indians on the other.
('83', 43, 5, 13, 83853) On the first item the people have the law and public opinion wholly on their side.
('83', 43, 5, 14, 83936) The Government machinery is always slow to move, more so now, when it is all pre mortgaged for military preparations.
('83', 43, 5, 15, 84054) People must everywhere learn to defend themselves against misbehaving individuals, no matter who they are.
('83', 43, 5, 16, 84161) The question of non violence and violence does not arise.
('83', 43, 5, 17, 84219) No doubt the non violent way is always the best, but where that does not come naturally the violent way is both necessary and honourable.
('83', 43, 5, 18, 84357) Inaction here is rank cowardice and unmanly.
('83', 43, 5, 19, 84402) It must be shunned at all cost.
('83', 43, 5, 20, 84434) Pandit Nehru told me that at the stations in the north, platform hawkers have banded themselves for self defence, so the troops are careful at those stations.
('83', 43, 5, 21, 84593) As to salt famine, the law is not quite on the people’s side but right is wholly on their side.
('83', 43, 5, 22, 84689) I am hoping that the Government will put the widest construction on the clause referring to salt in Gandhi Irwin pact and allow people to manufacture salt wherever they can.
('83', 43, 5, 23, 84863) And I would advise them to manufacture salt even at the risk of prosecution.
('83', 43, 5, 24, 84940) Necessity knows no law.
('83', 43, 5, 25, 84964) A starving man will help himself to food wherever he finds it.
('83', 43, 5, 26, 85027) Rishi Vishwamitra did so.
('83', 43, 5, 27, 85053) Number three is difficult to deal with.
('83', 43, 5, 28, 85093) But the same rule applies as to the second.
('83', 43, 5, 29, 85137) Food cannot be manufactured as easily as salt.
('83', 44, 0, 1, 85184) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 45
('83', 44, 1, 2, 85227) up to the merchants to band themselves to do what they can and force the hands of the Government to do the right thing by suggesting wise rules for the supply of food to the poor people at fixed prices.
('83', 44, 1, 3, 85430) If this is not done in time looting shops is sure to be a daily event.
('83', 44, 1, 4, 85501) As to four, I have no doubt that the authorities may not ask people to vacate except where they are ready to offer equivalent land and buildings and cart the people and their belongings to the places prepared for them and pay them a living wage till they find suitable occupation.
('83', 44, 1, 5, 85782) The people, if they have nowhere to move to, should simply refuse to vacate and suffer the consequences.
('83', 44, 1, 6, 85887) As to the fifth, the people should refuse to submit to discrimination and it will break down.
('83', 44, 1, 7, 85981) Most of these difficulties take place because we have cultivated the habit of submitting to them.
('83', 44, 1, 8, 86079) In the words of the late Lord Willingdon, we must learn resolutely to say ‘no’, when that is the real answer possible and take the consequences.
('83', 44, 1, 9, 86224) SEVAGRAM, June 22, 1942 Harijan, 28 6 1942

('83', 45, 1, 2, 87029) 53. THE LATE DR.
('83', 45, 2, 3, 87046) In Dr. Datta, Principal of Forman Christian College, the country has lost a staunch Christian nationalist.
('83', 45, 2, 4, 87153) I had the privilege of knowing him intimately soon after my return from South Africa.
('83', 45, 2, 5, 87239) He was an intimate friend of the late Deenabandhu Andrews and he would not be satisfied until he had brought me in touch with every one of his friends.
('83', 45, 2, 6, 87391) Dr. Datta worked whole heartedly day and night at the Unity Conference during the anxious time of my 21 days’ fast in 1924 in Delhi.
('83', 45, 2, 7, 87524) I saw him again equally earnestly at work at the time of the Second Round Table Conference.
('83', 45, 2, 8, 87616) His loss at this critical juncture in the country’s history would be doubly felt.
('83', 45, 2, 9, 87698) I tender my condolences to Mrs. Datta.
('83', 45, 2, 10, 87737) His numerous friends will share her sorrow.
('83', 45, 3, 11, 87781) SEVAGRAM, June 23, 1942
('83', 45, 4, 12, 87805) Harijan, 28 6 1942
('83', 45, 5, 13, 87824) 54. TALK WITH HORACE ALEXANDER 1
('83', 45, 6, 14, 87857) SEVAGRAM, [On or after June 23, 1942] 2
('83', 45, 7, 15, 87897) HORACE ALEXANDER: We were wondering if it was auspicious for an English party to arrive in India, when you were asking the British to withdraw.
('83', 45, 7, 16, 88041) Agatha suggested that we might have a party from India to work with us, and make of our party a mixed party.
('83', 45, 8, 17, 88150) GANDHIJI: My first writing did, I am afraid, give rise to that kind of fear.
('83', 45, 8, 18, 88227) That was because I had not given expression to the whole idea in my mind.
('83', 45, 8, 19, 88301) It is not my nature to work out and produce a finished thing all at once.
('83', 45, 8, 20, 88375) The moment a question was asked me, I made clear that no physical withdrawal of every Englishman was meant, I meant the withdrawal of the British domination.
('83', 45, 8, 21, 88533) And so every Englishman in India can convert himself into a friend—as you have come as
('83', 45, 9, 22, 88620) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Friends’ Ambulance Unit in Indian”.
('83', 45, 9, 23, 88690) Some of the members of the Unit felt that their experience in the bombed areas of Britain might prove of value in India and so a band of eight workers was sent to work in co operation with the volunteer agencies in India.
('83', 45, 9, 24, 88912) Horace Alexander, who arrived a little earlier with Richard Symonds, was the leader of the party.
('83', 45, 9, 25, 89010) 2 Horace Alexander arrived in Sevagram on June 23.
('83', 46, 0, 1, 89061) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 47
('83', 46, 1, 2, 89104) Friends—and remain here.
('83', 46, 1, 3, 89129) The condition is that every Englishman has to dismount from the horse he is riding and cease to be monarch of all he surveys and identify himself with the humblest of us.
('83', 46, 1, 4, 89300) The moment he does it, he will be recognized as a member of the family.
('83', 46, 1, 5, 89372) His role as a member of the ruling caste must end forever.
('83', 46, 1, 6, 89431) And so when I said ‘withdraw’, I meant ‘withdraw as masters’.
('83', 46, 1, 7, 89493) The demand for withdrawal had another implication.
('83', 46, 1, 8, 89544) You have to withdraw, irrespective of the wishes of anybody here.
('83', 46, 1, 9, 89610) You do not need the consent of a slave to give him freedom.
('83', 46, 1, 10, 89670) The slave often hugs the chains of slavery.
('83', 46, 1, 11, 89714) They become part of his flesh.
('83', 46, 1, 12, 89745) You have to tear them asunder and throw them away.
('83', 46, 1, 13, 89796) You must withdraw because it is your duty to do so, and not wait for the unanimous consent of all the sections or groups in India.
('83', 46, 1, 14, 89927) There is thus no question of the moment being inauspicious for you.
('83', 46, 1, 15, 89995) On the contrary, if you can assimilate my proposal, it is the most auspicious moment for you to arrive in India.
('83', 46, 1, 16, 90108) You will meet many Englishmen here.
('83', 46, 1, 17, 90144) They may have entirely misunderstood what I have said, and you have to explain to them what exactly I want them to do.
('83', 46, 1, 18, 90263) Really speaking, therefore, this should become the major part of your mission, and even the India Office who facilitated your coming here cannot possibly misunderstand you.
('83', 46, 1, 19, 90436) You have, therefore, not only the humanitarian mission—there may not be any bombing here, and in this vast country even if there is bombing you may not be able to reach everywhere—but you have also this peculiar mission of interpretation and reconciliation.
('83', 46, 1, 20, 90694) And it is well perhaps that your mission begins with me.
('83', 46, 1, 21, 90751) Begin it with finding out what exactly is at the back of my mind by putting to me all the questions that may be agitating you.
('83', 46, 1, 22, 90878) You will see that I have used the words ‘orderly withdrawal’.
('83', 46, 1, 23, 90940) I had, when I used the phrase, Burma and Singapore in mind.
('83', 46, 1, 24, 91000) It was a disorderly withdrawal from there.
('83', 46, 1, 25, 91043) For there left Burma and Malaya neither to God, nor to anarchy, but to the Japanese.
('83', 46, 1, 26, 91128) Here I say: ‘Don’t repeat that story here.
('83', 46, 1, 27, 91171) Don’t leave India to Japan, but leave India to Indians in an orderly manner.
('83', 46, 1, 28, 91248) So you have now to do what Andrews did—understand me, pitilessly cross examine me, and then if you are convinced be my messenger.
('83', 46, 2, 29, 91378) H. A. We dare not assume his mantle.
('83', 46, 2, 30, 91415) We can but try.
('83', 46, 2, 31, 91431) Harijan, 5 7 1942

('83', 48, 1, 2, 92511) 57. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA June 24, 1942
('83', 48, 2, 3, 92551) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS, As Swami is going, I am sending this with him.
('83', 48, 2, 4, 92617) I feel this meeting of Goseva Sangh was inevitable.
('83', 48, 2, 5, 92669) The land and other things given to us are in two parts.
('83', 48, 2, 6, 92725) One is that which Jamnalalji gave and the other that for which the Ashram has paid.
('83', 48, 2, 7, 92809) This money was given for both immovable and movable property.
('83', 48, 2, 8, 92871) What the Ashram has paid now was from the money mostly given by you brothers.
('83', 48, 2, 9, 92949) That means it was your donation.
('83', 48, 2, 10, 92982) We shall now do what you consider best.
('83', 48, 2, 11, 93022) If you want to draw the amount from the Goseva Sangh, you will save that much money; otherwise that will be your additional donation to Goseva Sangh.
('83', 48, 2, 12, 93172) I on my part can neither make donation out of a donation nor earn any merit from it.
('83', 48, 2, 13, 93257) I hope I have been able to make myself clear.
('83', 48, 2, 14, 93303) Now do whatever you think best.
('83', 48, 2, 15, 93335) My mind is working fast on what I have undertaken.
('83', 48, 2, 16, 93386) The Empire’s wickedness is terrible.
('83', 48, 2, 17, 93423) I feel unhappy and also angry at what is said against me.
('83', 48, 2, 18, 93481) But one should not feel either unhappy or angry— all these things are transitory.
('83', 48, 2, 19, 93563) I have almost finalized the strategy for the struggle.
('83', 48, 2, 20, 93618) I am waiting for the Working Committee meeting.
('83', 48, 2, 21, 93666) As far as I am concerned, I am fully prepared.
('83', 48, 2, 22, 93713) The rest when we meet.

('83', 49, 12, 25, 95279) I hope you will deal with them in a proper way in Harijan.
('83', 49, 13, 26, 95338) (1) The first and the great point made against the Congress is that the Congress does not care for the Sikhs.

('83', 49, 13, 28, 95588) We tell them that Working
('83', 50, 0, 1, 95614) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 51

('83', 50, 2, 3, 95772) (2) Several years ago while discussing the thesis of non violence in Young India you said that ‘Guru Govind Singh was a misguided patriot’ or words to that effect.
('83', 50, 2, 4, 95936) 1 When fiery speakers mention this it makes a great sentimental appeal to the Sikhs.

('83', 52, 11, 24, 101290) June 26, 1942
('83', 52, 12, 25, 101304) These examinations are unlike the orthodox university examinations which are at best a test of book knowledge and depend on the whims of examiners.
('83', 52, 12, 26, 101452) Here even if you do not pass in your examinations what you have learnt is not lost; it has profited the country.
('83', 52, 12, 27, 101565) Failure means inadequate practice or work, and the next year
('83', 52, 13, 28, 101626) 1 The addressee was worried about the marriage of his daughter Jyotsna.
('83', 52, 13, 29, 101698) 2 Omission as in the source 3 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “With Khadi Workers”.
('83', 52, 13, 30, 101781) The occasion was the distribution of certificates.
('83', 53, 0, 1, 101832) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 53, 1, 2, 101873) you will increase your knowledge and production.
('83', 53, 1, 3, 101922) Then the orthodox examinations prepare the examinees at best for clerkships, and those who pass have no illusions about adding anything to the wealth of the country, while even the failures amongst you have added something to the wealth of the country, if not quite as much as those who have passed.
('83', 53, 1, 4, 102222) Then there is another very vital difference.
('83', 53, 1, 5, 102267) The boys in the schools and colleges pay heavy fees, but far heavier than their fees are the expenses incurred by Government on their education.
('83', 53, 1, 6, 102412) The country gets nothing by way of return for this enormous expenditure; if there is any little gain it belongs to an alien government.
('83', 53, 1, 7, 102548) Then the system of examinations is most mechanical and tiring and calculated to add little to the examinees’ intellectual calibre.
('83', 53, 1, 8, 102679) Here the end in view is to qualify students to add more and more to the country’s wealth, to stimulate originality and, apart from giving them a living, render service of the country.
('83', 53, 1, 9, 102863) One last point which if you have not grasped I want you to grasp today.
('83', 53, 1, 10, 102935) Inasmuch as service of the country is the final aim, the failures have no cause for disappointment, the passes have no reason to look down upon the failures, and there is little scope for unhealthy rivalry.
('83', 53, 1, 11, 103142) The students in the ordinary schools and colleges throw away their books after they have passed their examinations, for they think they are no longer going to be of use to them.
('83', 53, 1, 12, 103320) Here you cannot afford to throw away your books or tools, for they are always of value, and once a khadi student is always a khadi student, he goes on adding to his knowledge and fitness as a khadi worker.
('83', 53, 2, 13, 103526) Gandhiji next addressed himself to a vital difference between spinning as practised in ancient times and as it is being taught and practised now.
('83', 53, 2, 14, 103672) It is a thing which has to be borne in mind by both the taught and the teachers and the examiners, for the latter not only teach the students but teach themselves in the process The distinction I desire to invite your attention to is fundamental.
('83', 53, 2, 15, 103919) Our ancestors did spin and weave and produce their own cloth, but they were just spinners and weavers, toiling either for their bread or for their employers, e.g., the East India Company.
('83', 53, 2, 16, 104107) There was little joy about their work, and no spirit of service or knowledge.
('83', 53, 2, 17, 104185) They toiled because they could not help it, and often it was such irksome drudgery that it drove them to cut off their own fingers in order that the slave drivers may drive them no more.
('83', 53, 2, 18, 104372) Their toil was their slavery.
('83', 53, 2, 19, 104402) They have left nothing for us to emulate.
('83', 53, 2, 20, 104444) We have to do penance for and wipe out that slavery.
('83', 53, 2, 21, 104497) Their toil would have been perfectly honourable, if there had been knowledge at the back of it, as also the
('83', 54, 0, 1, 104605) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 55
('83', 54, 1, 2, 104648) desire for the country’s freedom, the determination not to bend the knee to the slave driver, and a sense of art.
('83', 54, 1, 3, 104762) A revival of the industry means adoption of all these life giving virtues, it means infusing new life into the dead bones of the old industry.
('83', 54, 2, 4, 104905) Harijan, 5 7 1942
('83', 54, 3, 5, 104923) 65. DISCUSSION WITH KHADI WORKERS 1
('83', 54, 4, 6, 104959) SEVAGRAM, June 26, 1942
('83', 54, 5, 7, 104983) The first question discussed was about adding to the capital by making collections and raising loans.
('83', 54, 5, 8, 105085) The collections could, it was explained, be made by every one of the branches, but they should be made on behalf of the A.I.S.A., which must determine the way of their disposal.
('83', 54, 5, 9, 105263) Gandhiji had no objection to raising loans, but those who advanced loans must be told, in this uncertain time of war, they were taking obvious risks, though perhaps no more then deposits in banks.
('83', 54, 5, 10, 105460) If we survive the war and the terrible struggle ahead, we should repay every pie, but if we don’t survive, they stand every risk of losing their money.
('83', 54, 5, 11, 105612) It is likely that no one would care to advance loans.
('83', 54, 5, 12, 105666) It was better therefore to concentrate on self and sacrificial spinning, and on getting gifts of yarn and cotton.
('83', 54, 6, 13, 105780) “But those who advance loans to us may have another fear,” someone asked “Even as it is, there is the obvious risk of war, but by advancing loans to us they may feel that they add to their risk.”
('83', 54, 7, 14, 105976) GANDHIJI: Then let them know they will have earned the merit of having lost money in a good cause.

('83', 54, 9, 21, 106511) But there may be quixotic and arbitrary orders given to the people in the midst of whom we are working.
('83', 54, 9, 22, 106615) We could reason with the authorities, but if they do not listen, we might be involved in spite of ourselves.

('83', 55, 5, 16, 108028) 66. OH!
('83', 55, 5, 17, 108036) THE TROOPS
('83', 55, 6, 18, 108047) I have to pay a heavy price for having drawn up an entrancing picture of a free India without a single British soldier.
('83', 55, 6, 19, 108167) Friends are confounded now to discover that my proposal admits of the presence of British and even American troops under any circumstance at all.
('83', 55, 6, 20, 108313) In vain do I argue that the Allied troops, if they remain, will do so not to exercise authority over the people, or at India’s expense, but they will remain under treaty with the Government of free India at the United Nations’ expense for the sole purpose of repelling Japanese attack and helping China.
('83', 55, 6, 21, 108617) It has been pointed out that not to consent to the Allied troops remaining in India during the period of the war is to hand over India and China to Japan, and to ensure the defeat of the Allied powers.
('83', 55, 6, 22, 108819) This could never have been contemplated by me.
('83', 55, 6, 23, 108866) The only answer, therefore, to give was to suffer the presence of the troops but under circumstance the reverse of the existing.
('83', 55, 6, 24, 108995) They will remain under permission of free India and not at all in the role of masters but of friends.
('83', 55, 6, 25, 109097) My proposal presupposes shedding of all fear and distrust.
('83', 55, 6, 26, 109156) If we have confidence in ourselves, we need neither fear nor suspect the
('83', 56, 0, 1, 109229) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 57
('83', 56, 1, 2, 109272) presence of Allied troops.
('83', 56, 1, 3, 109299) May I suggest also that it is altogether premature and wrong to pore over the weakest points of a very difficult project which may not be accepted even with the troops remaining in India?
('83', 56, 1, 4, 109487) It will be most assuredly an event of the century and may be a turning point in the war if Britain can honestly perform the act of renouncing India with all that the renunciation would mean.
('83', 56, 1, 5, 109678) The virtue and the value of the renunciation in my opinion will not be affected in the least, because the Allied troops will be operating in India with the sole object of preventing Japanese attack.
('83', 56, 1, 6, 109877) After all India is as much interested as the Allies in warding off the attack and yet under my proposal India will not have to pay a single pie over the expenses of the troops.
('83', 56, 1, 7, 110054) As I have already said in the previous issue of Harijan, the British acceptance of my proposal may itself lead to a most honourable peace and hence automatic withdrawal of the troops.
('83', 56, 1, 8, 110238) I would therefore ask the doubters to concentrate their attention upon the grandeur of the proposed renunciation and help to the utmost of their power the fruition of the great act.
('83', 56, 1, 9, 110420) Let them not dread the presence of the troops in India for the purpose indicated but regard it as an inevitable part of the proposal so as to make it not only justifiable but foolproof.
('83', 56, 1, 10, 110606) So far as I can see free India will run no risk by their presence.
('83', 56, 1, 11, 110673) Her freedom will certainly suffer no diminution thereby.
('83', 56, 1, 12, 110730) The implications of my proposal are: (1) India becomes free of all financial obligation to Britain; (2) The annual drain to Great Britain stops automatically; (3) All taxation ceases except what the replacing government imposes or retains; (4) The dead weight of an all powerful authority keeping under subjection the tallest in the land is lifted at once; (5) In short, India begins a new chapter in her national life, as I shall hope to affect the fortunes of the war with non violence as her predominant sanction.
('83', 56, 1, 13, 111247) This non violence will no longer take the shape of non co operation and the like.
('83', 56, 1, 14, 111329) It will express itself in her ambassadors going to the Axis powers not to beg for peace but to show them the futility of war for achieving an honourable end.
('83', 56, 1, 15, 111487) This can only be done if and when Britain sheds the gains of perhaps the most organized successful violence the world has seen.
('83', 57, 0, 1, 111615) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 57, 1, 2, 111656) All this may not come to pass, I do not mind.
('83', 57, 1, 3, 111702) It is worth fighting for, it is worth staking all that the nation has.
('83', 57, 2, 4, 111773) SEVAGRAM, June 27, 1942
('83', 57, 3, 5, 111797) Harijan, 5 7 1942

('83', 57, 8, 23, 112899) 68. QUESTION BOX
('83', 57, 9, 24, 112916) A FALLACY
('83', 57, 10, 25, 112926) Q. You consider it a vital necessity in terms of non violence to allow the Allied troops to remain in India.
('83', 57, 10, 26, 113035) You also say that, as you cannot present a foolproof non violent method to prevant Japanese occupation of India, you cannot throw the Allies over board.
('83', 57, 10, 27, 113188) But, don’t you consider that the non violent force created by your action which will be sufficient to force the English to withdraw will be sufficiently strong to prevent Japanese occupation also?
('83', 57, 10, 28, 113385) And is it not the duty of a non violent resister to equally consider it a vital necessity to see that his country, his home and
('83', 57, 11, 29, 113513) 1 This appeared under the heading “Notes”.
('83', 58, 0, 1, 113556) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 59
('83', 58, 1, 2, 113599) his all are not destroyed by allowing two foreign mad bulls to fight a deadly war on his soil?
('83', 58, 2, 3, 113694) A. There is an obvious fallacy in the question.
('83', 58, 2, 4, 113742) I cannot all of a sudden produce in the minds of Britishers, who have been for centuries trained to rely upon their muscle for their protection, a belief which has not made a very visible impression even on the Indian mind.
('83', 58, 2, 5, 113966) Non violent force must not act in the same way as violence.
('83', 58, 2, 6, 114026) The refusal to allow the Allied troops to operate on the Indian soil can only add to the irritation already caused by my proposal.
('83', 58, 2, 7, 114157) The first is inevitable, the second would be wanton.
('83', 58, 2, 8, 114210) Again, if the withdrawal is to take place, it won’t be due merely to the non violent pressure.
('83', 58, 2, 9, 114305) And in any case what may be enough to affect the old occupant would be wholly different from what would be required to keep off the invader.
('83', 58, 2, 10, 114446) Thus we can disown the authority of the British rulers by refusing taxes and in a variety of ways.
('83', 58, 2, 11, 114545) These would be inapplicable to withstand the Japanese onslaught.
('83', 58, 2, 12, 114610) Therefore, whilst we may be ready to face the Japanese, we may not ask the Britishers to give up their position of vantage merely on the unwarranted supposition that we would succeed by mere non violent effort in keeping off the Japanese.
('83', 58, 2, 13, 114849) Lastly, whilst we must guard ourselves in our own way, our non violence must preclude us from imposing on the British a strain which must break them.
('83', 58, 2, 14, 114999) That would be a denial of our whole history for the past twenty two years.
('83', 58, 3, 15, 115074) SEVAGRAM, June 28, 1942
('83', 58, 4, 16, 115098) Harijan, 5 7 1942

('83', 60, 1, 2, 117006) 71. QUESTION BOX
('83', 60, 2, 3, 117023) A BENGALI MOTHER’S Two Questions
('83', 60, 3, 4, 117056) Q. Bengal is threatened by the Japanese menace.
('83', 60, 3, 5, 117104) It is time now the political workers in this province composed their differences.
('83', 60, 3, 6, 117186) I believe they will readily forget their domestic squabble only if the right person mediates.
('83', 60, 3, 7, 117280) Would you not exert yourself to that end and save Bengal from the impending disaster?
('83', 60, 4, 8, 117366) A. What you say is too true.
('83', 60, 4, 9, 117395) But I doubt if I am the right person to mediate.
('83', 60, 4, 10, 117444) A Bengali should tackle the question.
('83', 60, 4, 11, 117482) I would go to Bengal today, if I had the confidence that I could perform the trick.
('83', 60, 4, 12, 117566) When one comes to think of it, the differences are too trivial to need any mediation.
('83', 60, 5, 13, 117652) Q. My husband is a teacher employed in a school of Calcutta.
('83', 60, 5, 14, 117713) His income is already alarmingly diminished.
('83', 60, 5, 15, 117758) It is apprehended in a month or so he will have no income at all.
('83', 60, 5, 16, 117824) He has now seven dependants.
('83', 60, 5, 17, 117853) Formerly he earned just enough to provide his family with the ordinary necessities of life.
('83', 60, 5, 18, 117945) He has now nothing to fall back upon.
('83', 60, 5, 19, 117983) I know my husband is patriotic and Congress minded.
('83', 60, 5, 20, 118035) But in order to be able to give us food he finds no alternative but to join war service.
('83', 60, 5, 21, 118124) What else can he do?
('83', 60, 5, 22, 118145) What is your advice to those who are similarly stranded?
('83', 60, 6, 23, 118202) A. This is a very serious question.
('83', 60, 6, 24, 118238) I know that joining the military is the shortest cut to bread winning.
('83', 60, 6, 25, 118309) If you and your husband are averse to all war like me, you will face starvation and prove your aversion.
('83', 60, 6, 26, 118414) God will prevent you from dying of starvation.
('83', 60, 6, 27, 118461) You might have to revise your way of living.
('83', 60, 6, 28, 118506) Middle classes have to come down to the level of the peasantry.
('83', 60, 6, 29, 118570) Then only shall we know real India and the way to deal with growing distress of the millions.
('83', 60, 6, 30, 118664) But if you have no such aversion, I see no harm in your husband joining military serivce.
('83', 60, 6, 31, 118754) He will do no worse then many are doing.

('83', 63, 7, 11, 122874) The Associated Press has circulated the following note about Khan Saheb:
('83', 63, 8, 12, 122947) The Frontier Provincial Congress Committee has released the following statement:
('83', 63, 9, 13, 123028) “We warn the public against the false propaganda that is being carried on against Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan, the undisputed leader of the Pathans and the Khudai Khidmatgar movement, in certain sections of the Press.
('83', 63, 9, 14, 123242) It has been hinted that the differences have arisen among the workers and party politics is raising its ugly head.
('83', 63, 9, 15, 123357) Not a single Khudai Khidmatgar has so far resigned.
('83', 63, 9, 16, 123409) They are all united like one man under Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan’s leadership.
('83', 63, 9, 17, 123486) All talk about parties among them has no foundation whatsoever.
('83', 63, 9, 18, 123550) All these so called differences, etc., exist only in the imagination of a few interested people who are craving for offices and think that by encouraging such talk they can gain their end.
('83', 63, 9, 19, 123739) The Government is at the back of all such propaganda.
('83', 63, 9, 20, 123793) But these people have no following among the Frontier masses.
('83', 63, 9, 21, 123855) Every true nationalist in the Frontier clearly realizes that we can have nothing to do with the British Government in India, much less with offices.
('83', 63, 9, 22, 124004) Whatever attraction the parliamentary programme may have elsewhere in India, it has certainly no place in the Frontier.
('83', 63, 10, 23, 124124) “Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan’s peaceful constructive humanitarian work among the villages for the maintenance of internal security and self sufficiency in matters of food and cloth has further endeared him to the people especially the poor, He has been hoping to carry his message of peace and goodwill even to the neighbouring tribes.
('83', 63, 10, 24, 124456) He has been devoting all his energy to raise a non violent and peaceful army who can render true service
('83', 64, 0, 1, 124561) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 65
('83', 64, 1, 2, 124604) to the people under difficult days ahead.
('83', 64, 1, 3, 124646) What the Government has failed to achieve at the cost of millions of rupees he is attempting to do with purely voluntary help.
('83', 64, 1, 4, 124773) He deserves the sympathy and co operation of every man, woman and child of the Frontier in this noble work.
('83', 64, 1, 5, 124881) We hope that the Frontier masses will respond to his call and the Press and journalists of India who have the true interests of the country at heart will take a dispassionate interest in his work.” The Frontier Provincial Congress Committee has done well to pass the resolution and circulate the note.

('83', 65, 9, 29, 127580) 81. LETTER TO FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT
('83', 65, 10, 30, 127616) SEVAGRAM, via WARDHA (INDIA.), July 1, 1942
('83', 65, 11, 31, 127660) DEAR FRIEND, I twice missed coming to your great country.
('83', 65, 11, 32, 127718) I have the privilege [of] having numerous friends there both known and
('83', 65, 12, 33, 127789) 1 The reference is to the compromise over the struggle in the State of Limdi; vide “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 3 6 1942 and 10 6 1942.
('83', 66, 0, 1, 127927) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 67
('83', 66, 1, 2, 127970) unknown to me.
('83', 66, 1, 3, 127985) Many of my countrymen have received and are still receiving higher education in America.
('83', 66, 1, 4, 128074) I know too that several have taken shelter there.
('83', 66, 1, 5, 128124) I have profited greatly by the writings of Thoreau and Emerson.
('83', 66, 1, 6, 128188) I say this to tell you how much I am connected with your country.
('83', 66, 1, 7, 128254) Of Great Britain I need say nothing beyond mentioning that in spite of my intense dislike of British rule, I have numerous personal friends in England whom I love as dearly as my own people.
('83', 66, 1, 8, 128445) I had my legal education there.
('83', 66, 1, 9, 128477) I have therefore nothing but good wishes for your country and Great Britain.
('83', 66, 1, 10, 128554) You will therefore accept my word that my present proposal, that the British should unreservedly and without reference to the wishes of the people of India immediately withdraw their rule, is prompted by the friendliest intention.
('83', 66, 1, 11, 128785) I would like to turn into goodwill the ill will which, whatever may be said to the contrary, exists in India towards Great Britain and thus enable the millions of India to play their part in the present war.
('83', 66, 1, 12, 128993) My personal position is clear.
('83', 66, 1, 13, 129024) I hate all war.
('83', 66, 1, 14, 129040) If, therefore, I could persuade my countrymen, they would make a most effective and decisive contribution in favour of an honourable peace.
('83', 66, 1, 15, 129180) But I know that all of us have not a living faith in non violence.
('83', 66, 1, 16, 129247) Under foreign rule however we can make no effective contribution of any kind in this war, except as helots.
('83', 66, 1, 17, 129355) The policy of the Indian National Congress, largely guided by me, has been one of non embarrassment to Britain, consistently with the honourable working of the Congress, admittedly the largest political organization, of the longest standing in India.
('83', 66, 1, 18, 129606) The British policy as exposed by the Cripps mission and rejected by almost all parties has opened our eyes and has driven me to the proposal I have made.
('83', 66, 1, 19, 129760) I hold that the full acceptance of my proposal and that alone can put the Allied cause on an unassailable basis.
('83', 66, 1, 20, 129873) I venture to think that the Allied declaration that the Allies are fighting to make the world safe for freedom of the individual and for democracy sounds hollow so long as India and, for that matter, Africa are exploited by Great Britain and America has the Negro problem in her own home.
('83', 66, 1, 21, 130162) But in order to avoid all complications, in my proposal I have confined myself only to India.
('83', 66, 1, 22, 130256) If India becomes free, the rest must follow, if it does not happen simultaneously.
('83', 66, 1, 23, 130339) In order to make my proposal foolproof I have suggested that, if the Allies think it necessary, they may keep their troops, at their own expense in India, not for keeping internal order but for preventing Japanese aggression and defending China.
('83', 66, 1, 24, 130585) So far as India is
('83', 67, 0, 1, 130604) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 67, 1, 2, 130645) concerned, we must become free even as America and Great Britain are.
('83', 67, 1, 3, 130715) The Allied troops will remain in India during the war under treaty with the free Indian Government that may be formed by the people of India without any outside interference, direct or indirect.
('83', 67, 1, 4, 130910) It is on behalf of this proposal that I write this to enlist your active sympathy.
('83', 67, 1, 5, 130993) I hope that it would commend itself to you.
('83', 67, 1, 6, 131037) Mr. Louis Fischer is carrying this letter to you.
('83', 67, 1, 7, 131087) If there is any obscurity in my letter, you have but to send me word and I shall try to clear it.
('83', 67, 1, 8, 131185) I hope finally that you will not resent this letter as an intrusion but take it as an approach from a friend and well wisher of the Allies.
('83', 67, 2, 9, 131325) I remain,
('83', 67, 3, 10, 131335) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI PRESIDENT FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT

('83', 68, 1, 2, 132110) 83. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW
('83', 68, 2, 3, 132140) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, C. P., July 2, 1942
('83', 68, 3, 4, 132178) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW, I venture to approach you again on a humanitarian matter wholly unconnected with politics.
('83', 68, 3, 5, 132291) Dr. Rajendra Prasad, who has been touring in Bihar, brings me the news that British and American troops are spread all over Bihar and that numberless cattle are slaughtered for their beef.
('83', 68, 3, 6, 132480) These include milch cows and plough cattle.
('83', 68, 3, 7, 132524) Though the number of cattle in India is great a vast number, if not the majority, are, as you are aware, a burden upon the land.
('83', 68, 3, 8, 132653) Now if plough cattle and milch cows are slaughtered the burden increases and ploughing becomes difficult and the milk supply which is already poor suffers further reduction.
('83', 68, 3, 9, 132827) I wonder if you can use your influence with the Military so as to save milch cows and plough cattle from slaughter.
('83', 68, 4, 10, 132943) When you write to them please send my regards to Lady Anne 2
('83', 68, 5, 11, 133004) and Southby 3. I hope they and the baby are getting on well.
('83', 68, 7, 12, 133065) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('83', 68, 8, 13, 133095) The Transfer of Power, Vol. II, p.

('83', 71, 9, 23, 137365) 89. GURU GOVIND SINGH
('83', 71, 10, 24, 137387) At last after diligent search Mahadev Desai and others have traced the writing in which I have referred to Guru Govind Singh.
('83', 71, 10, 25, 137513) 2 It appears in Young India of 9th April, 1925. It is headed ‘My Friend the Revolutionary’.
('83', 71, 10, 26, 137605) I would commend it to my Sikh friends and, for that matter, others the whole of the article.
('83', 71, 10, 27, 137698) It is seasonable and they will profit by it, whether they accept or reject the views propounded in it.
('83', 71, 10, 28, 137801) Here I must content myself with only relevant extracts from that article.
('83', 71, 10, 29, 137875) Here they are:
('83', 71, 11, 30, 137890) 1 Vide the preceding item where too Gandhiji speaks of fatigue.
('83', 71, 11, 31, 137954) 2 In the article “For the Sikh Friends”, 26 6 42, Gandhiji had said that he could not find the writing in which he was alleged to have said that Guru Govind Singh was a misguided patriot.
('83', 71, 11, 32, 138142) For the text of the article, vide “My Friend, The Revolutionary”, 9 4 1925.
('83', 72, 0, 1, 138218) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 73
('83', 72, 1, 2, 138261) One of your objections against the revolutionaries is that their movement is not mass movement, consequently the mass at large will be very little benefited by the revolution, for which we are preparing.
('83', 72, 1, 3, 138465) That is indirectly saying that we shall be most benefited by it.
('83', 72, 1, 4, 138530) Is it really what you mean to say?
('83', 72, 1, 5, 138565) Do you believe that those persons who are ever ready to die for their country—those mad lovers of their country—I mean the revolutionaries of India in whom the spirit of Nishkama Karma reigns, will betray their motherland and secure privileges for a life—this trifling life?
('83', 72, 1, 6, 138840) It is true that we will not drag the mass just now in the field of action, because we know that it is weak; but when the preparation is complete we shall call them in the open field.
('83', 72, 1, 7, 139023) We profess to understand the present Indian psychology full well, because we daily get the chance of weighing our brethren along with ourselves.
('83', 72, 1, 8, 139168) We know the mass of India is after all Indian, it is not weak by itself but there is want of efficient leaders; so when we have begot the number of leaders required by constant propaganda and preaching, and the arms, we shall not shrink from calling, and if necessary, dragging the mass in the open field to prove that they are the descendants of Shivaji, Ranjit, Pratap and Govind Singh.
('83', 72, 1, 9, 139557) Besides we have been constantly preaching that the mass is not for the revolution but the revolution is for the mass.
('83', 72, 1, 10, 139675) Is it sufficient to remove your prejudice in this connection?
('83', 72, 1, 11, 139737) I neither say nor imply that the revolutionary benefits if the masses do not.
('83', 72, 1, 12, 139815) On the contrary, and as a rule, the revolutionary never benefits in the ordinary sense of the word.
('83', 72, 1, 13, 139915) If the revolutionaries succeed in attracting, not ‘dragging’, the masses to them, they will find that the murderous campaign is totally unnecessary.
('83', 72, 1, 14, 140064) It sounds very pleasant and exciting to talk of ‘the descendants of Shivaji, Ranjit, Pratap and Govind Singh’.
('83', 72, 1, 15, 140175) But is it true?
('83', 72, 1, 16, 140191) Are we all descendants of these heroes in the sense in which the writer understands it?
('83', 72, 1, 17, 140279) We are their countrymen, but their descendants are the military classes.
('83', 72, 1, 18, 140352) We may in future be able to obliterate caste, but today it persists, and therefore the claim put up by the writer cannot in my opinion be sustained.
('83', 72, 2, 19, 140501) Last of all, I shall ask you to answer these questions: Was Guru Govind Singh a misguided patriot because he believed in warfare for noble cause?
('83', 72, 2, 20, 140647) What will you like to say about Washington, Garibaldi and Lenin?
('83', 72, 2, 21, 140712) What do you think of Kamal Pasha and De Valera?
('83', 72, 2, 22, 140760) Would you like to call Shivaji and Pratap well meaning and sacrificing physicians who prescribed arsenic when they should have given fresh grape juice?
('83', 72, 2, 23, 140912) Will you like to call Krishna Europeanized because he believed also in the vinasha of dushkritas?
('83', 72, 2, 24, 141010) This is a hard or rather awkward question.
('83', 72, 2, 25, 141053) But I dare not shirk it.
('83', 72, 2, 26, 141078) In the first instance Guru Govind Singh and the others whose names are mentioned did not believe in secret murder.
('83', 72, 2, 27, 141193) In the second, these patriots knew their work and their men,
('83', 73, 0, 1, 141254) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 73, 1, 2, 141295) whereas the modern Indian revolutionary does not know his work.
('83', 73, 1, 3, 141359) He has not the men, he has not the atmosphere, that the patriots mentioned had.
('83', 73, 1, 4, 141439) Though my views are derived from my theory of life I have not put them before the nation on that ground.
('83', 73, 1, 5, 141544) I have based my opposition to the revolutionaries on the sole ground of expedience.
('83', 73, 1, 6, 141628) Therefore, to compare their activities with those of Guru Govind Singh or Washington or Garibaldi or Lenin would be most misleading and dangerous.
('83', 73, 1, 7, 141775) But by test of the theory of non violence I do not hesitate to say that it is highly likely that, had I lived as their contemporary and in the respective countries, I would have called every one of them a misguided patriot, even though a succeessful and brave warrior.
('83', 73, 1, 8, 142044) As it is, I must not judge them.
('83', 73, 1, 9, 142077) I disbelieve history so far as details of acts of heroes are concerned.
('83', 73, 1, 10, 142149) I accept broad facts of history and draw my own lessons for my conduct.
('83', 73, 1, 11, 142221) I do not want to repeat it in so far as the broad facts contradict the highest laws of life.
('83', 73, 1, 12, 142314) But I positively refuse to judge men from the scanty material furnished to us by history.
('83', 73, 1, 13, 142404) De mortuis nil nisi bonum.
('83', 73, 1, 14, 142431) Kamal Pasha and De Valera too I cannot judge.
('83', 73, 1, 15, 142477) But for me as a believer in non violence out and out they cannot be my guides in life in so far as their faith in war is concerned.
('83', 73, 1, 16, 142609) I believe in Krishna perhaps more than the writer.
('83', 73, 1, 17, 142660) But my Krishna is the Lord of the Universe, the creator, preserver and destroyer of us all.
('83', 73, 1, 18, 142752) He may destroy because He creates.
('83', 73, 1, 19, 142787) But I must not be drawn into a philosophical or religious argument with my friends.
('83', 73, 1, 20, 142871) I have not the qualifications for teaching my philosophy of life.
('83', 73, 1, 21, 142937) I have barely qualifications for practising the philosophy I believe.
('83', 73, 1, 22, 143007) I am but a poor struggling soul yearning to be wholly good—wholly truthful and wholly non violent in thought, word and deed, but ever failing to reach the ideal which I know to be there.
('83', 73, 1, 23, 143194) I admit, and assure my revolutionary friends, it is a painful climb, but the pain of it is a positive pleasure for me.
('83', 73, 1, 24, 143313) Each step upward makes me feel stronger and fit for the next.
('83', 73, 1, 25, 143375) But all that pain and the pleasure are for me.
('83', 73, 1, 26, 143422) The revolutionaries are at liberty to reject the whole of my philosophy.
('83', 73, 1, 27, 143495) To them I merely present my own experiences as a co worker in the same cause even as I have successfully presented them to the Ali Brothers and many other friends.
('83', 73, 1, 28, 143659) They can and do applaud whole heartedly the action of Mustafa Kamal Pasha and possibly De Valera and Lenin.
('83', 73, 1, 29, 143767) But they realize with me that India is not like Turkey or Ireland or Russia and that revolutionary activity is suicidal at this stage of the country’s life at any rate, if not for all time, in a country so vast, so hopelessly divided and with the masses so deeply sunk in pauperism and so fearfully terror struck.
('83', 73, 1, 30, 144081) I reverted to the same subject in another article written a short time after, from which I need take only the following lines:
('83', 73, 2, 31, 144208) My belief about the Sikh Gurus is that they were all deeply religious
('83', 74, 0, 1, 144278) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 75
('83', 74, 1, 2, 144321) teachers and reformers, that they were all Hindus, and that Guru Govind Singh was one of the greatest defenders of Hinduism.
('83', 74, 1, 3, 144446) I believe too that he drew the sword in its defence.
('83', 74, 1, 4, 144499) But I cannot judge his actions nor can I use him as my model so far as his resort to the sword is concerned.
('83', 74, 2, 5, 144608) It must be clear even to him who runs that I never applied the word ‘misguided patriot’, to the Great Guru and that I have not written a word in disrespect or of which I have any reason to be ashamed or to repent.
('83', 74, 2, 6, 144822) I abide by every word I have said in that article.
('83', 74, 2, 7, 144873) I hope that now that the source of the mischief has been traced it will abate entirely and the Sikhs will count me, though a humble Hindu, as a fellow devotee of the Panth.
('83', 74, 3, 8, 145046) SEVAGRAM, July 4, 1942
('83', 74, 4, 9, 145069) Harijan, 12 7 1942
('83', 74, 5, 10, 145088) 90. “SARVODAYA” 2
('83', 74, 6, 11, 145106) Lovers of Hindi already know that the Sarvodaya is a monthly published from Wardha.
('83', 74, 6, 12, 145190) Kaka Kalelkar and Dada Dharmadhikari are its editors.
('83', 74, 6, 13, 145244) In fact there are three editors because Kishorelal generally contributes to every issue.
('83', 74, 6, 14, 145333) The aim of this monthly is to conduct a theoretical discussion of the science of satyagraha and to propagate it in its purest form, so that the whole world may be uplifted.
('83', 74, 6, 15, 145506) This monthly is being published for the last four years but every year there has been a loss of about two to three thousand rupees.
('83', 74, 6, 16, 145638) The question therefore is whether it should be continued in spite of so much loss.
('83', 74, 6, 17, 145721) Many friends are of the opinion that Sarvodaya should be continued even at a loss.
('83', 74, 6, 18, 145804) While others ask if it is any use continuing it when it is not worth the cost of its production.
('83', 74, 6, 19, 145901) Both these views can be defended to some extent.
('83', 74, 6, 20, 145950) But the middle course would be to consult the subscribers.
('83', 74, 6, 21, 146009) They do not have a clear picture of the loss.
('83', 74, 6, 22, 146055) If they think that the publication of Sarvodaya is necessary, then each one of them should enroll at least one new subscriber, then alone can we make up the loss.
('83', 74, 6, 23, 146218) At present there are about nine hundred subscribers.
('83', 74, 6, 24, 146271) The loss can be covered if there are two thousand of them.
('83', 74, 6, 25, 146330) Those who are unable to enroll new subscribers but are rich can themselves pay for one or two subscribers.
('83', 74, 6, 26, 146437) There are always some people who are curious
('83', 74, 7, 27, 146482) 1 Vide “Sikhism”, 1 10 1925. 2 This appeared under the heading “Notes”.
('83', 75, 0, 1, 146554) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 75, 1, 2, 146595) but would want a free copy.
('83', 75, 1, 3, 146623) In fact they cannot afford to pay the subscription.
('83', 75, 1, 4, 146675) So if we have someone to pay their subscription, Sarvodaya can be sent to them regularly.
('83', 75, 1, 5, 146765) The main reason for publishing this in Harijan Sevak is that those other than the subscribers of Sarvodaya may also know about the loss.
('83', 75, 1, 6, 146902) The policy of Sarvodaya is exactly the same as that of Harijan.
('83', 75, 1, 7, 146966) But in Sarvodaya the policy advocated in Harijan is discussed theoretically and objectively.
('83', 75, 1, 8, 147059) However, it is not obligatory on the part of the editors of Sarvodaya to follow the policy of Harijan.
('83', 75, 1, 9, 147162) They propagate it as far as they agree with it.

('83', 76, 6, 11, 148388) 93. QUESTION BOX
('83', 76, 7, 12, 148405) THE CONFLAGRATION
('83', 76, 8, 13, 148423) Q. What is the difference between Nero and yourself?
('83', 76, 8, 14, 148476) Nero was fiddling when Rome was burning.
('83', 76, 8, 15, 148517) Will you be also fiddling in Sevagram after you have ignited the fire which you will not be able to quench?
('83', 76, 9, 16, 148625) A. The difference will be known if match, if I have ever to light it, does not prove a ‘damp squib’.
('83', 76, 9, 17, 148726) Instead of fiddling in Sevagram you may expect to find me perishing in the flames of my own starting if I cannot regulate or restrain them.
('83', 76, 9, 18, 148866) But I have a grouse against you.
('83', 76, 9, 19, 148899) Why should you shove all the blame on to me for all that may happen by reason of my taking action for the discharge of an overdue debt and that, too, just when the discharge has become the necessary condition of my life?
('83', 76, 9, 20, 149120) In their schools the rulers teach us to sing “Britons never shall be slaves.” How can the refrain enthuse their slaves?
('83', 76, 9, 21, 149240) The British are pouring blood like water and squandering gold like dust in order to preserve their liberty.
('83', 76, 9, 22, 149348) Or, is it their right to enslave India and Africa?
('83', 76, 9, 23, 149399) Why should Indians do less to free themselves from bondage?
('83', 76, 9, 24, 149459) It is misuse of language to liken to the action of Nero that of a man who, in order to escape living death, lights his own funeral pyre to end the agony.
('83', 76, 10, 25, 149613) 1Vide “Question Box”, 3 7 1942.
('83', 77, 0, 1, 149645) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 77, 1, 2, 149686) ANDHRA SEPARATION
('83', 77, 2, 3, 149704) Q. You have, no doubt unintentionally, rather adversely affected Maharaj Kumar Sir Vijaya Anand’s popularity in Andhra by your ridiculing a part of Sir Vijaya’s letter on Andhra separation; 1 and do you regard Andhra separation in the same light as Pakistan, as some people in Andhra fear you do?
('83', 77, 3, 4, 150001) A. You are right in saying that I ridiculed Sir Vijaya’s letter.
('83', 77, 3, 5, 150066) I could take that liberty with him.
('83', 77, 3, 6, 150102) But nothing could be further from my thought than to discredit him in any way.
('83', 77, 3, 7, 150181) What reflection there was was meant for his informants.
('83', 77, 3, 8, 150237) As his letter showed, he had given me the impressions of his informants.
('83', 77, 3, 9, 150310) Every one of us is liable to be misled by our informants.
('83', 77, 3, 10, 150368) He is among the very few zamindars who have taken up the popular cause.
('83', 77, 3, 11, 150440) It will be a pity if the Andhras, by putting a wrong construction on my letter to him, fail to avail themselves of his services.
('83', 77, 3, 12, 150569) As to the second question, there can be no comparison between Pakistan and Andhra separation.
('83', 77, 3, 13, 150663) The Andhra separation is a redistribution on a linguistic basis.
('83', 77, 3, 14, 150728) The Andhras do not claim to be a separate nation having nothing in common with the rest of India.
('83', 77, 3, 15, 150826) Pakistan on the other hand is a demand for carving out of India a portion to be treated as a wholly independent sovereign State.
('83', 77, 3, 16, 150955) Thus there seems to be nothing common between the two.
('83', 77, 4, 17, 151010) SEVAGRAM, July 5, 1942
('83', 77, 5, 18, 151033) Harijan, 12 7 1942

('83', 80, 4, 16, 157608) 96. A. I. S. A. AND KINDRED INSTITUTIONS 1
('83', 80, 5, 17, 157651) The question of the connection with present politics of the members and the staff of the A.I.S.A., A. I. V. I. A., the Hindustani Talimi Sangh and the kindred institutions was raised at the recent meeting of the A. I. S. A. held in Wardha and is being raised by numerous correspondents.
('83', 80, 5, 18, 157938) It is better therefore for me to give my opinion in sufficient detail for the guidance of the persons concerned.
('83', 80, 5, 19, 158051) These institutions, though some are creations of the Congress, are wholly autonomous and unconnected with Congress or other politics.
('83', 80, 5, 20, 158185) Their mission is humanitarian, social, educational, economic or all combined.
('83', 80, 5, 21, 158263) Their work is wholly constructive and creative.
('83', 80, 5, 22, 158311) But it is true that most men and women in charge of them are Congressmen or Congress minded, though they are open to all.
('83', 80, 5, 23, 158433) There are cases of men unconnected with the Congress being found actively engaged in working or aiding them.
('83', 80, 5, 24, 158542) These institutions must not lose this non political character of theirs, if they are to retain their prestige, usefulness, and efficiency such as it is.
('83', 80, 5, 25, 158695) This is simple enough.
('83', 80, 5, 26, 158718) But the question raised is complicated.
('83', 80, 5, 27, 158758) It is clear that the members and the staff may not take part in any civil
('83', 80, 6, 28, 158832) 1 This appeared under the heading “Notes”.
('83', 81, 0, 1, 158875) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 81, 1, 2, 158916) resistance movement and be still connected with these organizations.
('83', 81, 1, 3, 158985) But what are they to do if they see a civil resister belaboured or a general lathi charge takes place in front of them?
('83', 81, 1, 4, 159105) I say unhesitatingly that the workers in these institutions are bound to render such aid as they can at the moment without considering the consequences.
('83', 81, 1, 5, 159258) This intervention is itself pure humanitarian work.
('83', 81, 1, 6, 159310) Persons engaged in these institutions must not be cowards nor may their work be used as a halter round their necks making them useless for service.
('83', 81, 1, 7, 159458) It is this fear of losing one’s job or risking the safety of one’s organization that has played a large part in hindering our march to freedom.
('83', 81, 1, 8, 159602) During the previous struggles all the most scrupulous care to avoid even the remotest suspicion of participation in politics did not save the men and these organizations from the attention of the authorities.
('83', 81, 1, 9, 159811) Therefore the golden rule is to dare to do the right at any cost.
('83', 81, 1, 10, 159877) But there should be no camouflage, no secrecy, no make believe.
('83', 81, 1, 11, 159941) Those who feel the urge to take part in the coming movement must resign before joining it.
('83', 81, 1, 12, 160032) In all other respects the organizations should run their even course.
('83', 81, 1, 13, 160102) Every moment they are building the temple of liberty and when it is won they will all be required as specialists for the numerous nation building activities.
('83', 81, 1, 14, 160260) Let them therefore diligently add to their knowledge and usefulness.
('83', 81, 1, 15, 160329) During all these twenty two years the true workers have proved their worth, they are responsible for creating and distributing lacs worth of material and lacs of rupees among lacs of poor men and women who, but for the work provided, would have lived in a state of semi starvation.

('83', 85, 6, 16, 165825) 105. DRAFT RESOLUTION FOR THE CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE 1
('83', 85, 7, 17, 165884) July 9, 1942
('83', 85, 8, 18, 165897) Events happening from day to day and the experience that the people of India are passing through confirm the opinion of the Congressmen that British rule must end immediately, not merely because foreign domination, even at its best, is an evil in itself, but because India in bondage can play no effective part in affecting the fortunes of the war that is desolating men and their possessions; that is to say not merely in the interests of India, but for the safety of the world and for the destruction of Nazism, Fascism and whatever other ‘ism’ Japan stands for.
('83', 85, 8, 19, 166462) Ever since the outbreak of the war the Congress has studiedly pursued the policy of non embarrassment.
('83', 85, 8, 20, 166565) Even at the risk of making its satyagraha ineffective it deliberately
('83', 85, 9, 21, 166635) 1 This is the earliest available revised version of the resolution, finally passed by the Congress Working Committee on July 14 (various other intermediate versions of the Resolution are to be found in the Selected Works of Jawaharlal Nehru).
('83', 85, 9, 22, 166878) The original draft was by Gandhiji.
('83', 85, 9, 23, 166914) To Nehru Gandhiji says: “I have read the resolution.
('83', 85, 9, 24, 166967) I note that you have tried to include some of my points” (p.
('83', 85, 9, 25, 167028) In a Press interview he says: “ .
('83', 85, 9, 26, 167062) the Working Committee has worked on my draft .
('83', 85, 9, 27, 167109) the Working Committee tried to accommodate me as much as they could .
('83', 85, 9, 28, 167179) To Amrit Kaur again, he writes: “The resolution is my draft.
('83', 85, 9, 29, 167240) Changes have been made for J. L.’s satisfaction, and of course Maulana’s”, p.
('83', 85, 9, 30, 167318) 306. For the text, vide Appendix “Resolutions Passed by Congress Working Committee”, 14 7 1942.
('83', 86, 0, 1, 167414) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 87
('83', 86, 1, 2, 167457) gave it a symbolic character, in the hope that this policy of non embarrassment carried to its extreme limit would be duly appreciated, and that enough real power would be transferred to the popular representatives so as to enable the nation to make its fullest contribution towards the realization of human freedom throughout the world, which is in danger of being crushed.
('83', 86, 1, 3, 167832) It had also hoped that negatively nothing would be done which was calculated to tighten Britain’s stranglehold on India.
('83', 86, 1, 4, 167953) These hopes have however been dashed to pieces.
('83', 86, 1, 5, 168001) The abortive Cripps proposals showed in the clearest possible manner that there was no change in the British attitude towards India and that the British hold on India was in no way to be relaxed.
('83', 86, 1, 6, 168197) It has also been observed that the ill will against the British is rapidly increasing and people openly wish success to the Japanese arms.
('83', 86, 1, 7, 168336) The Congress would like to avoid the experience of Singapore, Malaya and Burma and turn ill will into goodwill and make India a willing partner in their trial and troubles.
('83', 86, 1, 8, 168509) This is possible only if India feels the glow of freedom from foreign domination.
('83', 86, 1, 9, 168591) The Congress is convinced that the only cure for this intolerable state of affairs is that the British rule in India should end forthwith.
('83', 86, 1, 10, 168730) The Congress representatives tried their utmost to come to a settlement.
('83', 86, 1, 11, 168803) But this has been made impossible by reason of the presence of the foreign power whose history has been to follow relentlessly the policy of divide and rule.
('83', 86, 1, 12, 168961) Only after withdrawal of the British power can the wise men and women of the country put their heads together and evolve a scheme whereby a Constituent Assembly can be convened in order to prepare a constitution for the Government of India.
('83', 86, 1, 13, 169202) When the British power is withdrawn the present unreality will give place to reality and the prince and the peasant will stand on a par, the present political parties formed chiefly with an eye to the attention of the British power will probably be dissolved.
('83', 86, 1, 14, 169462) For the first time in India’s history realization will come home that Princes, jagirdars, zamindars, propertied and monied classes derive their wealth and property from the workers in the fields or factories to whom alone all power and authority must belong.
('83', 86, 1, 15, 169721) In making the proposal for withdrawal the Congress has no desire whatsoever to embarrass Great Britain or the Allied powers in their prosecution of the War.
('83', 86, 1, 16, 169878) The proposed withdrawal therefore should not in any way be interpreted as an invitation to Japan or the other members of the Axis to attack India and thus immediately to suffocate China.
('83', 86, 1, 17, 170065) Nor does the Congress intend to jeopardize the defensive capacity of the Allied
('83', 87, 0, 1, 170145) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 87, 1, 2, 170186) powers.
('83', 87, 1, 3, 170194) Therefore the Congress would he reconciled, if the Allies regard it to be necessary, to the presence at their own expense of their troops in India in order to ward off Japanese or other aggression and to protect and help China.
('83', 87, 1, 4, 170422) The proposal of withdrawal was never intended to mean the physical withdrawal of all Britishers from India, certainly not of those who would make India their home and live there as citizens and as equals with the others.
('83', 87, 1, 5, 170643) If the withdrawal takes place with goodwill, it is highly likely that there would be little difficulty in establishing a stable provisional government in India.
('83', 87, 1, 6, 170804) The Congress however is not unmindful of the possibility of a temporary breakdown of the ordered machinery of government.
('83', 87, 1, 7, 170926) Anarchy may set in and instead of different parties coming together for the common good they may compete with one another in establishing their own authority.
('83', 87, 1, 8, 171085) It is a risk which has got to be run in any country in order to achieve freedom.
('83', 87, 1, 9, 171166) The Congress therefore wishes to take no hasty step but would bespeak the help of the Allies in securing British acceptance of its demand.
('83', 87, 1, 10, 171305) Should however the appeal fail, the Congress will be reluctantly compelled to utilize all the non violent strength it might have gathered since 1920 when it adopted non violence as part of its policy for the vindication of political lights and liberty.
('83', 87, 1, 11, 171558) The struggle this time would have to resolve itself into a mass movement on the widest scale possible involving voluntary strikes, voluntary non co operation on the part of all those who are in Government employ or in departments connected with Government in any shape or form and it may involve also non payment of land revenue and taxes.
('83', 87, 1, 12, 171898) For the regulation and quick development of the mass movement the Working Committee authorize Gandhiji to take charge of it and regulate it in the manner he may think advisable.
('83', 87, 1, 13, 172076) In order that adequate time may be given to the Allied powers to consider and respond to the Congress appeal, as also to educate public opinion and to let the A.I.C.C. share the responsibility with the Working Committee for the tremendous step contemplated, the Committee fixes .
('83', 87, 1, 14, 172356) .for the meeting of the A. 1. C. C at.
('83', 87, 1, 15, 172395) .until which time the resolution should remain suspended.
