('83', 88, 1, 2, 172607) 106. CONGRESS AND WAR CONTRACTS 1
('83', 88, 2, 3, 172641) Q. Is it proper for Congressmen, especially members of Congress committees, to accept war contracts?
('83', 88, 3, 4, 172742) A. This question should be properly addressed to the Working Committee.
('83', 88, 3, 5, 172814) Personally however I think that Congressmen cannot accept war contracts.
('83', 88, 4, 6, 172887) SEVAGRAM, July 10, 1942
('83', 88, 5, 7, 172911) Harijan, 19 7 1942
('83', 88, 6, 8, 172930) 107. QUESTION BOX
('83', 88, 7, 9, 172948) HONOURABLE MEANS OF DYING
('83', 88, 8, 10, 172974) Q. Will you please explain more fully your dictum that “a person who would die rather than go through inhuman tortures would find honourable means of dying”?
('83', 88, 8, 11, 173132) Do you endorse suicide in such cases?
('83', 88, 8, 12, 173170) Or do you suggest that mere intense will to die will result in death?
('83', 88, 9, 13, 173240) A. I would not rule out suicide in such cases as a means of escape from torture—not for the pain of it, but for showing the tyrant that his torture would not bend the suicide.
('83', 88, 9, 14, 173416) Tyrants have prevented suicide for the purpose of the pleasure tortures give them.
('83', 88, 9, 15, 173499) But I do not regard suicide as necessarily an honourable means of dying.
('83', 88, 9, 16, 173572) Of course, the most honourable means would be the intense longing to die, so intense as to induce death for the mere will.
('83', 88, 9, 17, 173695) But this is given to one in a billion.
('83', 88, 9, 18, 173734) What I had in mind when I wrote the paragraph was a variety of struggles of the prisoners with the warder in which resistance through non violence must end in death.
('83', 88, 9, 19, 173900) Thus supposing that A compels B to crawl on his belly, resistance can be carried to the breaking point.
('83', 88, 9, 20, 174004) Every form of such resistance unto death I would count as honourable.
('83', 88, 9, 21, 174074) This resistance can be offered by the weakest as well as the strongest—by the weakest perhaps more effectively, certainly more expeditiously.
('83', 88, 9, 22, 174216) The indispensable condition is the possession of a stout heart and an iron will.
('83', 88, 9, 23, 174297) I am not writing theory.
('83', 88, 9, 24, 174322) My opinion is based on personal experience and that of others who have been under my observation.
('83', 88, 9, 25, 174420) A very weak woman could not be bent under the cruel will of her imperious husband.
('83', 88, 9, 26, 174503) Youngsters frail in body have successfully defied the orders of hard schoolmasters or
('83', 88, 10, 27, 174589) 1 This appeared under the heading “Notes”.
('83', 89, 0, 1, 174632) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 89, 1, 2, 174673) heartless parents.
('83', 89, 1, 3, 174692) The crux of the question is whether there is real readiness, nay, will to die.
('83', 89, 1, 4, 174771) The will will most assuredly point the way.
('83', 89, 2, 5, 174815) INEFFECTIVE SYMPATHY
('83', 89, 3, 6, 174836) Q. Why should not the Congress declare that as long as India is herself in bondage, she can be neither a friend nor an enemy of any country?
('83', 89, 3, 7, 174977) What is the value of her sympathies with China, Russia, etc., when she has no freedom to assist them in her own way?
('83', 89, 3, 8, 175094) Has Russia thought of India?
('83', 89, 4, 9, 175123) A. You are right.
('83', 89, 4, 10, 175141) India’s sympathy can give no effective help as her enmity can do no harm to any person or nation so long as India is herself not free.
('83', 89, 4, 11, 175276) Nevertheless Pandit Jawaharlal with his international outlook and generosity has accustomed us to express our sympathy to nations in distress without expectation of like return.
('83', 89, 4, 12, 175454) We lose nothing by expressing sympathy even though we realize that it can cut no ice.
('83', 89, 4, 13, 175540) If Russia has no thought of India today, in the long run she is bound to recognize the utterly unselfish character of our sympathy.
('83', 89, 4, 14, 175672) It should not be forgotten that sympathy without ability to render effective help has its own moral value.
('83', 89, 4, 15, 175779) We receive with appreciation sympathy from those who we know are unable to render us effective help in our struggle.
('83', 89, 4, 16, 175896) Your question is itself an additional justification for our demand for the immediate withdrawal of the British power.
('83', 89, 4, 17, 176014) Having learnt to show sympathy to nations in distress the knowledge of our helples sness and the knowledge that if we are free we can render much effective help makes us or should make us specially anxious and oblige us to realize our ambition even during the war.
('83', 89, 5, 18, 176279) SEVAGRAM, July 10, 1942
('83', 89, 6, 19, 176303) Harijan, 26 7 1942
('83', 89, 7, 20, 176322) 108. INTERVIEW TO “THE DAILY EXPRESS” 1
('83', 89, 8, 21, 176362) [Before July 11, 1942]
('83', 89, 9, 22, 176385) Q. Would you say that your movement will make it more difficult or less difficult for us to keep the Japanese out of India?
('83', 89, 9, 23, 176509) A. Our movement will make it more difficult for the Japanese to come in.
('83', 89, 9, 24, 176582) But of course if there is no co operation from Britain and the Allies, I cannot say.
('83', 89, 10, 25, 176667) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Two Minutes’ Interview” dated 11 7 1942
('83', 90, 0, 1, 176741) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 91
('83', 90, 1, 2, 176784) Q. But think of the war as a whole.
('83', 90, 1, 3, 176820) Do you think that your new movement will help the Allied nations towards victory, which you have said you also desire?
('83', 90, 2, 4, 176939) A. Yes, if my submission is accepted.
('83', 90, 3, 5, 176977) Q. What do you mean by your submission—that Britain should offer non violent battle?
('83', 90, 4, 6, 177062) A. No, no.
('83', 90, 4, 7, 177073) My submission that British rule in India should end.
('83', 90, 4, 8, 177126) If that is accepted victory for the Allied powers is assured.
('83', 90, 4, 9, 177188) Then India will become an independent power, and thus a real ally, while now she is only a slave.
('83', 90, 4, 10, 177286) The result of my movement, if it is sympathetically responded to, is bound to be speedy victory.
('83', 90, 4, 11, 177383) But if it is misunderstood by the British and they take up the attitude that they would like to crush it, then they would be responsible for the result, not I.
('83', 90, 5, 12, 177543) Q. Mr. Gandhi, you have been in London yourself.
('83', 90, 5, 13, 177592) Have you no comment to make on the heavy bombings which the British people have sustained?
('83', 90, 6, 14, 177683) A. Oh yes.
('83', 90, 6, 15, 177694) I know every nook and corner of London where I lived for three years so many years ago, and somewhat of Oxford and Cambridge and Manchester too; but it is London I specially feel for.
('83', 90, 6, 16, 177878) I used to read in the Inner Temple Library, and would often attend Dr. Parker’s sermons in the Temple Church.
('83', 90, 6, 17, 177988) My heart goes out to the people, and when I heard that the Temple Church was bombed I bled.
('83', 90, 6, 18, 178080) And the bombing of the Westminster Abbey and other ancient edifices affected me deeply.
('83', 90, 7, 19, 178168) Q. Then don’t you think, it would be wiser to postpone your movement until we have settled with the Germans and the Japanese?
('83', 90, 8, 20, 178294) A. No, because I know you will not settle with the Germans without us.
('83', 90, 8, 21, 178365) If we were free, we could give you cent per cent co operation in our own manner.
('83', 90, 8, 22, 178446) It is curious that such a simple thing is not understood.
('83', 90, 8, 23, 178504) Britain has today no contribution from a free India.
('83', 90, 8, 24, 178557) Tomorrow as soon as India is free, she gains moral strength and a powerful ally in a free nation—powerful morally.
('83', 90, 8, 25, 178672) This raises England’s power to the nth degree.
('83', 90, 8, 26, 178719) This is surely self proved.
('83', 90, 9, 27, 178747) Harijan, 19 7 1942
('83', 90, 10, 28, 178766) 109. IF “HARIJAN” IS SUPPRESSED
('83', 90, 11, 29, 178798) Anxious inquiries are being made as to what I would do if Harijan was suppressed.
('83', 90, 11, 30, 178880) Rumours are afloat that orders are on their way.
('83', 90, 11, 31, 178929) I would ask inquirers not to be agitated if Harijan is suppressed.
('83', 90, 11, 32, 178996) The paper may be suppressed.
('83', 90, 11, 33, 179025) The manager has been instructed to
('83', 91, 0, 1, 179060) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 91, 1, 2, 179101) stop the paper immediately orders are served on him.
('83', 91, 1, 3, 179154) It is no part of the movement to publish Harijan in defiance of orders.
('83', 91, 1, 4, 179226) But Harijan may be suppressed, its message cannot be, so long as I live.
('83', 91, 1, 5, 179299) Indeed, the spirit will survive the dissolution of tile body and somehow speak through the millions.
('83', 91, 1, 6, 179400) For, with due apologies to Veer Savarkar and Quaid e Azam Jinnah, I claim to represent the joint spirit of millions of Hindus and Mussalmans, and other non Hindus who call themselves children of Hindustan.
('83', 91, 1, 7, 179606) I am living, and hope to have the strength to die, for the freedom of every inhabitant of this land.
('83', 91, 1, 8, 179707) Let us see what Harijan is today.
('83', 91, 1, 9, 179741) It is being published in English, Hindi, Urdu (2 places), Tamil, Telugu (2 places), Ooriya, Marathi, Gujarati, Kanaree (2 places).
('83', 91, 1, 10, 179872) It is ready to be published in Bengali, only awaiting legal permission.
('83', 91, 1, 11, 179944) Applications have come from Assam, Kerala and Sind.
('83', 91, 1, 12, 179996) All but the one edition have a large circulation compared to the other weeklies.
('83', 91, 1, 13, 180077) I suggest that it is no small matter to suppress such a paper.
('83', 91, 1, 14, 180140) The loss will be more Government’s than the people’s.
('83', 91, 1, 15, 180194) They will incur much ill will by suppressing a popular paper.
('83', 91, 1, 16, 180256) Let it be known too that Harijan is a views paper as disting uished from a newspaper.
('83', 91, 1, 17, 180342) People buy and read it not for amusement but instruction and regulating their daily conduct.
('83', 91, 1, 18, 180435) They literally take their weekly lessons in non violence.
('83', 91, 1, 19, 180493) It cannot pay the authorities to deprive the people of their weekly food.
('83', 91, 1, 20, 180567) And Harijan is not an anti British paper.
('83', 91, 1, 21, 180609) It is pro British from head to foot.
('83', 91, 1, 22, 180646) It wishes well to the British people.
('83', 91, 1, 23, 180684) It tells them in the friendliest manner where in its opinion they err.
('83', 91, 1, 24, 180755) The Anglo Indian papers I know are Government favourites.
('83', 91, 1, 25, 180813) They represent a dying Imperialism.
('83', 91, 1, 26, 180849) Whether Britain wins or loses, Imperialism has to die.
('83', 91, 1, 27, 180904) It is certainly of no use now to the British people whatever it may have been in the past.
('83', 91, 1, 28, 180995) In that sense therefore Anglo Indian papers are really anti British as Harijan is pro British.
('83', 91, 1, 29, 181090) The former are disseminating hatred day by day by hiding the reality and bolstering Imperialism which is ruining Britain.
('83', 91, 1, 30, 181212) It is in order to arrest the progress of that ruin that, frail as I am, I have put my whole soul into a movement which, if it is designed to free India from the imperial yoke, is equally intended to contribute the mightiest war effort in their behalf.
('83', 91, 1, 31, 181464) If they suppress Harijan let them know what they will seek to suppress.
('83', 91, 1, 32, 181536) Let me add too that without needing any pressure from outside,
('83', 92, 0, 1, 181599) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 93
('83', 92, 1, 2, 181642) I am using the greatest restraint in the choice of printing matter.
('83', 92, 1, 3, 181710) Nothing is being consciously published that would give any clue to the ‘enemy’ as to military objectives or dispositions.
('83', 92, 1, 4, 181832) Care is being exercised to avoid all exaggeration or sensational matter.
('83', 92, 1, 5, 181905) Adjectives and adverbs are well weighed before being used.
('83', 92, 1, 6, 181964) And they know that I am ever ready to acknowledge errors and mend them.

('83', 92, 4, 9, 182081) 110. NOTES
('83', 92, 5, 10, 182092) IN CASE OF ILLNESS
('83', 92, 6, 11, 182111) Someone tells me that B.B.C. have been asking how I can hope to lead the impending non violent movement if I am ill and bed ridden.
('83', 92, 6, 12, 182243) Well, the doctors have not pronounced me such.
('83', 92, 6, 13, 182290) I am fatigued and they advise rest and a change to a cooler place for a fortnight.
('83', 92, 6, 14, 182373) I am struggling to give myself rest.
('83', 92, 6, 15, 182410) But sometimes duty, maybe passion or infatuation, forbids it.
('83', 92, 6, 16, 182472) But the relevant fact is that so long as the reason is unimpaired, physical illness is no bar to the conduct of a non violent struggle.
('83', 92, 6, 17, 182608) The peremptory belief in non violent conduct is that all urge comes from God—the Unseen, even Unfelt save through unconquerable faith.
('83', 92, 6, 18, 182743) Nevertheless as a seeker and experimenter I know that even physical illness, even fatigue, is counted as a defect in a non violent person.
('83', 92, 6, 19, 182882) Mens sana in corpore sano is literally accepted by votaries of truth and non violence.
('83', 92, 6, 20, 182969) But that is said of perfect men.
('83', 92, 6, 21, 183002) Alas I am far from the perfection I am aiming at.
('83', 92, 7, 22, 183052) TIMELY ACTION
('83', 92, 8, 23, 183066) Numerous inquiries have been made as to what should be done by evacuees and others who find it difficult and even impossible to comply with orders.
('83', 92, 8, 24, 183214) The comprehensive instructions of the Working Committee in the matter are quite timely.
('83', 92, 8, 25, 183302) The persons affected should know that these instructions are no part of the impending movement.
('83', 92, 8, 26, 183398) They are necessary in every case for the very existence of the persons affected.
('83', 92, 8, 27, 183479) Therefore, as the Working Committee very properly say, every precaution should be taken for obtaining relief through negotiation.
('83', 92, 8, 28, 183609) Disregard of orders should be resorted to only when it
('83', 93, 0, 1, 183664) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 93, 1, 2, 183705) becomes peremptory.
('83', 93, 1, 3, 183725) Needless to say there is no room here for profiteering or exorbitant demand.

('83', 93, 4, 6, 183845) 111. PERTINENT QUESTIONS
('83', 93, 5, 7, 183870) 1. If non violent activity is neutralized by and cannot go along with armed violence in the same area, will there remain any scope for non violent resistance to aggression in the event of India allowing foreign troops to remain on her soil and operate from here?
('83', 93, 5, 8, 184133) 2. If the maintenance of India’s freedom is allowed to be made dependent upon arms which, in the existing circumstances, will be led and controlled by Britain and America, can there be a feeling of real freedom experienced by the people of India, at any rate during the duration of the war?
('83', 93, 5, 9, 184424) 3. Whatever may be the terms of the ‘treaty’, if the Anglo American military machine is allowed to operate for the ‘defence’ of India, can Indians play any but a minor and subordinate role in the defence of this country?
('83', 93, 5, 10, 184645) 4. Supposing the British, not from any moral motive but only to gain a political and strategical advantage for the time being, agree to a ‘treaty’ under which they are allowed to maintain and increase their military forces in India, how can they be dislodged afterwards if they prefer to remain in possession?
('83', 93, 5, 11, 184955) 5. Is not the position postulated in the preceding question comparable to the position that would arise if, for instance, Subhas Babu made a treaty with Germany and Japan under which India would be declared ‘independent’ and the Axis forces would enter India to drive the British out?
('83', 93, 5, 12, 185240) 6. If the Congress, as Maulana Saheb has just stated, ‘considers defence as armed defence only’, is there any prospect of real independence for India, in view of the fact that India simply has not got the resources ‘independently’ to offer effective armed resistance to a formidable aggressor?
('83', 93, 5, 13, 185534) If we are to think in terms of armed defence only, can India, to mention only one thing, expect to remain independent with her 4,000 miles of coastline and no navy and ship building industry?
('83', 93, 5, 14, 185726) 7. What material aid could India send to China today, even if she
('83', 94, 0, 1, 185792) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 95
('83', 94, 1, 2, 185835) were declared ‘independent’ by the British?
('83', 94, 2, 3, 185879) A. (1) The flaw pointed out in the first question cannot be denied.
('83', 94, 2, 4, 185947) I have admitted it before now.
('83', 94, 2, 5, 185978) The tolerance of Allied troops by free India is an admission of the nation’s limitations.
('83', 94, 2, 6, 186068) The nation as a whole has never been and never been claimed to be non violent.
('83', 94, 2, 7, 186147) What part is cannot be said with any accuracy.
('83', 94, 2, 8, 186194) And what is decisive is that India has not yet demonstrated non violence of the strong such as would be required to withstand a powerful army of invasion.
('83', 94, 2, 9, 186349) If we had developed that strength we would have acquired our freedom long ago and there would be no question of any troops being stationed in India.
('83', 94, 2, 10, 186498) The novelty of the demand should not be missed.
('83', 94, 2, 11, 186546) It is a demand not for a transference of power from Great Britain to a free India.
('83', 94, 2, 12, 186629) For there is no party to which Britain would transfer such power.
('83', 94, 2, 13, 186695) We lack the unity that gives strength.
('83', 94, 2, 14, 186734) The demand therefore is not based on our demonstrable strength.
('83', 94, 2, 15, 186798) It is a demand made upon Britain to do the right irrespective of the capacity of the party wronged to bear the consequences of Britain’s right act.
('83', 94, 2, 16, 186946) Will Britain restore seized property to the victim merely because the seizure was wrong?
('83', 94, 2, 17, 187035) It is none of her concern to weigh whether the victim will be able to hold possession of the restored property.
('83', 94, 2, 18, 187147) Hence it is that I have been obliged to make use of the word anarchy in this connection.
('83', 94, 2, 19, 187236) This great moral act must give Britain moral status which should ensure victory.
('83', 94, 2, 20, 187317) Whether without India Britain would have any reason to fight is a question I need not consider.
('83', 94, 2, 21, 187413) If India is the stake and not British honour we should know.
('83', 94, 2, 22, 187474) My demand then loses force but not justness.
('83', 94, 2, 23, 187519) Such being the case my honesty and honour require me to provide for the flaw.
('83', 94, 2, 24, 187597) If to ask for the withdrawal of the Allied forces means their certain defeat, my demand must be ruled out as dishonest.
('83', 94, 2, 25, 187717) Force of circumstances has given rise to the demand and also to its limitations.
('83', 94, 2, 26, 187798) It must be admitted therefore that there will be little scope for non violent resistance of aggression, with the Allied troops operating in India, as there is practically none now.
('83', 94, 2, 27, 187979) For the troops are there today enjoying fill I mastery over us.
('83', 94, 2, 28, 188043) Under my demand they will operate under the nation’s terms.
('83', 94, 2, 29, 188103) 2. If Britain’s declaration is honest I see no reason why the presence of the troops should, in any shape or form, affect the feeling of real freedom.
('83', 94, 2, 30, 188254) Did the French feel differently when during the last war the English troops were operating in France?
('83', 94, 2, 31, 188356) When my master of yesterday becomes my equal and lives in my house on my
('83', 95, 0, 1, 188429) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 95, 1, 2, 188470) terms, surely his presence cannot detract from my freedom.
('83', 95, 1, 3, 188529) Nay, I may profit by his presence which I have permitted.
('83', 95, 1, 4, 188587) 3. The conception in my scheme is that we do not want these troops for our defence or protection.
('83', 95, 1, 5, 188685) If they left these shores we expect to manage somehow.
('83', 95, 1, 6, 188740) We may put up non violent defence.
('83', 95, 1, 7, 188775) If luck favours us, the Japanese may see no reason to hold the country after the Allies have withdrawn, if they discover that they are not wanted.
('83', 95, 1, 8, 188922) It is all speculation as to what can happen after withdrawal, voluntary and orderly or forced.
('83', 95, 1, 9, 189017) 4. We assume their or rather British honesty.
('83', 95, 1, 10, 189063) It would be not a matter of dislodging them, it is one of their fulfilling their plighted word.
('83', 95, 1, 11, 189159) If they commit breach of faith, we must have strength enough, non violent or violent, to enforce fulfilment.
('83', 95, 1, 12, 189268) 5. Surely there is as much difference between the South Pole and the North as there is between the imagined conditions.
('83', 95, 1, 13, 189388) My demand deals with the possessor; Subhas Babu will bring German troops to oust the possessor.
('83', 95, 1, 14, 189484) Germany is under no obligation to deliver India from bondage.
('83', 95, 1, 15, 189546) Therefore Subhas Babu’s performance can only fling India from the frying pan into the fire.
('83', 95, 1, 16, 189638) I hope the distinction is clear.
('83', 95, 1, 17, 189671) 6. Maulana Saheb, it is well known, does not hold my view that any country can defend itself without force of arms.
('83', 95, 1, 18, 189787) My demand is based on the view that it is possible to defend one’s country non violently.
('83', 95, 1, 19, 189877) 7. India at present gives such indifferent and ill conceived aid as the Allies think desirable.
('83', 95, 1, 20, 189973) Free India can send men and material that China may need.
('83', 95, 1, 21, 190031) India has affinities with China being part of Asia which the Allies cannot possibly possess and exploit.
('83', 95, 1, 22, 190136) Who knows that free India may not even succeed in persuading Japan to do the right by China?

('83', 98, 2, 3, 193392) July 14, 1942
('83', 98, 3, 4, 193406) To a question whether the Working Committee’s resolution met with his approval, Gandhiji said: It is difficult for me to answer the question.
('83', 98, 3, 5, 193548) When you are working in a committee you can’t have it all your own way.
('83', 98, 3, 6, 193620) Therefore, you have to compromise.
('83', 98, 3, 7, 193655) All this has happened in the Committee.
('83', 98, 3, 8, 193695) If I were an autocrat, undoubtedly the resolution would have been perhaps in somewhat different language.
('83', 98, 3, 9, 193801) As a matter of fact, the Working Committee has worked on my draft and I must say, too, that the Committee has been most considerate.
('83', 98, 3, 10, 193934) It was not humanly possible for people, however they may be alike in thought, to agree to the same language.
('83', 98, 3, 11, 194043) Here the Working Committee tried to accommodate me as much as they could and therefore, I must be entirely satisfied.
('83', 98, 4, 12, 194161) Q. Is it possible for you to tell us the things you might do after the All India Congress Committee meets and adopts the W. C. resolution?
('83', 98, 5, 13, 194300) A. Is not that question a little premature?
('83', 98, 5, 14, 194344) Supposing the A. I. C. C. vetoes the resolution, the whole things wears a different aspect.
('83', 98, 5, 15, 194436) But you may know that it will be a mass movement of a strictly non violent character and then you can fill in the details.
('83', 98, 5, 16, 194559) It will include all that a mass movement can include.
('83', 98, 6, 17, 194613) Q. Will you include closing of liquor shops and foreign cloth shops?
('83', 98, 7, 18, 194682) A. It will depend on the circumstances.
('83', 98, 7, 19, 194722) I don’t want rioting as a direct result.
('83', 98, 7, 20, 194763) If in spite of all precautions rioting does take place, it cannot be helped.
('83', 98, 8, 21, 194840) Q. Will you court imprisonment?
('83', 98, 9, 22, 194872) A. I am not going to court imprisonment.
('83', 98, 9, 23, 194913) The struggle does not involve courting imprisonment.
('83', 98, 9, 24, 194966) It is too soft a thing.
('83', 98, 9, 25, 194990) We had, no doubt, made it a business to court imprisonment up to now, but there will be no such thing this time.
('83', 98, 9, 26, 195103) My intention is to make the thing as short and swift as possible.
('83', 98, 10, 27, 195169) Q. Will you resort to fasting if sent to jail?
('83', 98, 11, 28, 195216) A. It is not my desire this time, as I have said, to court
('83', 98, 12, 29, 195275) 1 Mahadev Desai’s report of the interview published in Harijan under the heading “The Wardha Interview” has been collated with the report published in The Hindu.
('83', 98, 12, 30, 195437) 2 This question and answer have been taken from The Hindu.
('83', 99, 0, 1, 195496) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 99, 1, 2, 195538) imprisonment.
('83', 99, 1, 3, 195552) But if I am dragged into jail, it is difficult to say what I may do.
('83', 99, 1, 4, 195621) But I can fast, as I have fasted before now, though I should try to avoid such an extreme step so far as possible.
('83', 99, 2, 5, 195736) Q. Do you hope that negotiations may be opened by the British Government?
('83', 99, 3, 6, 195810) A. They may, but with whom they will do it I do not know.
('83', 99, 3, 7, 195868) For it is not a question of placating one party or another.
('83', 99, 3, 8, 195928) For it is the unconditional withdrawal of the British Power without reference to the wishes of any party that is our demand.
('83', 99, 3, 9, 196053) The demand is therefore based on its justice.
('83', 99, 3, 10, 196099) Of course it is possible that the British may negotiate a withdrawal.
('83', 99, 3, 11, 196169) If they do, it will be a feather in their cap.
('83', 99, 3, 12, 196216) Then it will cease to be a case for withdrawal.
('83', 99, 3, 13, 196264) If the British see, however, late, the wisdom of recognizing the independence of India, without reference to the various parties, all things are possible.
('83', 99, 3, 14, 196419) But the point I want to stress is this, viz., that there is no room left for negotiations in the proposal for withdrawal.
('83', 99, 3, 15, 196541) Either they recognize independence or they don’t.
('83', 99, 3, 16, 196591) After that recognition many things can follow.
('83', 99, 3, 17, 196638) For by that one single act the British representatives will have altered the face of the whole landscape and revived the hope of the people which has been frustrated times without number.
('83', 99, 3, 18, 196826) Therefore whenever that great act is performed, on behalf of the British people, it will be a red letter day in the history of India and the world.
('83', 99, 3, 19, 196974) And, as I have said, it can materially affect the fortunes of war.
('83', 99, 4, 20, 197041) Q. After the recognition of free India it starts to function at once?
('83', 99, 5, 21, 197111) A. Yes, from the very next moment.
('83', 99, 5, 22, 197146) For independence will not be on paper, but in action.
('83', 99, 5, 23, 197200) But your next legitimate question would be— ‘How will free India function?’ And because there was that knot, I said ‘Leave India to God or anarchy’.
('83', 99, 5, 24, 197349) But in practice what will happen is this—if withdrawal takes place in perfect goodwill, the change will be effected without the slightest disturbance.
('83', 99, 5, 25, 197500) People would have to come to their own without disturbance.
('83', 99, 5, 26, 197560) Wise people from among the responsible sections will come together and will evolve a Provisional Government.
('83', 99, 5, 27, 197669) Then there will be no anarchy, no interruption, and a crowning glory.
('83', 99, 6, 28, 197739) Q. Can you visualize the composition of the Provisional Government?
('83', 99, 7, 29, 197807) A. I do not need to do so.
('83', 99, 7, 30, 197834) But I am clear that it won’t be a party government.
('83', 99, 7, 31, 197886) All parties—including the Congress— will automatically dissolve.
('83', 99, 7, 32, 197951) Of course other parties may come into being afterwards.
('83', 99, 8, 33, 198007) 1 This sentence is from The Hindu.

('83', 100, 1, 2, 198086) They may function later and when they do they may function complementary to one another, each looking to the other in order to grow.
('83', 100, 1, 3, 198219) No party can grow at the expense of another.
('83', 100, 1, 4, 198264) 1 Then, as I have said, all unreality disappears like mist before the morning sun—we don’t know how, though we witness the phenomenon every day.
('83', 100, 2, 5, 198409) Q. But looking to all their past record will the British have the sense to come to terms?
('83', 100, 3, 6, 198499) A. Why not?
('83', 100, 3, 7, 198511) They are human beings and I have never discounted the possibility of human nature’s upward growth, and no other nation had ever had to face a freedom movement based not principally but wholly on non violence.
('83', 100, 4, 8, 198720) Q. But there is an apparent contradiction in your resolution.
('83', 100, 4, 9, 198782) The first paragraphs recount the fact that there is no intention on the part of the British to part with power.
('83', 100, 4, 10, 198894) Then suddenly you postulate such a desire on their part!
('83', 100, 5, 11, 198951) A. There is nothing inconsistent.
('83', 100, 5, 12, 198985) The facts are narrated in order to justify the suddenness of the demand for withdrawal.
('83', 100, 5, 13, 199073) The other paragraphs refer to possibilities.
('83', 100, 5, 14, 199118) Many things may happen and they may be altogether creditable to the British.
('83', 100, 6, 15, 199195) Q. May not your movement hamper the efforts of the Allies in China?
('83', 100, 7, 16, 199263) A. No, since the movement is intended to make common cause with the Allies, it should not hamper the Allied effort.
('83', 100, 8, 17, 199379) Q. But if there is no withdrawal, then disturbances are bound to happen?
('83', 100, 9, 18, 199452) A. You see ill will is already there.
('83', 100, 9, 19, 199490) It will grow apace.
('83', 100, 9, 20, 199510) Immediately the movement is started, the ill will may be changed into goodwill if the British people respond.
('83', 100, 9, 21, 199620) But even if they don’t respond, when people make an effort to free themselves from a foreign yoke, ill will needs no other opening.
('83', 100, 9, 22, 199752) It takes a healthy turn instead of the bad turn that it has today.
('83', 100, 10, 23, 199819) Asked if this was the last chance that was being given to the British Government, Gandhiji said: This is open rebellion of a non violent character.
('83', 100, 10, 24, 199967) There is no question of last chance.
('83', 100, 11, 25, 200004) Q. But only last week Mr. Amery reminded us that nothing is going to be done?
('83', 100, 12, 26, 200082) A. I am very much afraid that we shall have the misfortune to listen to a repetition of that language in stronger terms if possible.
('83', 100, 13, 27, 200215) 1 This sentence is from The Hindu.
('83', 100, 13, 28, 200250) 2 This paragraph has been taken from The Hindu.

('83', 101, 2, 3, 200422) Q. You desire to have India’s freedom in order to help the Allies.
('83', 101, 2, 4, 200489) Will free India

('83', 102, 1, 2, 201633) 117. INTERVIEW TO FOREIGN CORRESPONDENTS 1
('83', 102, 2, 3, 201676) WARDHA, [July 15, 1942] 2
('83', 102, 3, 4, 201702) STUART EMENY: Could you give me an idea of the plans of your movement?
('83', 102, 3, 5, 201773) Would it include breach of the Salt Laws, calling out Government servants and labour?
('83', 102, 4, 6, 201859) GANDHIJI: As I said yesterday the programme covers every activity of a strictly non violent character included in a mass movement.
('83', 102, 4, 7, 201990) Therefore undoubtedly the things you have mentioned are included.
('83', 102, 4, 8, 202056) But it is not my intention to undertake at once any overwhelming programme.
('83', 102, 4, 9, 202132) I want to watch and see, because whatever may be said to the contrary, even in conducting the movement I want to guard against a sudden outburst of anarchy or a state of things which may be calculated to invite Japanese aggression.
('83', 102, 4, 10, 202364) I believe that India’s demand is fundamental, it is indispensable for national existence as I conceive it to be.
('83', 102, 4, 11, 202477) Therefore I shall take every precaution I can to handle the movement gently, but I would not hesitate to go to the extremest limit, if I find that no impression is produced on the British Government or the Allied Powers.
('83', 102, 4, 12, 202698) I hold it to be legitimate to make the Allied Powers responsible for all that may happen in India, because it is open to them in the interests of the common cause to prevent the happening of anything that might disturb the even course of the war.
('83', 102, 4, 13, 202945) I think I have sufficiently answered your very pertinent question.
('83', 102, 4, 14, 203012) I am unable to give you a more detailed answer, not because I want to suppress or shirk it, but I am not ready with a planned programme as yet.
('83', 102, 5, 15, 203156) E. It will be your biggest movement?
('83', 102, 6, 16, 203193) G. Yes, my biggest movement.
('83', 102, 7, 17, 203222) E. But if there is no response, what time limit would you set before launching your campaign?
('83', 102, 8, 18, 203316) G. Assuming that the A. I. C. C. confirms the resolution there will be some time—but not very long—taken.
('83', 102, 8, 19, 203422) As far as I can see just

('83', 103, 3, 4, 203926) G. Of course—as I have always done before launching on every struggle.

('83', 103, 5, 6, 204072) G. Oh yes.

('83', 103, 9, 11, 204453) G. This struggle has been conceived in order to avert a catastrophe.

('83', 103, 9, 18, 205190) It would then become as much India’s interest as the Allies’ interest to resist Japanese aggression with all her might.
('83', 103, 10, 19, 205310) E. But with time so short don’t you think you have a moral duty to stand beside the Russians and the Chinese?

('83', 103, 11, 21, 205524) But even with the combined influence of every member of the Working Committee, it would have been impossible to enthuse the masses in favour of the Allied cause, which they do not understand, cannot understand.
('83', 103, 12, 22, 205735) E. But I have the feeling myself that you could, if you would, with your tremendous authority with the masses, do anything.
('83', 103, 12, 23, 205859) They are sure to listen to you.

('83', 103, 13, 25, 205982) And in proof of this I shall give you two solid facts.
('83', 103, 13, 26, 206037) If I had that influence you will agree that we would already
('83', 104, 0, 1, 206098) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 105
('83', 104, 1, 2, 206142) have won our independence without causing any trouble to anybody.
('83', 104, 1, 3, 206208) But, as you know, I have no influence, nor has the Working Committee with the Muslim League and the Princes.
('83', 104, 1, 4, 206317) That is one solid fact.
('83', 104, 1, 5, 206341) Then, there is another thing.
('83', 104, 1, 6, 206371) During the last War as you perhaps know, I had thrown myself heart and soul into it.
('83', 104, 1, 7, 206456) I had become a voluntary recruiting agent for the British.
('83', 104, 1, 8, 206515) And I began my agency in the district in which I had just been leading a campaign for agricultural relief with fair success.
('83', 104, 1, 9, 206640) I should have made great headway there.
('83', 104, 1, 10, 206680) But I tell you I did not do so.
('83', 104, 1, 11, 206712) I used to walk miles in the hot burning sun in order to collect recruits and to make an impression on the people about the urgency of it.
('83', 104, 1, 12, 206850) But I could not.
('83', 104, 1, 13, 206867) You will see, therefore, that my influence, great as it may appear to outsiders, is strictly limited.
('83', 104, 1, 14, 206969) I may have considerable influence to conduct a campaign for redress of popular grievances because people are ready and need a helper.
('83', 104, 1, 15, 207103) But I have no influence to direct people’s energy in a channel in which they have no interest.
('83', 104, 2, 16, 207198) STEELE: Then, what part of the people, you think, will believe in your movement?
('83', 104, 2, 17, 207279) `G. I wish I could tell you definitely.
('83', 104, 2, 18, 207319) It is all problematical.
('83', 104, 2, 19, 207344) I simply trade on the absolute purity of the cause and the equal purity of the means which are non violent.
('83', 104, 3, 20, 207452) S. Are you not apprehensive that the Working Committee’s resolution will antagonize American opinion?
('83', 104, 4, 21, 207554) G. Of course it may.
('83', 104, 4, 22, 207575) But I have never embarked upon any campaign in the belief that I would have world sympathy at my back.
('83', 104, 4, 23, 207678) On the contrary, the odds, almost in every case, have been against me.
('83', 104, 4, 24, 207749) And in the very first satyagraha struggle which started in South Africa, every outward element was hostile to me.
('83', 104, 4, 25, 207863) I had stated then—though I had no experience of the working of satyagraha that I have now—that a handful though we were in the midst of millions who had no sympathy for us, we had to rely upon our own inner strength and the absolute justice of our cause.
('83', 104, 4, 26, 208118) And that sustained us through the long drawn out agony lasting eight years.
('83', 104, 4, 27, 208194) I do not know why I should lose the sympathy of the American people, or the British people, for that matter.
('83', 104, 4, 28, 208303) And why should they fight shy of a just demand for absolute freedom?
('83', 104, 5, 29, 208372) Speaking as an American, I can say that the reaction of many Americans would be that a movement for freedom may be unwise at this moment for it would lead to complications in India which may be prejujudicial to the efficient prosecution of the war.
('83', 105, 0, 1, 208621) 106 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 105, 1, 2, 208663) G. This belief is born of ignorance.
('83', 105, 1, 3, 208700) What possible internal complication can take place if the British Government declare today that India is absolutely independent?
('83', 105, 1, 4, 208829) It would be in my opinion the least risk the Allies could take on behalf of the war effort.
('83', 105, 1, 5, 208921) I am open to conviction.
('83', 105, 1, 6, 208946) If anybody could convince me that in the midst of war, the British Government cannot declare India free without jeopardising the war effort, I should like to hear the argument.
('83', 105, 1, 7, 209123) I have not as yet heard any cogent one.
('83', 105, 2, 8, 209163) If you were convinced, would you call off the campaign?
('83', 105, 3, 9, 209219) G. Of course.
('83', 105, 3, 10, 209233) My complaint is that all these good critics talk at me, swear at me, but never condescend to talk to me.
('83', 105, 4, 11, 209338) RICHARD JEN: You have implicit faith in non violence.
('83', 105, 4, 12, 209392) But we have seen that armed resistance alone can succeed against the Japanese.
('83', 105, 5, 13, 209471) G. China never tried any experiment in non violence.
('83', 105, 5, 14, 209524) That the Chinese remained passive for some time is no proof that it was a non violent attitude.
('83', 105, 5, 15, 209620) For the first time in history non violence instead of being confined to individuals, religious enthusiasts and mystics, has been brought down to the political field and been experimented on by vast masses of mankind.
('83', 105, 5, 16, 209837) Just imagine, that instead of a few Indians, or even a million or so, all 400,000,000 Indians were non violent, would Japan make any headway in India, unless they were intent upon extermin ating all the four hundred million?
('83', 105, 6, 17, 210062) S. If India were made of four hundred million Gandhis.
('83', 105, 7, 18, 210117) G. Here we come to brass tacks.
('83', 105, 7, 19, 210149) That means India is not sufficiently non violent.
('83', 105, 7, 20, 210199) If we had been, there would have been no parties, and there would be no Japanese attack.
('83', 105, 7, 21, 210288) I know non violence is limited in both numbers and quality, but deficient as it is in both these respects, it has made a great impression and infused life into the people which was absent before.
('83', 105, 7, 22, 210484) The awakening that showed itself on April 6, 1919, was a matter of surprise to every Indian.
('83', 105, 7, 23, 210577) I cannot today account for the response we then had from every nook and corner of the country where no public worker had ever been.
('83', 105, 7, 24, 210709) We had not then gone among the masses, we did not know we could go and speak to them.
('83', 105, 8, 25, 210795) R. J. What can free India do for China?
('83', 105, 9, 26, 210835) G. If India were to listen to me, she would give non violent help to China.
('83', 105, 9, 27, 210911) But I know that will not be.
('83', 105, 9, 28, 210940) Free India would want to be militarist.
('83', 105, 9, 29, 210980) She will then get all the material and men she needs—
('83', 106, 0, 1, 211034) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 107
('83', 106, 1, 2, 211078) although it appears that China with her vast populations will not need men.
('83', 106, 1, 3, 211154) Today unfree India cannot send a single person to China.
('83', 106, 1, 4, 211211) I go further—free India can even plead with Japan and Japan will have to listen.
('83', 106, 2, 5, 211292) R. J. Can you give me an idea who would take the lead in forming a Provisional Government—you, Congress, or the Muslim League?
('83', 106, 3, 6, 211419) G. The Muslim League certainly can; the Congress can.
('83', 106, 3, 7, 211473) If everything went right, it would be a combined leadership.
('83', 106, 3, 8, 211534) No one party would take the lead.
('83', 106, 4, 9, 211568) R. J. Would it be within the present constitutional structure?
('83', 106, 5, 10, 211631) G. The constitution will be dead.
('83', 106, 5, 11, 211665) The Government of India Act of 1935 is dead.
('83', 106, 5, 12, 211710) The I. C. S. would have to go and it might be anarchy but there need be no anarchy, if the British withdraw with goodwill.
('83', 106, 5, 13, 211833) Free India Government would set up a constitution suited to Indian genius, evolved without dictation from outside.
('83', 106, 5, 14, 211948) But whether India would be cut up into autonomous provinces or not, I do not know.
('83', 106, 5, 15, 212031) The permanent structure may take time—all the time the war may require.
('83', 106, 5, 16, 212103) But the Provisional Government may continue to function.
('83', 106, 5, 17, 212160) It may be somewhat after the pattern of the present government, but with great modifications.
('83', 106, 5, 18, 212254) The two communities will certainly work in hearty combination.
('83', 106, 5, 19, 212317) It would be a combination not superimposed, but brought about by internal effort.
('83', 106, 5, 20, 212399) The dictating factor will not be an outside one, but wisdom.
('83', 106, 5, 21, 212460) And I believe there will be abundant wisdom among us.
('83', 106, 6, 22, 212514) R. J. Would the Viceroy cease to exist as such?
('83', 106, 7, 23, 212562) G. We shall be friends even then, but on a par, and I have no doubt that Lord Linlithgow will welcome the day when he will be one of the people.
('83', 106, 8, 24, 212707) E. Why can’t all this be done today, without the British withdrawal?
('83', 106, 9, 25, 212776) G. The answer is simple.
('83', 106, 9, 26, 212801) Why can’t a prisoner do a thing which a free man can do?
('83', 106, 9, 27, 212858) You may not have been behind prison bars, but I have been and I know.
('83', 106, 9, 28, 212928) Imprisonment means civil death, and I suggest to you that the whole of India is civilly dead.
('83', 106, 9, 29, 213022) The very breath is controlled by British power.
('83', 106, 9, 30, 213070) Then there is another experience that you lack.
('83', 106, 9, 31, 213118) You have not been a member of a nation that has been under subjection for several centuries.
('83', 106, 9, 32, 213211) Our habit has been that we can never be free.
('83', 106, 9, 33, 213257) You know the case of Shri Subhas Bose, a man of great self sacrifice who might have had a distinguished career in the Indian

('83', 107, 2, 3, 213582) Q. 1 You have said there is no more room for negotiation.

('83', 107, 2, 5, 213716) G. So far as we are concerned, we have closed our hearts.

('83', 111, 8, 20, 220427) 126. QUESTION BOX
('83', 111, 9, 21, 220445) VILLAGE SWARAJ
('83', 111, 10, 22, 220460) Q. In view of the situation that may arise at any moment in India, would you give an outline or skeleton of a village swaraj committee, which could function in all village matters in the absence of, and without relying upon, an overhead Government or other organization?
('83', 111, 10, 23, 220731) In particular, how would you ensure that the Committee should be fully representative and that it would act impartially, efficiently and without favour or fear?
('83', 111, 10, 24, 220892) What should be the scope of authority and the machinery to enforce its commands?
('83', 111, 10, 25, 220973) And what should be the manner in which a committee or an individual
('83', 112, 0, 1, 221041) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 113
('83', 112, 1, 2, 221085) member of it could be removed for corruption, inefficiency or other unfitness?
('83', 112, 2, 3, 221164) A. My idea of village swaraj is that it is a complete republic, independent of its neighbours for its own vital wants, and yet interdependent for many others in which dependence is a necessity.
('83', 112, 2, 4, 221358) Thus every village’s first concern will be to grow its own food crops and cotton for its cloth.
('83', 112, 2, 5, 221454) It should have a reserve for its cattle, recreation and playground for adults and children.
('83', 112, 2, 6, 221546) Then if there is more land available, it will grow useful money crops, thus excluding ganja, tobacco, opium and the like.
('83', 112, 2, 7, 221668) The village will maintain a village theatre, school and public hall.
('83', 112, 2, 8, 221737) It will have its own waterworks, ensuring clean water supply.
('83', 112, 2, 9, 221799) This can be done through controlled wells or tanks.
('83', 112, 2, 10, 221851) Education will be compulsory up to the final basic course.
('83', 112, 2, 11, 221910) As far as possible every activity will be conducted on the co operative basis.
('83', 112, 2, 12, 221989) There will be no castes such as we have today with their graded untouchability.
('83', 112, 2, 13, 222069) Non violence with its technique of satyagraha and non co operation will be the sanction of the village community.
('83', 112, 2, 14, 222183) There will be a compulsory service of village guards who will be selected by rotation from the register maintained by the village.
('83', 112, 2, 15, 222314) The government of the village will be conducted by a Panchayat of five persons annually elected by the adult villagers, male and female, possessing minimum prescribed qualifications.
('83', 112, 2, 16, 222497) These will have all the authority and jurisdiction required.
('83', 112, 2, 17, 222558) Since there will be no system of punishments in the accepted sense, this Panchayat will be the legislature, judiciary and executive combined to operate for its year of office.
('83', 112, 2, 18, 222734) Any village can become such a republic today without much interference even from the present Government whose sole effective connection with the villages is the exaction of the village revenue.
('83', 112, 2, 19, 222928) I have not examined here the question of relations with the neighbouring villages and the centre if any.
('83', 112, 2, 20, 223033) My purpose is to present an outline of village government.
('83', 112, 2, 21, 223092) Here there is perfect democracy based upon individual freedom.
('83', 112, 2, 22, 223155) The individual is the architect of his own government.
('83', 112, 2, 23, 223210) The law of non violence rules him and his government.
('83', 112, 2, 24, 223264) He and his village are able to defy the might of a world.
('83', 112, 2, 25, 223322) For the law governing every villager is that he will suffer death in the defence of his and his village’s honour.
('83', 112, 2, 26, 223436) The reader may well ask me—I am asking myself while penning these lines—as to why I have not been able to model Sevagram after the picture here drawn.
('83', 112, 2, 27, 223587) My answer is: I am making the attempt.
('83', 112, 2, 28, 223626) I can see dim traces of success though I can show nothing visible.
('83', 112, 2, 29, 223693) But there
('83', 113, 0, 1, 223703) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 113, 1, 2, 223745) is nothing inherently impossible in the picture drawn here.
('83', 113, 1, 3, 223805) To model such a village may be the work of a lifetime.
('83', 113, 1, 4, 223860) Any lover of true democracy and village life can take up a village, treat it as his world and sole work, and he will find good results.
('83', 113, 1, 5, 223996) He begins by being the village scavenger, spinner, watchman, medicine man and schoolmaster all at once.
('83', 113, 1, 6, 224100) If nobody comes near him, he will be satisfied with scavenging and spinning.
('83', 113, 2, 7, 224177) SEVAGRAM, July 18, 1942
('83', 113, 3, 8, 224201) Harijan, 26 7 1942
('83', 113, 4, 9, 224220) 127. TO EVERY JAPANESE 1
('83', 113, 5, 10, 224245) I must confess at the outset that though I have no ill will against you, I intensely dislike your attack upon China.
('83', 113, 5, 11, 224362) From your lofty height you have descended to imperial ambition.
('83', 113, 5, 12, 224426) You will fail to realize that ambition and may become the authors of the dismem berment of Asia, thus unwittingly preventing World Federation and brotherhood without which there can be no hope for humanity.
('83', 113, 5, 13, 224633) Ever since I was a lad of eighteen studying in London, over fifty years ago, I learnt, through the writings of the late Sir Edwin Arnold, to prize the many excellent qualities of your nation.
('83', 113, 5, 14, 224825) I was thrilled when in South Africa I learnt of your brilliant victory over Russian arms.
('83', 113, 5, 15, 224915) After my return to India from South Africa in 1915, I came in close touch with Japanese monks who lived as members of our Ashram from time to time.
('83', 113, 5, 16, 225063) One of them became a valuable member of the Ashram in Sevagram, and his application to duty, his dignified bearing, his unfailing devotion to daily worship, affability, unruffl edness under varying circumstances and his natural smile, which was positive evidence of his inner peace, had endeared him to all of us.
('83', 113, 5, 17, 225377) And now that owing to your declaration of war against Great Britain he has been taken away from us, we miss him as a dear co worker.
('83', 113, 5, 18, 225510) He has left behind him as a memory his daily prayer and his little drum, to the accompaniment of which we open our morning and evening prayers.
('83', 113, 5, 19, 225654) In the background of these pleasant recollections I grieve deeply as I contemplate what appears to me to be your unprovoked
('83', 113, 6, 20, 225778) 1 This was published in three Japanese newspapers—Nichi Nichi, Yomiuri and Miyako.
('83', 114, 0, 1, 225861) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 115
('83', 114, 1, 2, 225905) attack against China and, if reports are to be believed, your merciless devastation of that great and ancient land.
('83', 114, 1, 3, 226021) It was a worthy ambition of yours to take equal rank with the great powers of the world.
('83', 114, 1, 4, 226110) Your aggression against China and your alliance with the Axis powers was surely an unwarranted excess of the ambition.
('83', 114, 1, 5, 226229) I should have thought that you would be proud of the fact that that great and ancient people, whose old classical literature you have adopted as your own, are your neighbours.
('83', 114, 1, 6, 226405) Your understanding of one another’s history, tradition, literature should bind you as friends rather than make you the enemies you are today.
('83', 114, 1, 7, 226547) If I was a free man, and if you allowed me to come to your country, frail though I am, I would not mind risking my health, maybe my life, to come to your country to plead with you to desist from the wrong you are doing to China and the world and therefore to yourself.
('83', 114, 1, 8, 226816) But I enjoy no such freedom.
('83', 114, 1, 9, 226845) And we are in the unique position of having to resist an imperialism that we detest no less than yours and Nazism.
('83', 114, 1, 10, 226960) Our resistance to it does not mean harm to the British people.
('83', 114, 1, 11, 227023) We seek to convert them.
('83', 114, 1, 12, 227048) Ours is an unarmed revolt against British rule.
('83', 114, 1, 13, 227096) An important party in the country is engaged in a deadly but friendly quarrel with the foreign rulers.
('83', 114, 1, 14, 227199) But in this they need no aid from foreign powers.
('83', 114, 1, 15, 227249) You have been gravely misinformed, as I know you are, that we have chosen this particular moment to embarrass the Allies when your attack against India is imminent.
('83', 114, 1, 16, 227414) If we wanted to turn Britain’s difficulty into our opportunity we should have done it as soon as the war broke out nearly three years ago.
('83', 114, 1, 17, 227553) Our movement demanding the withdrawal of the British power from India should in no way be misunderstood.
('83', 114, 1, 18, 227658) In fact if we are to believe your reported anxiety for the independence of India, a recognition of that independence by Britain should leave you no excuse for any attack on India.
('83', 114, 1, 19, 227838) Moreover the reported profession sorts ill with your ruthless aggression against China.
('83', 114, 1, 20, 227926) I would ask you to make no mistake about the fact that you will be sadly disillusioned if you believe that you will receive a willing welcome from India.
('83', 114, 1, 21, 228080) The end and aim of the movement for British withdrawal is to prepare India, by making her free for resisting all militarist and imperialist ambition, whether it is called British Imperialism, German Nazism, or
('83', 115, 0, 1, 228290) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 115, 1, 2, 228332) your pattern.
('83', 115, 1, 3, 228346) If we do not, we shall have been ignoble spectators of the militarization of the world in spite of our belief that in non violence we have the only solvent of the militarist spirit and ambition.
('83', 115, 1, 4, 228541) Personally I fear that without declaring the independence of India the Allied powers will not be able to beat the Axis combination which has raised violence to the dignity of a religion.
('83', 115, 1, 5, 228728) The Allies cannot beat you and your partners unless they beat you in your ruthless and skilled warfare.
('83', 115, 1, 6, 228832) If they copy it their declaration that they will save the world for democracy and individual freedom must come to naught.
('83', 115, 1, 7, 228954) I feel that they can only gain strength to avoid copying your ruthlessness by declaring and recognizing now the freedom of India, and turning sullen India’s forced co operation into freed India’s voluntary co operation.
('83', 115, 1, 8, 229174) To Britain and the Allies we have appealed in the name of justice, in proof of their professions, and in their own self interest.
('83', 115, 1, 9, 229304) To you I appeal in the name of humanity.
('83', 115, 1, 10, 229345) It is a marvel to me that you do not see that ruthless warfare is no body’s monopoly.
('83', 115, 1, 11, 229431) If not the Allies some other power will certainly improve upon your method and beat you with your own weapon.

('83', 115, 1, 13, 229629) They cannot take pride in a recital of cruel deeds however skilfully achieved.
('83', 115, 1, 14, 229708) Even if you win it will not prove that you were in the right; it will only prove that your power of destruction was greater.
('83', 115, 1, 15, 229833) This applies obviously to the Allies too, unless they perform now the just and righteous act of freeing India as an earnest and promise of similarly freeing all other subject peoples in Asia and Africa.
('83', 115, 1, 16, 230036) Our appeal to Britain is coupled with the offer of free India’s willingness to let the Allies retain their troops in India.
('83', 115, 1, 17, 230160) The offer is made in order to prove that we do not in any way mean to harm the Allied cause, and in order to prevent you from being misled into feeling that you have but to step into the country that Britain has vacated.
('83', 115, 1, 18, 230381) Needless to repeat that if you cherish any such idea and will carry it out, we will not fail in resisting you with all the might that our country can muster.
('83', 115, 1, 19, 230539) I address this appeal to you in the hope that our movement may even influence you and your partners in the right direction and deflect you and them from the course which is bound to end in your moral ruin and the reduction of human beings to robots.
('83', 115, 1, 20, 230789) The hope of your response to my appeal is much fainter than that of response from Britain.

('83', 116, 5, 11, 231525) 128. TO MY CRITICS
('83', 116, 6, 12, 231544) The critics who impute motives to the Working Committee or to me harm the cause they profess to serve.
('83', 116, 6, 13, 231647) The members of the Working Committee are all seasoned servants of the nation with full sense of their responsibility.
('83', 116, 6, 14, 231765) It is no use damning me as a dictator like Herr Hitler.
('83', 116, 6, 15, 231821) He does not argue with his co workers if he may be said to have any.
('83', 116, 6, 16, 231890) He merely issues orders which can only be disobeyed on pain of death or worse.
('83', 116, 6, 17, 231969) I argue with my friends for days.
('83', 116, 6, 18, 232003) I argued at the last meeting for eight days.
('83', 116, 6, 19, 232048) The members agreed when their reason was satisfied.
('83', 116, 6, 20, 232100) My sanction with my friends as well as self styled enemies has ever been reason and love.
('83', 116, 6, 21, 232190) It is a travesty of truth therefore to compare me with Hitler or to call me a dictator in any current sense of the term.
('83', 116, 6, 22, 232311) It is an equal travesty of truth to abuse the Congress by calling it a Hindu or communal organization.
('83', 116, 6, 23, 232414) It is national in the fullest sense of the term.
('83', 116, 6, 24, 232463) It is a purely political organization with which can undoubtedly be compared the Liberal Party which is without the slightest communal taint.
('83', 116, 6, 25, 232605) Unfortunately today although it has politicians who have a record of distinguished service, it has admittedly little or no following in the country by reason of its members holding unpopular views.
('83', 116, 6, 26, 232803) Thus the Congress remains the sole representative national organization in India with a mass following.
('83', 116, 6, 27, 232907) Its gains belong not merely to itself but to the whole nation, irrespective of caste or creed or race.
('83', 116, 6, 28, 233010) It is mischievous and misleading to discredit this organization in America and Great Britain as a communal or pro Axis or a purely Hindu organization.
('83', 116, 6, 29, 233161) If it was a
('83', 117, 0, 1, 233173) 118 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 117, 1, 2, 233215) pro Axis organization, it has courage and influence enough to make a public declaration to that effect in disregard of the consequences that might overtake it.
('83', 117, 1, 3, 233375) It is not, and has never been, a secret or a violent organization.
('83', 117, 1, 4, 233442) If it had been either, it would have been suppressed long ago.
('83', 117, 1, 5, 233505) So much about some manifest misrepresentations.
('83', 117, 1, 6, 233553) Now about suppression of relevant Congress position.
('83', 117, 1, 7, 233606) Nobody has contended that the demand for withdrawal of British power is not an inherent right of the nation, irrespective of the demand to the contrary by those who by centuries of habit have lost the sense of freedom.
('83', 117, 1, 8, 233825) It is said that it is wrong not intrinsically, but because of the Congress declaration of non embarrassment to ask for such withdrawal at this moment.
('83', 117, 1, 9, 233976) The critics conveniently omit to mention the fact that in order to prove its bona fides and to prevent the Japanese attack the Congress has agreed that, in spite of the withdrawal of the British, the Allied troops should remain in India, naturally under a treaty with the free India Government to be.
('83', 117, 1, 10, 234277) So long as that Government, provisional or otherwise, has not come into being, there will be no authority to check their operations save their honour.
('83', 117, 1, 11, 234428) For by declaring India free they will have absolved themselves from consulting anybody formally as they have to consult today members of their nomination.
('83', 117, 1, 12, 234583) In this sense the declaration of independence leaves them freer to adopt the military measures they may consider necessary.
('83', 117, 1, 13, 234707) I know that this is an anomalous position for a free country to be in.
('83', 117, 1, 14, 234778) But honesty dictates the course.
('83', 117, 1, 15, 234811) As I have said and repeat here the Congress demand is foolproof.
('83', 117, 1, 16, 234876) Critics who are anxious to serve the Allies would do well to examine the Congress position and point out flaws if there are any.
('83', 117, 1, 17, 235005) Let me inform them that those who have come to me to understand my demand and who had serious misgivings went away convinced that it was wholly just and that if justice was not done the Congress would be right in taking action to vindicate its position.

('83', 120, 4, 9, 240201) 131. PANDIT KACHRU EXTERNED
('83', 120, 5, 10, 240229) Pandit Kachru is a well known public worker attached to the States People’s Conference.
('83', 120, 5, 11, 240317) When Shri Jainarayan Vyas went on hunger strike at Jodhpur, he was deputed by the President Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru to proceed to Jodhpur and watch events and report to me.
('83', 120, 5, 12, 240490) For reasons known to the authorities and unknown to Pandit Kachru he was served with an externment order on the 5th instant, at 11.40 p.m., to depart from Jodhpur the next morning by 7.15 a.
('83', 120, 5, 13, 240681) He telephoned to me for instructions and Mahadev Desai who answered the phone advised him in the first instance to obey the order and report.
('83', 120, 5, 14, 240823) He is now in Wardha trying to finish his report to the point he was able to reach in Jodhpur.
('83', 120, 5, 15, 240917) Here is the order:
('83', 120, 6, 16, 240936) From information received the Government of Jodhpur is satisfied that Dwarkanath Kachru (name) is acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order and the efficient prosecution of war.
('83', 120, 7, 17, 241138) With a view to prevent the said Dwarkanath Kachru from so acting, the Government of Jodhpur, in exercise of its powers conferred by Rule 26(I)(a) of the Defence of India Rules as applied to the Jodhpur State territory is pleased to order that the said Dwarkanath Kachru shall remove himself from Marwar in railway train I up of 6 7 42 (manner) which leaves Jodhpur at 7.15 a.m.
('83', 120, 7, 18, 241516) (via Marwar Junction) and further that the said Dwarkanath Kachru shall not return to Marwar for a period of one year from the date of this order.
('83', 120, 8, 19, 241663) The Inspector General of Police, Jodhpur, is hereby directed to see that the above order is promptly carried out.
('83', 120, 8, 20, 241777) The important question arising is how long will the States regard

('83', 121, 1, 2, 241885) people from outside their jurisdiction as foreigners and deal with them summarily as the Jodhpur authorities have done?
('83', 121, 1, 3, 242005) And how long must they allow themselves to be treated as such?
('83', 121, 1, 4, 242068) The Congress has exercised the greatest self restraint in this matter.
('83', 121, 1, 5, 242139) Its men deserve a better treatment.
('83', 121, 1, 6, 242175) If the authorities have justification for their order, they should publicly state it.
('83', 121, 1, 7, 242261) It is not a matter that can be forgotten.
('83', 121, 1, 8, 242303) Pandit Kachru ought to be able to return unless satisfactory explanation is offered for his externment.
('83', 121, 2, 9, 242407) SEVAGRAM, July 12, 1942 [PS.] Since the foregoing was written, much is reported to have happened in Jodhpur.

('83', 121, 2, 11, 242563) But repression is said to be going on merrily.

('83', 121, 5, 21, 243430) 132. FASTING IN NON VIOLENT ACTION
('83', 121, 6, 22, 243465) If the struggle which we are seeking to avoid with all our might has to come, and if it is to remain non violent as it must in order to succeed, fasting is likely to play an important part in it.
('83', 121, 6, 23, 243661) It has its place in the tussle with authority and with our own people in the event of wanton acts of violence and obstinate riots for instance.
('83', 121, 6, 24, 243805) There is a natural prejudice against it as part of a political struggle.
('83', 121, 6, 25, 243878) It has a recognized place in religious practice.
('83', 121, 6, 26, 243927) But it is considered a vulgar interpolation in politics by the ordinary politician
('83', 122, 0, 1, 244010) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 123
('83', 122, 1, 2, 244054) though it has always been resorted to by prisoners in a haphazard way with more or less success.
('83', 122, 1, 3, 244151) By fasting, however, they have always succeeded in drawing public attention and disturbing the peace of jail authorities.
('83', 122, 1, 4, 244273) My own fasts have always, as I hold, been strictly according to the law of satyagraha.
('83', 122, 1, 5, 244360) Fellow satyagrahis too in South Africa fasted partially or wholly.
('83', 122, 1, 6, 244427) My fasts have been varied.
('83', 122, 1, 7, 244454) There was the Hindu Muslim unity fast of 21 days in 1924 started under the late Maulana Mahomed Ali’s roof in Delhi.
('83', 122, 1, 8, 244571) The indeterminate fast against the MacDonald Award was taken in the Yeravda Prison in 1932. The 21 days’ purificatory fast was begun in the Yeravda Prison and was finished at Lady Thakersey’s, as the Government woul not take the burden of my being in the Prison in that condition.
('83', 122, 1, 9, 244852) Then followed another fast in the Yeravda Prison in 1933 against the Government refusal to let me carry on anti untouchability work through Harijan (issued from prison) on the same basis as facilities had been allowed me four months before.
('83', 122, 1, 10, 245093) They would not yield, but they discharged me when their medical advisers thought I could not live many days if the fast was not given up.
('83', 122, 1, 11, 245231) Then followed the ill fated Rajkot fast in 1939. A false step taken by me thoughtlessly during that fast thwarted the brilliant result that would otherwise certainly have been achieved.
('83', 122, 1, 12, 245417) In spite of all these fasts, fasting has not been accepted as a recognized part of satyagraha.
('83', 122, 1, 13, 245512) It has only been tolerated by the politicians.
('83', 122, 1, 14, 245559) I have however been driven to the conclusion that fasting unto death is an integral part of satyagraha programme, and it is the greatest and most effective weapon in its armoury under given circumstances.
('83', 122, 1, 15, 245764) Not everyone is qualified for undertaking it without a proper course of training.
('83', 122, 1, 16, 245846) I may not burden this note with an examination of the circumstances under which fasting may be resorted to and the training required for it.
('83', 122, 1, 17, 245987) Non violence in its positive aspect as benevolence (I do not use the word love as it has fallen into disrepute) is the greatest force because of the limitless scope it affords for self suffering without causing or intending any physical or material injury to the wrongdoer.
('83', 122, 1, 18, 246261) The object always is to evoke the best in him.
('83', 122, 1, 19, 246308) Self suffering is an appeal to his better nature, as retaliation is to his baser.
('83', 122, 1, 20, 246390) Fasting under proper circumstances is such an appeal par excellence.
('83', 122, 1, 21, 246459) If the politician does not perceive its propriety in political matters, it is because it is a novel use of this very fine weapon.
('83', 123, 0, 1, 246589) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 123, 1, 2, 246631) To practice non violence in mundane matters is to know its true value.
('83', 123, 1, 3, 246702) It is to bring heaven upon earth.
('83', 123, 1, 4, 246736) There is no such thing as the other world.
('83', 123, 1, 5, 246779) All worlds are one.
('83', 123, 1, 6, 246799) There is no ‘here’ and no ‘there’.
('83', 123, 1, 7, 246834) As Jeans has demonstrated, the whole universe including the most distant stars, invisible even through the most powerful telescope in the world, is compressed in an atom.
('83', 123, 1, 8, 247005) I hold it therefore to be wrong to limit the use of non violence to cave dwellers and for acquiring merit for a favoured position in the other world.
('83', 123, 1, 9, 247155) All virtue ceases to have use if it serves no purpose in every walk of life.
('83', 123, 1, 10, 247232) I would therefore plead with the purely political minded people to study non violence and fasting as its extreme manifestation with sympathy and understanding.
('83', 123, 2, 11, 247392) SEVAGRAM, July 20, 1942
('83', 123, 3, 12, 247416) Harijan, 26 7 1942
('83', 123, 4, 13, 247435) 133. LETTER TO NAZIR AHMAD

('83', 123, 6, 15, 247500) DEAR FAKIR SAHEB, I have your kind letter.

('83', 123, 6, 17, 247629) Both are ready at any moment to settle with the League on the usual terms, i.e., arbitration in the absence of agreement.

('83', 124, 1, 2, 248357) 134. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('83', 124, 2, 3, 248383) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, July 20, 1942
('83', 124, 3, 4, 248415) AMRIT, I get not a moment for letter writing.
('83', 124, 3, 5, 248461) Harijan and interviews absorb my time.
('83', 124, 3, 6, 248500) I have replied to your repeated question.
('83', 124, 3, 7, 248542) You can join me in Bombay.
('83', 124, 3, 8, 248569) But if S[hummy] would be better pleased for you to stay in Simla till 15th August, I should stay on if I were you.

('83', 126, 1, 2, 250915) 137. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 4
('83', 126, 2, 3, 250943) [On or before July 21, 1942]
('83', 126, 3, 4, 250972) Q. 1. Whether Gandhiji is willing to see British go while Japanese on the frontier.
('83', 126, 4, 5, 251056) A. This question should not occur to anybody who has read my writings, for they contemplate Allied arms operating in India during the war.
('83', 126, 5, 6, 251195) Q. 2. Whether he would urge non co operation with Japanese after Japanese occupation.
('83', 126, 6, 7, 251281) A. Japanese occupation is inconceivable while Allied arms are operating on the Indian soil.
('83', 126, 6, 8, 251373) If Japanese inflict defeat on Allied arms and succeed in occupying India I would most decidedly advise full non co operation.
('83', 126, 7, 9, 251499) Q. 3. Whether he would persist in urging non co operation if Japs shot non co operators .
('83', 126, 8, 10, 251589) Q. 4. Whether he would rather be shot than co operate himself.
('83', 126, 9, 11, 251652) A. TO 3 & 4: Non co operation worth the name must invite shooting.
('83', 126, 9, 12, 251719) In any case I would rather be shot than submit to Japanese or any other power.
('83', 126, 10, 13, 251798) Harijan, 26 7 1942

('83', 127, 5, 13, 252705) 1 The Viceroy, writing to Amery, summarized Mirabehn’s talk with Laithwaite on July 17, as follows: (a) She continued to insist on vital necessity for full acceptance of Gandhi’s demand for recognition of Indian independence.
('83', 127, 5, 14, 252931) Nothing else could possibly save a situation which was very rapidly deteriorating.
('83', 127, 5, 15, 253014) Gandhi was inspired by pure friendship for us.
('83', 127, 5, 16, 253061) We were loathed through the country by all parties, Congress or non Congress.
('83', 127, 5, 17, 253139) Only Congress (subject to the declaration of independence) could remedy the situation.
('83', 127, 5, 18, 253226) Once the declaration had been made everything would fall properly into its place.
('83', 127, 5, 19, 253308) Disunity would disappear, etc., etc.
('83', 127, 5, 20, 253345) (b) Gandhi had on the last occasion taken steps to call off the movement where there had been cases of violence.
('83', 127, 5, 21, 253458) On this occasion, he would do his very utmost to ensure non violence.
('83', 127, 5, 22, 253528) But he would not feel justified in calling the movement off merely because cases of violence occurred.
('83', 127, 5, 23, 253631) He could not do so without doing greater violence to the ideals for which he was working.
('83', 127, 5, 24, 253721) (c) Gandhi was greatly moved in his decision to press this policy by the state of moral degradation into which he thought the country had fallen.
('83', 127, 5, 25, 253867) It must regain its own soul.
('83', 127, 5, 26, 253896) At the moment it was prepared, while hating the British, to lick their boots.
('83', 127, 5, 27, 253974) This is an intolerable position and no price was too high to pay to remedy it.
('83', 127, 5, 28, 254053) (d) On the last occasion Congressmen put in prison had obeyed the rules and been strictly non violent.
('83', 127, 5, 29, 254156) That would not be so now.
('83', 127, 5, 30, 254182) It would be a case of victory or death.
('83', 127, 5, 31, 254222) Gandhi might be put in prison, etc., but could not be kept there.
('83', 127, 5, 32, 254288) She hinted definitely that he intended to see the business to a finish, even at the cost of his own life.
('83', 127, 5, 33, 254394) He would do all he could to guide the movement on non violent lines, but must be left free to guide it.
('83', 127, 5, 34, 254498) If he was not left to guide it by word or writing there was nothing left for him but death.
('83', 127, 5, 35, 254590) (That no doubt may be the meaning of Gandhi’s statement to the Press about a short and swift struggle.) She was given no reason to hope that any modification of our attitude could be looked for or that the Congress claim could be entertained.

('83', 128, 5, 7, 255166) 140. CHARKHA JAYANTI 1
('83', 128, 6, 8, 255189) ‘Gandhi Jayanti’ is just a pretext, the real thing is Charkha Jayanti.
('83', 128, 6, 9, 255260) Had there been no charkha, there would perhaps have been no Jayanti (Birthday) celebrations, and even if there had been such celebrations, they would have had little importance.
('83', 128, 6, 10, 255438) There is no point in having birthday celebrations of any person without any definite end in view, otherwise they must be confined to just the innocent rejoicings of relatives and friends.
('83', 128, 6, 11, 255626) But because Gandhi Jayanti has been turned into Charkha Jayanti—a great and comprehensive end— the celebration has assumed a national importance.
('83', 128, 7, 12, 255772) The Charkha Sangh has decided to celebrate the Jayanti by collecting funds for khadi work, by enlisting self spinners, and making yarn collections.
('83', 128, 7, 13, 255920) In fixing up its programme it has had before it the example of Shri Narandas Gandhi’s annual work in this direction.
('83', 128, 7, 14, 256037) He and those who associate with him pledge themselves to do a certain amount of work each year, and he has had more and more success every year.
('83', 128, 7, 15, 256182) There is no reason why such success should not attend the Charkha Sangh’s efforts.
('83', 128, 7, 16, 256265) Only it needs workers with a will to bring the work to fruition.
('83', 128, 7, 17, 256330) Without khadi there may come a time when people may have to go without any clothing.
('83', 128, 7, 18, 256415) Only the Charkha Sangh can prevent this catastrophe.
('83', 128, 7, 19, 256468) I hope that all will co operate with the Sangh in its noble endeavour.
('83', 128, 7, 20, 256539) SEVAGRAM, July 22, 1942 Harijan, 9 8 1942
('83', 128, 8, 21, 256581) 1 This was originally published in Hindi in Khadi Jagat.
('83', 128, 8, 22, 256638) 2 In the source here are added the words “and comprehensive end in view”— apparently a printer’s error.
