('83', 130, 11, 12, 258458) 145. THE FIRST VICTIM
('83', 130, 12, 13, 258480) Shri Satis Chandra Das Gupta of Khadi Pratishthan has been arrested 2 and sentenced to two years imprisonment for disobedience of an order under 26(1) of the Defence of India Rules.
('83', 130, 12, 14, 258662) His offence consisted in advising distressed people not to move from their places unless provided with an equivalent.
('83', 130, 12, 15, 258780) This procedure was in strict accord with my writings in Harijan and the recent resolution of the Congress Working Committee.
('83', 130, 13, 16, 258905) 1 The telegram was in reply to the addressee’s letter of July 23, 1942. 2 He was arrested in Noakhali on July 23.
('83', 131, 0, 1, 259019) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 131, 1, 2, 259061) There is no doubt that Satis Babu’s breach was deliberate.
('83', 131, 1, 3, 259120) It was broken at the dictates of humanity, as will be clear from his letter to the District Magistrate printed elsewhere.
('83', 131, 1, 4, 259242) Satis Babu and his men have worked for years in these parts and distributed thousands of rupees among the spinners and weavers.
('83', 131, 1, 5, 259370) Satis Babu’s letter shows that the grievance is real.
('83', 131, 1, 6, 259424) A great war claimed to be for the emancipation of the human mind and human body cannot be won by the suppression of those whose willing association is desired and desirable.
('83', 131, 1, 7, 259598) The masses of India are undoubtedly steeped in ignorance.
('83', 131, 1, 8, 259656) They are meek and regarded by historians as the gentlest on earth.
('83', 131, 1, 9, 259723) They are easily led.
('83', 131, 1, 10, 259744) They follow the guidance of their leaders.
('83', 131, 1, 11, 259787) Hence the proper way to deal with them is to deal with the leaders.
('83', 131, 1, 12, 259855) Leaders are of two kinds: self styled, who become leaders to exploit them, and those who become leaders by right of service.
('83', 131, 1, 13, 259980) They are the trusted ones.
('83', 131, 1, 14, 260007) It is quite easy to distinguish between the two species.
('83', 131, 1, 15, 260064) It is wrong to tear these latter from their men.
('83', 131, 2, 16, 260113) Satis Babu belongs to the second category.
('83', 131, 2, 17, 260156) He is no politician, though he knows politics.
('83', 131, 2, 18, 260203) He is a businessman.
('83', 131, 2, 19, 260224) He is one of the favourite pupils of Acharya Ray, the distinguished scientist and life philanthropist, who never earned a pie for himself.
('83', 131, 2, 20, 260363) Satis Babu is one of the makers of the famous Bengal Chemical Works—one of Acharya Ray’s many creations.
('83', 131, 2, 21, 260468) He gave up the Chemical Works of which he was the manager on a high salary.
('83', 131, 2, 22, 260544) He took up khadi and became a poor man.
('83', 131, 2, 23, 260584) His partner in his joys and sorrows followed him heart and soul in his austere life, and so did his brother and promising sons, one of whom died while he was serving.
('83', 131, 2, 24, 260751) His brother Shri Kshitish Chandra Das Gupta is also a chemist, and has dedicated himself to the Khadi Pratishthan, giving all his time and energy to handicrafts like bee keeping, paper making and so on.
('83', 131, 2, 25, 260954) Satis Babu deprived his sons of the high education he had himself taken.
('83', 131, 2, 26, 261027) He threw himself into his new work with such great energy that he became an expert in khadi work and built up Khadi Pratishthan, which has become a great centre of philanthropic activities.
('83', 131, 2, 27, 261217) Satis Babu is one of the truest and gentlest of men I have had the privilege of working with.
('83', 131, 2, 28, 261311) He tries with all his might to live up to the message of truth and
('83', 132, 0, 1, 261378) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 133
('83', 132, 1, 2, 261422) non violence which he accepted not as a political expedient but as a rule of life.
('83', 132, 1, 3, 261505) If this country was not ruled by the law of exploitation on behalf of its conquerors but by popular representatives, men like Satis Babu would be much in demand by those in authority in times of need.
('83', 132, 1, 4, 261706) This is a time of great need.
('83', 132, 1, 5, 261736) But all the use the authorities have for him is to punish him for the breach of their laws which express not the will of the nation but of one man whose rule is imposed upon them.
('83', 132, 1, 6, 261916) Satis Babu has kindled a light which will not be extinguished.
('83', 132, 1, 7, 261979) The law is wrong, Satis Babu the servant of his people is right.
('83', 132, 2, 8, 262044) SEVAGRAM, July 24, 1942
('83', 132, 3, 9, 262068) Harijan, 2 8 1942

('83', 133, 0, 1, 262377) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 133, 1, 2, 262419) 147. INTERVIEW TO JOURNALIST 1
('83', 133, 2, 3, 262450) [Before July 25, 1942] 2
('83', 133, 3, 4, 262475) He talked of the public feeling in his province.
('83', 133, 3, 5, 262524) “It is more anti British than pro Japanese”, he said.
('83', 133, 3, 6, 262578) “There is a vague notion that we have had enough of this rule, and almost anything would be better than the existing state of things.
('83', 133, 3, 7, 262712) People are happy when Subhas Babu says on the radio that there are no differences between him and you and when he says you are now out to fight for liberty at any cost.”
('83', 133, 4, 8, 262882) GANDHIJI: But I suppose you know that there he is wrong and I cannot possibly appropriate the compliments he is paying me.
('83', 133, 4, 9, 263005) ‘Liberty at any cost’ has a vastly different connotation for me from what it has for him.
('83', 133, 4, 10, 263095) ‘At any cost’ does not exist in my dictionary.
('83', 133, 4, 11, 263142) It does not for instance include bringing in foreigners in order to help us win our liberty.
('83', 133, 4, 12, 263235) I have no doubt that it means exchanging one form of slavery for another possibly much worse.
('83', 133, 4, 13, 263329) But of course we have to fight for our liberty and make whatever sacrifice it demands.
('83', 133, 4, 14, 263416) In spite of all the hypocrisy that you find in all the inspired Press of Britain and America I do not relent.
('83', 133, 4, 15, 263526) I deliberately use the word hypocrisy, for they are now proving that when they were talking of the freedom of India they did not mean it.
('83', 133, 4, 16, 263664) So far as I am concerned I have no doubt about the righteousness of my step.
('83', 133, 4, 17, 263741) It seems to me to be axiomatic that the Allies are in for a defeat this time if they will not do this initial act of justice, and thus put their own case on an unassailable basis.
('83', 133, 4, 18, 263921) If they don’t, they must face the opposition of those who cannot tolerate their rule and are prepared to die in order to get rid of it.
('83', 133, 4, 19, 264057) ‘Convert the deepening ill will into goodwill’ is a sound proposition.
('83', 133, 4, 20, 264128) It is not open to them to say that we must smother our consciences and say or do nothing because there is war.
('83', 133, 4, 21, 264239) That is why I have made up my mind that it would be a good thing if a million people were shot in a brave and non violent rebellion against British rule.
('83', 133, 4, 22, 264393) It may be that it may take us years before we can evolve order out of chaos.
('83', 133, 4, 23, 264470) But we can then face the world, we cannot face the world today.
('83', 133, 4, 24, 264534) Avowedly the different nations are fighting for their liberty.
('83', 133, 4, 25, 264597) Germany, Japan, Russia, China are pouring their blood and money like water.
('83', 133, 4, 26, 264673) What is our
('83', 133, 5, 27, 264685) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Fire Raging in Me”, 25 7 1942. The journalist was present not in his capacity as a journalist “but as one interested in Gandhiji’s movement”.
('83', 133, 5, 28, 264861) 2 Ibid.
('83', 134, 0, 1, 264869) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 135
('83', 134, 1, 2, 264913) record?
('83', 134, 1, 3, 264921) You talk of the newspapers doing good business out of the war.
('83', 134, 1, 4, 264984) It is a shame to be thus bought and to refrain from speaking out at Government’s dictation.
('83', 134, 1, 5, 265076) There is many a way of earning an honest crust of bread.
('83', 134, 1, 6, 265133) If British money—which is our money—can buy us Heaven help our country !
('83', 134, 1, 7, 265206) We are betraying a woeful cowardice.
('83', 134, 1, 8, 265243) I do not mind the blood bath in which Europe is plunged.
('83', 134, 1, 9, 265300) It is bad enough, but there is a great deal of heroism—mothers losing their only children, wives their husbands and so on.
('83', 134, 1, 10, 265423) Lord Lytton’s only son was killed the other day.
('83', 134, 1, 11, 265472) British history is filled with such heroic sacrifice.
('83', 134, 1, 12, 265526) It is not the criticism of the British and American Press that worries me, but it is our Press listening to the British censor.
('83', 134, 1, 13, 265654) If only to resist that awful atmosphere I must gird up my loins.
('83', 134, 1, 14, 265719) I do not feel flattered when Subhas Babu says I am right.
('83', 134, 1, 15, 265777) I am not right in the sense he means.
('83', 134, 1, 16, 265815) For there he is attributing pro Japanese feeling to me.
('83', 134, 1, 17, 265871) If I were to discover that by some strange miscalculation I had not realized the fact that I was helping the entry of the Japanese in this country, I should not hesitate to retrace my steps.
('83', 134, 1, 18, 266062) As regards the Japanese, I am certain that we should lay down our lives in order to resist them as we would to resist the British.
('83', 134, 1, 19, 266193) But it won’t be the work of human hands.
('83', 134, 1, 20, 266234) It will be the work of a Force—incalculable and invisible—which works, often upsetting all our calculations.
('83', 134, 1, 21, 266343) I rely implicitly on it.
('83', 134, 1, 22, 266368) Otherwise I should go mad in face of all this torrent of what I must call irritating criticism.
('83', 134, 1, 23, 266464) They do not know my agony.

('83', 140, 1, 2, 279361) 151. FOR THE PRINCES
('83', 140, 2, 3, 279382) A kind of nervousness creeps over me as I think of the Princes of India, although I have the privilege of knowing many and some even intimately.
('83', 140, 2, 4, 279527) My nervousness arises from the painful knowledge that they are a creation of the British rulers.
('83', 140, 2, 5, 279624) Though some of them pre existed before the British advent, their existence thereafter depended solely on British goodwill, which in its turn depended upon the price the then incumbents paid for that commodity.
('83', 140, 2, 6, 279834) The present incumbents are sole creation of the Imperial Power.
('83', 140, 2, 7, 279898) Its simple frown can undo them.
('83', 140, 2, 8, 279930) But they need not feel so helpless if they could consider themselves as an integral part of the nation instead of being, as they are, an integral part of the Imperial machine.
('83', 140, 2, 9, 280106) If the machine topples they may disappear unless they become part of, and depend upon, the nation.
('83', 140, 2, 10, 280205) The Empire is going either by the will of the British people or by the force of circumstances beyond their control.
('83', 140, 2, 11, 280321) India shall not always be a slave country.
('83', 140, 2, 12, 280364) Will the Princes march with the times or must they remain tied to the Imperial chariot wheel?
('83', 140, 2, 13, 280458) If they take their courage in both their hands and make common cause with the nation they can run the risk of dispossession.
('83', 140, 2, 14, 280583) This I admit is a heroic step.
('83', 140, 2, 15, 280614) They can adopt the middle course.
('83', 140, 2, 16, 280648) They may earn the goodwill of their people by sharing their powers with them.
('83', 140, 2, 17, 280726) They will never be able to retain their absolutism for all time.
('83', 140, 2, 18, 280791) But they may certainly hope to retain much if they can secure the contentment and active co operation of the people within their jurisdiction, in the administration of their own affairs.
('83', 140, 2, 19, 280978) I think it is wrong of the Princes to let their critics say of their people that they are too backward to deserve freedom.
('83', 140, 2, 20, 281101) It is a reflection on them.
('83', 140, 2, 21, 281129) The people in the States belong to the same stock as those outside their borders.

('83', 140, 2, 25, 281437) The arbitrary powers they enjoy should go.

('83', 140, 2, 27, 281601) Nor can any person, whether Prince or a Princely zamindar or merchant, be the sole owner and disposer of possessions hereditary or self acquired.

('83', 141, 4, 24, 283573) 152. URDU EXAMINATION 1
('83', 141, 5, 25, 283597) The Hindustani Prachar Sabha has begun its work in right earnest.

('83', 141, 6, 30, 284058) 1 This appeared under the heading “Notes”.

('83', 142, 1, 2, 284145) mean Hindi plus Urdu.
('83', 142, 1, 3, 284167) Everyone who attends Congress meetings realizes this truth, for when a Congressman speaks in Hindi the Urdu speaking men do not fully understand him, if at all, and the same thing applies to Urdu speakers.
('83', 142, 1, 4, 284373) Therefore if you wish to be understood by all, you have to speak a combination of the two as I have heard Malaviyaji and Babu Bhagwandas doing.
('83', 142, 1, 5, 284517) Hence the necessity of Indian nationalists speaking both the varieties of Hindustani speech.
('83', 142, 1, 6, 284610) No one may be said to speak Hindustani who is not equally at home with both the varieties.

('83', 142, 1, 8, 284774) To supply this felt want is one of the main causes of founding the Hindustani Prachar Sabha.
('83', 142, 1, 9, 284867) Its founders were and are members of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan.
('83', 142, 1, 10, 284932) But their ambition was not satisfied with mere Hindi propaganda.

('83', 144, 1, 2, 287953) 155. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('83', 144, 2, 3, 287981) Q. 1. Will you be satisfied by a joint guarantee by America, China and Soviet Russia?
('83', 144, 3, 4, 288067) A. No guarantee is contemplated by the Congress demand, because present delivery of independence is the need of the hour, not because of distrust about future delivery but because India as an independent Power wants to play, if it is at all possible, a decisive part in favour of the Allies.
('83', 144, 3, 5, 288359) India today is becoming progressively hostile to the Allied Powers notwithstanding their ability to command recruits and the like.
('83', 144, 3, 6, 288490) What is wanted is an enthusiastic response from a free and willing India.
('83', 144, 3, 7, 288564) Many of us think that that is the indispensable condition of the success of Allied arms.
('83', 144, 4, 8, 288653) Q. 2. What should be the nature of the provisional government and who should be the possible members?
('83', 144, 4, 9, 288755) A. It is difficult to foresee what will happen when India is declared free but I imagine that any provisional government to be stable in the absence of outside imposition can only be by the willing consent of different popular parties.
('83', 144, 4, 10, 288991) This willing consent is impossible so long as the third party is present to look up to for favours.
('83', 144, 4, 11, 289091) The Congress President has already suggested that the Government may simultaneously with the declaration of independence deliver their power to any of the organized popular parties including the Muslim League and the Congress.
('83', 144, 4, 12, 289318) It will be up to the deliveree to compose with the remaining parties in order to secure stability, because in free India Government must depend wholly upon the willing consent of the people.
('83', 144, 4, 13, 289509) It should be remembered that all the time that free India Government is functioning, the Allied troops will carry on their operations without let or hindrance, subject to the treaty that will be negotiated between free India Government and the Allied Powers.
('83', 144, 5, 14, 289768) Q. 3. How do you hope to avert anarchy during the transitional period?
('83', 144, 5, 15, 289839) A. The anarchy is automatically averted if a provisional Government is formed, which will be the case under the Congress president’s suggestion.
('83', 144, 6, 16, 289984) Q. 4. Will you accept a joint guarantee by the Socialist and Liberal parties of England for Indian independence?
('83', 144, 7, 17, 290097) A. Reply to this is contained in reply to the first.
('83', 144, 8, 18, 290150) SEVAGRAM, July 28, 1942
('83', 144, 9, 19, 290174) Harijan, 2 8 1942
('83', 144, 10, 20, 290192) 1 The questions were from the United Press, London.

('83', 146, 4, 7, 291997) 158. LETTER TO ABDUL HAQ
('83', 146, 5, 8, 292022) DELHI, July 28, 1942
('83', 146, 6, 9, 292043) BHAI SAHEB, I am sending herewith a copy of the constitution of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha.
('83', 146, 6, 10, 292137) You will find some mistakes of Urdu.
('83', 146, 6, 11, 292174) I do not have anyone who is proficient in Urdu.
('83', 146, 6, 12, 292222) I am looking for such a person.
('83', 146, 6, 13, 292254) Can you help?
('83', 146, 6, 14, 292268) The person must know Hindi as well.
('83', 146, 6, 15, 292304) I have left it to you whether or not you will join the Sabha.
('83', 146, 6, 16, 292366) I remain hopeful that you will come when you find the right occasion.
('83', 146, 6, 17, 292436) You will see from the constitution that all the posts on the executive committee have not been filled in the hope that an opportunity will certainly come for you to be included.
('83', 146, 6, 18, 292614) And now I come to the main purpose of this letter.
('83', 146, 6, 19, 292665) In Hindustani Prachar our first step should be to hold an examination for beginners.
('83', 146, 6, 20, 292750) We have decided to hold one such examination on November 22. Does your Anjuman hold any examination which even those who know no Urdu can take?
('83', 146, 6, 21, 292894) If so we shall prepare candidates for such an examination provided you open examination centres wherever candidates are available.
('83', 146, 6, 22, 293025) If you like we are willing to be your agents.
('83', 146, 6, 23, 293071) If you are not equipped to do this, can you send us some instructions?
('83', 146, 6, 24, 293142) Can you suggest some books?
('83', 146, 6, 25, 293170) Will you agree to be the examiner or will you send some names from your office?
('83', 146, 6, 26, 293250) We shall all be obliged to you for any help you can give.
('83', 146, 7, 27, 293308) From the Hindi original: Pyarelal Papers Courtesy: Pyarelal

('83', 154, 5, 12, 303977) 176. QUESTION BOX
('83', 154, 6, 13, 303995) SEVAGRAM, [On or before August 2, 1942] 1
('83', 154, 7, 14, 304037) WORLD FEDERATION
('83', 154, 8, 15, 304054) Q. Instead of striving for India’s freedom why would you not strive for a far greater and nobler end—world federation?
('83', 154, 8, 16, 304173) Surely that will automatically include India’s freedom as the greater includes the less.
('83', 154, 9, 17, 304262) A. There is an obvious fallacy in this question.
('83', 154, 9, 18, 304311) Federation is undoubtedly a greater and nobler end for free nations.
('83', 154, 9, 19, 304380) It is a greater and nobler end for them to strive to promote federation than be self centred, seeking only to preserve their own freedom.
('83', 154, 9, 20, 304518) They are finding it difficult if not impossible for individuals to retain freedom without a combination.
('83', 154, 9, 21, 304623) It has become a necessity while the war lasts and it
('83', 154, 10, 22, 304676) 1 This and the following item were written in Sevagram where Gandhiji remained up to this date.
('83', 155, 0, 1, 304772) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 155, 1, 2, 304814) would be good if they voluntarily pledge themselves now, to remain united even after the war.
('83', 155, 1, 3, 304908) Defeat of any one member should make no difference.
('83', 155, 1, 4, 304960) The survivors will not rest content till the defeated member is avenged.
('83', 155, 1, 5, 305033) Still this won’t be a world federation.
('83', 155, 1, 6, 305073) It would be a mere defensive alliance between a certain combination.
('83', 155, 1, 7, 305142) The very first step to a world federation is to recognize the freedom of conquered and exploited nations.
('83', 155, 1, 8, 305248) Thus, India and Africa have to be freed.
('83', 155, 1, 9, 305289) The second step would be to announce to and assure the aggressor powers, in the present instance, the Axis powers, that immediately the war ends, they will be recognized as members of the world federation in the same sense as the Allies.
('83', 155, 1, 10, 305527) This presupposes an agreement among the members of the world federation as to the irreducible fundamentals.
('83', 155, 1, 11, 305635) If this is not forthcoming, the federation will fall to pieces under the slightest strain.
('83', 155, 1, 12, 305726) Therefore it has to come about voluntarily.
('83', 155, 1, 13, 305770) I suggest that non violence is the basis of voluntariness.
('83', 155, 1, 14, 305829) It is because of all the nations of the world India is the one nation which has a message, however limited and crude it may be, in that direction that it must have immediate freedom to enable it to play its part.
('83', 155, 1, 15, 306042) You may not quote against me Maulana Abul Kalam Azad and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.
('83', 155, 1, 16, 306124) I know that they do not hold the view I hold on non violence.
('83', 155, 1, 17, 306186) When India gets her freedom the probability is that I shall no longer be wanted by any party and everybody would be war mad.
('83', 155, 1, 18, 306311) Nevertheless there will be, I am quite sure, a respectable number of votaries of nonviolence who will make their contribution.
('83', 155, 1, 19, 306438) But this subject is not germane to the question.
('83', 155, 1, 20, 306487) Moreover, I am discussing that aspect more fully elsewhere.
('83', 155, 1, 21, 306547) I hope you will agree with me that India, in seeking first to be free, is not retarding federation.
('83', 155, 1, 22, 306647) It wants her freedom for the sake of the nations in distress, especially China and Russia and for the whole of humanity—in your language world federation.
('83', 155, 1, 23, 306802) You will also, I hope, see that no universal federation is possible without India becoming free now.
('83', 155, 1, 24, 306903) It would be an earnest too of the Allied declarations.

('83', 158, 3, 6, 311476) 180. AN APPROPRIATE QUESTION
('83', 158, 4, 7, 311505) [August 2, 1942] 1
('83', 158, 5, 8, 311524) I take the following from The Hindu:
('83', 158, 6, 9, 311561) The Manchester Guardian, in an editorial commenting on the Wardha resolution, says that the resolution suggested that if Britain would immediately withdraw, India would help her and the Allies to ‘resist aggression’.
('83', 158, 6, 10, 311778) In India, as here, it is being asked what is meant by ‘resistance’.
('83', 158, 6, 11, 311846) Would it be armed resistance or would it be ‘resistance’ of the kind which Mr. Gandhi has always advocated—non violent non co operation?
('83', 158, 6, 12, 311983) The text of the resolution ought to settle the question, but it does not.
('83', 158, 6, 13, 312057) Pandit Nehru and some other Congress leaders have said that they themselves believe in offering armed resistance, provided that Britain makes the necessary political concessions.
('83', 158, 6, 14, 312236) But Mr. Gandhi’s belief is that Indians would most effectively ‘resist’ Japan and any other aggressor by pure non violence.
('83', 158, 6, 15, 312360) How is Britain to know what sort of ‘resistance’ the proposed Indian Government would organize, concludes the Manchester Guardian.
('83', 158, 6, 16, 312491) This is a good question.
('83', 158, 6, 17, 312516) But who can speak for the proposed Indian Government?
('83', 158, 6, 18, 312570) It must be clear that it won’t be Congress Government; nor will it be Hindu Mahasabha Government, nor Muslim League Government.
('83', 158, 6, 19, 312698) It will be all India Government.
('83', 158, 6, 20, 312731) It will be a government not backed by any military power unless the so called military classes seize the opportunity and overawe the populace and declare themselves the Government as Franco has done.
('83', 158, 6, 21, 312931) If they play the game then the proposed government would be a government though provisional in the first instance, broad based upon the will of the people.
('83', 158, 6, 22, 313087) Let us assume that the military minded persons being without the backing of the powerful British arms will think [it] wise not to seize power.
('83', 158, 6, 23, 313230) The popular Government to be must represent Parsis, Jews, Indian Christians, Muslims and Hindus not as separate
('83', 158, 7, 24, 313342) 1 From the Gujarati version published in the Harijanbandhu, 9 8 1942
('83', 159, 0, 1, 313411) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 159, 1, 2, 313453) religious groups but as Indians.
('83', 159, 1, 3, 313486) The vast majority won’t be believers in non violence.
('83', 159, 1, 4, 313540) The Congress does not believe in non violence as a creed.
('83', 159, 1, 5, 313598) Very few go to the extreme length I do as the Manchester Guardian properly puts it.
('83', 159, 1, 6, 313682) The Maulana and Pandit Nehru believe in offering armed resistance.
('83', 159, 1, 7, 313749) And, I may add, so do many Congressmen.
('83', 159, 1, 8, 313789) Therefore, whether in the country as a whole or in the Congress, I shall be in a hopeless minority.

('83', 160, 1, 2, 315264) 182. DEMANDS OF MARWAR LOK PARISHAD
('83', 160, 2, 3, 315300) The following are the demands of the Marwar Lok Parishad in Jodhpur as supplied to me:
('83', 160, 3, 4, 315387) 1. The Government of Jodhpur shall reaffirm the terms of the compromise of 1940 arrived at between the Government and the Marwar Lok Parishad as a result of the last satyagraha movement in Marwar.
('83', 160, 4, 5, 315584) 2. The Government shall see that rule of law is established in the State and more especially in the jagiri areas and that full civil liberties (in terms of the agreement of 1940) are enjoyed by the Lok Parishad workers without any fear of intimidation or victimization (i.e., physical violence or damage to property, etc.) at the hands of jagirdars or their subordinates.
('83', 160, 5, 6, 315956) 3. The New Reforms (Advisory Assembly) recently introduced shall immediately be scrapped and the Constitutional Reforms originally passed in the Council and assented to by His Highness the Maharaja shall instead be introduced as an earnest of further constitutional development on the path to full responsible government under the aegis of His Highness the Maharaja Saheb Bahadur.
('83', 160, 6, 7, 316337) 4. The Municipal Act (passed in 1940 but not yet enforced) shall be revised consistently with the growing needs and aspirations of the people and real local self government shall be established with the people’s representatives enjoying real powers.
('83', 160, 7, 8, 316587) 5. Government shall make effective and satisfactory arrangements for regular Latai.
('83', 160, 8, 9, 316671) NOTE: In this connection mention must be made of the circular of the Government to the district officers ordering them to arrange for regular Latai at places where it was delayed.
('83', 160, 8, 10, 316851) The circular was unfortunately withdrawn by the Government in 1941 thereby leaving the district authorities powerless and the cultivators at the mercy of the jagirdars.
('83', 160, 9, 11, 317020) 6. The exaction of illegal and unlawful cesses and other exactions shall immediately be stopped and proper arrangements shall forthwith be made to see that the practice is not resumed.
('83', 160, 9, 12, 317205) In addition, the Government shall appoint a commission of inquiry to go into the jagiri problem as a whole to make necessary recommendations regarding the levy of various cesses, taxes and other exactions held lawful at present.
('83', 160, 10, 13, 317434) 7. The Government shall immediately enforce the Registration of Arms Act in the case of jagirdars also.
('83', 160, 10, 14, 317538) The present policy of making invidious discrimination between the jagirdar class, in whose case the date of registration is being postponed from month to month, and the rest of the
('83', 161, 0, 1, 317719) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 161, 1, 2, 317761) people, who have been compelled to register their arms and secure licences for possessing them, is fraught with grave consequences for the internal peace and security of Marwar, especially In these days of grave crisis.
('83', 161, 2, 3, 317981) 8. An inquiry shall also be held into the following happenings:
('83', 161, 3, 4, 318045) (a) The excesses committed by the jagirdars and their men on the Lok Parishad workers in the jagirs of Chandawal, Ladnun, Roru, etc
('83', 161, 4, 5, 318177) (b) Ill treatment meted out by the jail authorities to the political prisoners.
('83', 161, 5, 6, 318257) (c) The lathi charge and other excesses of the 19th June and the subsequent days.
('83', 161, 5, 7, 318339) There is nothing in the demands that one can cavil at.
('83', 161, 5, 8, 318394) There is nothing extravagant in them.
('83', 161, 5, 9, 318432) They take note of the limitations of Rajputana States whatever the cause thereof.
('83', 161, 5, 10, 318514) It is for the compliance with these demands that Shri Jainarain Vyas and his companions are in jail and Bisa lost his life.
('83', 161, 5, 11, 318638) 1 It is for that reason that many Jodhpuris including women—a strange sight in Jodhpur—have resolved to offer civil disobedience.
('83', 161, 5, 12, 318768) Let me hope that the Jodhpur Durbar will satisfy the moderate demands of the Parishad and let me further hope that the people of Jodhpur having resolved upon achieving their purpose through suffering will not rest till they have reached their immediate goal.
('83', 161, 5, 13, 319027) ON WAY TO BOMBAY, AUGUST 2, 1942
('83', 161, 6, 14, 319060) Harijan, 9 8 1942
('83', 161, 7, 15, 319078) 183. TO AMERICAN FRIENDS
('83', 161, 8, 16, 319103) ON WAY TO BOMBAY, August 3, 1942
('83', 161, 9, 17, 319136) DEAR FRIENDS, As I am supposed to be the spirit behind the much discussed and equally well abused resolution of the Working Committee of the Indian National Congress on independence, it has become necessary for me to explain my position.
('83', 161, 9, 18, 319374) For I am not unknown to you.
('83', 161, 9, 19, 319403) I have in America perhaps the largest number of friends in the West—not even excepting Great Britain, British friends knowing me personally
('83', 161, 10, 20, 319543) 1 Vide “Jodhpur”, 30 5 1942, “Jodhpur Tragedy”, 14 6 1942, “Jodhpur”, 29 6 1942 and “Pandit Kachru Externed”, 20 7 1942.
('83', 162, 0, 1, 319664) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 163
('83', 162, 1, 2, 319708) are more discerning than the American.
('83', 162, 1, 3, 319747) In America I suffer from the well known malady called hero worship.
('83', 162, 1, 4, 319815) The good Dr. Holmes, until recently of the Unity Church of New York, without knowing me personally became my advertising agent.
('83', 162, 1, 5, 319943) Some of the nice things he said about me I never knew myself.
('83', 162, 1, 6, 320005) So I receive often embarrassing letters from America expecting me to perform miracles.
('83', 162, 1, 7, 320092) Dr. Holmes was followed much later by the late Bishop Fisher who knew me personally in India.
('83', 162, 1, 8, 320186) He very nearly dragged me to America but fate had ordained otherwise and I could not visit your vast and great country with its wonderful people.
('83', 162, 1, 9, 320332) Moreover, you have given me a teacher in Thoreau, who furnished me through his essay on the ‘Duty of Civil Disobedience’ scientific confirmation of what I was doing in South Africa.
('83', 162, 1, 10, 320514) Great Britain gave me Ruskin, whose Unto This Last transformed me overnight from a lawyer and city dweller into a rustic living away from Durban on a farm, three miles from the nearest railway station and Russia gave me in Tolstoi a teacher who furnished a reasoned basis for my non violence.
('83', 162, 1, 11, 320807) He blessed my movement in South Africa when it was still in its infancy and of whose wonderful possibilities I had yet to learn.
('83', 162, 1, 12, 320936) It was he who had prophesied in his letter to me that I was leading a movement which was destined to bring a message of hope to the downtrodden people of the earth.
('83', 162, 1, 13, 321101) So you will see that I have not approached the present task in any spirit of enmity to Great Britain and the West.
('83', 162, 1, 14, 321216) After having imbibed and assimilated the message of Unto This Last, I could not be guilty of approving of Fascism or Nazism, whose cult is suppression of the individual and his liberty.
('83', 162, 1, 15, 321402) I invite you to read my formula of withdrawal or, as it has been popularly called, ‘Quit India’, with this background.
('83', 162, 1, 16, 321521) You may not read into it more than the context warrants.
('83', 162, 1, 17, 321578) I claim to be a votary of truth from my childhood.
('83', 162, 1, 18, 321629) It was the most natural thing to me.
('83', 162, 1, 19, 321666) My prayerful search gave me the revealing maxim ‘Truth is God’ instead of the usual one ‘God is Truth’.
('83', 162, 1, 20, 321770) That maxim enables me to see God face to face as it were.
('83', 162, 1, 21, 321828) I feel Him pervade every fibre of my being.
('83', 162, 1, 22, 321872) With this Truth as witness between you and me, I assert that I would not have asked my country to invite Great Britain to withdraw her rule over India, irrespective of any demand to the contrary, if I had not seen at once that for the sake of Great Britain and the Allied cause it was necessary for Britain boldly
('83', 163, 0, 1, 322186) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 163, 1, 2, 322228) to perform the duty of freeing India from bondage.
('83', 163, 1, 3, 322279) Without this essential act of tardy justice, Britain could not justify her position before the unmurmuring world conscience, which is there nevertheless.
('83', 163, 1, 4, 322433) Singapore, Malaya and Burma taught me that the disaster must not be repeated in India.
('83', 163, 1, 5, 322520) I make bold to say that it cannot be averted unless Britain trusts the people of India to use their liberty in favour of the Allied cause.
('83', 163, 1, 6, 322659) By that supreme act of justice Britain would have taken away all cause for the seething discontent of India.
('83', 163, 1, 7, 322768) She will turn the growing ill will into active goodwill.
('83', 163, 1, 8, 322825) I submit that it is worth all the battleships and airships that your wonderworking engineers and financial resources can produce.
('83', 163, 1, 9, 322955) I know that interested propaganda has filled your ears and eyes with distorted versions of the Congress position.
('83', 163, 1, 10, 323069) I have been painted as a hypocrite and enemy of Britain under disguise.
('83', 163, 1, 11, 323141) My demonstrable spirit of accommodation has been described as my inconsistency, proving me to be an utterly unreliable man.
('83', 163, 1, 12, 323265) I am not going to burden this letter with proof in support of my assertions.
('83', 163, 1, 13, 323342) If the credit I have enjoyed in America will not stand me in good stead, nothing I may argue in self defence will carry conviction against the formidable but false propaganda that has poisoned American ears.
('83', 163, 1, 14, 323550) You have made common cause with Great Britain.
('83', 163, 1, 15, 323597) You cannot therefore disown responsibility for anything that her representatives do in India.
('83', 163, 1, 16, 323691) You will do a grievous wrong to the Allied cause if you do not sift the truth from the chaff whilst there is yet time.
('83', 163, 1, 17, 323810) Just think of it.
('83', 163, 1, 18, 323828) Is there anything wrong in the Congress demanding unconditional recognition of India’s independence?
('83', 163, 1, 19, 323929) It is being said, ‘But this is not the time.’ We say, ‘This is the psychological moment for that recognition.’ For then and then only can there be irresistible opposition to Japanese aggression.
('83', 163, 1, 20, 324124) It is of immense value to the Allied cause if it is also of equal value to India.
('83', 163, 1, 21, 324206) The Congress has anticipated and provided for every possible difficulty in the way of recognition.
('83', 163, 1, 22, 324305) I want you to look upon the immediate recognition of India’s independence as a war measure of first class magnitude.

('83', 164, 1, 2, 324518) 184. QUESTION BOX
('83', 164, 2, 3, 324536) WHAT EDITORS CAN DO
('83', 164, 3, 4, 324556) Q. What do you expect the editors to do in the crisis that has overtaken us?
('83', 164, 3, 5, 324633) A. I am proud of the way the Indian Press as a whole has reacted to the Congress resolution.
('83', 164, 3, 6, 324726) The acid test has yet to come.
('83', 164, 3, 7, 324757) I hope that the Press will then fearlessly represent the national cause.
('83', 164, 3, 8, 324830) It is better not to issue newspapers than to issue them under a feeling of suppression.
('83', 164, 3, 9, 324918) At the same time I do not want them to be blind followers of the Congress and to endorse what their reason or conscience rebels against.
('83', 164, 3, 10, 325055) The national cause will never suffer by honest criticism of national institutions and national policies.
('83', 164, 3, 11, 325160) The danger to be guarded against is the inflaming of communal passions.
('83', 164, 3, 12, 325232) The forthcoming movement will mean nothing if it does not end in bringing communal harmony and honourable peace with the British people.
('83', 164, 3, 13, 325369) Whatever may be said to the contrary I maintain that the Congress policy has been framed in no hostile spirit against the British people.
('83', 164, 3, 14, 325507) For the spirit behind the policy is wholly non violent.
('83', 164, 3, 15, 325563) I do hope, therefore, that the Press will warn those who have the nation’s cause at heart against countenancing violence either against the British people or among ourselves.
('83', 164, 3, 16, 325738) It must retard our progress towards our goal.

('83', 168, 1, 2, 332541) 188. DRAFT INSTRUCTIONS FOR CIVIL RESISTERS 1
('83', 168, 2, 3, 332587) Confidential BOMBAY, For Working Committee Members Only August 4, 1942 2
('83', 168, 3, 4, 332660) On the day of the hartal no processions should be taken out nor meetings held in the cities.
('83', 168, 3, 5, 332753) All the people should observe a twenty four hours’ fast and offer prayers.
('83', 168, 3, 6, 332828) If the owners of shops approve of our satyagraha struggle, they will all close their shops, but no one should be made to close his shop under coercion.
('83', 168, 3, 7, 332980) In the villages, however, where there is no fear of violence or disturbance, meetings may be held and processions taken out and responsible Congressmen who believe in mass civil disobedience should explain the meaning of the contemplated satyagraha struggle to the people.
('83', 168, 3, 8, 333253) The object of our satyagraha is to secure the withdrawal of British rule and the attainment of independence for the whole of India.
('83', 168, 3, 9, 333385) After the withdrawal of British rule, the constitution of the future government of the country will be settled by the joint deliberation of the whole nation, including all parties.
('83', 168, 3, 10, 333566) That government will belong not to the Congress nor to any particular group or party, but to the entire 35 crores of the people of India.
('83', 168, 3, 11, 333704) All Congressmen should make it clear

('83', 169, 1, 15, 337011) Those employed in Government offices, Government factories, railways, post offices, etc., may not participate in the hartal, because our object is to make it clear that we will never tolerate Japanese, Nazi or Fascist invasion, nor British rule.

('83', 170, 1, 2, 338110) If any government servant is called upon to perpetrate excesses or injustice it will be his clear duty to resign at once, giving the real reasons.
('83', 170, 1, 3, 338257) Free Indian Government will be under no obligation to continue in its service all those Government functionaries who are at present serving the Empire on huge salaries; nor will it be under an obligation to continue the large pensions which are being drawn at present.
('83', 170, 1, 4, 338526) All students reading in institutions conducted or controlled by the Government should come out of these institutions.
('83', 170, 1, 5, 338644) Those who are above sixteen years of age should join the Satyagraha.
('83', 170, 1, 6, 338713) Those who so leave these institutions should do so with a clear understanding that they are not to return to them until independence is achieved.
('83', 170, 1, 7, 338859) There should be no coercion whatsoever in this matter.
('83', 170, 1, 8, 338914) Only those who of their own free will wish to do so, should come out.
('83', 170, 1, 9, 338984) No good can come out of coercion.
('83', 170, 1, 10, 339018) If excesses are committed in any place by the Government, people should offer resistance and endure the penalty.
('83', 170, 1, 11, 339131) For instance, if villagers, labourers or householders are ordered to vacate their farms or homes they should flatly refuse to obey such orders.
('83', 170, 1, 12, 339275) If an adequate compensation is offered or if they are suitably provided for by grant of land, etc., elsewhere, they may vacate their farms or homes.
('83', 170, 1, 13, 339424) Here there is no question of civil disobedience, but of simply refusing to submit to coercion or injustice.
('83', 170, 1, 14, 339532) We do not want to hinder military activities, but neither shall we submit to arbitrary high handedness.
('83', 170, 1, 15, 339636) The salt tax causes great hardship to the poor.
('83', 170, 1, 16, 339684) Therefore, wherever salt can be made, poor people may certainly manufacture it for themselves and risk the penalty.
('83', 170, 1, 17, 339800) Land tax is due only to a government which we recognize as our own.
('83', 170, 1, 18, 339868) It is long since we have mentally ceased to recognize the existing Government as such, but until now we have not gone to the length of refusing the payment of land tax because we felt that the country was not prepared to go so far.
('83', 170, 1, 19, 340100) But the time has now come when those who have the courage and are prepared to risk their all, should refuse to pay it.
('83', 170, 1, 20, 340219) The Congress holds that the land belongs to those who work on it and to no one else.
('83', 170, 1, 21, 340304) If they part with a share of the produce to anyone, it is for the furtherance of their own interests.
('83', 170, 1, 22, 340406) There are various systems of collecting land revenue.
('83', 170, 1, 23, 340460) Where the zamindari system prevails the zamindars pay the tax to the Government and the
('83', 171, 0, 1, 340548) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 171, 1, 2, 340590) ryot to the zamindar.
('83', 171, 1, 3, 340612) In such cases, if the zamindar makes common cause with the ryot, his portion of the revenue, which may be settled by mutual agreement, should be given to him.
('83', 171, 1, 4, 340771) But if a zamindar wants to side with the Government, no tax should be paid to him, This will, in the immediate present, spell ruin to the ryot.
('83', 171, 1, 5, 340915) Therefore, only those who are prepared to face utter ruin should refuse payment of land revenue.
('83', 171, 1, 6, 341012) Besides these, there are several other items which could be taken up.
('83', 171, 1, 7, 341082) Directions in regard to these will be issued when the occasion arises.

('83', 173, 8, 15, 344796) 3 I think that the procedure thus adopted of searching the A.I.C.C. Office and seizing documents was in itself reprehensible.
('83', 173, 8, 16, 344922) The Congress is not an illegal organization.

('83', 173, 9, 18, 345041) 1 The addressee in his letter to Gandhiji, of August 1, had said: “I fear that if civil disobedience is started at this juncture it may lead to very serious consequences, some of which we do not realize”.

('83', 174, 1, 3, 346638) Such an organization deserves, to say the least, a better treatment than the Government had accorded it by its procedure with the A.I.C.C. Their action becomes more reprehensible when they make what I consider illegitimate use of the documents seized.

('83', 175, 1, 2, 348630) deliberate, from my draft as to the foreign policy of the Congress and, therefore, any reference to China and Russia.

('83', 175, 1, 6, 349086) Not only that.
('83', 175, 1, 7, 349101) I have often expressed the opinion that they cannot win the war, if only Great Britain will once for all shed her imperialism.
('83', 175, 1, 8, 349228) I have given expression to that opinion more than once in the columns of Harijan and I repeat here that in spite of all my wish to the contrary and of others, if disaster overtakes Great Britain and the Allied Powers, it will be because even at the critical moment— most critical in her history—she had most obstinately refused to wash herself of the taint of imperialism which she has carried with her for at least a century and a half.
('83', 175, 1, 9, 349666) The suppressed races of the earth will never see the fine distinction that Panditji and following him I can see and make between Fascism and imperialism.
('83', 175, 1, 10, 349820) The difference, if any, discerned by the man in the street will be not of kind but only of degree, and therefore I have pleaded and shall plead even as I am fighting with all the earnestness I command that Britain will shed that taint, and that her great ally America will make her do so, and then be sure of victory, no matter how prolonged the struggle and what cost it requires.
('83', 175, 1, 11, 350202) To say the least, then the Allied Powers will earn the blessings of the dumb but countless millions, apart from the gain in men and material that the free association of these peoples will bring to the Allies.
('83', 175, 1, 12, 350412) I would count their blessings to be of far higher value than every other consideration.
('83', 175, 1, 13, 350500) I have, therefore, nothing to withdraw and nothing to be ashamed of about the draft I had the privilege of sending to the Working Committee.

('83', 176, 1, 2, 351108) confidence—for which many of my friends say I have no warrant—in the efficacy of the weapon of non violent non co operation with all its implications that I have presented to the nation, I maintain that I could not be guilty of harbouring any such thought you have attributed to me.
('83', 176, 1, 3, 351391) Panditji has explained quite clearly what could be his own meaning and interpretation of my draft.
('83', 176, 1, 4, 351490) I add by way of emphasis that I had purposely incorporated the sentence about negotiations with Japan, and if ultimately it was dropped and I associated myself with the deletion, I did so out of my regard for my co workers not because I was uncertain as to what I meant to do.
('83', 176, 1, 5, 351767) It is the essence of the use of the weapon that you will always give your opponent the opportunity of doing the right thing, and if India became an independent nation tomorrow and I was witness to the grand phenomenon, I would certainly advise and plead with the Provisional Government to send me—old as I am—to Japan and I would plead with her in the first instance, to free China, her great neighbour, from the menace that Japan has become and to tell her that if she does not do this elementary justice, she will have to count upon the stubborn resistance of millions who had at long last found themselves in possession of a thing which every nation prizes before everything else.

('83', 178, 8, 18, 356340) 196. INTERVIEW TO THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
('83', 178, 9, 19, 356379) BOMBAY, August 6, 1942
('83', 178, 10, 20, 356402) Q. Does the resolution 1 mean peace or war?
('83', 178, 10, 21, 356446) There is an interpretation particularly among the foreign journalists, that it means declaration of war and that the last three paragraphs of the resolution are the really operative part.
('83', 178, 10, 22, 356634) Is the emphasis on the first part or the last part of the resolution?
('83', 178, 10, 23, 356704) A. The emphasis in any non violent struggle, projected or in operation, is always on peace.
('83', 178, 10, 24, 356796) War, when it becomes an absolute necessity.
('83', 178, 11, 25, 356840) Q. Do you contemplate the immediate establishment of a provisional government and, if so, how do you expect it to come into being?
('83', 178, 11, 26, 356971) ‘Do you think that
('83', 178, 12, 27, 356990) 1 Vide Appendix “Resolution Passed by All India Congress Committee”, 8 8 1942.
('83', 179, 0, 1, 357069) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 179, 1, 2, 357111) there would be a period of interregnum between the endorsement of the resolution by the A. 1. C. C. and the starting of the mass struggle?
('83', 179, 1, 3, 357250) A. If independence is ushered in with perfect British goodwill, then I expect an almost simultaneous establishment of a provisional government which, being just now based, as it must be of necessity, on non violence, will, to command universal confidence, represent the free and voluntary association of all parties.
('83', 179, 2, 4, 357567) Q. Do you contemplate any negotiation between the Congress and the British Government before launching a mass struggle?
('83', 179, 2, 5, 357687) A. I have definitely contemplated an interval between the passing of the Congress resolution and the starting of the struggle.
('83', 179, 2, 6, 357814) I do not know that what I contemplate doing according to my wont can be in any way described as being in the nature of negotiation, but a letter will certainly go to the Viceroy, not as an ultimatum but as an earnest pleading for avoidance of a conflict.
('83', 179, 2, 7, 358069) If there is a favourable response, then my letter can be the basis for negotiation.
('83', 179, 3, 8, 358153) Q. What is the maximum time you are prepared to wait to see if there is any response from the British Government and the United Nations to the ‘last minute appeal’ of the A. I. C. C. A. The object with which the demand for immediate withdrawal is made does not allow of a long interval for the simple reason that the war will not be suspended while, in expectation of something turning up, the interval is contemplated.
('83', 179, 3, 9, 358573) The Working Committee itself, which is sincerely eager to mobilize the whole of free Indian opinion in favour of the war effort, is impatient to do so, and in view of the terrible suspense created throughout India it is altogether wrong both for the Congress and British Power to prolong the suspense for a day longer than is warranted by force of circumstance beyond control.

('83', 188, 3, 4, 377050) I congratulate you on the resolution that you have just passed.
('83', 188, 3, 5, 377114) I also congratulate the three comrades on the courage they have shown in pressing their amendments to a division, even though they knew that there was an overwhelming majority in favour of the resolution, and I congratulate the thirteen friends who voted against the resolution.
('83', 188, 3, 6, 377393) In doing so, they had nothing to be ashamed of.

('83', 208, 1, 7, 426398) I realize that all could not be carried in motor cars.
('83', 208, 1, 8, 426453) I have been before now carried in prison vans.
('83', 208, 1, 9, 426500) And this time too we should have been carried with our comrades.
('83', 208, 1, 10, 426565) In relating this incident my object is to inform the Government that in the altered conditions and the altered state of my mind, I can no longer accept special privileges which hitherto I have accepted though reluctantly.
('83', 208, 1, 11, 426787) I propose this time to accept no privileges and comforts which comrades may not receive, except for the special food so long as the Government allow it for my bodily need.
('83', 208, 1, 12, 426959) There is another matter to which I must draw your attention.
('83', 208, 1, 13, 427020) I have told my people that this time our method is not courting imprisonment, that we must prepare for much higher sacrifice and so those who choose may peacefully resist arrest.
('83', 208, 1, 14, 427199) So a young man 1 who was in the party offered such resistance.
('83', 208, 1, 15, 427262) He was therefore hauled to the prison van.
('83', 208, 1, 16, 427305) This was ugly enough.
('83', 208, 1, 17, 427327) But it was a painful sight when an impatient English sergeant rough handled him and shoved him into the lorry as if he was a log of wood.
('83', 208, 1, 18, 427465) In my opinion the sergeant deserves correction.
('83', 208, 1, 19, 427513) The struggle has become bitter enough without such scenes.
('83', 208, 1, 20, 427572) This temporary jail is commodious enough to take in all who were arrested with me.
('83', 208, 1, 21, 427655) Among them are Sardar Patel and his daughter.
('83', 208, 1, 22, 427701) She is his nurse and cook.
('83', 208, 1, 23, 427728) I have great anxiety about the Sardar who never got over the intestinal collapse which he had during his last incarceration.
('83', 208, 1, 24, 427853) Ever since his release I have been personally regulating his diet, etc.
('83', 208, 1, 25, 427925) I request that both he and his daughter be placed with me.
('83', 208, 1, 26, 427984) And so should the other prisoners though not on the same imperative grounds as are applicable in the case of the Sardar and his daughter.
('83', 208, 1, 27, 428122) I submit that it is not right to separate co workers arrested for the same cause unless they are dangerous criminals.
('83', 208, 1, 28, 428240) I have been told by the Superintendent that I am not to be supplied with newspapers.
('83', 208, 1, 29, 428325) Now I was given by one of my fellow

('83', 209, 10, 16, 429191) 212. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW
('83', 209, 11, 17, 429222) THE AGA KHAN’S PALACE, August 14, 1942
('83', 209, 12, 18, 429261) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW, The Government of India were wrong in precipitating the crisis.
('83', 209, 12, 19, 429347) The Government resolution justifying this step is full of distortions and misrepresentations.
('83', 209, 12, 20, 429441) That you have the approval of your Indian “colleagues” can have no significance, except this, that in India you
('83', 209, 13, 21, 429553) 1Vide Appendix “Resolution of the Government of India”, 7 8 1942.
('83', 210, 0, 1, 429619) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 211
('83', 210, 1, 2, 429663) can always command such services.
('83', 210, 1, 3, 429697) That co operation is an additional justification for the demand of withdrawal irrespective of what people and parties may say.
('83', 210, 1, 4, 429824) The Government of India should have waited at least till the time I inaugurated mass action.
('83', 210, 1, 5, 429917) I had publicly stated that I fully conte mplated sending you a letter before taking concrete action.
('83', 210, 1, 6, 430018) It was to be an appeal to you for an impartial examination of the Congress case.
('83', 210, 1, 7, 430099) As you know, the Congress has readily filled in every omission that has been discovered in the conception of its demand.
('83', 210, 1, 8, 430220) So could I have dealt with every difficulty if you had given me the opportunity.
('83', 210, 1, 9, 430301) The precipitate action of the Government leads one to think that they were afraid that the extreme caution and gradualness with which the Congress was moving towards direct action might make world opinion veer round to the Congress, as it had already begun doing, and expose the hollowness of the grounds for the Government’s rejection of the Congress demand.
('83', 210, 1, 10, 430661) They should surely have waited for an authentic report of my speeches on Friday and on Saturday night after the passing of the resolution by the All India Congress Committee.
('83', 210, 1, 11, 430836) You would have found in them that I would not hastily begin action.
('83', 210, 1, 12, 430904) You should have taken advantage of the interval foreshadowed in them, and explored every possibility of satisfying the Congress demand.
('83', 210, 1, 13, 431040) The resolution says:
('83', 210, 2, 14, 431061) The Government of India have waited patiently in the hope that wiser counsels might prevail.
('83', 210, 2, 15, 431154) They have been disappointed in that hope.
('83', 210, 2, 16, 431196) I suppose wiser counsels here means abandonment of its demand by the Congress.
('83', 210, 2, 17, 431275) Why should the abandonment of the demand legitimate at all times be hoped for by a Government pledged to guarantee independence to India?
('83', 210, 2, 18, 431413) Is it a challenge that could only be met by immediate repression instead of patient reasoning with the demanding party?
('83', 210, 2, 19, 431533) I venture to suggest that it is a long draft upon the credulity of mankind to say that the acceptance of the demand; “would plunge India into confusion”.
('83', 210, 2, 20, 431687) Anyway the summary rejection of the demand has plunged the nation and the Government into confusion.
('83', 210, 2, 21, 431788) The Congress was making every effort to identify India with the Allied cause.
('83', 210, 2, 22, 431866) The Government resolution says:
('83', 210, 3, 23, 431898) The Governor General in Council has been aware too for some days past of dangerous preparations by the Congress Party for unlawful and in some
('83', 211, 0, 1, 432041) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 211, 1, 2, 432083) cases violent activities, directed among other things to interruption of communications and public utility services, the organization of strikes, tamp ering with the loyalty of Government servants, and interference with defence measures including recruitment.
('83', 211, 1, 3, 432343) This is a gross distortion of the reality.
('83', 211, 1, 4, 432386) Violence was never contemplated at any stage.
('83', 211, 1, 5, 432432) A definition of what could be included in non violent action has been interpreted in a sinister and subtle manner, as if the Congress was preparing for violent action.
('83', 211, 1, 6, 432600) Every thing was openly discussed among Congress circles, for nothing was to be done secretly.
('83', 211, 1, 7, 432694) And why is it tampering with your loyalty if I ask you to give up a job which is harming the British people?
('83', 211, 1, 8, 432803) Instead of publishing behind the backs of principal Congressmen the misleading paragraph the Government, immediately they came to know of the “preparations”, should have brought to book the parties concerned with the preparations.
('83', 211, 1, 9, 433034) That would have been the appropriate course.
('83', 211, 1, 10, 433079) By their unsupported allegations in the resolution they have laid themselves open to the charge of unfair dealing.
('83', 211, 1, 11, 433194) The Congress movement was intended to evoke in the people the measure of sacrifice sufficient to compel attention.
('83', 211, 1, 12, 433309) It was intended to demonstrate what measure of popular support it had.
('83', 211, 1, 13, 433380) Was it wise at this time of the day to seek to suppress a popular movement avowedly non violent?
('83', 211, 1, 14, 433477) The Government resolution further says:
('83', 211, 2, 15, 433517) The Congress is not India’s mouthpiece.
('83', 211, 2, 16, 433557) Yet in the interests of securing their own dominance and in pursuit of their totalitarian policy its leaders have consistently impeded efforts made to bring India to full nationhood.
('83', 211, 2, 17, 433740) It is a gross libel thus to accuse the oldest national organization of India.
('83', 211, 2, 18, 433818) This language lies ill in the mouth of a Government which has, as can be proved from published records, consistently thwarted every national effort for attaining freedom and sought to suppress the Congress by hook or by crook.
('83', 211, 2, 19, 434045) The Government of India have not condescended to consider the Congress offer that if simultaneously with the declaration of the independence of India, they could not trust the Congress to form a stable provisional government, they should ask the Muslim League to do so and that any national government formed by the League would be loyally accepted by the Congress.
('83', 211, 2, 20, 434411) Such an offer is hardly consistent with the charge of totalitarianism against the Congress.
('83', 212, 0, 1, 434503) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 213
('83', 212, 1, 2, 434547) Let me examine the Government offer:
('83', 212, 2, 3, 434584) It is that as soon as hostilities cease, India shall devise for herself, with full freedom of decision and on a basis embracing all and not only a single party, the form of government which she regards as most suited to her conditions.
('83', 212, 2, 4, 434820) Has this offer any reality about it?
('83', 212, 2, 5, 434857) All parties have not agreed now.
('83', 212, 2, 6, 434890) Will it be any more possible after the war?
('83', 212, 2, 7, 434934) And if the parties have to act before independence is in their hands?
('83', 212, 2, 8, 435004) Parties grow up like mushrooms, for without proving their representative character, the Government will welcome them as they have done in the past and if they, the parties, oppose the Congress and its activities, though they may do lip homage to independence, frustration is inherent in the Government offer.
('83', 212, 2, 9, 435313) Hence the logical cry of withdrawal first.
('83', 212, 2, 10, 435356) Only after the end of the British power and a fundamental change in the political status of India from bondage to freedom, will the formation of a truly representative government, whether provisional or perm anent, be possible.
('83', 212, 2, 11, 435584) The living burial of the author of the demand has not resolved the deadlock, it has aggravated it.
('83', 212, 2, 12, 435683) Then the resolution proceeds:
('83', 212, 3, 13, 435713) The suggestion put forward by the Congress Party that the millions of India uncertain as to the future are ready, despite the sad lessons of so many martyr countries, to throw themselves into the arms of the invaders, is one that the Government of India cannot accept as a true representation of the feeling of the people of this great country.
('83', 212, 3, 14, 436058) I do not know about the millions, but I can give my own evidence in support of the Congress statement.
('83', 212, 3, 15, 436161) It is open to the Government not to believe the Congress evidence.
('83', 212, 3, 16, 436228) No imperial power likes to be told that it is in peril.
('83', 212, 3, 17, 436284) It is because the Congress is anxious for Great Britain to avoid the fate that has overtaken other imperial powers that it asks her to shed imperialism voluntarily by declaring India independent.
('83', 212, 3, 18, 436480) The Congress has not approached the movement with any but the friendliest motives.
('83', 212, 3, 19, 436563) Congress seeks to kill imperialism as much for the sake of the British people and humanity as for India.
('83', 212, 3, 20, 436668) Notwithstanding assertions to the contrary, I maintain that the Congress has no interests of its own, apart from that of the whole of India and the world.
('83', 212, 3, 21, 436823) The following passage from the peroration in the resolution is interesting:
('83', 212, 4, 22, 436899) But on them lies the task of defending India, of maintaining India’s
('83', 213, 0, 1, 436968) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 213, 1, 2, 437010) capacity to wage war, of safeguarding India’s interests, of holding the balance
('83', 213, 2, 3, 437090) between the different sections of her people without fear or favour.
('83', 213, 2, 4, 437159) All I can say is that it is a mockery of truth after the experience of Malaya, Singapore and Burma.
('83', 213, 2, 5, 437259) It is sad to find the Government of India claiming to hold the “balance” between the parties for which it is itself demonstrably responsible.
('83', 213, 2, 6, 437401) One thing more.
('83', 213, 2, 7, 437417) The declared cause is common between the Government of India and us.
('83', 213, 2, 8, 437486) To put it in the most concrete terms, it is the protection of the freedom of China and Russia.
('83', 213, 2, 9, 437581) The Government of India think that the freedom of India is not necessary for winning the cause.
('83', 213, 2, 10, 437677) I think exactly the opposite.
('83', 213, 2, 11, 437707) I have taken Jawaharlal Nehru as my measuring rod.
('83', 213, 2, 12, 437758) His personal contacts make him feel much more the misery of the impending ruin of China and Russia than I can—and may I say than even you can.
('83', 213, 2, 13, 437901) In that misery he tried to forget his old quarrel with imperialism.
('83', 213, 2, 14, 437969) He dreads much more than I do the success of Fascism and Nazism.
('83', 213, 2, 15, 438034) I have argued with him for days together.
('83', 213, 2, 16, 438076) He fought against my position with a passion which I have no words to describe.
('83', 213, 2, 17, 438156) But the logic of facts overwhelmed him.
('83', 213, 2, 18, 438196) He yielded when he saw clearly that without the freedom of India that of the other two was in great jeopardy.
('83', 213, 2, 19, 438306) Surely you are wrong in having imprisoned such a powerful friend and ally.
('83', 213, 2, 20, 438381) If notwithstanding the common cause, the Government’s answer to the Congress demand is hasty repression, they will not wonder if I draw the inference that it was not so much the Allied cause that weighed with the British Government, as the unexpressed determination to cling to the possession of India as an indispensable part of the imperial policy.
('83', 213, 2, 21, 438732) This determination led to the rejection of the Congress demand and precipitated repression.
('83', 213, 2, 22, 438824) The present mutual slaughter on a scale never before known to history is suffocating enough.
('83', 213, 2, 23, 438917) But the slaughter of truth accompanying the butchery and enforced by the falsity of which the resolution is reeking adds strength to the Congress position.
('83', 213, 2, 24, 439073) It causes me deep pain to have to send you this long letter.
('83', 213, 2, 25, 439134) But however much I dislike your action, I remain the same friend you have known me.
('83', 213, 2, 26, 439218) I would still plead for reconsideration of the Government of India’s whole policy.
('83', 213, 2, 27, 439301) Do not disregard the pleading
('83', 214, 0, 1, 439331) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 215

('83', 215, 5, 12, 441527) 215. PREFACE 2
('83', 215, 6, 13, 441542) For the benefit of the readers of Indian Opinion (South Africa), I wrote a few articles under the heading “Guide to Health” in or about the year 1906. 3 These were later published in book form.
('83', 215, 6, 14, 441736) I found that it was known to the Indian public.
('83', 215, 6, 15, 441784) But copies were not available in India.
('83', 215, 6, 16, 441824) The late Swami Akhandanand asked for my permission to publish an Indian edition.
('83', 215, 6, 17, 441905) The enterprise proved very popular.
('83', 215, 6, 18, 441941) The book was translated into several Indian languages.
('83', 215, 6, 19, 441996) An English translation also appeared.
('83', 215, 6, 20, 442034) This reached the West, and was translated into several European languages.
('83', 215, 6, 21, 442109) The result was that the book became the most popular of all my writings.
('83', 215, 6, 22, 442182) I have never been able to understand the reason for this popularity.
('83', 215, 6, 23, 442251) I had written those articles casually, and I did not attach much importance to them.
('83', 215, 6, 24, 442336) But perhaps the reason for the popularity is to be sought in the fact that I have looked upon the problem of health from a novel point of view, somewhat different from the orthodox methods adopted by doctors
('83', 215, 7, 25, 442544) 1 From the contents; Mahadev Desai died on August 15, 1942. 2 In “A Word by the Publisher”, in the source, Jivanji D. Desai explains: “The original was written in Gujarati and Gandhiji got it translated into Hindustani and English by Dr. Sushila Nayyar under his own guidance.
('83', 215, 7, 26, 442821) He also went through both the translations to give them the final touches.
('83', 215, 7, 27, 442896) The reader can therefore take the translation as Gandhiji’s own rendering.” The item here is placed according to the date on which the last chapter of the book was revised by Gandhiji.
('83', 215, 7, 28, 443081) 3 The articles were serialized under the title “General Knowledge about Health” in 1913. They appeared in thirty three instalments from January 4 to August 16.
('83', 216, 0, 1, 443241) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 217
('83', 216, 1, 2, 443285) and vaidyas.
('83', 216, 1, 3, 443298) Whether my presumption is correct or not, many friends have been pressing me to publish a new edition, putting forth my views to date.
('83', 216, 1, 4, 443433) I have never been able to revise the original.
('83', 216, 1, 5, 443480) I have never had the time for it.
('83', 216, 1, 6, 443514) The present enforced rest 1 offers me such an opportunity and I am taking advantage of it.
('83', 216, 1, 7, 443605) I have not even got the original with me.
('83', 216, 1, 8, 443647) The experience of so many years cannot but have left its mark upon my thought.

('83', 216, 1, 10, 443892) Therefore whatever change the reader may find will, I hope, be in the nature of a progress.

('83', 216, 6, 18, 444475) DEAR SIR, With reference to the Government orders about the writing of letters by the security prisoners, it seems that the Government do not know that for over thirty five years, I have ceased to live family life and have been living what has been called Ashram life in association with persons who have more or less shared my views.

('83', 217, 1, 4, 445042) If I cannot write to the widow and her son or the other members of the deceased’s family living in the Ashram, I can have no interest in writing to anyone else.
('83', 217, 1, 5, 445203) Nor can I be confined to writing about personal and domestic matters.

('83', 217, 6, 24, 446759) BOMBAY GOVT., BOMBAY
('83', 217, 7, 25, 446780) SIR, Khan Bahadur Kateley kindly handed me yesterday the letters written by late Shri Mahadev Desai’s wife and son.
('83', 217, 7, 26, 446896) At the time of
('83', 218, 0, 1, 446911) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 219
('83', 218, 1, 2, 446955) handing me the letters, Khan Bahadur told me that he has to explain to me the delay caused in sending my “letter” 1. He could however give no explanation.
('83', 218, 1, 3, 447110) I missed even a formal expression of regret for the inordinate delay.
('83', 218, 1, 4, 447180) There appears to have been in the Bombay Secretariat a disregard of the feelings of a bereaved wife and bereaved son.
('83', 218, 1, 5, 447298) From these letters I gather that what was on the face of it a telegram, and was handed to the I.G.P. with the request that it should go as an express telegraphic message was posted as a letter.
