('83', 223, 5, 11, 456405) 225. KEY TO HEALTH 3
('83', 223, 6, 12, 456426) December18, 1942 4
('83', 223, 7, 13, 456445) PART 1 1. THE HUMAN BODY It is necessary to understand the meaning of the word health,
('83', 223, 8, 14, 456532) 1 In this the addressee had said, “Government is unable to sanction your request to be allowed to communicate with him.
('83', 223, 8, 15, 456652) If, however, you desire to advise him, for humanitarian reasons, to abandon his fast, this Government will make arrangements to communicate your advice to him.” 2 Vide “Telegram to Secretary, Home Department Government of Bombay”, 24 11 1942. 3 In “A Word by the Publisher”, in the source, Jivanji D. Desai explains: “The original was written in Gujarati, and Gandhiji got it translated into Hindustani and English by Dr. Sushila Nayyar under his own guidance.
('83', 223, 8, 16, 457113) He also went through both the translations to give them the final touches.
('83', 223, 8, 17, 457188) The reader can therefore take the translation as Gandhiji’s own rendering.” The item here is placed according to the date on which the last chapter of the book was revised by Gandhiji.
('83', 223, 8, 18, 457373) For Gandhiji’s Preface to this, vide “Preface”, 27 8 1942. 4 This and the subsequent date lines are reproduced from Arogyani Chavi, the Gujarati original.
('83', 224, 0, 1, 457528) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 225
('83', 224, 1, 2, 457572) before entering upon a description of the human body.
('83', 224, 1, 3, 457626) ‘In health’ means body ease.
('83', 224, 1, 4, 457655) He is a healthy man whose body is free from all diseases; he carries on his normal activities without fatigue.
('83', 224, 1, 5, 457766) Such a man should be able with ease to walk ten to twelve miles a day, and perform ordinary physical labour without getting tired.
('83', 224, 1, 6, 457897) He can digest ordinary simple food.
('83', 224, 1, 7, 457933) His mind and his senses are in a state of harmony and poise.
('83', 224, 1, 8, 457994) This definition does not include prize fighters and such like.
('83', 224, 1, 9, 458057) A man with extraordinary physical strength is not necessarily healthy.
('83', 224, 1, 10, 458128) He has merely developed his musculature, possibly at the expense of something else.
('83', 224, 1, 11, 458212) It is necessary to have enough knowledge of the human body which is expected to attain the above standard of health.
('83', 224, 1, 12, 458329) God alone knows what kind of education was prevalent in ancient times.
('83', 224, 1, 13, 458400) Research workers on the subject may be able to tell us something, but only something, about it.
('83', 224, 1, 14, 458496) But all of us have some experience of modern education in this country.
('83', 224, 1, 15, 458568) It has no relation with our everyday life.
('83', 224, 1, 16, 458611) Thus it leaves us almost utterly ignorant about our own body.
('83', 224, 1, 17, 458673) Our knowledge of our own village and our fields shares a similar fate.
('83', 224, 1, 18, 458744) We are taught, on the other hand, much about things that have no bearing on our daily life.
('83', 224, 1, 19, 458836) I do not mean to say that such knowledge is of no use.
('83', 224, 1, 20, 458891) But everything has its own place.
('83', 224, 1, 21, 458925) We must first know enough of our own body, our own house, our village and its surroundings, the crops that grow there and its history before going on to anything else.
('83', 224, 1, 22, 459093) General knowledge broad based on this primary knowledge alone can enrich life.
('83', 224, 2, 23, 459172) August 29, 1942
('83', 224, 3, 24, 459188) The human body is composed of what the ancient philosophers have described as the five elements.
('83', 224, 3, 25, 459285) These are earth, water, ether, light and air.
('83', 224, 3, 26, 459331) All human activity is carried on by means of the mind aided by the ten senses.
('83', 224, 3, 27, 459410) These are the five senses of action, i.e., hands, feet, mouth, anus and the genitals, and the five senses of perception, i.e., the sense of touch through the skin, of smell through the nose, of taste through the tongue, of seeing through the eyes and of hearing through the ears.
('83', 224, 3, 28, 459690) Thinking is the function of the mind and some people have called it the eleventh sense.
('83', 224, 3, 29, 459778) In health all the senses and the mind act in perfect co ordination.
('83', 224, 4, 30, 459846) 1 Arogyani Chavi adds: “Few enjoy such good health.”
('83', 225, 0, 1, 459899) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 225, 1, 2, 459941) The inner working of the human machine is wonderful.
('83', 225, 1, 3, 459994) The human body is the universe in miniature.
('83', 225, 1, 4, 460039) That which cannot be found in the body is not to be found in the universe.
('83', 225, 1, 5, 460114) Hence the philosopher’s formula 1, that the universe within reflects the universe without.
('83', 225, 1, 6, 460205) It follows therefore that if our knowledge of our own body could be perfect, we would know the universe.
('83', 225, 1, 7, 460310) But even the very best of doctors and hakims and vaids have not been able to acquire it.
('83', 225, 1, 8, 460399) It will be presumptuous for a layman to aspire to it.
('83', 225, 1, 9, 460453) No one has yet discovered an instrument which can give us any information about the human mind.
('83', 225, 1, 10, 460549) Scientists have given attractive descriptions of the activities going on within and without the body, but no one can say what sets the wheel going.
('83', 225, 1, 11, 460697) Who can explain the why and wherefore of death or foretell its time?
('83', 225, 1, 12, 460766) In short, after infinite reading and writing, after infinite experience, man has come to know how little he knows.
('83', 225, 1, 13, 460881) A happy working of the human machine depends upon the harmonious activity of the various component parts.
('83', 225, 1, 14, 460987) If all these work in an orderly manner, the machine runs smoothly.
('83', 225, 1, 15, 461054) If even one of the essential parts is out of order, it comes to a stop.
('83', 225, 1, 16, 461126) For instance, if the digestion is out of order, the whole body becomes slack.
('83', 225, 1, 17, 461204) Therefore he who takes indigestion and constipation lightly does not know the A B C of the rules of health.
('83', 225, 1, 18, 461312) These two are the root causes of innumerable ailments.
('83', 225, 1, 19, 461367) August 30, 1942
('83', 225, 2, 20, 461383) The question that demands our attention next is: What is the right use of the human body?
('83', 225, 2, 21, 461473) Everything in the world can be used and abused.
('83', 225, 2, 22, 461521) This applies to the body also.
('83', 225, 2, 23, 461552) We abuse it when we use it for selfish purposes, for self indulgence or in order to harm another.
('83', 225, 2, 24, 461650) It is put to its right use if we exercise self restraint and dedicate ourselves to the service of the whole world.
('83', 225, 2, 25, 461765) The human soul is a part of the universal spirit of God.
('83', 225, 2, 26, 461822) When all our activity is directed towards the realization of this link, the body becomes a temple worthy for the spirit to live in.
('83', 225, 2, 27, 461954) The body has been described as a mine of dirt.
('83', 225, 2, 28, 462001) Looked at in its proper perspective, there is no exaggeration in this statement.
('83', 225, 2, 29, 462082) If the body was nothing else but this, there could be no point in taking such pains to look after it.
('83', 225, 2, 30, 462184) But if this so called mine of dirt can be put to its
('83', 226, 0, 1, 462237) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 227
('83', 226, 1, 2, 462281) proper use, it becomes our first duty to cleanse it and keep it in a fit condition.
('83', 226, 1, 3, 462365) The mines of precious stones and gold also have the look of ordinary earth on the surface.
('83', 226, 1, 4, 462456) The knowledge that there are gold and precious stones underneath, induces men to spend millions and engage scientific brains in order to get at what lies in those mines.
('83', 226, 1, 5, 462626) Similarly, we cannot take too much pains over keeping in a fit condition the temple of the spirit—the human body.
('83', 226, 1, 6, 462740) Man came into the world in order to pay off the debt owed by him to it, that is to say, in order to serve God and (or through) His creation.
('83', 226, 1, 7, 462881) Keeping this point of view before him, man acts as a guardian of his body.
('83', 226, 1, 8, 462956) It becomes his duty to take such care of his body as to enable it to practise the ideal of service to the best of its ability.
('83', 226, 1, 9, 463083) August 31, 1942
('83', 226, 3, 10, 463099) No one can live without air as one can without water for a few days and without food much longer.
('83', 226, 3, 11, 463197) Therefore, nature has surrounded us with air on all sides so that we can get it without any effort.
('83', 226, 3, 12, 463297) We take in air through the nose into our lungs.
('83', 226, 3, 13, 463345) The lungs act as a sort of bellows.
('83', 226, 3, 14, 463381) The atmospheric air which we breathe in has a life giving substance—a gas known as oxygen.
('83', 226, 3, 15, 463472) The air that we breathe out contains poisonous gases.
('83', 226, 3, 16, 463526) These can kill us if they are not immediately allowed to spread out and get diluted by the atmospheric air.
('83', 226, 3, 17, 463634) Hence the necessity of proper ventilation.
('83', 226, 3, 18, 463677) The air comes into close contact with blood in the lungs and purifies it.
('83', 226, 3, 19, 463751) Many people do not know the art of breathing.
('83', 226, 3, 20, 463797) This defect prevents an adequate purification of their blood.
('83', 226, 3, 21, 463859) Some people breathe through the mouth instead of through the nose.
('83', 226, 3, 22, 463926) This is a bad habit.
('83', 226, 3, 23, 463947) Nature has so designed the nose that it acts as a sort of filter for the in going air and also warms it.
('83', 226, 3, 24, 464052) In mouth breathers the atmospheric air reaches the lungs without the preliminary filtration or warming.
('83', 226, 3, 25, 464156) It follows therefore that those who do not know how to breathe should take breathing exercises.
('83', 226, 3, 26, 464252) They are as easy to learn as they are useful.
('83', 226, 3, 27, 464298) I do not wish to go into a discussion of the various asanas or postures.
('83', 226, 3, 28, 464371) I do not mean to say that these are not important or useful.
('83', 226, 3, 29, 464432) But I do wish to emphasize that a well regulated life outweighs the advantage
('83', 227, 0, 1, 464510) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 227, 1, 2, 464552) of studying and practising elaborate postures or exercises.
('83', 227, 1, 3, 464612) Any comfortable posture that ensures breathing through the nose and free chest expansion is enough for our purpose.
('83', 227, 1, 4, 464728) If we keep the mouth tightly closed, the breathing will have to be carried out by the nose.
('83', 227, 1, 5, 464820) Just as we wash our mouth every morning, the nose should also be cleaned.
('83', 227, 1, 6, 464894) Clean water, cold or lukewarm, is the best agent for that purpose.
('83', 227, 1, 7, 464961) It should be taken in a cup or in the palm of the hand and drawn up through the nostrils.
('83', 227, 1, 8, 465051) It is possible to draw the water up through one nostril, the other remaining closed, and expel it through the other by opening it and closing the former.
('83', 227, 1, 9, 465205) The process should be carried out gently so as to avoid discomfort.
('83', 227, 1, 10, 465273) In order to cleanse the back portion of the nose known as nasopharynx, water should be brought out by the mouth or even swallowed.
('83', 227, 1, 11, 465404) We must see that the air that we breathe in is fresh.
('83', 227, 1, 12, 465458) It is good to cultivate the habit of sleeping in the open under the stars.
('83', 227, 1, 13, 465533) The fear of catching a chill should be dismissed from the mind.
('83', 227, 1, 14, 465597) Cold can be kept out by plenty of covering.
('83', 227, 1, 15, 465641) This covering should not extend beyond the neck.
('83', 227, 1, 16, 465690) If cold is felt on the head, it can be covered with a separate piece of cloth.
('83', 227, 1, 17, 465769) The opening of the respiratory passage—the nose— should never be covered up.
('83', 227, 1, 18, 465846) The day clothes should be changed for loose night clothes before retiring.
('83', 227, 1, 19, 465921) As a matter of fact no clothes are necessary at night when one sleeps covered with a sheet.
('83', 227, 1, 20, 466013) Tight fitting clothes should be avoided even during the day.
('83', 227, 1, 21, 466074) The atmospheric air around us is not always pure, neither is it the same in every country.
('83', 227, 1, 22, 466165) The choice of the country does not always lie in our hands but the choice of a suitable house in a suitable locality does rest with us to some extent.
('83', 227, 1, 23, 466316) The general rule should be to live in a locality which is not too congested and insist upon the house being well lighted and well ventilated.
('83', 227, 1, 24, 466458) September 1, 1942
('83', 227, 2, 25, 466476) 3. WATER
('83', 227, 3, 26, 466485) Next to air, water is a necessity of life.
('83', 227, 3, 27, 466528) We cannot live without it for more than a few days, just as without air we cannot live for more than a few minutes.
('83', 227, 3, 28, 466644) Therefore, as in the case of air, nature has provided us with ample amount of water.
('83', 227, 3, 29, 466729) Man cannot live on barren land where there is no water.
('83', 227, 3, 30, 466785) Vast tracts of desert land such as Sahara lie utterly uninhabited.
('83', 228, 0, 1, 466852) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 229
('83', 228, 1, 2, 466896) In order to keep healthy, everyone should take 5 lb.
('83', 228, 1, 3, 466949) of water or other liquid food in 24 hours.
('83', 228, 1, 4, 466992) Drinking water must be pure.

('83', 260, 2, 14, 547979) Let us descend from the akash above to the akash within and immediately about us.

('83', 273, 2, 4, 566844) Contrary to the biblical injunction, I have allowed many suns to set on a quarrel I have harboured against you, but I must not allow the old year to expire without disburdening myself of what is rankling in my breast against you.

('83', 275, 5, 9, 572622) Personal January 19, 1943
('83', 275, 6, 10, 572648) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW, I received your kind letter 2 of 13th instant yesterday at 2.30 p.m.
('83', 275, 6, 11, 572739) I had almost despaired of ever hearing from you.
('83', 275, 6, 12, 572788) Please excuse my impatience.
('83', 275, 6, 13, 572817) Your letter gladdens me to find that I have not lost caste with you.
('83', 275, 6, 14, 572886) My letter 3 of 31st December was a growl against you.
('83', 275, 6, 15, 572940) Yours is a counter growl.
('83', 275, 6, 16, 572966) It means that you maintain that you were right in arresting me and you were sorry for the omissions of which, in your opinion, I was guilty.
('83', 275, 6, 17, 573107) The inference yon draw from my letter is, I am afraid, not correct.
('83', 275, 6, 18, 573175) I have re read my letter in the light of your interpretation, but have failed to find your meaning in it.
('83', 275, 6, 19, 573281) I wanted to fast and should still want to, if nothing comes out of our correspondence and I have to be a helpless witness to what is going on in the country, including the priv ations of the millions owing to the universal scarcity stalking the land.
('83', 275, 6, 20, 573532) If I do not accept your interpretation of my letter, you want me to make a positive suggestion.
('83', 275, 6, 21, 573628) This I might be able to do, only if you put me among the members of the Working Committee of the Congress.
('83', 275, 7, 22, 573735) 1 According to The Transfer of Power, Vol. III, pp.

('83', 276, 1, 2, 574246) If I could be convinced of my error or worse, of which you are evidently, I should need to consult nobody, so far as my own action is concerned, to make a full and open confession and make ample amends.

('83', 276, 2, 5, 574573) September, 1942. I adhere to what I have said in it and in my letter 2 to you of 14th August, 1942. Of course, I deplore the happenings which have taken place since 9th August last.
('83', 276, 2, 6, 574755) But have I not laid the whole blame for them at the door of the Government of India?
('83', 276, 2, 7, 574840) Moreover I could not express any opinion on events which I cannot influence or control, and of which I have but a one sided account.
('83', 276, 2, 8, 574973) You are bound prima facie to accept the accuracy of reports that may be placed before you by your departmental heads.
('83', 276, 2, 9, 575091) But you will not expect me to do so.
('83', 276, 2, 10, 575128) Such reports have before now often proved fallible.
('83', 276, 2, 11, 575180) It was for that reason that, in my letter of 31st December, I pleaded with you to convince me of the correctness of the information on which your conviction was based.
('83', 276, 2, 12, 575348) You will perhaps appreciate my fundamental difficulty in making the statement you have expected me to make.
('83', 276, 2, 13, 575456) This, however, I can say from the house top, that I am as confirmed a believer in non violence as I have ever been.
('83', 276, 2, 14, 575572) You may not know that any violence on the part of Congress workers I have condemned openly and unequivocally.
('83', 276, 2, 15, 575682) I have even done public penance 3 more than once.
('83', 276, 2, 16, 575732) I must not weary you with examples.
('83', 276, 2, 17, 575768) The point I wish to make is that on every such occasion I was a free man.
('83', 276, 2, 18, 575842) This time the retracing, as I have submitted, lies with the Government.
('83', 276, 2, 19, 575914) You will forgive me for expressing an opinion challenging yours.
('83', 276, 2, 20, 575979) I am certain that nothing but good would have resulted, if you had stayed your hand and granted me the interview, which I had announced 4 on the night of the 8th August, I was to seek.
('83', 276, 2, 21, 576164) But that was not to be.
('83', 276, 2, 22, 576188) Here may I remind you that the Government of India have before now owned their mistakes as, for instance, in the Punjab when

('83', 278, 1, 2, 578706) 228. INDEPENDENCE DAY PLEDGE 1
('83', 278, 2, 3, 578737) [January 25, 1943] 2
('83', 278, 3, 4, 578758) My immediate objective is and for years has been for India to gain her independence, complete in every sense of the term by truthful and non violent means.
('83', 278, 3, 5, 578914) And in prosecution of that objective, I re pledge myself on this [thirteenth anniversary of] 3 Independence Day not to rest; [nor will I let those on whom I have some influence to rest] 4 till it is gained.
('83', 278, 3, 6, 579121) I seek for the fulfilment of my pledge the assistance of that divine and unseen Power which we recognize by such familiar names as God, Allah and Paramatma.

('83', 282, 1, 2, 587343) You have allowed an expression to slip from your pen for which I was unprepared.
('83', 282, 1, 3, 587424) In the concluding sentence of the second paragraph, you describe the step as an attempt “to find an easy way out”.
('83', 282, 1, 4, 587539) That you, as a friend, can impute such a base and cowardly motive to me passes comprehension.
('83', 282, 1, 5, 587633) You have also described it as “a form of political blackmail”.

('83', 282, 1, 11, 588017) “Profound distrust” of the published reports is in no way inconsistent with my having an open mind.

('83', 282, 1, 21, 588960) Surely there is nothing wrong in my asking you to show me the evidence on which you hold them guilty.
('83', 282, 1, 22, 589062) What you say in your letter carries no conviction.
('83', 282, 1, 23, 589113) Proof should correspond to the canons of English jurisprudence.
('83', 282, 1, 24, 589177) If the wife of a member of the Working Committee is actively engaged in “planning the bomb outrages and other acts of terrorism”, she should be tried before a court of law and punished, if found guilty.
('83', 282, 1, 25, 589380) The lady you refer to could only have done the things attributed to her after the wholesale arrests of 9th August last, which I have dared to describe as leonine violence.

('83', 283, 1, 13, 591526) I must be a strange friend of yours whom you believe to be capable of asking for recognition of such things as lawful.

('83', 284, 5, 12, 593079) 232. LETTER TO SIR RICHARD TOTTENHAM
('83', 284, 6, 13, 593116) February 8, 1943
('83', 284, 7, 14, 593133) DEAR SIR RICHARD 2. I have very carefully studied your letter 3. I am sorry to say that there is nothing in the correspondence which has taken place between His Excellency and myself, or your letter, to warrant a recalling of my intention to fast.
('83', 284, 7, 15, 593381) I have mentioned in my letters to His Excellency the conditions which can induce prevention or suspension of the step.
('83', 284, 7, 16, 593500) If the temporary release is offered for my convenience, I do not need it.
('83', 284, 7, 17, 593574) I shall be quite content to take my fast as a detenu or prisoner.
('83', 284, 7, 18, 593640) If it is for the convenience of the Government, I am sorry I am unable to suit them, much as I should like to do so.
('83', 284, 7, 19, 593757) I can say this much that I, as a prisoner, shall avoid, as far as is humanly possible, every cause of inconvenience to the Government save what is inherent in the fast itself.
('83', 284, 7, 20, 593933) The impending fast has not been conceived to be taken as a free man.

('83', 286, 3, 7, 596625) This is my submission about the visits: 1. It is not fair to leave the initiative to me.
('83', 286, 3, 8, 596714) In the present state of my mind I have no initiative about such visits.
('83', 286, 3, 9, 596786) If, therefore, the Government wish that I should receive visitors, they should inform the public that, if any member of the public specially desires to see me, they will give him the permission.
('83', 286, 3, 10, 596981) Their names need not be referred to me.
('83', 286, 3, 11, 597021) For, I will not thwart the wish of any friend to see me.
('83', 286, 3, 12, 597078) It is highly probable that my children and other relatives as also inmates of the Ashram and other friends who are intimately connected with me through one or more of my many activities may want to see me.
('83', 286, 3, 13, 597284) If Rajaji, for instance, who had already applied to the Government for permission to see me in connection with the communal problem, wants to see me about that matter or any other, I should be glad to see him.
('83', 286, 3, 14, 597494) But even regarding him I would not take the initiative of submitting his name to the Government.
('83', 286, 3, 15, 597591) 2. If the visitors are permitted to see me without any restrictions as to the matters they might discuss with me, the object of discussions would be largely frustrated if the discussions cannot be published.
('83', 286, 3, 16, 597799) I would, of course, always and in every circumstance, myself rule out, without needing any external pressure, any discussion that can, by any stretch of imagination, be helpful to the Fascist powers, including Japan.

('83', 288, 5, 8, 601285) February 21, 1943
('83', 288, 6, 9, 601303) From those who had already seen him, I had gathered that Gandhiji was passing through unprecedented mental agony.
('83', 288, 6, 10, 601417) It distressed him beyond words that of all persons Lord Linlithgow should have so far misunderstood him as to believe that he who had dedicated his life to non violence and who valued non violence more than life itself, could ever countenance or condone violence of any kind.
('83', 288, 6, 11, 601693) It hurt him deeply that though grave charges were made by Government against him and the Congress, no opportunity was given to them to refute them.
('83', 288, 6, 12, 601841) This agony as well as the anxiety of the fast was writ large on his face.
('83', 288, 7, 13, 601915) He responded to my salutation with his characteristic smile.

('83', 288, 7, 18, 602356) Then he began speaking in whispers, and as he spoke his voice grew more and more audible.

('83', 294, 6, 9, 614726) 242. ANSWER TO QUESTIONS 3
('83', 294, 7, 10, 614753) [After March 3, 1943] 4
('83', 294, 8, 11, 614777) QUESTION: It is alleged that you have compromised with your faith in non violence.
('83', 294, 8, 12, 614860) Is it true?
('83', 294, 9, 13, 614872) ANSWER : Not only does my faith in non violence remain unshaken but you could even say that after the detention of six months, my faith in non violence has, if possible, gone up further

('83', 295, 0, 1, 616541) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 295, 2, 2, 616583) How do you then reconcile your faith in non violence with the allegations made against you and the Congress that all these acts of sabotage and violence that took place after the 8th of August so happened because of some secret instructions issued by you or by the Congress?
('83', 295, 2, 3, 616858) There is absolutely no truth in it.
('83', 295, 2, 4, 616894) I never issued any secret or overt instructions in favour of sabotage or any other kind of violence.
('83', 295, 2, 5, 616995) Had Congress issued instructions, I would have known it.
('83', 295, 2, 6, 617052) No such instructions were issued either by me or by the Congress.
('83', 295, 3, 7, 617118) Do you then disapprove of these acts of sabotage and violence?
('83', 295, 3, 8, 617181) I definitely disapprove of them.
('83', 295, 3, 9, 617214) I have made it clear to all those friends who have met me during the period of my fast.
('83', 295, 3, 10, 617302) I do not want to judge anyone who believes in violence.
('83', 295, 3, 11, 617358) But then I would say to them to declare it unequivocally that they are committing these acts of violence on their own behalf and because of their belief in violence.
('83', 295, 3, 12, 617524) It is but fair to the Congress that these perpetrators of violence and sabotage should make it absolutely clear.
('83', 295, 3, 13, 617637) I would also say that though one may not be a Congressman and yet has respect for me, should give up all methods of secrecy and violence.
('83', 295, 3, 14, 617775) If they would listen to my advice, I would suggest that they should surrender themselves to the police.
('83', 295, 3, 15, 617879) In this way they would only help the cause of the country.
('83', 295, 3, 16, 617938) But if one does not believe in the Congress creed and my method, he should make it clear to all concerned.
('83', 295, 4, 17, 618045) It has been suggested that you started this movement under the notion that the Allies were going to be defeated and that you synchronized the movement with the time when Allied nations were in difficulties and that you wanted to take undue advantage of their position.
('83', 295, 4, 18, 618314) There is absolutely no truth in it.
('83', 295, 4, 19, 618350) You can read my writings in Harijan, and I have made it more than clear that this was not my intention.
('83', 295, 5, 20, 618454) Yes, I have read your articles in Harijan, and what I gathered therefrom was that you are not only not pro German or pro Japan, but you are anti Nazi and anti Fascist.
('83', 295, 5, 21, 618622) Am I right?
('83', 295, 5, 22, 618634) Definitely.
('83', 295, 5, 23, 618646) No one has used stronger words than myself about Nazism and Fascism.
('83', 295, 5, 24, 618715) I have called the Nazis and Fascists the scum of the earth.
('83', 295, 5, 25, 618775) I wrote a letter 1 some time in May 1942 to Mirabehn while she was in Orissa.
('83', 295, 5, 26, 618853) I cannot give you a copy of that letter since I am in
('83', 295, 6, 27, 618907) 1 Vide “Letter to Mirabehn”, 31 5 1942.
('83', 296, 0, 1, 618947) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 297
('83', 296, 1, 2, 618991) I understand Mirabehn has sent a copy of that letter to the Government.
('83', 296, 1, 3, 619063) You can ask the Government to supply you with a copy of it and satisfy yourself.
('83', 296, 1, 4, 619144) I have given in that letter complete instructions as to how to resist the Japanese, if they at all invade India.
('83', 296, 1, 5, 619257) No one after reading that letter could charge me with any sympathy with Nazism and Fascism or with Japan.
('83', 296, 2, 6, 619363) Is it not the position that the Congress has pledged itself to give military help for Allied cause in case of India being free and a national government being established?
('83', 296, 2, 7, 619535) You are absolutely correct in drawing the conclusion that you have drawn.
('83', 296, 2, 8, 619609) The national government will, no doubt, in case of India being made free, fight for the Allies’ cause with all the military resources at its disposal and will co operate with the Allied nations in every possible manner.
('83', 296, 3, 9, 619829) Yes, this is the policy of the Congress.
('83', 296, 3, 10, 619870) But you being a pacifist, would you obstruct the Congress plan to give military help to the Allied nations?
('83', 296, 3, 11, 619978) Certainly not.
('83', 296, 3, 12, 619993) I am a pacifist.
('83', 296, 3, 13, 620010) But if the national government is formed and takes power on the basis of giving military help to the Allied nations, I obviously cannot obstruct and will not obstruct.
('83', 296, 3, 14, 620178) I cannot directly participate in any act of violence.
('83', 296, 3, 15, 620232) But Congress is not pacifist in the manner as I am.
('83', 296, 3, 16, 620284) And I naturally would not do anything to obstruct the execution of the Congress intention.
('83', 296, 4, 17, 620375) It would surprise you to know that, although you claim to be the best friend of U. K., you are just now very much distrusted.
('83', 296, 4, 18, 620501) I know this and say that this is very unfortunate.
('83', 296, 4, 19, 620552) But I am not at all worried about it.
('83', 296, 4, 20, 620590) I have no doubt that the distrust will disappear, and the trust will come back with the same strength as the distrust.

('83', 300, 7, 15, 626288) In accordance with their known policy in regard to correspondence or interviews with Mr. Gandhi, the Government of India have decided that this letter cannot be forwarded and have so informed Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Jinnah.
('83', 300, 7, 16, 626507) They are not prepared to give facilities for political correspondence or contact to a person detained for promoting an illegal mass movement which he has not disavowed, and thus gravely embarrassing India’s war effort at a critical time.

('83', 301, 0, 1, 627234) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 301, 1, 2, 627276) 249. LETTER TO LORD SAMUEL
('83', 301, 2, 3, 627303) DETENTION CAMP, May 15, 1943
('83', 301, 3, 4, 627332) DEAR LORD SAMUEL 1, I enclose herewith a cutting from The Hindu dated 8th April last, containing Reuter’s summary of your speech in the House of Lords during the recent debate.
('83', 301, 3, 5, 627509) Assuming the correctness of the summary, I feel impelled to write this letter.
('83', 301, 3, 6, 627588) The report distressed me.
('83', 301, 3, 7, 627614) I was wholly unprepared for your unqualified association with the one sided and unsifted 2 statement of the Government of India against the Congress and me.
('83', 301, 3, 8, 627771) You are a philosopher and liberal.
('83', 301, 3, 9, 627806) A philosophic mind has always meant for me a detached mind and liberalism, a sympathetic understanding of men and things.
('83', 301, 3, 10, 627928) As it seems to me, there is nothing in what the Government has said to warrant the conclusion to which you are reported to have come.
('83', 301, 3, 11, 628062) From the summary, I select below a few of the items which, in my opinion, are inconsistent with facts.
('83', 301, 4, 12, 628165) 1. The Congress Party has to a great extent thrown over democratic philosophy.
('83', 301, 4, 13, 628244) The Congress Party has never “thrown over democratic philosophy”.
('83', 301, 4, 14, 628310) Its career has been one progressive march towards democracy.
('83', 301, 4, 15, 628371) Everyone who subscribes to the attainment of the goal of independence through peaceful and legitimate means and pays four annas per year can become its member.
('83', 301, 5, 16, 628531) 2. It shows signs of turning towards totalitarianism.
('83', 301, 5, 17, 628585) You have based your charge on the fact that the Working Committee of the Congress had control over the late Congress Ministries.
('83', 301, 5, 18, 628714) Does not the successful party in the House of Commons do likewise?
('83', 301, 5, 19, 628781) I am afraid even when democracy has come to full maturity, parties will be running elections and their managing committees will be controlling the actions and policies of their members.
('83', 301, 5, 20, 628967) Individual Congressmen did not run elections independently of the party machinery.
('83', 301, 5, 21, 629050) Candidates were officially chosen and they were helped
('83', 301, 6, 22, 629105) 1 Herbert Louis Samuel, First Viscount; Liberal Party leader 2 Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government has “unjustified”.
('83', 302, 0, 1, 629233) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 303
('83', 302, 1, 2, 629277) by all India leaders.
('83', 302, 1, 3, 629299) ‘Totalitarian’, according to the Oxford Pocket Dictionary, means “designating a party that permits no rival loyalties or parties”.
('83', 302, 1, 4, 629430) ‘Totalitarian State’ means “with only one governing party”.
('83', 302, 1, 5, 629490) It must have violence as its sanction for keeping control.
('83', 302, 1, 6, 629549) A Congress member, on the contrary, enjoys the same freedom as the Congress President, or any member of the Working Committee.
('83', 302, 1, 7, 629676) There are parties within the Congress itself.
('83', 302, 1, 8, 629722) Above all the Congress eschews violence.
('83', 302, 1, 9, 629763) Members render voluntary obedience.
('83', 302, 1, 10, 629799) The All India Congress Committee can at any moment unseat the members of the Working Committee and elect others.
('83', 302, 2, 11, 629912) 3. They (Congress Ministers) 1 resigned (not?) 2 because they had not the support of their Assemblies.
('83', 302, 3, 12, 630015) They resigned because de jure they were responsible to their electorates, de facto they were responsible to the Working Committee of the Congress and the High Command.
('83', 302, 3, 13, 630183) That is not democracy.
('83', 302, 3, 14, 630206) That is totalitarianism .
('83', 302, 3, 15, 630232) You would not have said this if you had known the full facts.
('83', 302, 3, 16, 630294) The de jure responsibility of the Ministers to the electorate was not diminished in any way by their de facto responsibility to the Congress Working Committee, for the very simple and valid reason that the Working Committee derives its power and prestige from the very electorate to whom the Ministers were responsible.
('83', 302, 3, 17, 630614) The prestige that the Congress enjoys is due solely to its service of the people.
('83', 302, 3, 18, 630696) As a matter of fact, the Ministers conferred with the members of their parties in their respective Assemblies and they tendered their resignations with their approval.
('83', 302, 3, 19, 630864) But totalitarianism is fully represented by the Government of India which is responsible to no one in India.
('83', 302, 3, 20, 630973) It is a tragic irony that a Government which is steeped in totalitarianism brings that very charge against the most democratic body in India.
('83', 302, 4, 21, 631115) 4. India is unhappy in that the line of party division is the worst any country can have—it is a division according to religious communities.
('83', 302, 4, 22, 631257) Political parties in India are not divided according to religious communities.
('83', 302, 4, 23, 631336) From its very commencement the Congress has deliberately remained a purely political organization.
('83', 302, 4, 24, 631435) It has had Britishers and Indians, including Christians, Parsis, Muslims and
('83', 302, 5, 25, 631512) 1 Words in parentheses are Gandhiji’s.
('83', 303, 0, 1, 631551) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 303, 1, 2, 631593) Hindus, as Presidents.
('83', 303, 1, 3, 631616) The Liberal Party of India is another political organization, not to mention others that are wholly non sectarian.
('83', 303, 1, 4, 631731) That there are also communal organizations based on religion and that they take part in politics is undoubtedly true.
('83', 303, 1, 5, 631849) But that fact cannot sustain the categorical statement made by you.
('83', 303, 1, 6, 631917) I do not wish in any way to minimize the importance of these organizations or the considerable part they play in the politics of the country.
('83', 303, 1, 7, 632059) But I do assert that they do not represent the political mind of India.
('83', 303, 1, 8, 632131) It can be shown that historically the politico religious organizations are the result of the deliberate application by the alien Government of their “divide and rule” policy.
('83', 303, 1, 9, 632306) When the British imperial influence is totally withdrawn, India will probably be represented solely by political parties drawn from all classes and creeds.
('83', 303, 2, 10, 632462) 5. The Congress can claim at best barely more than half the population of India.
('83', 303, 2, 11, 632543) Yet in their totalitarian spirit they claim to speak for the whole.
('83', 303, 2, 12, 632611) If you measure the representative character of the Congress by the number of members on the official roll, then it does not represent even half the population.
('83', 303, 2, 13, 632771) The official membership is infinitesimal compared to India’s vast population of nearly four hundred millions.
('83', 303, 2, 14, 632881) The enrolled membership began only in 1920. Before that the Congress was represented by its All India Committees whose members were mainly elected by various political associations.
('83', 303, 2, 15, 633063) Nevertheless the Congress has, so far as I know, always claimed to speak the mind of India, not even excluding the Princes.
('83', 303, 2, 16, 633187) A country under alien subjection can only have one political goal, namely, its freedom from that subjection.
('83', 303, 2, 17, 633296) And considering that the Congress has always and predominantly exhibited that spirit of freedom, its claim to represent all India 1 can hardly be denied.
('83', 303, 2, 18, 633450) That some parties repudiate the Congress, does not derogate from the claim in the sense in which it has been advanced.
('83', 303, 3, 19, 633569) 6. When Mr. Gandhi called upon the British Government to quit India, he said it would be for the Congress to take delivery.
('83', 303, 3, 20, 633693) I never said that when the British quitted India, “the Congress would take delivery”.
('83', 303, 3, 21, 633779) This is what I said in my letter to His Excellency the Viceroy, dated 29th January last:
('83', 303, 4, 22, 633868) The Government have evidently ignored or overlooked the very material
('83', 303, 5, 23, 633938) 1 Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government has “the whole of India”.
('83', 304, 0, 1, 634012) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 305
('83', 304, 1, 2, 634056) fact that the Congress by its August resolution asked nothing for itself.
('83', 304, 1, 3, 634130) All its demands were for the whole people.
('83', 304, 1, 4, 634173) As you should be aware, the Congress was willing and prepared for the Government inviting Qaid e Azam Jinnah to form a national government, subject to such agreed adjustments as may be necessary, for the duration of the war, such government being responsible to a duly elected assembly.
('83', 304, 1, 5, 634460) Being isolated from the Working Committee, except Shrimati Sarojini Devi, I do not know its present mind.
('83', 304, 1, 6, 634566) But the Committee is not likely to have changed its mind.
('83', 304, 2, 7, 634624) 7. If this country or Canada, Australia, New Zealand or South Africa or the United States had abstained from action as the Congress in India abstained .
('83', 304, 2, 8, 634777) 2 then perhaps the cause of freedom everywhere would have gone under.
('83', 304, 2, 9, 634847) 3 It is a pity that the leaders of the Congress do not realize that glory is not to be won in India by abandoning the cause of mankind.
('83', 304, 2, 10, 634983) How can you compare India with Canada and other dominions which are virtually independent entities, let alone Great Britain or the United States—wholly independent countries?
('83', 304, 2, 11, 635158) Has India a spark of the freedom of the type enjoyed by the countries named by you?
('83', 304, 2, 12, 635242) India has yet to attain her freedom.
('83', 304, 2, 13, 635279) Supposing the Allied powers were to lose, and supposing further that the Allied forces were to withdraw from India under military necessity, which I do not expect, the countries you name may not lose their independence.
('83', 304, 2, 14, 635499) But unhappy India will be obliged to change masters, if she is even then in her defenceless state.

('83', 305, 1, 2, 636622) It was in 1935 that I was successful in my attempt to sever all formal connections with the Congress.
('83', 305, 1, 3, 636724) There was no coolness between the Congress Working Committee members and myself.
('83', 305, 1, 4, 636805) But I realized that I was cramped and so were the members whilst I was officially connected with the Congress.
('83', 305, 1, 5, 636916) The growing restraints which my conception of non violence required from time to time were proving too hard to bear.
('83', 305, 1, 6, 637033) I felt therefore that my influence should be strictly moral.
('83', 305, 1, 7, 637094) I had no political ambition.
('83', 305, 1, 8, 637123) My politics were subservient to the demands of truth and non violence as I had defined and practised for practically the whole of my life.
('83', 305, 1, 9, 637262) And so I was permitted by the fellow members to sever the official connection even to the extent of giving up the four anna membership.
('83', 305, 1, 10, 637398) It was understood between us that I should attend the meetings of the Working Committee only when the members required my presence for consultation in matters involving the application of non violence or affecting communal unity.
('83', 305, 1, 11, 637628) Since that time I have been wholly unconnected with the routine work of the Congress.
('83', 305, 1, 12, 637714) Many meetings of the Working Committee have, therefore, taken place without me.
('83', 305, 1, 13, 637794) These proceedings I have often seen only when they have been published in the newspapers.
('83', 305, 1, 14, 637884) The members of the Working Committee are independent minded men.
('83', 305, 1, 15, 637949) They engage me often in prolonged discussions before they accept my advice on the interpretation of non violence as applied to the problems rising from new situations.
('83', 305, 1, 16, 638117) It will be, therefore, unjust to them and to me to say that I exercise any influence over them beyond what reason commands.
('83', 305, 1, 17, 638241) The public know how even until quite recently in matters of moment the majority of the members of the Working Committee have on several occasions rejected my advice.
('83', 305, 2, 18, 638407) 8. They have not merely abstained from action, but the Congress has deliberately proclaimed the formula that it is wrong to help the British war effort by men or money and that the only worthy effort is to resist all war with non violent resistance.
('83', 305, 2, 19, 638657) In the name of non violence they have led a movement which was characterized in many places by the utmost violence, and the White Paper gives clear proof of the complicity of the Indian leaders in the disorders.

('83', 323, 2, 3, 679489) DETENTION CAMP, May 27, 1943
('83', 323, 3, 4, 679518) DEAR SIR RICHARD TOTTENHAM, I received last evening your letter 1 of the 24th instant refusing my request to forward my letter addressed to Qaid e Azam Jinnah.
('83', 323, 3, 5, 679678) I wrote 2 only yesterday to the Superintendent of this camp asking him kindly to inquire whether my letter to Qaid e Azam Jinnah, and the later one, dated the 15th instant to Right Hon’ble Lord Samuel, had been forwarded to the respective addressees.
('83', 323, 3, 6, 679929) I am sorry for the Government’s decision.
('83', 323, 3, 7, 679971) For, my letter to the Qaid e Azam was sent in reply to his public invitation to me to write to him, and I was especially encouraged to do so because his language had led me to think that, if I wrote to him, my letter would be forwarded to him.
('83', 323, 3, 8, 680215) The public too are anxious that the Qaid e Azam and I should meet or at least establish contact.
('83', 323, 3, 9, 680312) I have always been anxious to meet the Qaid e Azam, if per chance we could devise some solution of the communal tangle which might be generally acceptable.
('83', 323, 3, 10, 680468) Therefore the disability in the present instance is much more that of the public than mine.
('83', 323, 3, 11, 680560) As a satyagrahi I may not regard as disabilities the restrictions which the Government have imposed upon me.
('83', 323, 3, 12, 680669) As the Government are aware, I have denied myself even the pleasure of writing to my relatives as I am not allowed to perform the service of writing to my co workers who are in a sense more to me than my relatives.
('83', 323, 3, 13, 680884) The advance copy of the contemplated communique 3 with which you have considerably favoured me requires emendation in more places than one.
('83', 323, 3, 14, 681024) For, as it stands, it does not square with facts.
('83', 323, 3, 15, 681074) As to the disavowal referred to in the proposed communique, the Government are aware that I regard the non violent mass movement, for the launching of which the Congress gave me authority on the 8th of August last, as perfectly legitimate and in the interest
('83', 323, 4, 16, 681333) 1 This was from E. Conran Smith; vide footnote of “Letter to Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 4 5 1943. 2 Vide the preceding item.
('83', 323, 4, 17, 681481) 3 Vide footnote of “Letter to Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 4 5 1943.
('83', 324, 0, 1, 681571) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 325
('83', 324, 1, 2, 681615) both of the Government and the public.
('83', 324, 1, 3, 681654) As it is, the Government left me no time to start the movement.
('83', 324, 1, 4, 681718) Therefore how could a movement, which was never started, embarrass “India’s” war effort?
('83', 324, 1, 5, 681807) If then, there was any embarrassment by reason of the popular resentment of the Government’s action in resorting to the wholesale arrests of principal Congressmen, the responsibility was solely that of the Government.
('83', 324, 1, 6, 682025) The mass movement, as the resolution sanctioning it said in so many words, was sanctioned in order to promote India wide effort on behalf of the Allied cause, including the causes of Russia and China, whose danger was very great in August last and from which, in my opinion, they are by no means free even now.
('83', 324, 1, 7, 682336) I hope the Government will not feel offended when I say that all the war effort that is being put forth in India is not India’s but the alien Government’s.
('83', 324, 1, 8, 682492) I submit that, if the Government had complied with the request of the Congress as embodied in its August resolution, there would have been a mass effort without parallel for winning the battle for human freedom and ridding the world of the menace that Fascism, Nazism, Japanism and imperialism are.
('83', 324, 1, 9, 682791) I may be wholly wrong; anyway this is my deliberate and honest opinion.
('83', 324, 1, 10, 682863) In order to make the communique accord with facts, I suggest the following alterations in the first paragraph: After “Mr. Jinnah” add “in response to his public invitation to Mr. Gandhi to write to him, stating that he (Mr. Gandhi) would be willing to correspond with or meet him according as he wished”.
('83', 324, 1, 11, 683168) I hope that the remaining portion of the communique too will be suitably amended in the light of my submission.
('83', 324, 3, 12, 683280) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('83', 325, 1, 2, 683731) 254. LETTER TO SIR RICHAD TOTTENHAM
('83', 325, 2, 3, 683767) May 28, 1943
('83', 325, 3, 4, 683780) DEAR SIR RICHARD TOTTENHAM, I handed my reply 1 to your letter 2 of the 24th instant, at about one o’clock yesterday, to the Superintendent.
('83', 325, 3, 5, 683921) I hurried the writing and the despatch in the hope of my letter reaching you before the publication of the communique.
('83', 325, 3, 6, 684040) I was, therefore, astonished and grieved to find the communique in the papers received in the afternoon, and Reuter’s report 3 of the reactions 4\ upon it in London.
('83', 325, 3, 7, 684206) Evidently there was no meaning in an advance copy of the communique being sent to me.
('83', 325, 3, 8, 684292) I regard the communique not only to be inconsistent with the facts but unfair to me.
('83', 325, 3, 9, 684377) The only way partial redress can be given to me is the publication of the correspondence between us.
('83', 325, 3, 10, 684478) I, therefore request that it may be published.
('83', 325, 5, 11, 684525) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('83', 326, 1, 2, 685895) 255. TALK WITH MIRABEHN
('83', 326, 2, 3, 685919) May 29, 1943
('83', 326, 3, 4, 685932) I asked Bapuji how one could best help races who have an undeveloped idea of God, and suggested that one should not put before them any orthodox religion, but speak only in a very simple way of the Supreme Soul, and for the rest serve them and strive according to the ideals in which one believes.
('83', 326, 3, 5, 686230) Bapu replied: You should not even talk of the Supreme Soul.
('83', 326, 3, 6, 686290) It is my profound conviction that Truth is self acting.
('83', 326, 3, 7, 686346) Truth, which is God, is ever present, ever working in all beings.
('83', 326, 3, 8, 686412) Therefore one should 1 simply live one’s own life amongst them and serve them according to their needs.
('83', 326, 3, 9, 686516) Three R’s have a value all their own.
('83', 326, 3, 10, 686554) Therefore giving that knowledge to the illiterate is a special service obligatory on those who have that knowledge.
('83', 326, 3, 11, 686670) For the rest, if we have Truth in us, it will go out to them without effort, for it is self acting.
('83', 326, 3, 12, 686770) God, i.e., Truth, comes to those who seek Him.
('83', 326, 3, 13, 686817) If we know Him more than they (of which we can never be sure) the more will doubtless go out to them.
('83', 326, 3, 14, 686919) [PS.] I had it copied for you.
('83', 326, 4, 15, 686950) From a photostat: G.N. 9100
('83', 326, 5, 16, 686978) 256. TALK WITH MIRABEHN
('83', 326, 6, 17, 687002) May 31, 1943
('83', 326, 7, 18, 687015) When I looked through what you had written down of our conversation 3, I saw that I should express what I had said in a shorter and clearer manner.
('83', 326, 7, 19, 687163) I have now put it in the form of an aphorism.
('83', 326, 7, 20, 687209) As a matter of fact it was only yesterday that I fully realized the value of the three R’s In the past, I have often expressed indifference to them.
('83', 326, 7, 21, 687358) But yesterday it came to me that the three R’s have unique place and value, and in serving illiterate peoples it is a vital part of one’s duty to give them this knowledge.
('83', 326, 7, 22, 687530) The man who cannot read, write or add, must remain in many ways an ignoramus.
('83', 326, 7, 23, 687608) Whereas with this know ledge at his command he can reach out to further and further development.
('83', 326, 7, 24, 687705) Of course this means that when I impart the three R’s, I

('83', 327, 1, 2, 687901) must try to do it in such a way as to whet the man’s appetite for further knowledge.
('83', 327, 1, 3, 687986) There can be no question for me of just counting heads and passing on.
('83', 327, 1, 4, 688057) I do not impart the knowledge for all round advance.
('83', 327, 1, 5, 688110) If he advances materially all very well and good.
('83', 327, 1, 6, 688160) Though my concern is with his spiritual development, it is through material service that I have to approach him.
('83', 327, 1, 7, 688273) His body is all there, his soul is as yet unknown to him.
('83', 327, 1, 8, 688331) Day by day, as he goes on accepting my material services, he will become more curious about my life.
('83', 327, 1, 9, 688432) He will begin to notice something more than the physical side of my life: why do I sometimes sit in certain postures, why do I shut my eyes at times, what is it I am murmuring.
('83', 327, 1, 10, 688609) When his curiosity leads him to ask me what it all means, I can explain it to him.
('83', 327, 1, 11, 688692) How the information will affect him is not my concern.
('83', 327, 1, 12, 688747) It is not for me to interfere with the working of the spirit.
('83', 327, 1, 13, 688809) When I am face to face with a man, in proportion as I have God’s spirit in me will it go out to him.
('83', 327, 1, 14, 688910) 1 My purpose is not to give him my religion.
('83', 327, 1, 15, 688955) My purpose is to let him see God through me if I have Him and express Him in reality, in my daily doings.

('83', 329, 0, 1, 691154) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 329, 1, 2, 691196) 259. LETTER TO ADDITIONAL SECRETARY, HOME DEPARTMENT, GOVERNMENT OF INDIA
('83', 329, 2, 3, 691270) DETENTION CAMP, July 15, 1943
('83', 329, 3, 4, 691300) THE ADDITIONAL SECRETARY HOME DEPARTMENT GOVERNMENT OF INDIA NEW DELHI
('83', 329, 4, 5, 691371) SIR, In reply to my request 1 dated 5th March last for a copy of Government of India publication entitled Congress Responsibility for the Disturbances, 1942 43, I received a copy on 13th April.
('83', 329, 4, 6, 691565) It contains several corrections marked in red ink.
('83', 329, 4, 7, 691616) Some of them are striking.
('83', 329, 4, 8, 691643) 2. I take it that the Government have based the charges made in the publication against the Congress and myself on the material printed therein and not on the evidence which, as stated in the Preface, is withheld from the public.
('83', 329, 4, 9, 691873) 3. The Preface is brief and is signed by Sir R. Tottenham, Additional Secretary to the Government of India, Home Department.
('83', 329, 4, 10, 691998) It is dated 13th February last, i.e., three days after the commencement of my recent fast.
('83', 329, 4, 11, 692089) The date is ominous.
('83', 329, 4, 12, 692110) Why was the period of my fast chosen for publishing a document in which I am the target?
('83', 329, 4, 13, 692199) 4. The Preface commences thus:
('83', 329, 5, 14, 692230) In response to demands which have reached Government from several sources, Government have now prepared a review which brings together a number of facts .
('83', 329, 5, 15, 692385) bearing on the responsibility of Mr. Gandhi and the Congress High Command for the disturbances which followed the sanction of a mass movement by the A.I.C.C. on August 8, 1942. There is an obvious mis statement here.
('83', 329, 5, 16, 692602) The disturbances followed not the “sanctioning of the mass movement by the A.I.C.C.” but the arrests made by the Government.
('83', 329, 5, 17, 692727) As for the “demands”, so far as I am aware, they began soon after the wholesale
('83', 329, 6, 18, 692807) 1 The request was actually made by Pyarelal on behalf of Gandhiji; vide “Letter to Sir Richard Tottenham”, 5 3 1943
('83', 330, 0, 1, 692923) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 331
('83', 330, 1, 2, 692967) arrests of principal Congressmen all over India.
('83', 330, 1, 3, 693016) As the Government are aware, in my letters to His Excellency the Viceroy, the last 1 being dated 7th February, 1943, I had asked for proof in support of my alleged guilt.
('83', 330, 1, 4, 693187) The evidence now produced might have been given to me when I raised the question.
('83', 330, 1, 5, 693269) Had my request been complied with, one advantage would certainly have accrued.
('83', 330, 1, 6, 693348) I would have been heard in answer to the charges brought against me.
('83', 330, 1, 7, 693417) That very process would have delayed the fast and, who knows, if Government had been patient with me, it might have even prevented it.
('83', 330, 1, 8, 693552) 5. The Preface contains the following sentence:
('83', 330, 2, 9, 693600) Almost all the facts presented in this review are, or should be, already within the knowledge of the public.
('83', 330, 2, 10, 693709) Therefore, so far as the public are concerned, there was no such hurry as to require publication of the document during the fast.
('83', 330, 2, 11, 693839) This train of reasoning has led me to the inference that it was published in expectation of my death which medical opinion must have considered almost a certainty.
('83', 330, 2, 12, 694003) It was feared even during my previous long fasts.
('83', 330, 2, 13, 694053) I hope my inference is wholly wrong, and the Government had a just and valid reason for choosing the time that they did for the publication of what is after all an indictment of the Congress and me.
('83', 330, 2, 14, 694252) I hope to be pardoned for putting on paper an inference which, if true, must discredit the Government.
('83', 330, 2, 15, 694355) I feel that I am being just to them by unburdening myself of a suspicion instead of harbouring it and allowing it to cloud my judgment about their dealings with me.
('83', 330, 2, 16, 694520) 6. I now come to the indictment itself.
('83', 330, 2, 17, 694560) It reads like a presentation of his case by a prosecutor.
('83', 330, 2, 18, 694618) In the present case the prosecutor happens to be also the policeman and jailor.
('83', 330, 2, 19, 694698) He first arrests and gags his victims, and then opens his case behind their backs.
('83', 330, 2, 20, 694781) 7. I have read it again and again.
('83', 330, 2, 21, 694816) I have gone through the numbers of Harijan which my companions happened to have with them, and I have come to the conclusion that there is nothing in my writings and doings that could have warranted the inferences and the innuendoes of which the indictment is full.
('83', 330, 2, 22, 695082) In spite of my desire to see myself in my writings, as the author has seen me, I have completely failed.
('83', 330, 2, 23, 695187) 8. The indictment opens with a misrepresentation.
('83', 330, 2, 24, 695237) I am said to have deplored “the introduction of foreign soldiers into India to aid
('83', 330, 3, 25, 695320) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 7 2 1943.
('83', 331, 0, 1, 695366) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 331, 1, 2, 695408) in India’s defence”.
('83', 331, 1, 3, 695429) In the Harijan article 1, on which the charge is based, I have refused to believe that India was to be defended through the introduction of foreign soldiers.
('83', 331, 1, 4, 695587) If it is India’s defence that is aimed at, why should trained Indian soldiers be sent away from India and foreign soldiers brought in instead?
('83', 331, 1, 5, 695730) Why should the Congress— an organization which was born and lives for the very sake of India’s freedom —be suppressed?
('83', 331, 1, 6, 695849) I am clearer today in my mind than I was when I penned that article on 19th April, that India is not being defended, and that if things continue to shape themselves as they are, India will sink at the end of the war deeper than she is today, so that she might forget the very word freedom.
('83', 331, 1, 7, 696139) Let me quote the relevant passages from the Harijan article referred to by the author.
('83', 331, 2, 8, 696226) I must confess that I do not look upon this event with equanimity.
('83', 331, 2, 9, 696293) Cannot a limitless number of soldiers be trained out of India’s millions?
('83', 331, 2, 10, 696367) Would they not make as good fighting material as any in the world?
('83', 331, 2, 11, 696434) Then why foreigners?
('83', 331, 2, 12, 696455) We know what American aid means.
('83', 331, 2, 13, 696488) It amounts, in the end, to American influence, if not American rule, added to British.
('83', 331, 2, 14, 696575) It is a tremendous price to pay for the possible success of Allied arms.
('83', 331, 2, 15, 696648) I see no Indian freedom peeping through all this preparation for the so called defence of India.
('83', 331, 2, 16, 696745) It is a preparation pure and simple for the defence of the British Empire, whatever may be asserted to the contrary.
('83', 331, 2, 17, 696862) 9. The second paragraph of the indictment opens with this pregnant sentence:
('83', 331, 3, 18, 696939) It will be suggested that during the period of Mr. Gandhi’s first advocacy of British withdrawal from India and the meeting of the All India Congress Committee in Bombay on August 7, the Congress High Comm and, and, in the later stages, the Congress organization as a whole, were deliberately setting the stage for a mass movement designed to free India finally from British rule.
('83', 331, 3, 19, 697320) Let me italicize the phrase, It will be suggested.
('83', 331, 3, 20, 697371) Why should anything be left to suggestion about a movement which is open and above board?
('83', 331, 3, 21, 697461) Much ado has been made about the simplest things which nobody has cared to deny and of which Congressmen are even proud.
('83', 331, 3, 22, 697582) The Congress organization as a whole “deliberately set the stage designed to free India finally from British rule” as early as the year 1920, and not since my “first advocacy of British withdrawal from India” as suggested in the indictment.
('83', 331, 3, 23, 697823) Ever since that year the effort for a mass movement has never relaxed.
('83', 331, 3, 24, 697894) This can be proved
('83', 331, 4, 25, 697913) 1Vide “Foreign Soliders in India”, 19 4 1942.
('83', 332, 0, 1, 697959) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 333
('83', 332, 1, 2, 698003) from numerous speeches of Congress leaders and from Congress resolutions.
('83', 332, 1, 3, 698077) Young and impatient Congressmen and even elder men have not hesitated, at times, to press me to hasten the mass movement.
('83', 332, 1, 4, 698199) But I who knew better always restrained their ardour, and I must gratefully admit that they gladly submitted to the restraint.
('83', 332, 1, 5, 698326) The contraction of this long period to the interval between my advocacy of British withdrawal from India and the meeting of the All India Congress Committee in Bombay on August 7, is wholly wrong and misleading.
('83', 332, 1, 6, 698538) I know of no special staging since 26th April, 1942. 10. The same paragraph then says that “an essential prelimi nary” to an examination of the type of movement “is a clear understanding of the real motives underlying the move”.
('83', 332, 1, 7, 698767) Why should motives be searched when everything is there in black and white?
('83', 332, 1, 8, 698843) I can say without any hesitation that my motives are always plain.
('83', 332, 1, 9, 698910) Why I asked for the immediate withdrawal of the British power from India has been discussed by me almost threadbare in public.
('83', 332, 1, 10, 699037) 11. At page 2 of the indictment 1, a phrase has been taken from my article 2 entitled “One Thing Needful” dated 10th May, 1942, and I am represented as saying that I would devote the whole of my “energy” to this “supreme act”.
('83', 332, 1, 11, 699264) By simply detaching the phrase from its context, mystery has been made to surround it.
('83', 332, 1, 12, 699351) The phrase “supreme act” occurs in an argument addressed to an English friend and, if it is read in its setting, it ceases to be mysterious or objectionable, unless the very idea of withdrawal is held objectionable.
('83', 332, 1, 13, 699567) Here are the relevant parts from the argument:
('83', 332, 2, 14, 699614) I am convinced, therefore, that the time has come during the war, not after it, for the British and the Indians to be reconciled to complete separation from each other.
('83', 332, 2, 15, 699783) That way, and that way alone, lies the safety of both and, shall I say, the world.
('83', 332, 2, 16, 699866) I see with the naked eye that the estrangement is growing.
('83', 332, 2, 17, 699925) Every act of the British Government is being interpreted, and I think rightly, as being in its own interest and for its own safety.
('83', 332, 2, 18, 700057) There is no such thing as joint common interest....
('83', 332, 2, 19, 700109) racial superiority is treated not as a vice but a virtue.
('83', 332, 2, 20, 700167) This is true not only in India; but it is equally true in Africa, it is true in Burma
('83', 332, 3, 21, 700253) 1 Which reads: “Although his earlier proposals for British withdrawal all emphasized the importance of this withdrawal being a voluntary act willingly performed, Mr. Gandhi had already by May 10 decided that he must devote the whole of his energy to this ‘supreme act’; and it is clear that very shortly afterwards, he began to think in terms of a struggle to achieve his object” (The Indian Annual Register, 1942, Vol. II, p.
('83', 332, 3, 22, 700680) 2 Vide “One Thing Needful”, 4 5 1942.
('83', 333, 0, 1, 700718) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('83', 367, 2, 18, 793824) My own experience being quite to the contrary, I have not the shadow of a doubt that if the Government had not by their summary action unnecessarily provoked the people beyond endurance, there never would have been any violence.
('83', 367, 2, 19, 794053) The members of the Working Committee were anxious that violence on the part of the people should be avoided, not from any philanthropic motive, but from the conviction borne in upon them from the experience of hard facts, that violence by the people could not usher in independence.

('83', 368, 0, 1, 794437) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 369
('83', 368, 1, 2, 794481) because of the leaders’ belief in constitutional agitation and faith in British promises and declarations, and since 1920, because of the belief, in the first instance induced by me and then enforced by experience, that mere constitutional agitation, though it had served up to a point, could never bring in independence, and that regard being had to the condition of India, non violent action was the only sanction through which independence could be attained in the quickest manner possible.
('83', 368, 1, 3, 794975) The accumulated experience of the past thirty years, the first eight of which were in South Africa, fills me with the greatest hope that in the adoption of non violence lies the future of India and the world.
('83', 368, 1, 4, 795184) It is the most harmless and yet equally effective way of dealing with the political and economic wrongs of the downtrodden portion of humanity.
('83', 368, 1, 5, 795328) I have known from early youth that non violence is not a cloistered virtue to be practised by the individual for his peace and final salvation, but it is a rule of conduct for society if it is to live consistently with human dignity and make progress towards the attainment of peace for which it has been yearning for ages past.
('83', 368, 1, 6, 795657) It is, therefore, sad to think that a Government, the most powerful in the world, should have belittled the doctrine and put its votaries, however imperfect they may be, out of action.

('83', 375, 1, 6, 813843) 63. Independently of the argument in the indictment, I must now say something about non violence as I know it.
('83', 375, 1, 7, 813954) Its spread in all walks of life has been my mission from early youth.
('83', 375, 1, 8, 814024) This covers a period of very nearly sixty years.
('83', 375, 1, 9, 814073) It was adopted at my instance as a policy by the Congress in 1920. In its very nature it was not meant to be paraded before the world, but it was accepted as a means indispensable for the attainment of swaraj.
('83', 375, 1, 10, 814283) Congressmen saw at an early date that its mere adoption on paper had no value.
('83', 375, 1, 11, 814362) It was of use only in so far as it was put into practice individually and collectively.
('83', 375, 1, 12, 814450) It was of no more use as a badge than a rifle in the hands of a person who did not know how to use it effectively on due occasion.
('83', 375, 1, 13, 814581) Therefore if non violence has raised the Congress prestige and popularity since its adoption, it has done so in exact proportion to its use, even as the power which the rifle gives to its possessor is in exact proportion to its effective use.
('83', 375, 1, 14, 814824) The comparison cannot be carried very far.
('83', 375, 1, 15, 814867) Thus while violence is directed towards the injury, including the destruction of the aggressor and is successful only when it is stronger than that of the opponent, non violent action can be taken in respect of an opponent, however powerfully organized for violence.
('83', 375, 1, 16, 815134) Violence per se of the weak has never been known to succeed against the stronger in violence.
('83', 375, 1, 17, 815228) Success of non violent action of the very weak is a daily occurrence.
('83', 375, 1, 18, 815298) I make bold to say that I have applied to the present struggle the principles of non violence as enunciated here.
('83', 375, 1, 19, 815412) Nothing could be farther from my thought than injury to the person or property of those who are manning and regulating the machinery of British imperialism as it operates in India.
('83', 375, 1, 20, 815593) My non violence draws a fundamental distinction between the man and his machine.
('83', 375, 1, 21, 815674) I would destroy a harmful machine without compunction, never the man.
('83', 375, 1, 22, 815744) And this rule I have enforced in my dealings with my nearest relatives as also friends and associates, not without considerable success.
('83', 375, 1, 23, 815881) 64. After disposing of non violence the author has summarized what he calls the “ostensible aims” of the Wardha resolution 1 of July 14 and the Bombay resolution 2 of August 8 as follows:
('83', 375, 2, 24, 816069) 1Vide “Resolutions passed by Congress working Committee”, 14 7 1942. 2 ibid
