('83', 376, 1, 2, 816189) Three main ostensible aims are common to both the Wardha resolution of July 14 (Appendix III 1) and the Bombay resolution of August 8 (Appendix III 2).
('83', 376, 1, 3, 816341) These are: 1. To remove foreign domination over India.
('83', 376, 1, 4, 816396) 2. To check the growing ill will against Britain, with its danger of passive acceptance by the masses of aggression against India; to build up a spirit of resistance to aggression among Indians; and by granting India’s millions immediate freedom to release that energy and enthusiasm which alone can enable India to play an effective part in her own defence and in the war as a whole.
('83', 376, 1, 5, 816781) 3. To achieve unity, by the removal of the foreign power with its policy of divide and rule, which will be followed by the formation of a provisional government representative of all sections of the Indian people.
('83', 376, 1, 6, 816995) Three further aims appeared for the first time in the Bombay resolution: 4. To bring all subject and oppressed humanity to the side of the United Nations, thus giving these Nations the moral and spiritual leadership of the world.
('83', 376, 1, 7, 817225) 5. To assist Asiatic nations under foreign domination to regain their freedom and to ensure that they are not again placed under the rule of any colonial power.
('83', 376, 1, 8, 817386) 6. To bring about world federation, which would ensure the disbanding of national armies, navies and air forces, and the pooling of the world’s resources for the common good of all.
('83', 376, 1, 9, 817568) He says that “the genuineness of the first of these aims is undeniable.
('83', 376, 1, 10, 817640) The freedom of India, in whatever terms it may have been expressed, has long been the main goal of the Congress and it has been shown above how this aim coincides with one of the main motives underlying the ‘Quit India’ move.” Strange as it appears to me, notwithstanding this admission of the genuineness of the first aim, he ridicules the others in some shape or form.
('83', 376, 1, 11, 818011) I contend that all the others follow from the first.
('83', 376, 1, 12, 818064) Thus if the foreign domination goes by agreement, ill will against Britain is automatically turned into goodwill, and the energy of millions is set free on behalf of the Allied cause.
('83', 376, 1, 13, 818248) Similarly communal unity must follow as day follows night when the night of foreign domination is gone.
('83', 376, 1, 14, 818352) If nearly four hundred million people become free, other portions of oppressed humanity must also become free and naturally the Allied nations being privy to this freedom, the moral and spiritual leadership of the world comes to them without seeking.
('83', 376, 1, 15, 818603) The fifth aim is included in the fourth, and the sixth is but a repetition of the aim of the whole of humanity which it
('83', 377, 0, 1, 818723) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 377, 1, 2, 818765) must attain or perish without.
('83', 377, 1, 3, 818796) It is true that the three last aims were added in Bombay.
('83', 377, 1, 4, 818854) That surely is not a matter to cavil at.
('83', 377, 1, 5, 818895) Even if they were a result of criticism, what is there wrong about it?
('83', 377, 1, 6, 818966) No democratic organization can afford to defy criticism, for it has to live upon the fresh air of criticism.
('83', 377, 1, 7, 819075) As a matter of fact, however, world federation and rights of non white people are no new ideas for Congressmen.
('83', 377, 1, 8, 819187) They have been mentioned in Congress resolutions on other occasions.
('83', 377, 1, 9, 819256) The paragraph about world federation found place in the August resolution at the instance of a European friend, and about non white people at mine.
('83', 377, 1, 10, 819404) 65. As to the disturbances that took place after the arrests of 9th August, I have carefully read Chapters IV and V of the indictment detailing them as also the appendices purporting to be instructions from various bodies.
('83', 377, 1, 11, 819627) I must refuse to judge these one sided statements or unverified documents.
('83', 377, 1, 12, 819702) As to the so called instructions, I can say that, so far as they are contrary to non violence, they can never have my approval.
('83', 377, 1, 13, 819830) 66. One searches in vain in the indictment for a detailed account of the measures taken by the Government by way of reprisals.
('83', 377, 1, 14, 819957) And if one is to believe what has been allowed to appear in the Press about these measures, the so called misdeeds of exasperated people, whether they can be described as Congressmen or not, pale into insignificance.
('83', 377, 1, 15, 820174) 67. Now for the responsibility for the happenings after the wholesale arrests of 9th August last.
('83', 377, 1, 16, 820272) The most natural way to look at the disturbances is that they broke out after the arrests which were, therefore, the cause.
('83', 377, 1, 17, 820396) The indictment has been framed for the sole purpose, as the title shows, of fastening the responsibility on the Congress.
('83', 377, 1, 18, 820518) The argument seems to me to be this.
('83', 377, 1, 19, 820555) First I and then the Congress had been setting the stage for a mass movement since April 1942 when I first bruited the idea of British withdrawal popularly known as “Quit India”.
('83', 377, 1, 20, 820734) Mass movement was bound to result in the outbreak of violence.
('83', 377, 1, 21, 820797) I and the Congressmen who had accepted my guidance had intended that violence should take place.
('83', 377, 1, 22, 820894) Leaders had been preaching it.
('83', 377, 1, 23, 820925) Hence the disturbances were to take place in any case.
('83', 377, 1, 24, 820980) The arrest, therefore, merely anticipated the violent movement and nipped it in the bud.
('83', 377, 1, 25, 821069) This sums up the reasoning in the indictment.
('83', 377, 1, 26, 821115) 68. I have endeavoured to show that no special stage for a mass movement was set or contemplated because of my proposal for British
('83', 378, 0, 1, 821247) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 379
('83', 378, 1, 2, 821291) withdrawal, that violence was never contemplated by me or any Congress leader, that I had declared that, if Congressmen indulged in an orgy of violence, they might not find me alive in their midst, that the mass movement was never started by me, the sole charge for starting it was vested in me, that I had contemplated negotiations with the Government, that I was to start the movement only on failure of negotiations and that I had envisaged an interval of “two or three weeks” for the negotiations.
('83', 378, 1, 3, 821793) It is, therefore, clear that but for the arrests no such disturbances would have taken place as happened on 9th August last and after.
('83', 378, 1, 4, 821928) I would have strained every nerve first to make the negotiations successful and secondly, if I had failed, to avoid disturbances.
('83', 378, 1, 5, 822058) The Government would have been no less able to suppress them than they were in August last.
('83', 378, 1, 6, 822150) Only they would have had some case against me and the Congress.
('83', 378, 1, 7, 822214) It was the duty of the Government, before taking action, to study the speeches of the Congress leaders and myself at the All India Congress Committee meeting.
('83', 378, 1, 8, 822373) 69. The Congress leaders were desirous that the movement should remain non violent, if only because they knew that no violent movement in the existing circumstances could possibly succeed when matched against a most powerfully equipped Government.
('83', 378, 1, 9, 822621) Whatever violence was committed by people, whether Congressmen or others, was, therefore, committed in spite of the leaders’ wishes.
('83', 378, 1, 10, 822754) If it is held otherwise by the Government, it should be proved beyond doubt before an impartial tribunal.
('83', 378, 1, 11, 822860) But why seek to shift the responsibility when the cause is patent?
('83', 378, 1, 12, 822927) The Government action in enforcing India wide arrests was so violent that the populace which was in sympathy with the Congress lost self control.
('83', 378, 1, 13, 823073) The loss of self control cannot imply Congress complicity but it does imply that the power of endurance of human nature has limitations.
('83', 378, 1, 14, 823210) If Government action was in excess of the endurance of human nature, it and, therefore, its authors were responsible for the explosions that followed.
('83', 378, 1, 15, 823361) But the Government may assert that the arrests were necessary.
('83', 378, 1, 16, 823424) If so, why should the Government fight shy of taking the responsibility for the consequences of their action?
('83', 378, 1, 17, 823534) The wonder to me is that the Government at all need to justify their action when they know their will is law.
('83', 378, 1, 18, 823644) 70. Let me analyse the system of Government in vogue here.
('83', 378, 1, 19, 823703) A population numbering nearly four hundred millions of people,
('83', 379, 0, 1, 823766) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 379, 1, 2, 823808) belonging to an ancient civilization, are being ruled by a British representative called Viceroy and Governor General aided by 250 officials called Collectors and supported by a strong British garrison with a large number of Indian soldiers, trained by British officers, and carefully isolated from the populace.
('83', 379, 1, 3, 824121) The Viceroy enjoys within his own sphere powers much larger than the King of England.
('83', 379, 1, 4, 824207) Such powers, as far as I know, are not enjoyed by any other person in the world.
('83', 379, 1, 5, 824288) The Collectors are miniature Viceroys in their own spheres.
('83', 379, 1, 6, 824348) They are first and foremost, as their name implies, collectors of revenue in their own districts and have magisterial powers.
('83', 379, 1, 7, 824474) They can requisition the military to their aid when they think necessary.
('83', 379, 1, 8, 824548) They are also political agents for the small chieftains within their jurisdiction, and they are in the place of overlords to them.
('83', 379, 1, 9, 824679) 71. Contrast this with the Congress, the most truly democratic organization in the world—not because of its numerical strength, but because its only sanction deliberately adopted is non violence.
('83', 379, 1, 10, 824875) From its inception the Congress has been a democratic body, seeking to represent all India.
('83', 379, 1, 11, 824967) However feeble and imperfect the attempt may have been, the Congress has never in its history of now nearly sixty years shifted its gaze from the Pole Star of India’s freedom.
('83', 379, 1, 12, 825143) It has progressed from stage to stage in its march towards democracy in the truest term.
('83', 379, 1, 13, 825232) If it is said, as it has been, that the Congress learnt the spirit of democracy from Great Britain, no Congressman would care to deny the statement, though it must be added that the roots were to be found in the old panchayat system.
('83', 379, 1, 14, 825466) It can never brook Nazi, Fascist or Japanese domination.
('83', 379, 1, 15, 825523) An organization whose very breath is freedom, and which pits itself against the most powerfully organized imperialism, will perish to a man in the attempt to resist all domination.
('83', 379, 1, 16, 825704) So long as it clings to non violence it will be uncrushable and unconquerable.
('83', 379, 1, 17, 825783) 72. What can be the cause of the extraordinary resentment against the Congress into which the Government have betrayed themselves?
('83', 379, 1, 18, 825914) I have never known them before to exhibit so much irritation.
('83', 379, 1, 19, 825976) Does the cause lie in the “Quit India” formula?
('83', 379, 1, 20, 826024) Disturbances cannot be the cause, because the resentment began to show itself soon after the publication of my proposal for British withdrawal.
('83', 379, 1, 21, 826168) It crystallized into the wholesale arrests of 9th August last which were prearranged and merely awaited the passing of the resolution of 8th August.
('83', 379, 1, 22, 826317) Yet there was nothing novel in the resolution
('83', 380, 0, 1, 826363) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 381
('83', 380, 1, 2, 826407) save the “Quit India” formula.
('83', 380, 1, 3, 826438) Mass movements have been known to be on the Congress programme ever since 1920. But freedom seemed elusive.
('83', 380, 1, 4, 826546) Now the Hindu Miuslim disunity, now the pledges to the Princes, now the interests of the scheduled classes, now the vested interests of Europeans barred the gateway to freedom.
('83', 380, 1, 5, 826723) Divide and rule was an inexhaustible well.
('83', 380, 1, 6, 826766) The sands of time were running out.
('83', 380, 1, 7, 826802) Rivers of blood were flowing fast among the warring nations, and politically minded India was looking on helplessly—the masses were inert.
('83', 380, 1, 8, 826941) Hence the cry of “Quit India”.
('83', 380, 1, 9, 826972) It gave body to the freedom movement.
('83', 380, 1, 10, 827010) The cry was unanswerable.
('83', 380, 1, 11, 827036) Those who were anxious to play their part in the world crisis found vent in that cry of anguish.
('83', 380, 1, 12, 827133) Its root is in the will to save democracy from Nazism as well as imperialism.
('83', 380, 1, 13, 827211) For, satisfaction of the Congress demand meant assurance of victory of democracy over any combination of reactionary forces and deliverance of China and Russia from the menace of Japan and Germany respectively.
('83', 380, 1, 14, 827422) But the demand irritated the Government.
('83', 380, 1, 15, 827463) They distrusted those who were associated with the demand and thereby they themselves became the greatest impediment to the war effort.
('83', 380, 1, 16, 827599) It is wrong, therefore, to accuse the Congress of hindering war effort.
('83', 380, 1, 17, 827671) Congress activity up to the night of 8th August was confined to resolutions only.
('83', 380, 1, 18, 827753) The dawn of the 9th saw the Congress imprisoned.
('83', 380, 1, 19, 827802) What followed was a direct result of the Government action.
('83', 380, 1, 20, 827862) 73. The resentment over what I hold to be a just and honourable desire confirms the popular suspicion about the bonafides of the Government professions about democracy and freedom after the war.
('83', 380, 1, 21, 828057) If the Government were sincere, they would have welcomed the offer of help made by the Congress.
('83', 380, 1, 22, 828154) Congressmen who have been fighting for India’s liberty for over half a century would have flocked to the Allied banner as one man for the defence of India’s freedom newly won.
('83', 380, 1, 23, 828330) But the Government did not wish to treat India as an equal partner and ally.
('83', 380, 1, 24, 828407) They put out of action those who made this demand.
('83', 380, 1, 25, 828458) Some of them are even being hounded as if they were dangerous criminals.
('83', 380, 1, 26, 828531) I have in mind Shri Jayaprakash Narayan and others like him.
('83', 380, 1, 27, 828592) A reward of Rs. 5,000, now doubled, has been promised to the informant who would show his hiding place.
('83', 380, 1, 28, 828696) I have taken Shri Jayaprakash Narayan purposely as my illustration because, as he very rightly says, he differs from me on several fundamentals.
('83', 380, 1, 29, 828841) But my differences, great as they are, do not blind me to his indomitable courage and his sacrifice of all that a man holds dear for the love of
('83', 381, 0, 1, 828986) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 381, 1, 2, 829028) his country.
('83', 381, 1, 3, 829041) I have read his manifesto which is given as an appendix to the indictment.
('83', 381, 1, 4, 829116) Though I cannot subscribe to some of the views expressed therein, it breathes nothing but burning patriotism and his impatience of foreign domination.
('83', 381, 1, 5, 829267) It is a virtue of which any country would be proud.
('83', 381, 1, 6, 829319) 74. So much for politically minded Congressmen.
('83', 381, 1, 7, 829367) In the constructive department of the Congress also the Government have deprived themselves of the best talent in the country for the organization of hand industries which are so vital a need in war time.
('83', 381, 1, 8, 829572) The All India Spinners’ Association, which is responsible for having distributed without fuss over three crores of rupees as wages among the poor villagers whom no one had reached and whose labour was being wasted, has come in for a heavy hand.
('83', 381, 1, 9, 829817) Its President Shri Jajuji 1 and many of his co workers have been imprisoned without trial and without any known reason.
('83', 381, 1, 10, 829937) Khadi centres which are trust property have been confiscated to the Government.
('83', 381, 1, 11, 830017) I do not know the law under which such property can be confiscated.
('83', 381, 1, 12, 830085) And the tragedy is that the confiscators are themselves unable to run these centres which were producing and distributing cloth.
('83', 381, 1, 13, 830214) Khadi and charkhas have been reported to have been burnt by the authorities.
('83', 381, 1, 14, 830291) The All India Village Industries’ Association worked by Kumarappa brothers 2 has also received much the same treatment.
('83', 381, 1, 15, 830411) Shri Vinoba Bhave is an institution by himself.
('83', 381, 1, 16, 830459) Many workers were incessantly doing creative labour under his guidance.
('83', 381, 1, 17, 830531) Most men and women of constructive organization are not political workers.
('83', 381, 1, 18, 830606) They are devoted to constructive work of the highest merit.
('83', 381, 1, 19, 830666) And if some of them have found it necessary to appear at all on the political field, it is a matter for the Government to reflect upon.
('83', 381, 1, 20, 830802) To put such organizations and their supervisors under duress is, in my opinion, an unpardonable interference with war effort.
('83', 381, 1, 21, 830928) The self satisfaction with which the highest officials proclaim that limitless men and material are being had from this unhappy land is truly amazing while the inhabitants of India are suffering from shortage of food, clothing and many other necessaries of life.
('83', 381, 1, 22, 831191) I make bold to say that this scarcity would have been largely minimized, if not altogether obviated, if, instead of imprisoning Congress workers throughout India, the Government had utilized their services.
('83', 381, 1, 23, 831398) The Government had two striking illustrations of the efficient working by the Congress agency—I mean the handling of the disastrous Bihar earthquake 3 by Congressmen under
('83', 381, 2, 24, 831570) 1 Shrikrishnadas Jaju 2 J. C. Kumarappa and Bharatan Kumarappa 3 In 1934
('83', 382, 0, 1, 831643) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 383
('83', 382, 1, 2, 831687) Dr. Rajendra Prasad and of the equally disastrous flood 1 in Gujarat under Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel.
('83', 382, 1, 3, 831788) 75. This brings me to the end of my reply to the indictment.
('83', 382, 1, 4, 831849) It has become much longer than I had wanted to make it.
('83', 382, 1, 5, 831905) It has cost me and my co workers in the camp no end of labour.
('83', 382, 1, 6, 831968) Although I must ask, in fairness to myself and the cause I represent, for the publication of this reply, my chief purpose is to carry conviction to the Government that the indictment contains no proof of the allegations against the Congress and me.
('83', 382, 1, 7, 832217) The Government know that the public in India seem to have distrusted the indictment and regarded it as designed for foreign propaganda.
('83', 382, 1, 8, 832353) Men like Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and the Rt.
('83', 382, 1, 9, 832396) Shri M. R. Jayakar have given their opinion that the “evidence” produced in the indictment is of no judicial value.
('83', 382, 1, 10, 832512) Therefore the Government should withdraw the indictment.
('83', 382, 1, 11, 832569) I see from the preface to the indictment that the Government have in their possession “valuable evidence”, presumably incriminating the detenus.
('83', 382, 1, 12, 832714) I submit that if the Government cannot safely divulge the evidence, they should discharge the detenus and bring to book those who, after discharge, may be caught in the act of committing or promoting crimes.
('83', 382, 1, 13, 832922) With limitless power at their back, they need not resort to unsustainable accusations.
('83', 382, 1, 14, 833009) 76. It will be noticed that although the indictment is a Government publication, I have only criticized its unknown author in the fond hope that the individual members composing the Government of India have not read the originals on which it is based.
('83', 382, 1, 15, 833261) For, I am of opinion that no one having a knowledge of the originals could possibly endorse the inferences and innuendoes with which it is replete.
('83', 382, 1, 16, 833409) 77. Lastly I wish to state that if I have anywhere erred in analysing the indictment, and if my error is pointed out to me, I shall gladly correct myself.
('83', 382, 1, 17, 833564) I have simply written as I have felt.
('83', 382, 2, 18, 833602) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI [PS.] 1
('83', 382, 3, 19, 833635) It is requested that the appendices should be regarded as an integral part of the reply.
('83', 382, 4, 20, 833724) M. K.G.

('83', 383, 1, 2, 833784) APPENDIX I
('83', 383, 2, 3, 833795) BRITISH WITHDRAWAL
('83', 383, 3, 4, 833814) In its earlier stage, Mr. Gandhi’s “Quit India” move was meant and was widely interpreted as a proposal for the physical withdrawal from India of the British, and of all British and Allied troops (Indictment p.
('83', 383, 4, 5, 834025) (A) CONFUSION 1
('83', 383, 5, 6, 834041) (B) OUT OF TOUCH 2
('83', 383, 6, 7, 834060) (C) FREE INDIA CAN HELP BEST
('83', 383, 7, 8, 834089) Answering to the question of a Press correspondent whether his present policy
('83', 383, 8, 9, 834167) as revealed by his writings did not vitiate his own declaration that he was a friend of
('83', 383, 9, 10, 834255) China, Gandhiji said:
('83', 383, 10, 11, 834277) “My answer is an emphatic ‘No’.
('83', 383, 10, 12, 834309) I remain the passionate friend of China that I
('83', 383, 11, 13, 834356) have always claimed to be.
('83', 383, 11, 14, 834383) I know what the loss of freedom means.
('83', 383, 11, 15, 834422) Therefore I could
('83', 383, 12, 16, 834440) not but be in sympathy with China which is my next door neighbour in distress.
('83', 383, 13, 17, 834519) if I believed in violence and if I could influence India, I would put in motion every
('83', 383, 14, 18, 834605) force at my command on behalf of China to save her liberty.
('83', 383, 14, 19, 834665) In making,
('83', 383, 15, 20, 834676) therefore, the suggestion which I have made about withdrawal of British power, I have
('83', 383, 16, 21, 834762) not lost sight of China.
('83', 383, 16, 22, 834787) But, because I have China in mind, I feel that the only
('83', 383, 17, 23, 834843) effective way for India to help China is to persuade Great Britain to free India and let a
('83', 383, 18, 24, 834934) free India make her full contribution to the war effort.
('83', 383, 18, 25, 834991) Instead of being sullen and
('83', 383, 19, 26, 835019) discontented, India free will be a mighty force for the good of mankind in general.
('83', 383, 20, 27, 835103) is true that the solution I have presented is a heroic solution beyond the ken of
('83', 383, 21, 28, 835185) Englishmen.
('83', 383, 21, 29, 835197) But, being a true friend of Britain and China and Russia, I must not
('83', 383, 22, 30, 835266) suppress the solution which I believe to be eminently practical and probably the only
('83', 383, 23, 31, 835352) one in order to save the situation, and in order to convert the war into a power for
('83', 383, 24, 32, 835437) good instead of being what it is, a peril to humanity.

('83', 383, 25, 34, 835579) 91, where it precedes the letter.
('83', 383, 25, 35, 835613) According to Correspondence with Mr. Gandhi, “the cover of Mr. Gandhi’s original reply contained the request”.
('83', 383, 25, 36, 835724) The postscript and appendices are not available in the photostat source.

('83', 384, 0, 1, 836086) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 385
('83', 384, 1, 2, 836130) I AM NOT PRO JAPANESE
('83', 384, 2, 3, 836152) “Pandit Nehru told me yesterday that he heard people in Lahore and Delhi
('83', 384, 3, 4, 836225) saying that I have turned pro Japanese.
('83', 384, 3, 5, 836265) I could only laugh at the suggestion for, if I
('83', 384, 4, 6, 836312) am sincere in my passion for freedom, I could not consciously or unconsciously take
('83', 384, 5, 7, 836396) a step which will involve India in the position of merely changing masters.
('83', 384, 6, 8, 836472) spite of my resistance to the Japanese menace with my whole soul, the mishap
('83', 384, 7, 9, 836549) occurs, of which I have never denied the possibility, then the blame would rest
('83', 384, 8, 10, 836629) wholly on British shoulders.
('83', 384, 8, 11, 836658) I have no shadow of doubt about it.
('83', 384, 8, 12, 836694) I have made no
('83', 384, 9, 13, 836709) suggestion, which, even from the military standpoint, is fraught with the slightest
('83', 384, 10, 14, 836793) danger to British power or to Chinese.
('83', 384, 10, 15, 836832) It is obvious that India is not allowed to pull
('83', 384, 11, 16, 836880) her weight in favour of China.
('83', 384, 11, 17, 836911) If British power is withdrawn from India in an orderly
('83', 384, 12, 18, 836966) manner, Britain will be relieved of the burden of keeping the peace in India and at the
('83', 384, 13, 19, 837054) same time gain in a free India an ally not in the cause of the Empire—because she
('83', 384, 14, 20, 837136) would have renounced in toto all her imperial designs—but in a defence, not pretended
('83', 384, 15, 21, 837222) but wholly real, of human freedom.
('83', 384, 15, 22, 837257) That I assert and that only is the burden of my
('83', 384, 16, 23, 837305) recent writings, and I shall continue to do so, so long as I am allowed by the British
('83', 384, 17, 24, 837392) power.”
('83', 384, 18, 25, 837400) NO SECRECY
('83', 384, 19, 26, 837411) “Now what about your plan; you are reported to have matured plans for
('83', 384, 20, 27, 837481) launching some big offensive?” was the next question.
('83', 384, 20, 28, 837535) Gandhiji replied:
('83', 384, 21, 29, 837553) “Well, I have never believed in secrecy nor do I do so now.
('83', 384, 21, 30, 837613) There are certainly
('83', 384, 22, 31, 837633) many plans floating in my brain.
('83', 384, 22, 32, 837666) But just now I merely allow them to float in my
('83', 384, 23, 33, 837714) My first task is to educate the public mind in India and world opinion, in so far
('83', 384, 24, 34, 837796) as I am allowed to do so.
('83', 384, 24, 35, 837822) And when I have finished that process to my satisfaction, I
('83', 384, 25, 36, 837882) may have to do something.
('83', 384, 25, 37, 837908) That something may be very big, if the Congress is with
('83', 384, 26, 38, 837964) me and the people are with me.
('83', 384, 26, 39, 837995) But British authority will have a full knowledge of
('83', 384, 27, 40, 838047) anything I may wish to do, before I enforce it.
('83', 384, 27, 41, 838095) Remember, I have yet to see the
('83', 384, 28, 42, 838127) Maulana Saheb.
('83', 384, 28, 43, 838142) My talks with Pandit Nehru are yet unfinished.
('83', 384, 28, 44, 838189) I may say that they
('83', 384, 29, 45, 838209) were wholly of a friendly nature and we have come nearer to each other even with the
('83', 384, 30, 46, 838294) unfinished talk of yesterday.
('83', 384, 30, 47, 838324) Naturally I want to carry the whole of the Congress with
('83', 384, 31, 48, 838381) me, if I can, as I want to carry the whole of India with me.
('83', 384, 31, 49, 838442) For, my conception of
('83', 384, 32, 50, 838464) freedom is no narrow conception.

('83', 385, 1, 2, 838670) TO RESIST SLAVE DRIVERS
('83', 385, 2, 3, 838694) “How are we to help in driving away the British from here?” was the first question that was asked.
('83', 385, 2, 4, 838793) “We don’t want to drive away the British people from here.
('83', 385, 2, 5, 838852) It is the British rulers whom we are asking quietly to withdraw.
('83', 385, 2, 6, 838917) It is the British domination that we want to vanish from our land.
('83', 385, 2, 7, 838984) We have no quarrel with the Englishmen, many of whom are my friends, but we want the rule to end altogether, for that is the poison that corrupts all it touches, that is the obstacle that stops all progress.
('83', 385, 2, 8, 839192) “And what is needed for this are two things the knowledge that the domination is a greater evil than any other evil we can think of, and that we have to get rid of it no matter what it may cost.
('83', 385, 2, 9, 839387) The knowledge is so necessary because the British exercise their power and domination in all kinds of subtle and insidious ways that it is sometimes difficult to know that we are bound hand and foot.
('83', 385, 2, 10, 839587) Next is the will to throw off the chains.
('83', 385, 2, 11, 839629) We have simply to cultivate the will not to do the rulers’ biddings.
('83', 385, 2, 12, 839698) Is it very difficult?
('83', 385, 2, 13, 839720) How can one be compelled to accept slavery?
('83', 385, 2, 14, 839764) I simply refuse to do the master’s bidding.
('83', 385, 2, 15, 839808) He may torture me, break my bones to atoms and even kill me.
('83', 385, 2, 16, 839869) He will then have my dead body, not my obedience.
('83', 385, 2, 17, 839919) Ultimately, therefore, it is I who am the victor and not he, for he has failed in getting me to do what he wanted done.
('83', 385, 2, 18, 840039) “That is what I am trying to impress both on those whom I want to retire and those who are bound in their chains.
('83', 385, 2, 19, 840153) I am going to use all my powers to do so, but not violence—simply because I have no faith in it....
('83', 385, 2, 20, 840253) “But I am going to be patient, I am not going to hurry or hustle you.

('83', 395, 1, 2, 864996) WHY NOT TODAY?
('83', 395, 2, 3, 865011) “Why can’t all this be done today, without the British withdrawal?” said Mr. Emeny returning to the charge.
('83', 395, 2, 4, 865119) “The answer is simple.
('83', 395, 2, 5, 865142) Why can’t a prisoner do a thing which a free man can do?
('83', 395, 2, 6, 865199) You may not have been behind prison bars, but I have been and I know.

('83', 395, 2, 8, 865363) The very breath is controlled by British power.

('83', 395, 2, 11, 865552) Our habit has been that we can never be free.

('83', 395, 3, 15, 865925) (R) TO AMERICAN FRIENDS
('83', 395, 4, 16, 865949) I claim to be a votary of truth from my childhood.
('83', 395, 4, 17, 866000) It was the most natural thing to me.
('83', 395, 4, 18, 866037) My prayerful search gave me the revealing maxim “Truth is God” instead of the usual one “God is Truth”.
('83', 395, 4, 19, 866141) That maxim enables me to see God face to face as it were.
('83', 395, 4, 20, 866199) I feel Him pervade every fibre of my being.
('83', 395, 4, 21, 866243) With this Truth as witness between you and me, I assert that I would not have asked my country to invite Great Britain to withdraw her rule over India, irrespective of any demand to the contrary, if I had not seen at once that for the sake of Great Britain and the Allied cause it was necessary for British boldly to perform the duty of freeing India from bondage.
('83', 395, 4, 22, 866608) Without this essential act of tardy justice, Britain could not justify her position before the unmurmuring world conscience, which is there nevertheless.
('83', 395, 4, 23, 866762) Singapore, Malaya and Burma taught me that the disaster must not be repeated in India.
('83', 395, 4, 24, 866849) I make bold to say that it cannot be averted unless Britain trusts the people of India to use their liberty in favour of the Allied cause.
('83', 395, 4, 25, 866988) By that supreme act of justice Britain would have taken away all cause for the seething discontent of India.
('83', 395, 4, 26, 867097) She will turn the growing ill will into active goodwill.
('83', 395, 4, 27, 867154) I submit that it is worth all the battleships and airships that your wonder working engineers and financial resources can produce.

('83', 395, 4, 29, 867434) It is of immense value to the Allied cause, if it is also of equal value to India.

('83', 396, 2, 3, 868038) JUSTICE OF CONGRESS DEMAND
('83', 396, 3, 4, 868065) The justice of the demand for the ending of British power has never been questioned; the moment chosen for enforcing it is the target of attack.
('83', 396, 3, 5, 868210) It is clear as crystal in the Working Committee resolution, why this moment is chosen.
('83', 396, 3, 6, 868297) Let me paraphrase it: India is not playing any effective part in the war.

('83', 396, 3, 9, 868728) We feel that such an event would be a calamity of the first magnitude.
('83', 396, 3, 10, 868799) We can avoid it if India gains her freedom.
('83', 396, 3, 11, 868843) To distrust this simple, natural and honest declaration is to court disaster.
('83', 396, 4, 12, 868921) AZAD’S STATEMENT CITED
('83', 396, 5, 13, 868944) But the critics say: ‘To whom are the British rulers to hand the keys on their withdrawal?’ It is a good question.
('83', 396, 5, 14, 869059) Here is what Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, the Congress President, has said: “The Congress always stands, firstly, for sympathy towards democratic countries, secondly, never desires to embarrass Britain and war efforts, and thirdly, it stands for opposition to the Japanese aggression.
('83', 396, 5, 15, 869340) The Congress does not desire to take power for itself but for all.
('83', 396, 5, 16, 869407) If real power is handed over to the Congress, surely it will approach other parties and will persuade them to join.” The Congress President added that he “had no objection to Britain handing over power to the Muslim League or any other party, provided it was real independence.
('83', 396, 5, 17, 869685) The party will have to approach other parties as no single party can function properly without the co operation of other parties.” The only thing needful is to hand over complete control without reservation save that, during the war period, the Allied troops will operate to stem the Japanese or Axis attack.
('83', 396, 5, 18, 869994) But they will have no power of interference with the affairs of India which will be as free as Great Britain herself.

('83', 399, 4, 11, 876339) DEAR LORD LLNLITHGOW,
('83', 399, 5, 12, 876361) My only excuse for writing you this letter is the deep pain I feel, as one born of English parents, over the falsehoods regarding Gandhiji and the Indian National Congress which seem to have appeared in certain English papers without being officially contradicted.
('83', 399, 6, 13, 876626) Within the limits of the newspapers that reach me here, I have been watching the ever growing volume of anti Congress propaganda in the British Press.
('83', 399, 6, 14, 876777) Of the various untruths that are being circulated, I want, in this letter, to deal with only one, namely, the assertion that Gandhiji and the Congress are pro Japanese.
('83', 399, 6, 15, 876946) For samples of such propaganda that has come to my notice, I would refer to The Bombay Chronicle Weekly of November 29, 1942, page 22, and to The Hindu, (Dak Edition) of December 19, 1942, page 4, column 3.
('83', 399, 7, 16, 877153) Amongst the quotations and facsimiles given in The Bombay Chronicle Weekly, is a photograph of the first page of the London Daily Sketch of August 5, 1942, showing a full page headline “Gandhi’s India Jap Peace Plan Exposed”, and lower down, on the same page, a photograph of myself with the sub heading “English Woman Gandhi’s Jap Peace Envoy”.
('83', 399, 7, 17, 877499) The Punch cartoons of which facsimiles are also given, are, if possible, even more disgraceful.
('83', 399, 7, 18, 877595) In The Hindu, there is a protest by Shri K. M. Munshi from which it would appear that this libellous propaganda has spread even to the London Daily Herald.
('83', 399, 8, 19, 877751) 1 For the text under these titles, vide “Question Box”, 3 6 1942; 12 6 1942; 30 5 1942; “Answers to Questions”, on or before 21 7 1942 and “Cable to The Sunday Despatch”, on or before 29 5 1942. 2 ibid
('83', 400, 0, 1, 877953) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 401
('83', 400, 1, 2, 877997) Now the reason for my bringing this matter before you is that I have in my possession correspondence that passed between Gandhiji and myself while I was in Orissa, after the April meeting of the All India Congress Committee at Allahabad, which proves beyond the shadow of a doubt that Gandhiji is cent per cent anti Japanese.

('83', 400, 28, 31, 880079) [I] MIRABEHN’S QUESTION ON THE FEARED INVASION AND
('83', 400, 29, 32, 880130) OCCUPATION BY THE JAPANESE
('83', 400, 30, 33, 880157) We may take it that the Japanese will land somewhere along the Orissa coast.
('83', 400, 30, 34, 880234) Probably there will be no bombing or firing at the time of landing, as there are no
('83', 401, 0, 1, 880318) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 401, 1, 2, 880360) defence measures on the coast.
('83', 401, 1, 3, 880391) From the coast they will advance rapidly across the flat, dry rice fields, where the only obstructions are rivers and ditches, now mostly dry and nowhere unfordable.
('83', 401, 1, 4, 880557) As far as we are able to make out, there will be no serious attempts to hold the Japanese advance until the hilly and wooded regions of the Orissa State are reached.
('83', 401, 1, 5, 880723) The army of defence, whatever it is, is reported to be hidden in the jungles of those parts.
('83', 401, 1, 6, 880816) It is likely to make a desperate attempt to defend the Jamshedpur road, but the chances of its being successful must be very small.
('83', 401, 1, 7, 880948) That means we may expect a battle to be fought in the north west of Orissa, after which the Japanese army will pass on into Bihar.
('83', 401, 1, 8, 881079) At that time the Japanese are not likely to be broadly distributed over the country, but concentrated on their lines of communication between the sea and their advancing army.
('83', 401, 1, 9, 881255) The British administration will have previously disappeared from the scene.
('83', 401, 1, 10, 881331) The problem before us is, in the event of these things happening how are we to act?
('83', 401, 1, 11, 881415) The Japanese armies will rush over the fields and through the villages not as avowed enemies of the population, but as chasers and destroyers of the British and American war effort.
('83', 401, 1, 12, 881597) The population in its turn is vague in its feeling.
('83', 401, 1, 13, 881649) The strongest feeling is fear and distrust of the British, which is growing day by day, on account of the treatment they are receiving.
('83', 401, 1, 14, 881785) Anything that is not British is therefore something welcome.
('83', 401, 1, 15, 881846) Here is a funny example.
('83', 401, 1, 16, 881871) The villagers in some parts say: “Oh, the aeroplanes that make a great noise are British, but there are silent planes also, and they are Mahatma planes.” I think the only thing possible for these simple innocent people to learn is the attitude of neutrality, for, it is, in reality, the only position that can be made logical to them.
('83', 401, 1, 17, 882206) The British not only leave them to their fate without even instructing them in self protection from bombing, etc., but they issue such orders as will, if obeyed, kill them before the day of battle comes.
('83', 401, 1, 18, 882410) How then can they be ready enthusiastically to obstruct the Japanese who are chasing this detested raj, especially when the Japanese are saying: “It is not you we have come to fight.” But I have found the villagers ready to take up the position of neutrality.
('83', 401, 1, 19, 882670) That is to say, they would leave the Japanese to pass over their fields and villages and try as far as possible not to come in contact with them.
('83', 401, 1, 20, 882816) They would hide their food stuffs and money, and decline to serve the Japanese.
('83', 401, 1, 21, 882896) But even that much resistance would be difficult to obtain in some parts, the dislike of the British raj being so great that anything anti British will be welcomed with open arms.
('83', 401, 1, 22, 883076) I feel we have got to try and gauge the maximum resistance which the average inhabitants may be expected to put up, and maintain, and make that our definite stand.
('83', 401, 1, 23, 883240) A steady, long sustained stand, though not cent per cent resistance, will be more effective in the long run than a stiff stand which quickly breaks.
('83', 401, 1, 24, 883389) This maximum sustainable stand which we may expect from the average people is probably:
('83', 402, 0, 1, 883477) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 403
('83', 402, 1, 2, 883521) 1. To resist firmly, mostly non violently, the commandeering by the Japanese of any land, houses, or movable property.
('83', 402, 1, 3, 883640) 2. To render no forced labour to the Japanese.
('83', 402, 1, 4, 883687) 3. Not to take up any sort of administrative service under the Japanese.
('83', 402, 1, 5, 883760) (This may be hard to control in connection with some type of city people, Government opportunists and Indians brought in from other parts.) 4. To buy nothing from the Japanese.
('83', 402, 1, 6, 883937) 5. To refuse their currency and any efforts on their part at setting up a raj.
('83', 402, 1, 7, 884016) (Lack of workers and lack of time make it very hard, we have to strive to stem the tide.) Now as to certain difficulties and questions which arise: 1. The Japanese may offer to pay for labour, food and materials in British currency notes.
('83', 402, 1, 8, 884255) Should the people refuse to sell for good prices or work for a good wage?
('83', 402, 1, 9, 884329) For long sustained resistance over many months it may be difficult to prevent this.
('83', 402, 1, 10, 884413) So long as they refuse to buy or take “service”, the exploitation danger is kept off.
('83', 402, 1, 11, 884499) 2. What should be done about the rebuilding of bridges, canals, etc., which the British will have blown up?
('83', 402, 1, 12, 884607) We shall also need the bridges and canals.
('83', 402, 1, 13, 884650) Should we, therefore, set our hands to their rebuilding, even if it means working side by side with the Japanese, or should we retire on the approach of Japanese bridge builders?
('83', 402, 1, 14, 884829) 3. If Indian soldiers, who were taken prisoners in Singapore and Burma, land with the Japanese invading army, what should be our attitude towards them?
('83', 402, 1, 15, 884981) Should we treat them with the same aloofness as we are to show the Japanese, or should we try to win them over to our way of thinking?
('83', 402, 1, 16, 885116) 4. After the exodus (before the approaching Japanese) of the British raj what shall we do about currency?
('83', 402, 1, 17, 885222) 5. After the battles have been fought and the Japanese armies will have advanced, the battle fields will be left strewn with dead and wounded.
('83', 402, 1, 18, 885365) I think we must unhesitatingly work side by side with the Japanese in burning and burying the dead and picking up and serving the wounded.
('83', 402, 1, 19, 885504) The Japanese are likely to attend to the lightly wounded of their own men and take prisoners the lightly wounded of their enemy, but the rest would probably be left, and it will be our sacred duty to attend to them.
('83', 402, 1, 20, 885720) For this we are from now planning the training of volunteers under the guidance of local doctors.
('83', 402, 1, 21, 885818) Their services can also be used in case of internal disturbances, epidemics, etc.
('83', 402, 1, 22, 885900) 6. Besides dead and wounded on the battle field, a certain amount of rifles, revolvers and other small arms are likely to be left lying about unpicked up by the Japanese.
('83', 402, 1, 23, 886071) If we do not make a point of collecting these things, they are likely to fall into the hands of robbers, thieves and other bad characters, who always come down like hawks to loot a battle field.
('83', 402, 1, 24, 886266) In an unarmed country like India this would lead to
('83', 403, 0, 1, 886318) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 403, 1, 2, 886360) much trouble.
('83', 403, 1, 3, 886374) In the event of our collecting such arms and ammunition, what should we do with them?
('83', 403, 1, 4, 886460) My instinct is to take them out to sea and drop them in the ocean.
('83', 403, 1, 5, 886527) Please tell us what you advise.
('83', 403, 2, 6, 886559) [J] MY REPLY TO THE ABOVE
('83', 403, 3, 7, 886585) SEVAGRAM, via WARDHA,
('83', 403, 4, 8, 886607) May 31, 1942
('83', 403, 5, 9, 886620) I have your very complete and illuminating letter.
('83', 403, 5, 10, 886671) The report of the interview is perfect, your answers were straight, unequivocal and courageous.
('83', 403, 5, 11, 886767) I have no criticism to make.
('83', 403, 5, 12, 886796) I can only say: ‘Go on as you are doing.’ I can quite clearly see that you have gone to the right place at the right time.
('83', 403, 5, 13, 886919) I, therefore, need do nothing more than come straight to your questions which are all good and relevant.
('83', 403, 5, 14, 887024) 1. I think we must tell the people what they should do.
('83', 403, 5, 15, 887080) They will act according to their capacity.
('83', 403, 5, 16, 887123) If we begin to judge their capacity and give directions accordingly, our directions will be halting and even compromising which we should never do.
('83', 403, 5, 17, 887271) You will, therefore, read my instruction in that light.
('83', 403, 5, 18, 887327) Remember that our attitude is that of complete non cooperation with the Japanese army.
('83', 403, 5, 19, 887414) Therefore we may not help them in any way, nor may we profit by any dealings with them.
('83', 403, 5, 20, 887502) Therefore we cannot sell anything to them.
('83', 403, 5, 21, 887545) If people are not able to face the Japanese army, they will do as armed soldiers do, i.e., retire when they are overwhelmed.
('83', 403, 5, 22, 887670) And if they do so, the question of having any dealings with the Japanese does not and should not arise.
('83', 403, 5, 23, 887774) If, however, the people have not the courage to resist the Japanese unto death and not the courage and capacity to evacuate the portion invaded by the Japanese, they will do the best they can in the light of instructions.
('83', 403, 5, 24, 887996) One thing they should never do to yield willing submission to the Japanese.
('83', 403, 5, 25, 888072) That will be a cowardly act, and unworthy of a freedom loving people.
('83', 403, 5, 26, 888142) They must not escape from one fire only to fall into another and probably more terrible.
('83', 403, 5, 27, 888231) Their attitude, therefore, must always be of resistance to the Japanese.
('83', 403, 5, 28, 888304) No question, therefore, arises of accepting British currency notes or Japanese coins.
('83', 403, 5, 29, 888390) They will handle nothing from Japanese hands.
('83', 403, 5, 30, 888436) So far as dealings with our own people are concerned, they will either resort to barter or make use of such British currency that they have in the hope that the national government that may take the place of British Government will take up from the people all the British currency in accordance with its capacity.
('83', 403, 5, 31, 888750) 2. Question about co operation in bridge building is covered by the above.
('83', 403, 5, 32, 888825) There can be no question of this co operation.
('83', 403, 5, 33, 888872) 3. If Indian soldiers come in contact with our people, we must fraternize with them if they are well disposed, and invite them, if they can, to join the nation.
('83', 403, 5, 34, 889033) Probably they have been brought under promise that they will deliver the country from foreign yoke.
('83', 403, 5, 35, 889133) There will be no foreign yoke and they will be expected to befriend people and obey national government that might have been set up in place
('83', 404, 0, 1, 889274) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 405
('83', 404, 1, 2, 889318) of British Government.
('83', 404, 1, 3, 889341) If the British have retired in an orderly manner leaving things in Indian hands, the whole thing can work splendidly, and it might even be made difficult for Japanese to settle down in India or any part of it in peace, because they will have to deal with a population which will be sullen and resistant.
('83', 404, 1, 4, 889645) It is difficult to say what can happen.
('83', 404, 1, 5, 889685) It is enough if people are trained to cultivate the power of resistance, no matter which power is operating—the Japanese or the British.
('83', 404, 1, 6, 889822) 4. Covered by 1 above.

('83', 404, 2, 11, 890262) (K) “FIRE RAGING IN ME”
('83', 404, 3, 12, 890286) A journalist was on a visit here the other day.
('83', 404, 3, 13, 890334) He was full of the happenings in his province.
('83', 404, 3, 14, 890381) He talked of the public feeling in his province.
('83', 404, 3, 15, 890430) “It is more anti British than pro Japanese,” he said.
('83', 404, 3, 16, 890484) “There is a vague notion that we have had enough of this rule, and almost anything would be better than the existing state of things.
('83', 404, 3, 17, 890618) People are happy when Subhas Babu says on the radio that there are no differences between him and you and when he says you are now out to fight for liberty at any cost.” “But I suppose you know that there he is wrong,” said Gandhiji, “and I cannot possibly appropriate the compliments he is paying me.
('83', 404, 3, 18, 890920) ‘Liberty at any cost’ has a vastly different connotation for me from what it has for him.
('83', 404, 3, 19, 891010) ‘At any cost’ does not exist in my dictionary.
('83', 404, 3, 20, 891057) It does not, for instance, include bringing in foreigners to help us in our liberty.
('83', 404, 3, 21, 891142) I have no doubt, it means exchanging one form of slavery for another, possibly much worse.
('83', 404, 3, 22, 891233) But, of course, we have to fight for our liberty and make whatever sacrifice it demands.
('83', 404, 3, 23, 891322) In spite of all the hypocrisy that you find in all the inspired Press of Britain and America, I do not relent.
('83', 404, 3, 24, 891433) I deliberately use the word hypocrisy, for they are now proving that when they were talking of the freedom of India, they did not mean it.
('83', 404, 3, 25, 891572) So far as I am concerned, I have no doubt about the righteousness of my step.
('83', 404, 3, 26, 891650) It seems to me to be axiomatic that the Allies are in for a defeat this time if they will not do this initial act of justice and thus put their own case on an unassailable basis.
('83', 404, 3, 27, 891829) If they don’t, they must face the opposition of those who cannot tolerate their rule and are prepared to die in order to get rid of it.
('83', 404, 3, 28, 891965) ‘Convert the deepening ill will into goodwill,’ is a sound proposition.
('83', 404, 3, 29, 892037) It is not open to them to say that we must smother our consciences and say or do nothing because there is war.
('83', 404, 3, 30, 892148) That is why I have made up my mind that it would be a good thing if a million people were shot in a brave and non violent rebellion against British rule.
('83', 404, 3, 31, 892302) It may be that it
('83', 405, 0, 1, 892320) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('83', 405, 1, 3, 892421) But we can then face the world; we cannot face the world today.
('83', 405, 1, 4, 892485) Avowedly the different nations are fighting for their liberty.
('83', 405, 1, 5, 892548) Germany, Japan, Russia, China are pouring their blood and money like water.

('83', 405, 1, 7, 892644) You talk of the newspapers doing good business out of the war.

('83', 405, 1, 11, 892933) “I do not feel flattered when Subhas Babu says, I am right.
('83', 405, 1, 12, 892993) I am not right in the sense he means.
('83', 405, 1, 13, 893031) For there he is attributing pro Japanese feeling to me.

('83', 407, 4, 12, 898180) (E) UNSEEMLY IF TRUE
('83', 407, 5, 13, 898201) Hindustan belongs to all those who are born and bred here and who have no other country to look to.
('83', 407, 5, 14, 898301) Therefore it belongs to Parsis, Beni Israels, to Indian Christians, Muslims and other non Hindus as much as to Hindus.

('83', 408, 10, 16, 900743) That involves the determination of India not to give quarter on any point whatsoever and to be ready to risk loss of several million lives.

('83', 409, 2, 14, 903251) (C) SCORCHED EARTH POLICY
('83', 409, 3, 15, 903277) Q. Would you advise non violent non co operation against scorched earth policy?
('83', 409, 3, 16, 903357) Would you resist the attempt to destroy sources of food and water?
('83', 409, 4, 17, 903424) A. Yes.
('83', 409, 4, 18, 903432) A time may come when I would certainly advise it; for, I think it is ruinous, suicidal and unnecessary—whether India believes in non violent non co operation or in violence.
('83', 409, 4, 19, 903606) And the Russian and Chinese examples make no appeal to me.

('83', 409, 5, 25, 904282) Q. But what about factories—especially factories for the manufacture of munitions?
('83', 409, 6, 26, 904365) A. Suppose there are factories for grinding wheat or pressing oilseeds, I should not destroy them.

('83', 409, 6, 28, 904574) Textile factories I would not destroy, and I would resist all such destruction.
('83', 409, 6, 29, 904654) However, it is a question of prudence.
('83', 409, 6, 30, 904693) I have not suggested immediate enforcement of the whole programme in pursuance of the demand for British withdrawal.

('83', 409, 6, 33, 904993) It is the most logical thing that I have suggested.

('83', 410, 1, 4, 905339) I have mentioned anarchy.

('83', 410, 2, 9, 906037) (D) WHAT WOULD FREE INDIA DO?
('83', 410, 3, 10, 906067) Gandhiji had over and over again said that an orderly withdrawal would result in a sullen India becoming a friend and ally.
('83', 410, 3, 11, 906191) These American friends now explored the implications of that possible friendship: “Would a free India declare war against Japan?” “Free India need not do so.
('83', 410, 3, 12, 906349) It simply becomes the ally of the Allied powers, simply out of gratefulness for the payment of a debt, however, overdue.
('83', 410, 3, 13, 906470) Human nature thanks the debtor when he discharges the debt.” “How then would this alliance fit in with India’s non violence?” “It is a good question.
('83', 410, 3, 14, 906620) The whole of India is not non violent.
('83', 410, 3, 15, 906659) If the whole of India had been non violent, there would have been no need for my appeal to Britain, nor would there be any fear of a Japanese invasion.
('83', 410, 3, 16, 906811) But my non violence is represented possibly by a hopeless minority, or, perhaps, by India’s dumb millions who are temperamentally non violent.
('83', 410, 3, 17, 906954) But there, too, the question may be asked: ‘What have they done?’ They have done nothing, I agree, but they may act when the supreme test comes, and they may not.
('83', 410, 3, 18, 907117) I have no non violence of millions to present Britain, and what we have has been discounted by the British as non violence of the weak.
('83', 410, 3, 19, 907253) And so all I have done is to make this appeal on the strength of bare inherent justice, so that it might find an echo in the British heart.
('83', 410, 3, 20, 907393) It is made from a moral plane, and even as they do not hesitate to act desperately in the physical field and take grave risks, let them for once act desperately on the moral field and declare that India is independent today, irrespective of India’s demand” (Harijan, 14 6 1942, p.

('83', 411, 1, 7, 908379) His question should really have been put thus: ‘How is it that, in spite of your work in India for over 22 years, there are not sufficient satyagrahis who can cope with external and internal menaces?’ My answer then would be that 22 years are nothing in the training of a nation for the development of non violent strength.

('83', 412, 6, 13, 911635) Bharatanandji 4, whose acquaintance the reader will make in another column, demurred to the compliment given to his countrymen, the Poles, by Gandhiji: “You say that the Poles were ‘almost non violent’.
('83', 412, 6, 14, 911838) I do not think so.
('83', 412, 6, 15, 911857) There was black hatred in the breast of Poland, and I do not think the compliment is deserved.” “You must not take what I say, so terribly literally.
('83', 412, 6, 16, 912007) If ten soldiers resist a force of a thousand soldiers armed cap a pie, the former are almost non violent, because there is no capacity for anything like proportionate violence in them.
('83', 412, 6, 17, 912192) But the instance I have taken of the girl is more appropriate.
('83', 412, 6, 18, 912255) A girl who attacks her assailant with her nails if she has grown them, or with her teeth if she has them, is almost non violent, because there is no premeditated violence in her.
('83', 412, 6, 19, 912434) Her violence is the violence of the mouse against the cat.” “Well then, Bapuji, I will give you an instance.
('83', 412, 6, 20, 912543) A young Russian girl was attacked by a soldier.
('83', 412, 6, 21, 912591) She used her nails and teeth against him and tore him, so to say, to pieces.
('83', 412, 6, 22, 912668) Was she almost non violent?” “How can it cease to be non violence, if offered on the spur of the moment, simply because it was successful?” I 5 interposed.
('83', 412, 6, 23, 912824) “No,” said Gandhiji almost inadvertently.
('83', 412, 6, 24, 912866) “Then I am really puzzled,” said Bharatanandji.
('83', 412, 6, 25, 912914) “You say, there should be no premeditated violence and no capacity to offer proportionate violence.
('83', 412, 6, 26, 913014) Here in this case she by her success proved that she had the capacity.” “I am sorry,” said Gandhiji, “that I inadvertently said ‘No’ to Mahadev.

('83', 413, 11, 30, 915121) “We do not wish to take advantage of the peril to Britain, Russia or China, nor do we want the Axis powers to win.
('83', 413, 11, 31, 915236) We mean to stop the Japanese and to help China and the wider cause of democracy and freedom, but the nature of the peril is such now not only to us but through us to China also that we want to meet it by converting the war into a people’s war as China has done.
('83', 413, 11, 32, 915498) The preparation of the Government of India is entirely inadequate.

('83', 414, 0, 1, 915650) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 415
('83', 414, 1, 2, 915694) PSYCHOLOGICAL REACTION
('83', 414, 2, 3, 915717) “We want to take up the present situation, even if we have to take risk in doing so.
('83', 414, 2, 4, 915802) We want to save ourselves from immediate peril, and not to take advantage of any situation in order to gain independence.
('83', 414, 2, 5, 915924) If we remain passive, we allow the popular will against the British Government to be broken gradually, and that will break the popular will to resistance.
('83', 414, 2, 6, 916079) We want to gamble with fate, if one chooses to call it so— and we will do it bravely.” Pandit Nehru said that it was not going to be a long drawn out affair but it would be short and swift.
('83', 414, 2, 7, 916269) How short and swift he did not know because that depended on psychological factors.
('83', 414, 2, 8, 916353) “Ours is not armed force.
('83', 414, 2, 9, 916379) Our struggle depends upon the psychological reaction of a few million.” In reply to a question by an American journalist, Pandit Nehru said “The movement can gain by what we do, and can be accelerated by what the Government does.” Gandhiji in his Harijan has indicated the steps, and the first step may be within a fortnight after the All India Congress Committee meeting.
('83', 414, 2, 10, 916752) That might be a preparatory step unless the Government takes such action as might accelerate it.
('83', 414, 2, 11, 916849) The present decision, the Pandit said, was not taken in a huff, but they came to the conclusion, following a close analysis of the current world politics and the method of the British Government in fighting the war.
('83', 414, 2, 12, 917065) He emphasized that when the Congress talked of independence, it was thought that it was in the nature of bargaining.
('83', 414, 2, 13, 917182) Therefore the demand for the withdrawal of British power from India had irritated the British.
('83', 414, 2, 14, 917277) He explained that this demand was inherent in the nationalist movement.
('83', 414, 2, 15, 917349) They were told that the “Quit India” demand was in the nature of blackmail, and India should wait till the situation was clear after the war.
('83', 414, 2, 16, 917491) Continuing, Pandit Nehru said that they waited these years and the Congress was on the point of starting satyagraha in 1940, but at the fall of France they desisted form starting the movement, because they did not want to embarrass England during her moment of great peril.
('83', 414, 2, 17, 917765) They wanted to face peril as far as possible.
('83', 414, 2, 18, 917811) They wanted to prevent the Japanese aggression upon India and help China.
('83', 414, 2, 19, 917885) He said that he could not have thrown in his weight with the British Government because the British policy was so deep rooted that they could do nothing.
('83', 414, 2, 20, 918039) There was no loophole to function effectively.
('83', 414, 2, 21, 918086) The Congress wanted India not to be a passive onlooker.
('83', 414, 2, 22, 918142) In conclusion, Pandit Nehru said that the average man in India looked to the Congress for a lead, and if the Congress failed, the result would be so much spiritual disillusionment that it might break their spirit.
('83', 414, 2, 23, 918356) So the alternative left to them was to take the risk to shake this spirit and change the whole of Europe and America into the conception of the war of freedom (United Press of India, The Bombay Chronicle, 1 8 1942).

('83', 415, 6, 13, 919346) “CORRECT SLOGAN”
('83', 415, 7, 14, 919363) “Gandhiji’s ‘Quit India’ slogan correctly represents our thoughts and sentiments.
('83', 415, 7, 15, 919445) Passivity on our part at this moment and hour of peril would be suicidal.
('83', 415, 7, 16, 919519) It will break down all our will to resistance.
('83', 415, 7, 17, 919566) It would destroy and emasculate us.
('83', 415, 7, 18, 919602) Our step is not merely for the love of independence.
('83', 415, 7, 19, 919655) We want to take it to protect ourselves, to strengthen our will to resistance, to give a fresh orientation to the war, to fight and to help China and Russia: it is an immediate and pressing necessity with us.”
('83', 415, 8, 20, 919865) PEOPLE’S WAR
('83', 415, 9, 21, 919878) Answering the question “How would you fight against Japan?”, Pandit Nehru said:
('83', 415, 10, 22, 919958) “We would fight in every way possible with non violence and with arms, by making it a people’s war, by raising people’s army, by increasing production and industrialization.
('83', 415, 10, 23, 920132) By making it our primary consuming passion, by fighting like Russia and China and no price would be too big to pay to achieve our success against the aggressor.”.
('83', 415, 11, 24, 920295) “Struggle—eternal struggle!
('83', 415, 11, 25, 920323) That is my reply to Mr. Amery and Sir Stafford Cripps,” said Pandit Nehru spiritedly criticizing the latest statements of Mr. Amery and Sir Stafford Cripps.
('83', 415, 12, 26, 920480) “India’s national self respect cannot be a matter of bargaining,” he added, “I am galled with sorrow and anger to note that I for years wanted some settlement because I felt that Britain was in trouble.
('83', 415, 12, 27, 920683) They have had their suffering and sorrow.
('83', 415, 12, 28, 920725) I wanted my country to move forward step in step with them as a free country.
('83', 415, 12, 29, 920803) But what is one to make of such statements!” (The Bombay Chronicle, 3 8 1942).
('83', 416, 0, 1, 920882) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 417
('83', 416, 1, 2, 920926) (C) PANDIT NEHRU’S STATEMENT ON THE SEIZED DOCUMENTS
('83', 416, 2, 3, 920979) I have just seen for the first time the Government’s communique issuing certain documents obtained during the police raid from the All India Congress Committee office.
('83', 416, 2, 4, 921147) It is astonishing to what a pass the Government of India has been reduced when it has to adopt these discreditable and dishonourable tactics.
('83', 416, 2, 5, 921289) Normally such tactics require no answer.
('83', 416, 2, 6, 921330) But as there is likely to be misapprehension, I wish to clear up some matters.
('83', 416, 2, 7, 921409) It is not our custom to keep detailed minutes of the Working Committee’s meetings.
('83', 416, 2, 8, 921492) Only final decisions are recorded.
('83', 416, 2, 9, 921527) On this occasion the Assistant Secretary took brief notes unofficially apparently for his own record.
('83', 416, 2, 10, 921629) These notes are very brief and disjointed and represent several days’ prolonged debate during which I must have spoken on various occasions for two or three hours.
('83', 416, 2, 11, 921793) Only a few sentences were taken down and torn from their context.
('83', 416, 2, 12, 921859) They often give a wrong impression.
('83', 416, 2, 13, 921895) None of us had a chance of seeing these notes, or of revising them.
('83', 416, 2, 14, 921963) The record is very unsatisfactory and incomplete and hence often incorrect.
('83', 416, 2, 15, 922039) In our discussions, Mahatma Gandhi was not present.
('83', 416, 2, 16, 922091) We had to consider every aspect of the question fully and to weigh the implications of words and phrases in the draft resolutions.
('83', 416, 2, 17, 922222) If Gandhiji had been there, much of this discussion might have been avoided as he could have explained to us his attitude more fully.
('83', 416, 3, 18, 922356) IMPORTANT OMISSION
('83', 416, 4, 19, 922375) Thus when the question of British withdrawal from India was considered, I pointed out that if the armed forces were suddenly withdrawn, the Japanese might well advance and invade the country without hindrance.
('83', 416, 4, 20, 922585) This obvious difficulty was removed when Gandhiji later explained that British and other armed forces might remain to prevent aggression.
('83', 416, 4, 21, 922723) In regard to the statement that Gandhiji expected an Axis victory, an important qualification has been omitted.
('83', 416, 4, 22, 922835) What he has repeatedly said and what I have referred to is his belief that unless Britain changes her whole policy in regard to India and her colonial possessions, she is heading for disaster.
('83', 416, 4, 23, 923028) He has further stated that if a suitable change in this policy was made and the war really became one for freedom for all people, then victory would assuredly come to the United Nations.
('83', 416, 5, 24, 923215) MAHATMA’S WAY
('83', 416, 6, 25, 923229) The references to negotiations with Japan were also incorrect and entirely torn from their context.
('83', 416, 6, 26, 923329) Gandhiji always sends notice to his adversary before coming into conflict.
('83', 416, 6, 27, 923404) He would thus have called upon Japan not only to keep away from India, but to withdraw from China, etc.
('83', 416, 6, 28, 923508) In any event he was determined to resist every aggressor in India and he advised our people to do so even to the point of death.
('83', 416, 6, 29, 923637) They were never to submit.
('83', 417, 0, 1, 923664) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 417, 1, 2, 923706) It is absurd to say that any of us envisaged any arrangements with Japan giving her right of passage, etc.
('83', 417, 1, 3, 923813) What I said was that Japan would want this, but we could never agree.
('83', 417, 1, 4, 923883) Our whole policy has all along been based on uttermost resistance to aggression (Associated Press of India —The Bombay Chronicle, 5 8 1942).
('83', 417, 2, 5, 924024) (D) EXTRACTS FROM PANDIT JAWAHARLAL NEHRU’S SPEECH AT THE ALL INDIA CONGRESS COMMITTEE MEETING

('83', 417, 4, 8, 924295) The position of China would be improved.
('83', 417, 4, 9, 924336) He was convinced that whatever change might come about in India would be for the better.

('83', 417, 4, 11, 924563) This he agreed so as not to facilitate Japanese action on the Indian frontier.

('83', 417, 6, 22, 925512) EXTRACTS FROM MAULANA ABUL KALAM AZAD’S SPEECH AT THE ALL INDIA CONGRESS COMMITTEE MEETING
('83', 417, 7, 23, 925603) August 7, 1942
('83', 417, 8, 24, 925618) The extraordinary danger which India was facing was such that they could not face it, unless they had in their hands the reins of power.
('83', 417, 8, 25, 925755) Danger was knocking at India’s doors and it was necessary that they should make all preparations to check the enemy as soon as he jumped into our courtyard.
('83', 417, 8, 26, 925912) That could be done only when they used every power in their possession.
('83', 417, 8, 27, 925984) At Allahabad it had been decided that if Japan stepped into the land, they would resist aggression with all their non violent strength; but during the last three months the world had not stood still.
('83', 417, 8, 28, 926184) It had moved
('83', 418, 0, 1, 926197) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 419
('83', 418, 1, 2, 926241) The sound of war drums was coming nearer, while the world was flowing in blood, and nations were fighting and pouring out their life blood to preserve their precious possession of freedom.
('83', 418, 1, 3, 926430) The Congress had made repeated proposals to Britain to give the people of India that freedom which would enable them to fight the aggressor.
('83', 418, 1, 4, 926571) They had not asked for the keys of power so that they could sit back and make merry.
('83', 418, 1, 5, 926656) That was not the way of the world today.
('83', 418, 1, 6, 926697) The whole world was straining at its leash, was rushing towards freedom.
('83', 418, 1, 7, 926770) In those circumstances, if they felt that conditions in India required a change, if they felt that their only salvation lay in making and bringing about drastic changes, then they should take such steps as would bring about those changes.
('83', 418, 1, 8, 927009) At the same time they had to consider the possible consequences of their step on the entire world.
('83', 418, 1, 9, 927108) They had to weigh the consequences of their action and inaction carefully in the balance.
('83', 418, 2, 10, 927198) WHEN INDIANS WILL FIGHT
('83', 418, 3, 11, 927222) Therefore the Working Committee had passed a resolution three weeks ago, after fully considering their responsibilities, their duties, the consequences of their action and how best they could achieve their object.
('83', 418, 3, 12, 927436) Their view was that unless some change was brought about at once, the same fate which overtook Burma, Malaya and Singapore would overtake this country also.
('83', 418, 3, 13, 927593) If they wanted to fight for the safety, freedom and honour of India, it was necessary that they should cast off the shackles that were holding them down, to shake off that lethargy and go to work in an entirely new spirit.
('83', 418, 3, 14, 927816) It was only when they felt that they were fighting for something which they held sacred that the people of this country could fight, pour out their energy and blood and lay down their lives.
('83', 418, 3, 15, 928007) They had made repeated appeals and entreaties to bring about this change and as they had failed, it had become their duty to take a positive step.
('83', 418, 3, 16, 928154) That step was certainly fraught with hardships; but they could do nothing unless they were prepared to suffer hardships and make sacrifices.
('83', 418, 3, 17, 928295) It was only by suffering and strife that they could achieve anything at all.
('83', 418, 3, 18, 928372) That was the meaning of the resolution of July 14. During these three weeks the message had spread throughout the land.
('83', 418, 3, 19, 928492) The resolution only reiterated the position which they had always taken.
('83', 418, 3, 20, 928565) As long as three years ago, the Congress had made its position clear and had cast its lot in favour of democracy and against Fascism.
('83', 418, 3, 21, 928699) Nothing that they had done since then was inconsistent with this fundamental position.
('83', 418, 3, 22, 928786) They had always said that they would whole heartedly aid the cause of freedom and democracy, if they were free.
('83', 418, 3, 23, 928898) For freedom itself they could wait.
('83', 418, 3, 24, 928934) But the present question was not merely of freedom, but of their very existence.
('83', 418, 3, 25, 929015) If they survived and lived, they could have freedom.
('83', 418, 3, 26, 929068) But the position now was that they could not live and survive without freedom.
('83', 419, 0, 1, 929147) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 419, 1, 2, 929189) TWICE TESTED
('83', 419, 2, 3, 929202) Continuing, the Congress President said that the demand they were putting forward before Britain and the United Nations was to be judged by the one and the only test, and that test was whether for the sake of the defence of India, for her very survival, freedom was necessary.
('83', 419, 2, 4, 929479) India had become a vital field of battle.
('83', 419, 2, 5, 929521) If India were free, she could have kindled a new light throughout the land and the cry of victory would ring from every corner.
('83', 419, 2, 6, 929649) No army could wage a relentless war unless it had behind it an administration which had the fullest popular support.
('83', 419, 2, 7, 929766) If anybody could show them that what they were doing would contribute to the defeat of freedom powers, they would be prepared to change their course.
('83', 419, 2, 8, 929916) But, if the argument was merely a threat holding out the prospect of civil war and chaos, he for one would tell them: ‘It is our right to wage a civil war; it is our responsibility to face chaos.’
('83', 419, 3, 9, 930113) Proceeding, the Congress President observed that having thus once tested the gold of their demand they took the bright gold and applied to it yet another test and that test was: ‘Are we contributing to others’ defeat, to others’ misfortune?’
('83', 419, 4, 10, 930355) If their demand was such that it would not contribute to the strength of the freedom powers, would not promote the cause of those powers fighting with valour for their freedom, they would never have put it forward.
('83', 419, 4, 11, 930570) They had considered this question for full nine days.
('83', 419, 4, 12, 930624) And the Congress President said: “Our demand is twice tested pure gold.” He challenged: “Is the British Government prepared to allow its actions and policies to be subjected to these same tests?”
('83', 419, 5, 13, 930820) Answering critics of the Congress, he said that there was no right thinking man who would not accept the tests he had propounded as valid.
('83', 419, 5, 14, 930959) It was the duty of the critics to understand their position correctly and not merely to give it a bad name.
('83', 419, 6, 15, 931067) In this connection he referred to the statement of Sir Stafford Cripps that if the Congress demand was accepted, the whole Government from the Viceroy to the sepoy would have to leave.
('83', 419, 6, 16, 931252) This was misrepresentation with a vengeance.
('83', 419, 6, 17, 931297) Their resolution had said in clear terms that as soon as Britain or the Allied nations declared India’s independence, India would enter into a treaty with Britain for the carrying out of the administration and the conduct of the war to victory.
('83', 419, 6, 18, 931542) They had not asked that all the Government officials should go home bag and baggage, and after reaching England, return to India for negotiations.
('83', 419, 6, 19, 931689) Gandhiji had repeatedly made it clear that “Quit India” demand meant only the removal of the British power and not the physical removal of British officers, administrators and army personnel.
('83', 419, 6, 20, 931881) All of them, including the armies of Britain and the Allies, would continue to stay here—only under an agreement with us and not against our will as at present.
('83', 419, 6, 21, 932042) Not to see this clear point was suicidal blindness.
('83', 420, 0, 1, 932094) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 421
('83', 420, 1, 2, 932138) SIMULTANEOUS DECISION ON BOTH ISSUES
('83', 420, 2, 3, 932175) The Maulana stated: “There was a time for mere promises.
('83', 420, 2, 4, 932232) But the resolution of July 14 makes one thing clear, namely, the condition of India and of the world has reached a stage when it was absolutely necessary that everything should be done at once.
('83', 420, 2, 5, 932426) What we ask for from Britain and the Allied powers should be done here and now.
('83', 420, 2, 6, 932506) We do not rely on mere promises about the future.
('83', 420, 2, 7, 932556) We have had bitter experiences of promises having been broken.
('83', 420, 2, 8, 932619) They also suspect our promise to fight with them against the Axis.
('83', 420, 2, 9, 932686) Let us come together today, and simultaneously decide both the issues —the freedom of India and India’s complete participation in the war efforts.
('83', 420, 2, 10, 932833) Let there be simultaneous declaration of India’s independence and the signing of a treaty between India and the United Nations.
('83', 420, 2, 11, 932961) If you do not trust us in this, we cannot trust you either.” Concluding, Maulana Azad observed that even in this grave hour when every minute counted, we had decided to make one last minute appeal to the United Nations to demonstrate to them that the object of India and the Allied powers was the same, that their interests were the same, that the satisfaction of India’s demand would promote the welfare of the Allies.
('83', 420, 2, 12, 933381) But if the Allies were obdurate and deaf to all appeals, it was their clear duty to do what they could to achieve freedom (The Bombay Chronicle, 8 8 1942).

('83', 424, 1, 2, 940798) 262. LETTER TO ARDESHIR E. KATELI 1
('83', 424, 2, 3, 940834) September 16, 1943 RESPECTED KATELI SAHEB, You have informed me that the Central Provinces Government desires to release me, since I was detained by that Government, but that if I want to stay here, I can do so under the present restrictions.
('83', 424, 2, 4, 941077) In reply to this, I have to say that I have come here only to serve Smt.
('83', 424, 2, 5, 941150) Kasturba Gandhi and, so long as she wants me here, I shall stay with her under the present restrictions.
('83', 424, 2, 6, 941255) Truly speaking, I should ascertain the wishes of my father, but I think that he will certainly want me to stay here to look after her.
('83', 424, 2, 7, 941390) I understand that if I wish to, I can obtain my release; hence there is no need to ascertain the wishes of my father.
