('83', 426, 1, 2, 944594) 3. I observe, too, that the Government did not desire “comments” upon the charges.
('83', 426, 1, 3, 944677) Previous pronouncements of the Government on such matters had led me to think otherwise.
('83', 426, 1, 4, 944766) Be that as it may, your current letter seems to invite an answer.
('83', 426, 1, 5, 944832) 4. In my opinion, I have, in my letter of 15th July last, unequivocally answered all charges referred to in your letter under reply.
('83', 426, 1, 6, 944965) I have no regret for what I have done or said in the course of the struggle for India’s freedom.
('83', 426, 1, 7, 945062) 5. As to the Congress resolution of 8th August, 1942, apart from my belief that it is not only harmless but good all round, I have no legal power to alter it in any way.
('83', 426, 1, 8, 945232) That can only be done by the body that passed that resolution, i.e., the All India Congress Committee which is no doubt guided by its Working Committee.
('83', 426, 1, 9, 945385) As the Government are aware, I offered 1 to meet the members of the Working Committee in order to discuss the situation and to know their mind.
('83', 426, 1, 10, 945529) But my offer was rejected.
('83', 426, 1, 11, 945556) I have thought and still think that my talk with them might have some value from the Government standpoint.
('83', 426, 1, 12, 945664) Hence I repeat my offer.
('83', 426, 1, 13, 945689) 2 But it may have no such value so long as the Government doubt my bona fides.
('83', 426, 1, 14, 945768) As a satyagrahi, however, in spite of the handicap, I must reiterate what I hold to be good and of immediate importance in terms of war effort.
('83', 426, 1, 15, 945912) But if my offer has no chance of being accepted so long as I retain my present views, and if the Government think that it is only my evil influence that corrupts people, I submit that the members of the Working Committee and other detenus should be discharged.
('83', 426, 1, 16, 946173) It is unthinkable that when India’s millions are suffering from preventable starvation and thousands are dying of it, thousands of men and women should be kept in detention on mere suspicion, when their energy and the expense incurred in keeping them under duress could, at this critical time, be usefully employed in relieving distress.
('83', 426, 1, 17, 946511) As I have said in my letter of 15th July last, Congressmen abundantly proved their administrative, creative and humanitarian worth at the time of the last
('83', 426, 2, 18, 946666) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 19 1 1943. 2 The offer was again rejected.

('83', 426, 2, 20, 947108) Both you and they are all aware of the conditions on which such a proposal could be entertained.

('83', 427, 1, 3, 947383) The huge place in which I am being detained with a large guard around me, I hold to be waste of public funds.
('83', 427, 1, 4, 947493) I should be quite content to pass my days in any prison.
('83', 427, 1, 5, 947550) 6. As to “satisfactory assurances” about my “good conduct”, I can only say that I am unaware of any unworthy conduct at any time.
('83', 427, 1, 6, 947680) I presume that the impression Government have of my conduct is referable to the charges mentioned in the indictment, as I have succinctly called, Congress Responsibility for the Disturbances, 1942 43. And since I have not only denied the charges in toto but, on the contrary, have ventured to bring counter charges against the Government, I think that they should agree to refer both to an impartial tribunal.
('83', 427, 1, 7, 948090) Seeing that a big political organization and not a mere individual is involved in the charges, I hold that it should be a vital part of the war effort to have the issue decided by a tribunal, if mutual discussion and effort are considered by the Government to be undesirable and/or futile.
('83', 427, 1, 8, 948380) 7. Whilst your letter rejects my request that my letter of 15th July last should, in fairness to me, be published 1, you inform me that their decision in this matter, however, “is without prejudice to the freedom of Government to use at any time and in any manner which they think fit the various admissions contained in the communication which you have voluntarily addressed to them”.

('83', 427, 1, 10, 948924) My request is that my letter should be published in full, if and when the Government think fit to make public use of it.

('83', 428, 1, 2, 949287) 266. LETTER TO ADDITIONAL SECRETARY, HOME DEPARTMENT, GOVERNMENT OF INDIA
('83', 428, 2, 3, 949361) DETENTION CAMP, November 16, 1943
('83', 428, 3, 4, 949395) THE ADDITIONAL SECRETARY GOVERNMENT OF INDIA (HOME DEPARTMENT) NEW DELHI
('83', 428, 4, 5, 949468) SIR, Dr. Nayyar 1, whom the Government of India, or maybe the Government of Bombay have placed with me, received on the 12th instant a wire addressed to her by her brother 2 who is a railway employee in New Delhi, to the effect that his wife had a Caesarian operation and had lost so much blood, that he had applied for Dr. Nayyar’s temporary discharge.
('83', 428, 4, 6, 949822) This wire was received in Yeravda, as appears from the date marked on it, on the morning of the 5th.
('83', 428, 4, 7, 949923) The second wire, which was sent from New Delhi on the 9th instant and received at Yeravda on the same afternoon, was delivered to her on the 15th instant.
('83', 428, 4, 8, 950078) The wire reports the patient’s death.
('83', 428, 4, 9, 950116) Dr. Nayyar has already complained about the delay in the delivery of the first wire.
('83', 428, 4, 10, 950201) She is naturally prostrate with grief which has been aggravated by the delay in the delivery of the wires.
('83', 428, 4, 11, 950308) I do not know that, if she were a condemned criminal, the news of the death of a dear one would be withheld from her as this has been, without any cause that I can guess.
('83', 428, 4, 12, 950479) It seems to me that those who are lodged with me have to suffer extra hardship by reason of their being so lodged.
('83', 428, 4, 13, 950594) For, it is not only Dr. Nayyar who has to suffer, others do likewise.
('83', 428, 4, 14, 950664) Thus Dr Gilder is debarred from receiving visits even from his ailing wife or his daughter.
('83', 428, 4, 15, 950756) Little Manu Gandhi can receive neither her father nor her sisters, nor can my wife receive visits from her sons or grandchildren.
('83', 428, 4, 16, 950886) I discount the fact that the former could have gone out if she resented the restrictions.
('83', 428, 4, 17, 950976) I know too, that my son Ramdas was permitted to visit his mother when she was very ill.
('83', 428, 4, 18, 951064) I do not understand this denial of ordinary rights of prisoners.
('83', 428, 4, 19, 951129) I can understand the restrictions against me by reason of the Government’s
('83', 428, 5, 20, 951204) 1 Dr. Sushila Nayyar 2 Mohanlal Nayyar; vide “Talk with Nirmala and Devdas Gandhi”, 7 12 1943.
('83', 429, 0, 1, 951299) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 429, 1, 2, 951341) special displeasure against me.
('83', 429, 1, 3, 951373) But the restrictions on the others it is difficult to understand, unless it be that the Government do not trust those who are put in charge of us.
('83', 429, 1, 4, 951520) On any other basis it is difficult to understand why the Superintendent of the camp, or even the Inspector General, cannot deal with the wires of the nature I have referred to, and with the visitors who may be permitted to visit the co detenus.
('83', 429, 1, 5, 951765) I request early relief.
('83', 429, 3, 6, 951789) Yours, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('83', 430, 5, 6, 953485) 268. TALK WITH MIRABEHN
('83', 430, 6, 7, 953509) November 18, 1943
('83', 430, 7, 8, 953527) When I asked Bapuji as to how we should deal with dangerous wild animals such as tigers, bears, panthers, etc., and also snakes and scorpions, he said: It is a difficult question.
('83', 430, 7, 9, 953707) If I am to give a definite answer for acting upon, I must debate it in my mind for a while.
('83', 430, 8, 10, 953799) I suggested to Bapuji that it was a question which we would have to settle on a nation wide scale before long, and I would ask him again after he had thought it over for two or three days.
('83', 430, 8, 11, 953988) When I again asked Bapuji he replied: If I were faced with the option of killing a tiger or a snake, or otherwise being killed by it, I would rather be killed by it than take its life.
('83', 430, 8, 12, 954173) But that is a personal position, not to be put forward for adoption by others.
('83', 430, 8, 13, 954252) If I had the fearless power to tame these dangerous creatures by the force of my love and my will, and could show others how to do likewise, then I should have the right to advise other people to follow my example.
('83', 430, 8, 14, 954467) But I have not that power.
('83', 430, 8, 15, 954494) I must, therefore, advise others to kill all creatures, dangerous to human life, such as tigers, bears, snakes, scorpions, etc., and also vermin such as fleas, flies and mosquitoes as well as rats and other crop destroying vermin.
('83', 430, 8, 16, 954725) It should be done in the most human way possible, and with regard to vermin, which is often the outcome of carelessness and dirt, we should try to live in such a way as not to give rise to its occurrence.
('83', 430, 9, 17, 954930) “Then,” I replied, “this means that you are no longer satisfied with the catching of snakes, rats, etc., and the turning of them loose elsewhere, as is done in Sevagram and other places.” That is so.
('83', 430, 9, 18, 955130) If one is not prepared to live in the company of these creatures oneself, one has no right to turn them loose on other people’s lands.
('83', 430, 9, 19, 955265) For that is what it comes to.
('83', 430, 9, 20, 955295) One may remove them
('83', 431, 0, 1, 955315) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 431, 1, 2, 955357) from the Ashram and let them go in a jungly place, but that jungly place also belongs to someone, and women and children will, as likely as not, be going there to gather cow dung and wood, or if it is rats one is letting loose, they will be sure to find their way to the nearest fields.
('83', 431, 1, 3, 955644) One has either got to live with these creatures or destroy them.
('83', 431, 1, 4, 955709) And to turn one’s own place into a vermin sanctuary is not fair on one’s neighbours either.
('83', 431, 1, 5, 955801) Therefore live cleanly and carefully, and if even then these creatures appear, they must be destroyed.
('83', 431, 2, 6, 955904) Then I said to Bapuji: “Seeing that tigers, bears, etc., have got to be killed, and that in the most human way possible, should not some suitable person in each village be provided with a rifle?” That is a difficult question.
('83', 431, 2, 7, 956130) If one man may have a rifle, why not all people who are capable of handling arms.
('83', 431, 2, 8, 956212) But be that as it may, if rifles are to be used and one man is to be chosen for the job, I think he should be elected by the villagers.
('83', 431, 3, 9, 956348) This is correct but I am not satisfied as it appears in cold writing.
('83', 431, 5, 10, 956418) From a photostat: G.N. 9103

('83', 435, 8, 14, 965151) 273. LETTER TO SIR RICHARD TOTTENHAM
('83', 435, 9, 15, 965188) DETENTION CAMP, December 22, 1943
('83', 435, 10, 16, 965222) SIR, This letter is to approach the Government about Shri Mirabehn who, forsaking the easy life of her English home came to me 19 years ago in search of things of the spirit for which her heart had been yearning.
('83', 435, 10, 17, 965435) I feel, therefore, a special responsibility for her welfare.
('83', 435, 11, 18, 965496) 1 Vide “Letter to Secretary, Home Department, Government of Bombay”, 1 12 1943.
('83', 436, 0, 1, 965576) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 437
('83', 436, 1, 2, 965620) Now, she has been suffering for the last seven months from pains in the region of the left shoulder blade, which often extend from the neck to the tips of her fingers.
('83', 436, 1, 3, 965788) She wrote to the Inspector General of Prisons describing her condition, and I understand her letter is before the Government.
('83', 436, 1, 4, 965914) Shah consulted the Civil Surgeon of Poona and the treatment he advised was carried out but without substantial benefit.
('83', 436, 1, 5, 966034) The Civil Surgeon then very kindly consulted Captain Simcox, R. A. M. C. of St. Bartholomew’s Hospital, London, who had made a special study of this condition.
('83', 436, 1, 6, 966194) He immediately diagnosed her case as adhesions, for which he said four or five manipulations together with daily exercises would be necessary.
('83', 436, 1, 7, 966337) He gave her the first manipulation then and there.
('83', 436, 1, 8, 966388) Unfortunately he had to leave the same day for Karachi and is not likely to return to Poona.
('83', 436, 1, 9, 966481) Shri Mirabehn has done her best with the exercises and the arm has considerably improved, but pains persist, and whenever she is a little run down, has a slight temperature or a sore throat, the pains return in full force and disable her for any work for some days.
('83', 436, 1, 10, 966747) She has become anxious lest the trouble may become chronic, and permanently incapacitate her for an active life.
('83', 436, 1, 11, 966860) I would suggest that she be either transferred to wherever Captain Simcox may be at present for completion of the manipula tions started by him, or that she be released on parole for getting available treatment.
('83', 436, 1, 12, 967072) I am sure the Government would not wish her to be permanently damaged.
('83', 436, 2, 13, 967143) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI
('83', 436, 3, 14, 967168) From a photostat : India Office Library and Records.
('83', 436, 3, 15, 967221) Courtesy : The British Library, London
('83', 436, 4, 16, 967260) 274. TALK WITH MIRABEHN
('83', 436, 5, 17, 967284) December 24, 1943
('83', 436, 6, 18, 967302) The fundamental essential in non violence is right thinking.
('83', 436, 6, 19, 967363) It may be asked —‘What is right thinking?’ Right thinking is not right contemplation or right planning; it is right conception of fundamentals, for example, ‘God is’ is right thinking, and ‘God is not’ is wrong thinking.
('83', 436, 6, 20, 967584) ‘I must be honest’ is right thinking, ‘I may be
('83', 437, 0, 1, 967632) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 437, 1, 2, 967674) dishonest’, is wrong thinking.
('83', 437, 1, 3, 967705) When the mind is habituated to right thinking, right action follows spontaneously, but when the mind turns to wrong thinking, wrong action will follow.
('83', 437, 1, 4, 967857) And, even if circumstances lead one 1 to right action, if the mind is given to wrong thinking, the right action will be lacking in convincing force, and it will also not bring to the doer all the fruits 2 of right action.
('83', 437, 1, 5, 968079) Non violence without right thinking will never carry within itself the vital power of faith—or, if you prefer, conviction.
('83', 437, 1, 6, 968202) Nor will the man who is not a habitual right thinker be able to depend on himself to act rightly (even if he wants to) at a given moment.
('83', 437, 2, 7, 968340) The foregoing is the cream of a conversation I had with Bapuji during the morning walk on December 24, 1943.
('83', 437, 3, 8, 968449) After discussing the meaning of right thinking, Bapuji applied it to the present situation in the country.
('83', 437, 3, 9, 968556) He pointed out how lack of right thinking led people to seek advancement of India through co operation with evil (in the form of the British system).
('83', 437, 3, 10, 968706) They pursue false hopes and empty promises.
('83', 437, 3, 11, 968750) And again it is wrong thinking which fills them with fear of the growing consolidation of the Muslims.
('83', 437, 3, 12, 968853) All these things are illusions after which and from which they run because they lack the right conception of fundamentals.
('83', 437, 4, 13, 968976) During the talk Bapuji said in parenthesis one very striking thing.
('83', 437, 4, 14, 969044) When he gave, as an illustration of wrong thinking, ‘I may be dishonest’, he added: Of course there is no such thing as ‘I must be dishonest.’ 3
('83', 437, 5, 15, 969189) Correct, December 29, 1943. BAPU
('83', 437, 6, 16, 969222) From a photostat: G.N. 9104
('83', 437, 7, 17, 969250) 1 Gandhiji had substituted the word for Mirabehn’s expression: “the reason”.
('83', 437, 7, 18, 969327) 2 Mirabehn’s note has: “doer the true fruits”.
('83', 437, 7, 19, 969374) 3 What follows is in Gandhiji’s hand.

('83', 438, 3, 9, 969787) She is receiving all the attention possible in a detention camp.
('83', 438, 3, 10, 969852) As for the subject matter of your letter, I am the same man you have known me.
('83', 438, 3, 11, 969931) The spirit of Andrews is ever with me.
('83', 438, 3, 12, 969970) But suspicion about my motives and utter distrust of my word in high places has hitherto rendered every move made by me nugatory.

('83', 438, 3, 14, 970145) Truth and non violence remain my sheet anchor as never before.

('83', 441, 7, 12, 975116) In the exercise of the right thus conferred upon me, I beg to say as follows: I admit that I took a leading part in the passage of the Congress resolution of 8th August, 1942. I must deny emphatically that the mass movement sanctioned by the Congress was “calculated to
('83', 441, 8, 13, 975386) 1 From the reference to Ranjit Pandit who died in Lucknow on January 14; vide also “Letter to Vijayalakshmi Pandit”, 1 2 1944. 2 Issued by the addressee under Section 7 of the Restriction and Detention Ordinance, 1944 (III of 1944).
('83', 441, 8, 14, 975619) It reads “(1) In pursuance of Section 7 of Ordinance No.
('83', 441, 8, 15, 975676) III of 1944, you, MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI, are informed that the grounds for your detention were that you took a leading part in the passing of the Congress resolution of August 8, 1942, sanctioning a mass movement which was calculated to impede the successful prosecution of the war, and there was reason to suppose that, if not detained, you would take an active part in directing the movement.
('83', 441, 8, 16, 976076) (2) You are informed that you have a right to make a representation in writing against the order under which you are detained.
('83', 441, 8, 17, 976203) If you wish to make such a representation, you should address it to the undersigned and forward it through the officer in charge of your place of detention as soon as possible” (File No.

('83', 442, 0, 1, 976438) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 443
('83', 442, 1, 2, 976482) impede the successful prosecution of the war”.
('83', 442, 1, 3, 976529) Moreover I am in a position to show conclusively from my speeches at the Congress meeting and otherwise that there was no intention on my part, as the person in sole charge of the movement, to start it immediately and that, as publicly announced by me, I was to enter into correspondence with H.E. the Viceroy with a view to avoiding the contemplated movement.
('83', 442, 1, 4, 976890) Had the correspondence proved abortive, being a firm and tried believer in non violence, I would have taken every precaution to keep the movement under restraint.
('83', 442, 1, 5, 977053) By their hasty and ill conceived action in arresting me and leading Congressmen, the Government goaded the populace to acts which they would otherwise have never done and thus did disservice to the Allied cause.
('83', 442, 1, 6, 977265) By their persistence in continuing the unfortunate policy of August 1942, the Government are increasing the existing bitterness between the Government and the people.
('83', 442, 1, 7, 977432) And this I say in spite of the fact that they are able to procure recruits and money enough for the military.
('83', 442, 1, 8, 977542) I have little hope of getting a fair or impartial hearing for my representation.
('83', 442, 1, 9, 977623) By their pamphlet Congress Responsibility for the Disturbances, 1942 43, Government have condemned unheard Congressmen and me.
('83', 442, 1, 10, 977750) That pamphlet bristles with inaccuracies and reckless statements.
('83', 442, 1, 11, 977816) In view of the foregoing, I ask for an open investigation by an independent tribunal into the charges against the Congress, Congressmen and me, and counter charges against the Government, or, in the alternative, the discharge of detained Congressmen and myself.

('83', 444, 1, 2, 979985) APPENDIX I
('83', 444, 2, 3, 979996) RESOLUTIONS PASSED BY CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE 1
('83', 444, 3, 4, 980047) July 14, 1942
('83', 444, 4, 5, 980061) The events happening from day to day and the experience that the people of India are passing through confirm the opinion of Congressmen that British rule in India must end immediately, not merely because foreign domination even at its best is an evil in itself and a continuing injury to the subject people, but because India in bondage can play no effective part in defending herself and in affecting the fortunes of the war that is desolating humanity.
('83', 444, 4, 6, 980516) The freedom of India is thus necessary not only in the interest of India, but also for the safety of the world and for the ending of Nazism, Fascism, militarism and other forms of imperialism, and the aggression of one nation over another.
('83', 444, 4, 7, 980756) Ever since the outbreak of the World War, the Congress has studiedly pursued a policy of non embarrassment.
('83', 444, 4, 8, 980864) Even at the risk of making its satyagraha ineffective, it deliberately gave it a symbolic character in the hope that this policy of non embarrassment carried to its logical extreme would be duly appreciated and that real power would be transferred to popular representatives so as to enable the nation to make its fullest contribution towards the realization of human freedom throughout the world, which is in danger of being crushed.
('83', 444, 4, 9, 981299) It had also hoped that negatively nothing would be done which was calculated to tighten Britain’s hold on India.
('83', 444, 5, 10, 981412) These hopes have, however, been dashed to pieces.
('83', 444, 5, 11, 981462) The abortive Cripps proposals showed in the clearest possible manner that there was no change in the British Government’s attitude towards India and that the British hold on India was in no way to be relaxed.
('83', 444, 5, 12, 981671) In the negotiations with Sir Stafford Cripps, Congress representatives tried their utmost to achieve a minimum, consistent with the national demand, but to no avail.
('83', 444, 5, 13, 981837) This frustration has resulted in a rapid and widespread increase of ill will against Britain and a growing satisfaction at the success of Japanese arms.
('83', 444, 6, 14, 981990) The Working Committee view this development with grave apprehension as this, unless checked, will inevitable lead to a passive acceptance of aggression.
('83', 444, 6, 15, 982143) The Committee hold that all aggression must be resisted, for any submission to it must mean the degradation of the Indian people and the continuation of their subjection.
('83', 444, 6, 16, 982314) The Congress is anxious to avoid the experience of Malaya, Singapore, and Burma and desires to build up resistance to any aggression on or invasion of India by the
('83', 444, 7, 17, 982478) 1 Vide “Draft Resolution for the Congress Working Committee”, 9 7 1942.
('83', 445, 0, 1, 982550) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 445, 1, 2, 982592) Japanese or any foreign power.
('83', 445, 1, 3, 982623) The Congress would change the present ill will against Britain into goodwill and make India a willing partner in a joint enterprise of securing freedom for the nations and peoples of the world and in the trials and tribulations which accompany it.
('83', 445, 1, 4, 982871) This is only possible if India feels the glow of freedom.
('83', 445, 2, 5, 982929) The Congress representatives have tried their utmost to bring about a solution of the communal tangle.
('83', 445, 2, 6, 983032) But this has been made impossible by the presence of the foreign power and only after the ending of foreign domination and intervention, can the present unreality give place to reality and the people of India, belonging to all groups and parties, face India’s problems and solve them on a mutually agreed basis.
('83', 445, 3, 7, 983344) The present political parties formed chiefly with a view to attract the attention of and influence the British power, will then probably cease to function.
('83', 445, 3, 8, 983500) For the first time in India’s history, the realization will come home that the Princes, ‘jagirdars,’ ‘zamindars’ and propertied and moneyed classes derive their wealth and property from the workers in the fields and factories and elsewhere, to whom essentially power and authority must belong.
('83', 445, 3, 9, 983794) On the withdrawal of British rule in India, responsible men and women of the country will come together to form a provisional government, representative of all important sections of the people of India which will later evolve a scheme by which a Constituent Assembly can be convened in order to prepare a Constitution for the Government of India acceptable to all sections of the people.
('83', 445, 3, 10, 984182) Representatives of free India and representatives of Great Britain will confer together for the adjustment of future relations and for the co operation of the two countries as allies in the common task of meeting aggression.
('83', 445, 4, 11, 984407) It is the earnest desire of the Congress to enable India to resist aggression effectively with the people’s united will and strength behind it.
('83', 445, 4, 12, 984551) In making the proposal for the withdrawal of the British rule from India, the Congress has no desire whatsoever to embarrass Great Britain or the Allied powers in their prosecution of the war, or in any way to encourage aggression on India or increase pressure on China by the Japanese or any other power associated with the Axis group.
('83', 445, 4, 13, 984888) Nor does the Congress intend to jeopardize the defensive capacity of the Allied powers.
('83', 445, 5, 14, 984976) The Congress is, therefore, agreeable to the stationing of the armed forces of the Allies in India, should they so desire, in order to ward off and resist Japanese or other aggression and to protect and help China.
('83', 445, 5, 15, 985191) The proposal of withdrawal of the British power from India was never intended to mean the physical withdrawal of all Britishers from India, and certainly not of those who would make India their home and live there as citizens and as equals with the others.
('83', 445, 5, 16, 985448) If such a withdrawal takes place with goodwill it would result in the establishing of a stable provisional government in India and co operation between this government and the United Nations in resisting aggression and helping China.
('83', 445, 5, 17, 985682) The Congress realizes that there may be
('83', 446, 0, 1, 985722) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 447
('83', 446, 1, 2, 985766) risks involved in such a course.
('83', 446, 1, 3, 985799) Such risks, however, have to be faced by any country in order to achieve freedom, and more especially at the present critical juncture in order to save the country and the larger cause of freedom the world over from far greater risks and perils.
('83', 446, 1, 4, 986045) While, therefore, the Congress is impatient to achieve the national purpose it wishes to take no hasty steps and would like to avoid, in so far as is possible any course of action that might embarrass the United Nations.
('83', 446, 1, 5, 986266) The Congress would be pleased with the British power if it accepts the very reasonable and just proposal herein made not only in the interest of India but also that of Britain and of the cause of freedom, to which the United Nations proclaim their adherence.
('83', 446, 1, 6, 986525) Should, however, this appeal fail the Congress cannot view without the gravest apprehension the continuation of the present state of affairs involving a progressive deterioration in the situation and the weakening of India’s will and power to resist aggression.
('83', 446, 1, 7, 986787) The Congress will then be reluctantly compelled to utilize all the non violent strength it might have gathered since 1920 when it adopted non violence as part of its policy for the vindication of the political rights and liberty.
('83', 446, 1, 8, 987017) Such a widespread struggle would inevitably be under the leadership of Mahatma Gandhi.
('83', 446, 1, 9, 987104) As issues raised are of the most vital and far reaching importance to the people of India as well as to the peoples of the United Nations the Working Committee refer them to the All India Congress Committee for final decision.
('83', 446, 1, 10, 987331) For this purpose the A.I.C.C. will meet in Bombay on the 7th of August, 1942.

('83', 446, 3, 13, 987504) APPENDIX II
('83', 446, 4, 14, 987516) LETTER FROM C. RAJAGOPALACHRI AND OTHERS 1
('83', 446, 5, 15, 987559) MADRAS, July 18, 1942
('83', 446, 6, 16, 987581) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('83', 446, 7, 17, 987597) We have carefully read the resolution passed by the Congress Working Committee at Wardha on July 14, which is to be placed before the meeting of the A. I. C. C. next month.
('83', 446, 7, 18, 987770) In view of the far reaching consequences of the adoption of this resolution, we feel it our duty, having worked with you since 1920, to place before you our considered views in this matter.
('83', 446, 7, 19, 987960) While there can be no difference of view over India’s demand for complete freedom from foreign domination, the idea of the withdrawal of Government being automatically replaced by another Government is altogether impossible.
('83', 446, 7, 20, 988185) The State is not a mere superstructure, but is so intimately
('83', 446, 8, 21, 988246) 1 Vide “Letter to C. Rajagopalachari”, 20 7 1942.
('83', 447, 0, 1, 988296) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 447, 1, 2, 988338) bound up with the functioning of every activity of the people that the withdrawal of the Government without a simultaneous replacement by another must involve a dissolution of the State and of society itself.
('83', 447, 1, 3, 988547) It is unnatural for any Government to withdraw without transferring power to a successor by consent or without being forcibly replaced by another.
('83', 447, 1, 4, 988694) The formation of a provisional government as well as the convening of the Constituents assembly are possible only if the continuity of the State is assured.
('83', 447, 2, 5, 988851) We feel, therefore, that, however difficult of achievement the Hindu Muslim settlement may be, while the British Government is here and functioning, it is essential that, before a demand for withdrawal can be reasonably made, the major political organizations of this country, namely, the Indian National Congress and the Muslim League, should evolve a joint plan with regard to the provisional government which can take over power and preserve the continuity of the State.
('83', 447, 2, 6, 989325) Even if we imagine that the British could ever under moral compulsion be made to withdraw unconditionally, we are convinced that the chaos that would follow under existing conditions would not permit within any reasonable time the formation of a provisional government such as you contemplate.
('83', 447, 3, 7, 989619) We consider it wrong to formulate a demand which, if complied with, must
('83', 447, 4, 8, 989692) necessarily lead to anarchy or to frame a programme of widespread self inflicted
('83', 447, 5, 9, 989773) suffering based on the refusal of such a demand.
('83', 447, 6, 10, 989822) Your proposal that while the civil power may be withdrawn, the British and Allied forces may Continue in India in anticipation of a treaty with a problematic provisional Indian government will only lead to the exercise of all governmental functions by the military forces.
('83', 447, 6, 11, 990095) This will happen if only for their own safety and effective functioning.
('83', 447, 6, 12, 990168) They are further likely to be urged towards this step by local chieftains and suffering people.
('83', 447, 6, 13, 990264) This would be the reinstallation of the British Government in a worse form.
('83', 447, 7, 14, 990340) In spite of these objections we might have submitted to your proposal if only because of the fact that the British are not going to withdraw, and in actual operation the movement would amount to a nationwide protest against the existing Government and may be productive of a satisfactory settlement in due course.
('83', 447, 7, 15, 990654) But the critical international situation in which India is directly involved makes it certain that the party to gain immediately by the movement will be Japan.
('83', 447, 7, 16, 990814) If the movement could possibly displace the British Government, installing a national government capable of resisting Japanese aggression, it might be worth taking all risks attached to it.
('83', 447, 7, 17, 991004) But as this result is not even remotely probable, it will only produce more intense and large scale repression and suffering which will facilitate Japaneses invasion and occupation.
('83', 448, 0, 1, 991186) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 449
('83', 448, 1, 2, 991230) It is hardly likely that the authorities will allow the movement to proceed under central direction in an orderly and direct fashion.
('83', 448, 1, 3, 991364) Even if we do not mind sporadic violence that may result from lack of proper control, there is another serious danger.
('83', 448, 1, 4, 991483) When responsible leaders are removed and their guidance is no longer available the movement can easily be taken advantage of by the enemy and be converted into a fifth column activity on his behalf.
('83', 448, 2, 5, 991682) Any movement started by you would have commanded our loyal participation, in spite of differences of opinion, if the movement did not involve such grave consequences as pointed out above.
('83', 448, 2, 6, 991870) Our conviction is strong enough to make it our duty publicly to oppose the proposal on these grounds.
('83', 448, 2, 7, 991972) But it may be thought at this stage that your move will operate as a protest with an international appeal and bring about a fresh approach towards a political settlement for India without actually plunging the country in direct action.
('83', 448, 2, 8, 992208) In order that any step on our part may not lessen this chance we refrain from giving public expression to our opposition but send this letter to entreat you to desist from taking the steps you have adumbrated.
('83', 448, 3, 9, 992418) (Sd.) C. Rajagopalachari, K. Santhanam, S. Ramanathan, Dr. T. S. S. Rajan
('83', 448, 4, 10, 992492) The Indian Annual Register, 1942. VoI.

('83', 448, 6, 13, 992552) C. RAJAGOPALACHARI’S FORMULA 1
('83', 448, 7, 14, 992583) Basis for terms of settlement between the Indian National Congress and the AII India Muslim League to which Gandhiji and Mr. Jinnah agree and which they will endeavour respectively to get the Congress and the League to approve:
('83', 448, 8, 15, 992811) (1) Subject to the terms set out below as regards the Constitution for free India, the Muslim League endorses the Indian demand for independence and will co operate with the Congress in the formation of a provisional interim government for the transitional period.
('83', 448, 9, 16, 993076) (2) After the termination of the War, a commission shall be appointed for demarcating contiguous districts in the north west and east of India, wherein the Muslim population is in absolute majority.
('83', 448, 9, 17, 993275) In the areas thus demarcated, a plebiscite of all the inhabitants held on the basis of adult suffrage or other practicable franchise shall ultimately decide the issue of separation from Hindustan.
('83', 448, 9, 18, 993472) If the majority decide in favour of forming a sovereign State separate from Hindustan, such decision shall

('83', 449, 0, 1, 993629) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 449, 1, 2, 993671) be given effect to, without prejudice to the right of districts on the border to choose to join either State.
('83', 449, 2, 3, 993781) (3) It will be open to all parties to advocate their points of view before the plebiscite is held.
('83', 449, 3, 4, 993880) (4) In the event of separation, mutual agreements shall be entered into for safeguarding defence, and commerce and communications and for other essential purposes.
('83', 449, 4, 5, 994044) (5) Any transfer of population shall only be on an absolutely voluntary basis.
('83', 449, 5, 6, 994123) (6) These terms shall be binding only in case of transfer by Britain of full power and responsibility for the governance of India.

('83', 449, 7, 8, 994278) APPENDIX IV
('83', 449, 8, 9, 994290) JAWAHARLAL NEHRU’S STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('83', 449, 9, 10, 994334) August 5, 1942
('83', 449, 10, 11, 994349) I have just seen for the first time the Government’s ‘communique’ issuing certain documents obtained during the police raid from the A.I.C.C. office.
('83', 449, 10, 12, 994499) It is astonishing to what a pass the Government of India has been reduced when it has to adopt these discreditable and dishonourable tactics.
('83', 449, 10, 13, 994641) Normally such tactics require no answer.
('83', 449, 10, 14, 994682) But as there is likely to be misapprehension, I wish to clear up some matters.
('83', 449, 11, 15, 994761) It is not our custom to keep detailed minutes of the Working Committee’s meetings.
('83', 449, 11, 16, 994844) Only final decisions are recorded.
('83', 449, 11, 17, 994879) On this occasion the Assistant Secretary took brief notes unofficially apparently for his own record.
('83', 449, 11, 18, 994981) These notes are very brief and disjointed and represent several days’ prolonged debate during which I must have spoken on various occasions for two or three hours.
('83', 449, 11, 19, 995145) Only a few sentences were taken down and torn from their context.
('83', 449, 11, 20, 995211) They often give a wrong impression.
('83', 449, 11, 21, 995247) None of us had a chance of seeing these notes or of revising them.
('83', 449, 11, 22, 995314) The record is very unsatisfactory and incomplete and hence often incorrect.
('83', 449, 12, 23, 995390) In our discussions Mahatma Gandhi was not present.
('83', 449, 12, 24, 995441) We had to consider every aspect of the question fully and to weigh the implications of words and phrases in the draft resolutions.
('83', 449, 12, 25, 995572) If Gandhiji had been there, much of this discussion might have been avoided as he could have explained to us his attitude more fully.
('83', 449, 13, 26, 995706) Thus when the question of British withdrawal from India was considered, I pointed out that if the armed forces were suddenly withdrawn, the Japanese might well advance and invade the country without hindrance.
('83', 449, 13, 27, 995916) This obvious difficulty was
('83', 449, 14, 28, 995944) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 5 8 1942.
('83', 450, 0, 1, 995987) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 451
('83', 450, 1, 2, 996031) removed when Gandhiji later explained that British and other armed forces might remain to prevent aggression.
('83', 450, 2, 3, 996141) In regard to the statement that Gandhiji expected an Axis victory, an important qualification has been omitted.
('83', 450, 2, 4, 996253) What he has repeatedly said and what I have referred to is his belief that unless Britain changes her whole policy in regard to India and her colonial possessions, she is heading for disaster.
('83', 450, 2, 5, 996446) He has further stated that if a suitable change in this policy was made and the War really became one for freedom for all people, then victory would assuredly come to the United Nations.
('83', 450, 3, 6, 996633) The references to negotiations with Japan are also incorrect and entirely torn from their context.
('83', 450, 3, 7, 996732) Gandhiji always sends notice to his adversary before coming into conflict.
('83', 450, 3, 8, 996807) He would thus have called upon Japan not only to keep away from India, but to withdraw from China, etc.
('83', 450, 3, 9, 996911) In any event he was determined to resist every aggressor in India and he advised our people to do so even to the point of death.
('83', 450, 3, 10, 997040) They were never to submit.
('83', 450, 4, 11, 997067) It is absurd to say that any of us envisaged any arrangements with Japan giving her right of passage, etc.
('83', 450, 4, 12, 997174) What I said was that Japan would want this, but we could never agree.
('83', 450, 4, 13, 997244) Our whole policy has all along been based on uttermost resistance to aggression.
('83', 450, 5, 14, 997325) The Bombay Chronicle, 5 8 1942, and Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, 1942 44, pp.
('83', 450, 6, 15, 997421) APPENDIX V
('83', 450, 7, 16, 997432) RESOLUTION PASSED BY ALL INDIA CONGRESS COMMITTEE 1
('83', 450, 8, 17, 997484) [August 8, 1942]
('83', 450, 9, 18, 997501) The All India Congress Committee has given the most careful consideration to the reference made to it by the Working Committee in their resolution dated July 14, 1942, and to subsequent events, including the development of the war situation, the utterances of responsible spokesmen of the British Government, and the comments and criticisms made in India and abroad.
('83', 450, 9, 19, 997868) The Committee approves of and endorses that resolution, and is of opinion that events subsequent to it have given it further justification, and have made it clear that the immediate ending of British rule in India is an urgent necessity, both for the sake of India and for the success of the cause of the United Nations.
('83', 450, 9, 20, 998189) The continuation of that rule is degrading and enfeebling India and making her progressively less capable of defending herself and of contributing to the cause of world freedom.
('83', 450, 10, 21, 998367) 1 Vide “Interview to the Associated Press”, 6 8 1942.
('83', 451, 0, 1, 998421) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 451, 1, 2, 998463) The Committee has viewed with dismay the deterioration of the situation on the Russian and Chinese fronts and conveys to the Russian and Chinese peoples its high appreciation of their heroism in defence of their freedom.
('83', 451, 1, 3, 998684) This increasing peril makes it incumbent on all those who strive for freedom and who sympathize with the victims of aggression, to examine the foundations of the policy so far pursued by the Allied Nations, which have led to repeated and disastrous failure.
('83', 451, 1, 4, 998942) It is not by adhering to such aims and policies and methods that failure can be converted into success, for past experience has shown that failure is inherent in them.
('83', 451, 1, 5, 999110) These policies have been based not on freedom so much as on the domination of subject and colonial countries, and the continuation of the imperialist tradition and method.
('83', 451, 1, 6, 999282) The possession of Empire, instead of adding to the strength of the ruling power, has become a burden and a curse.
('83', 451, 1, 7, 999396) India, the classic land of modern Imperialism, has become the crux of the question, for by the freedom of India will Britain and the United Nations be judged, and the people of Asia and Africa be filled with hope and enthusiasm.
('83', 451, 2, 8, 999625) The ending of British rule in this country is thus a vital and immediate issue on which depend the future of the war and the success of freedom and democracy.
('83', 451, 2, 9, 999784) A free India will assure this success by throwing all her great resources in the struggle for freedom and against the aggression of Nazism, Fascism and Imperialism.
('83', 451, 2, 10, 999949) This will not only affect materially the fortunes of the war, but will bring all subject and oppressed humanity on the side of the United Nations, and give these nations, whose ally India would be, the moral and spiritual leadership of the world.
('83', 451, 2, 11, 1000196) India in bondage will continue to be the symbol of British Imperialism and the taint of that Imperialism will affect the fortunes of all the United Nations.
('83', 451, 3, 12, 1000353) The peril of today, therefore, necessitates the independence of India and the ending of British dominations.
('83', 451, 3, 13, 1000462) No future promises or guarantees can affect the present situation or meet that peril.
('83', 451, 3, 14, 1000548) They cannot produce the needed psychological effect on the mind of the masses.
('83', 451, 3, 15, 1000627) Only the glow of freedom now can release that energy and enthusiasm of millions of people which will immediately transform the nature of the war.
('83', 451, 4, 16, 1000773) The A. I. C. C., therefore, repeats with all emphasis the demand for the withdrawal of the British power from India.
('83', 451, 4, 17, 1000890) On the declaration of India’s independence, a provisional government will be formed and free India will become an ally of the United Nations, sharing with them in the trials and tribulations of the joint enterprise of the struggle for freedom.
('83', 451, 4, 18, 1001134) The provisional government can only be formed by the co operation of the principal parties and groups in the country.
('83', 451, 4, 19, 1001252) It will thus be a composite government, representative of all important sections of the people of India.
('83', 451, 4, 20, 1001357) Its primary functions must be to defend India and resist aggression with all the armed as well as the non violent forces at its command, together with the Allied powers, and to promote the well being and progress of the workers in the fields
('83', 452, 0, 1, 1001599) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 453
('83', 452, 1, 2, 1001643) and factories and elsewhere, to whom essentially all power and authority must belong.
('83', 452, 1, 3, 1001729) The provisional government will evolve a scheme for a constitutent assembly which will prepare a constitution for the government of India acceptable to all sections of the people.
('83', 452, 1, 4, 1001909) This constitution, according to the Congress view, should be a federal one, with the largest measure of autonomy for the federating units, and with the residuary powers vesting in these units.
('83', 452, 1, 5, 1002102) The future relations between India and the Allied nations will be adjusted by representatives of all these free countries conferring together for their mutual advantage and for their co operation in the common task of resisting aggression.
('83', 452, 1, 6, 1002342) Freedom will enable India to resist aggression effectively with the people’s united will and strength behind it.
('83', 452, 2, 7, 1002455) The freedom of India must be the symbol of and prelude to this freedom of all other Asiatic nations under foreign domination.
('83', 452, 2, 8, 1002581) Burma, Malaya, Indo China, the Dutch Indies, Iran and Iraq must also attain their complete freedom.
('83', 452, 2, 9, 1002681) It must be clearly understood that such of these countries as are under Japanese control now must not subsequently be placed under the rule or control of any other colonial power.
('83', 452, 3, 10, 1002861) While the A. I. C. C. must primarily be concerned with the independence and defence of India in this hour of danger, the Committee is of opinion that the future peace, security and ordered progress of the world demand a world federation of free nations, and on no other basis can the problems of the modern world be solved.
('83', 452, 3, 11, 1003185) Such a world federation would ensure the freedom of its constituent nations, the prevention of aggression and exploitation by one nation over another, the protection of national minorities, the advancement of all backward areas and peoples, and the pooling of the world’s resources for the common good of all.
('83', 452, 3, 12, 1003495) On the establishment of such a world federation, disarmament would be practicable in all countries, national armies, navies and air forces would no longer be necessary, and a world federal defence force would keep the world peace and prevent aggression.
('83', 452, 4, 13, 1003749) An independent India would gladly join such a world federation and co operate on an equal basis with other countries in the solution of international problems.
('83', 452, 5, 14, 1003909) Such a federation should be open to all nations who agree with its fundamental principles.
('83', 452, 5, 15, 1004000) In view of the war, however, the federation must inevitably, to begin with, be confined to the United Nations.
('83', 452, 5, 16, 1004111) Such a step taken will have a most powerful effect on the war, on the peoples of the Axis countries, and on the peace to come.
('83', 452, 6, 17, 1004238) The Committee regretfully realizes, however, that despite the tragic and overwhelming lessons of the war and the perils that overhang the world, the governments of few countries are yet prepared to take this inevitable step towards world federation.
('83', 452, 6, 18, 1004488) The reactions of the British Government and the misguided criticism of the foreign Press also make it clear that even the obvious demand for India’s independence is resisted, though this has been made essentially to meet the present peril and to enable India to defend herself and help China and Russia in their hour of
('83', 453, 0, 1, 1004808) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 453, 1, 2, 1004850) The Committee is anxious not to embarrass in any way the defence of China or Russia, whose freedom is precious and must be preserved, or to jeopardize the defensive capacity of the United Nations.
('83', 453, 1, 3, 1005047) But the peril grows both to India and these nations, and inaction and submission to a foreign administration at this stage is not only degrading India and reducing her capacity to defend hereself and resist aggression, but is no answer to that growing peril and is no service to the peoples of the United Nations.
('83', 453, 1, 4, 1005361) The earnest appeal of the Working Committee to Great Britain and the United Nations has so far met with no response, and the criticisms made in many foreign quarters have shown an ignorance of India’s and the world’s need, and sometimes even hostility to India’s freedom, which is significant of a mentality of domination and racial superiority which cannot be tolerated by a proud people conscious of their strength and of the justice of their cause.
('83', 453, 2, 5, 1005813) The A. I. C.C. would yet again, at this last moment, in the interest of world freedom, renew this appeal to Britain and the United Nations.
('83', 453, 2, 6, 1005953) Bat the Committee feels that it is no longer justified in holding the nation back from endeavouring to assert its will against an imperialist and authoritarian government, which dominates over and prevents it from functioning in its own interest and in the interest of humanity.
('83', 453, 2, 7, 1006232) The Committee resolves, therefore, to sanction, for the vindication of India’s inalienable right to freedom and independence, the starting of a mass struggle on non violent lines on the widest possible scale, so that the country might utilize all the nonviolent strength it has gathered during the last twenty two years of peaceful struggle.
('83', 453, 2, 8, 1006574) Such a struggle must inevitably be under the leadership of Gandhiji and the Committee requests him to take the lead and guide the nation in the steps to be taken.
('83', 453, 2, 9, 1006737) The Committee appeals to the people of India to face the dangers and hardships that will fall to their lot with courage and endurance, and to hold together under tile leadership of Gandhiji and carry out his instructions as disciplined soldiers of Indian freedom.
('83', 453, 2, 10, 1007001) They must remember that nonviolence is the basis of this movement.
('83', 453, 2, 11, 1007068) A time may come when it may not be possible to issue instructions or for instructions to reach our people, and when no Congress committees can function.
('83', 453, 2, 12, 1007221) When this happens, every man and woman who is participating in this movement must function for himself or herself within the four corners of the general instructions issued.
('83', 453, 2, 13, 1007395) Every Indian who desires freedom and strives for it must be his own guide urging him on along the hard road where there is no resting place and which leads ultimately to the independence and deliverance of India.
('83', 453, 2, 14, 1007608) Lastly, whilst the A. I. C. C. has stated its own view of the future governance under free India the A. I. C. C. wishes to make it quite clear to all concerned that by embarking on mass struggle it has no intention of gaining power for the Congress.
('83', 453, 2, 15, 1007858) The power, when, it comes, will belong to the whole people of India.
('83', 453, 3, 16, 1007927) The Indian Annual Register, 1942, Vol. II, pp.
('83', 453, 3, 17, 1007974) 209 11; also Harijan, 9 8 1942 and The Transfer of Power, Vol. II, pp.

('83', 454, 7, 18, 1009099) It may be amusing that I should address a lecture on non violence to you.

('83', 454, 7, 20, 1009234) And Newton may go wrong if he refuses to do so.
('83', 454, 7, 21, 1009282) Anyway I have your [certifi]cate that did not go to my head at the time you gave that richly.
('83', 454, 7, 22, 1009376) I suppose you will not withdraw them because I have to differ from you now a la the nawabs.
('83', 454, 8, 23, 1009468) You may reiterate and insist as much as you like on non violence.
('83', 454, 8, 24, 1009534) But there is not a shadow of doubt.
('83', 454, 8, 25, 1009570) The momentum of your present move is wholly —almost wholly—the violence of the Axis powers and the critical state to which the British have been thereby reduced—not the non violence or love inherent in your proposals and plans.
('83', 454, 8, 26, 1009798) You are scientific enough to see this as plain as the chemist in a laboratory.
('83', 454, 9, 27, 1009877) What am I driving at?
('83', 454, 9, 28, 1009899) It is this.
('83', 454, 9, 29, 1009911) What you are now doing is not an adventure in non violence though it may have that delusive appearance.
('83', 454, 9, 30, 1010015) It is generating intense hatred in the British mind as a result of the utilization of the violence of others that they feel you are pitilessly making at a most critical point of time in the war.

('83', 455, 5, 8, 1010951) APPENDIX VII
('83', 455, 6, 9, 1010964) RESOLUTION OF THE GOVERNMENT OF INDIA 1
('83', 455, 7, 10, 1011004) NEW DELHI, August 7, 1942
('83', 455, 8, 11, 1011030) The A. I. C. C. have ratified the resolution passed by the Working Committee of the Indian National Congress on 5th August.
('83', 455, 8, 12, 1011154) That Resolution demands the immediate withdrawal of British power from India, and sanctions “the starting of a mass struggle on non violent lines on the widest possible scale”.
('83', 455, 8, 13, 1011331) The Governor General in Council has been aware, too, for some days past of dangerous preparations by the Congress Party for unlawful, and in some cases violent activities, directed among other things to the interruption of communications and public utility services, the organization of strikes, tampering with the loyalty of Government servants, and interference with defence measures, including recruitment.
('83', 455, 9, 14, 1011741) 2. The Government of India have waited patiently in the hope that wiser counsels might prevail.
('83', 455, 9, 15, 1011837) They have been disappointed in that hope.
('83', 455, 9, 16, 1011879) To a challenge such as the present there can only be one answer.
('83', 455, 9, 17, 1011944) The Government of India would regard it as wholly incompatible with their responsibilities to the people of India, and their obligations to the Allies, that a demand should be discussed the acceptance of which would plunge India into confusion and anarchy internally, and would paralyze her effort in the common cause of human freedom.
('83', 455, 10, 18, 1012280) 3. For the demand of the Congress leaders there is no warrant.
('83', 455, 10, 19, 1012343) In the view of the Government of India that demand is difficult, if not impossible, to reconcile with a full sense of responsibility on the part of the leaders of the Congress Party, or a full appreciation by them of the realities of the present situation.
('83', 455, 10, 20, 1012600) The Congress Working Committee admit that “there may be risks involved”.
('83', 455, 10, 21, 1012673) They are right.
('83', 455, 10, 22, 1012689) Acceptance of the resolution must mean the exposure of India to Axis attack from without.
('83', 455, 10, 23, 1012779) Internally the withdrawal of British rule invites civil war, the collapse of law and
('83', 455, 11, 24, 1012864) 1 Vide “Letter to Sir Roger Lumley”, 10 8 1942.
('83', 456, 0, 1, 1012912) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 457
('83', 456, 1, 2, 1012956) order, the outbreak of communal feud, the dislocation of economic life with its inevitable hardships.
('83', 456, 1, 3, 1013058) Nor can the Government of India accept the claim of the Congress Party to speak for India as a whole.
('83', 456, 1, 4, 1013160) The Congress Party has for long occupied a position of great prominence and great importance in Indian political life.
('83', 456, 1, 5, 1013279) At this day its importance is substantial.
('83', 456, 1, 6, 1013322) But it is the duty of the Government of India to take a balanced view of the interests of all sections of Indian thought and Indian opinion.
('83', 456, 1, 7, 1013463) And looking as they must to the repeated protests even in these last few days by the leaders of great communities and solidly established interests, by so many leaders of liberal thought, by those great sections of the population which are giving unstinted and invaluable support to war against Axis aggression, they are confirmed in their view that that claim has no solid foundation, and that acceptance of the proposals now put forward by the Congress Party must mean the abandonment of all those large and powerful elements in the population which have condemned the course of action proposed by the Congress Party and which resent and resist the widespread dislocation which its acceptance would involve of India’s war effort and of the general life of the community.
('83', 456, 2, 8, 1014236) 4. Nor can the Congress leaders claim that only thus can India’s future be assured.
('83', 456, 2, 9, 1014320) The Congress Party is not India’s mouthpiece, yet, in the interests of securing their own dominance, and in pursuit of their totalitarian policy its leaders have consistently impeded the efforts made to bring India to full nationhood.
('83', 456, 2, 10, 1014555) But for the resistance of the Congress Party to constructive endeavours, India might even now be enjoying self government.
('83', 456, 2, 11, 1014678) British policy for India’s future stands clear.
('83', 456, 2, 12, 1014726) It is that once hostilities cease, India shall devise for herself with full freedom of decision, and on a basis embracing all, and not only a single party, the form of government which she regards as most suited to her conditions: and that in the mean time Indian leaders shall fully participate in the government of their country, and in the counsels of the Commonwealth and of the United Nations.
('83', 456, 2, 13, 1015125) The fullest opportunity for the attainment of self government by the people of India has been guaranteed by His Majesty’s Government.
('83', 456, 2, 14, 1015259) It is on the basis fully accepted by His Majesty’s Government and by the people of Great Britain, that the fullest opportunity shall be given for the attainment of self government by the Indian people, that when the day of victory comes the final structure of India’s constitution will be erected by Indians themselves.
('83', 456, 2, 15, 1015579) That those guarantees given by the British Parliament and the British people are accepted by the people of India we firmly believe.
('83', 456, 2, 16, 1015711) The suggestion put forward by the Congress Party that the millions of India uncertain as to the future are ready, despite the sad lessons of so many martyr countries, to throw themselves into the arms of the invader is one that the Government of India cannot accept as a true representation of the feeling of the people of this great country.
('83', 456, 3, 17, 1016054) 5. The leaders of the Congress Party have claimed that the withdrawal of British rule “with goowill” will “result in establishing a stable provisional
('83', 457, 0, 1, 1016205) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 457, 1, 2, 1016247) government in India, and co operation between this Government and the United Nations in resisting aggression and helping China”.
('83', 457, 1, 3, 1016376) There is no justification for those claims.
('83', 457, 1, 4, 1016420) Nor can the Government of India accept the suggestion that a stable provisional government could be formed in a moment of time within a day or two of the withdrawal of British power.
('83', 457, 1, 5, 1016603) Past experience has shown to their profound regret the existence of the deep differences in this country, the harmonizing of which must be the object of all on whom responsibility falls, the removal of which is the ambition and the hope of the present Government of India.
('83', 457, 1, 6, 1016876) But to deny that those problems confront India today would be to ignore the facts: and the Government of India are satisfied that the interval between the withdrawal of British rule and the establishment of a stable provisional government would provide an open opportunity for the enemies of order and for all dissident elements in the population.
('83', 457, 1, 7, 1017224) In the view of the Government of India it is not too much to say that acceptance of the demand now put forward by the Congress Party must mean the betrayal of the Allies, whether in or outside India, the betrayal in particular of Russia and China, the betrayal of those ideal to which so much support has been given and is given today from the true heart and mind of India, the betrayal of India’s fighting men, whose glory is so great, and the betrayal of all those loyal and co operating elements in India which do not support the Congress Party, but which have played so active and so valuable a part in the prosecution of the War.
('83', 457, 2, 8, 1017859) 6. India has today a government stronger and more representative than ever in the past, a government predominantly Indian and non official, a government determined to prosecute the War and no less determined to lead India on to her political goal.
('83', 457, 2, 9, 1018107) There is nothing that the Government of India regret more than this challenge at so critical a juncture.
('83', 457, 2, 10, 1018212) But on them there lies the task of defending India, of maintaining India’s capacity to wage War, of safeguarding India’s interests, of holding the balance between the different sections of her people without fear or favour.
('83', 457, 2, 11, 1018436) That task the Government of India will discharge in face of the challenge now thrown down by the Congress Party with clear determination, but with an anxiety that action shall be preventive of the interruption of war effort and the other dangers to which they have referred rather than punitive, and with a full consciousness of responsibility to India and to the cause of the Allies and of civilization.
('83', 457, 2, 12, 1018841) Their duty is plain, and they have to discharge it, profoundly as they must deplore the situation which they have been called upon to face.
('83', 457, 2, 13, 1018981) They urge the people of India to unite with them in resistance to the present challenge of a party.
('83', 457, 2, 14, 1019081) They appeal to them to lay aside all political differences and for the period of the War to place before all other considerations the defence of their country, and the achievement of those common aims on which depends the future not only of India but of all the freedom loving peoples of the world.
('83', 457, 3, 15, 1019380) The Transfer of Power, Vol. II, pp.
('83', 458, 0, 1, 1019416) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 459
('83', 458, 1, 2, 1019460) APPENDIX VIII
('83', 458, 2, 3, 1019474) TALK WITH PYARELAL ON MARXISM
('83', 458, 3, 4, 1019504) [After August 9, 1942]
('83', 458, 4, 5, 1019527) After an extensive reading of Marxian literature during his last detention at Poona, he remarked: “I think I could have written Marx better than Marx, provided, of course, I had his scholarship which I do not have.
('83', 458, 4, 6, 1019742) He has the knack of making even simple things appear difficult.”.
('83', 458, 5, 7, 1019808) On the fly leaf of A Handbook of Marxism he scribbled: “All for each and each for all.” “From each according to his capacity to each according to his need.”...
('83', 458, 6, 8, 1019968) I tried to get him to give his appraisal of some aspects of the Marxist philosophy....
('83', 458, 7, 9, 1020055) I said, “Marx showed us that our ideologies, institutions, and ethical standards, literature, art, customs, even religion, are a product of our economic environment.”
('83', 458, 8, 10, 1020222) G. I do not agree that our ideologies, ethical standards and values are altogether a product of our material environment without any absolute basis outside it.
('83', 458, 8, 11, 1020382) On the contrary as we are so our environment becomes.
('83', 458, 9, 12, 1020436) Is not the Wardha scheme of Basic Education based upon the assumption that purposive activity of the hand moulds not only our thinking but our whole personality?
('83', 458, 9, 13, 1020598) Does that not come very near the materialistic theory of knowledge as propounded by Marx?
('83', 458, 10, 14, 1020688) But the Marxist wants to abolish the labouring hand altogether and substitute in its place the machine.
('83', 458, 10, 15, 1020792) He has no use for the hand.
('83', 458, 10, 16, 1020820) Dependence on manual labour, according to Marx, is the symbol and root cause of the destitution and slavery of the worker.
('83', 458, 10, 17, 1020943) It is the function of the machine to emancipate him from this state.
('83', 458, 10, 18, 1021012) I, on the other hand, hold that machine enslaves and only intelligent use of the hand will bring to the worker both freedom and happiness....
('83', 458, 11, 19, 1021154) The Marxist regards thought, as it were, ‘a secretion of the brain’ and the mind ‘a reflex of the material environment’.
('83', 458, 11, 20, 1021275) I cannot accept that.
('83', 458, 11, 21, 1021297) Above and beyond both matter and mind is He.
('83', 458, 11, 22, 1021342) If I have an awareness of that living principle within me, no one can fetter my mind.
('83', 458, 11, 23, 1021428) The body might be destroyed, the spirit will proclaim its freedom.
('83', 458, 11, 24, 1021495) This to me is not a theory; it is a fact of experience.
('83', 458, 12, 25, 1021551) P. The Marxists concede that an individual may transcend his material environment but class behaviour is essentially determined by it.
('83', 458, 12, 26, 1021686) It cannot change unless the economic environment is altered.
('83', 458, 12, 27, 1021747) To transform the capitalist the capitalistic order must be destroyed.
('83', 458, 13, 28, 1021817) G. What an individual can do, a whole class of people can be induced to do, it is all a question of discovering the right technique.
('83', 458, 13, 29, 1021950) The whole of our non violent
('83', 459, 0, 1, 1021979) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 459, 1, 2, 1022021) non co operation movement, which aims at transforming the British ruling class, is based on this hypothesis.
('83', 459, 1, 3, 1022130) Trusteeship is my answer to the issue of class conflict.
('83', 459, 2, 4, 1022187) I passed on to the Marxist doctrine of economic motivation of history.
('83', 459, 2, 5, 1022258) The wars were an inevitable consequence of the institution of private property in the capitalistic system.
('83', 459, 2, 6, 1022365) Gandhiji rejected the one and disagreed with the other.
('83', 459, 3, 7, 1022421) G. No, not the economic factor alone.
('83', 459, 3, 8, 1022459) Ultimately it is the Unseen Power that governs the course of events—even in the minds of men who make those events.
('83', 459, 3, 9, 1022575) Supposing Hitler were to die today, it would alter the whole course of current history.
('83', 459, 3, 10, 1022663) Similarly, supposing all capitalists were wiped out as a result of an earthquake or some other natural cataclysm, the history of class war would then be changed in a way least dreamt of by the exponents of economic interpretation of history.
('83', 459, 3, 11, 1022905) Would not the history of the present war have been different if instead of Chamberlain a more dynamic figure had been the Prime Minister of England?
('83', 459, 3, 12, 1023054) Or, if Chamberlain had not shown lack of political courage at the last moment?
('83', 459, 4, 13, 1023133) P. The Marxists say that to abolish war we have but to abolish the institution of private property.
('83', 459, 4, 14, 1023233) You have also taught that property is incompatible with the non violent way of life.
('83', 459, 5, 15, 1023318) G. This is only partly true.
('83', 459, 5, 16, 1023347) Was not Helen of Troy the cause of the Trojan War?
('83', 459, 5, 17, 1023398) Were the wars of the Rajputs related to the institution of private property?
('83', 459, 5, 18, 1023475) No, to banish war we have to do more.
('83', 459, 5, 19, 1023513) We have to eradicate possessiveness and greed and lust and egotism from our own hearts.
('83', 459, 5, 20, 1023601) We have to carry war within ourselves to banish it from society.
('83', 459, 6, 21, 1023666) P. The remedies prescribed by Marx are of course wrong but can we not make use of his diagnosis of the malaise that affects our society for a proper understanding of the problem and devising right remedies for the same?
('83', 459, 6, 22, 1023886) My point is that Marx knew of only one effective sanction, viz., of violence —force.
('83', 459, 6, 23, 1023971) If only he had been aware of the sanction of non violence or satyagraha and its potency, he might have adopted it in place of violence.
('83', 459, 6, 24, 1024107) Even in our own time industry is being changed over from steam to oil and electricity.
('83', 459, 7, 25, 1024194) G. 1 have also heard it said that often it is more economical to dispose of the old plant than to try to adapt it from one kind of motive power to another.
('83', 459, 7, 26, 1024350) In the present case, the difference between violence and non violence is fundamental.
('83', 459, 7, 27, 1024436) It cuts at the very root of the Marxist theory.
('83', 459, 7, 28, 1024484) If you alter the foundation the whole superstructure will have to be changed.
('83', 459, 8, 29, 1024562) P. 1 agree.
('83', 459, 8, 30, 1024574) But you have derived non violence from the Gita.
('83', 459, 8, 31, 1024623) I find a powerful support in the Marxist analysis for your method of non violent non co operation.
('83', 459, 9, 32, 1024722) G. My interpretation of the Gita is rejected by those who do not believe in ahimsa and those who are believers in ahimsa do not need it.
('83', 459, 9, 33, 1024859) Your interpretations will
('83', 460, 0, 1, 1024885) VOL. 83 : 7 JUNE, 1942 26 JANUARY, 1944 461
('83', 460, 1, 2, 1024929) be dubbed un Marxist by convinced Marxists.
('83', 460, 1, 3, 1024973) It will not appeal to them....
('83', 460, 2, 4, 1025004) After some further discussion Gandhiji said:
('83', 460, 3, 5, 1025049) You can advance this as your own original thesis on Marx.
('83', 460, 3, 6, 1025107) It might provide a rationale for the practice of satyagraha to those who lack the spiritual background.
('83', 460, 3, 7, 1025211) What has made the teaching of Marx dynamic is that he regarded mankind as a whole and transcending class divisions indentified himself with the cause of the poor oppressed toilers of the world.
('83', 460, 3, 8, 1025405) But in that he is not alone.
('83', 460, 3, 9, 1025434) Others besides him have done the same.
('83', 460, 4, 10, 1025473) He would not concede that Marx had founded an absolute science of society or discovered any laws of social dynamics which a priori have an objective validity.
('83', 460, 4, 11, 1025632) The Marxian system was just an attempt to forge a tool for the achievement of a certain goal which Marx held to be desirable.
('83', 460, 4, 12, 1025758) Finally he said:
('83', 460, 5, 13, 1025775) We may criticize Marx but that he was a great man who can deny?
('83', 460, 5, 14, 1025839) His analysis of social ills or the cures he prescribed for them may or may not be correct.
('83', 460, 5, 15, 1025930) I do not accept his economic theories but this much I know that the poor are being ground down.
('83', 460, 5, 16, 1026026) Something has got to be done for it.
('83', 460, 5, 17, 1026063) Marx set about to do that in his own way.
('83', 460, 5, 18, 1026105) He had acumen, scholarship, genius.
('83', 460, 6, 19, 1026141) Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. II, pp.
('83', 460, 7, 20, 1026185) APPENDIX IX
('83', 460, 8, 21, 1026197) LETTER FROM LORD LINLITHGOW 1
('83', 460, 9, 22, 1026227) Personal January 13, 1943
('83', 460, 10, 23, 1026253) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('83', 460, 11, 24, 1026270) Thank you for your personal letter of December 31 which I have just received.
('83', 460, 11, 25, 1026348) I fully accept its personal character, and I welcome its frankness.
('83', 460, 11, 26, 1026416) And my reply will be, as you would wish it to be, as frank and as entirely personal as your letter itself.
('83', 460, 12, 27, 1026523) 2. I was glad to have your letter, for, to be as open with you as our previous relations justify, I have been profoundly depressed during recent months; first, by the policy that was adopted by the Congress in August, secondly, because while that policy gave rise, as it was obvious it must, throughout the country to violence and crime (I say nothing of the risks to India from outside aggression), no word of condemnation for that violence and crime should have come from you, or from the Working Committee.
('83', 460, 12, 28, 1027033) When you were first at Poona, I knew that you were not receiving newspapers, and I accepted that as explaining your silence.
('83', 460, 13, 29, 1027158) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 19 1 1943 and “Letter to Lord Samuel”, 15 5 1943.
('83', 461, 0, 1, 1027244) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('83', 461, 1, 2, 1027286) arrangements were made that you and the Working Committee should have such newspapers as you desired, I felt certain that the details those newspapers contained of what was happening would shock and distress you as much as it has us all, and that you would be anxious to make your condemnation of it categorical and widely known.
('83', 461, 1, 3, 1027616) But that was not the case; and it has been a real disappointment to me, all the more when I think of these murders, the burning alive of police officials, the wrecking of trains, the destruction of property, the misleading of these young students, which has done so much harm to India’s good name, and to the Congress party.
('83', 461, 1, 4, 1027941) You may take it from me that the newspaper accounts you mention are well founded—I only wish they were not, for the story is a bad one.
('83', 461, 1, 5, 1028077) I well know the immense weight of your great authority in the Congress movement and with the party and those who follow its lead, and I wish I could feel, again speaking very frankly, that a heavy responsibility did not rest on you.
('83', 461, 1, 6, 1028310) (And unhappily, while the initial responsibility rests with the leaders, others have to bear the consequences, whether as lawbreakers, with the results that that involves, or as the victims.) 3. But if I am right in reading your letter to mean that in the light of what has happened you wish now to retrace your steps and dissociate yourself from the policy of last summer, you have only to let me know and I will at once consider the matter further.
('83', 461, 1, 7, 1028761) And, if I have failed to understand your object, you must not hesitate to let me know without delay in what respect I have done so, and tell me what positive suggestion you wish to put to me.
('83', 461, 1, 8, 1028953) You know me well enough after these many years to believe that I shall be only too concerned to read with the same close attention as ever any message which I receive from you, to give it the fullest weight, and to approach it with the deepest anxiety to understand your feeling and your motives.
('83', 461, 2, 9, 1029250) Yours sincerely,
('83', 461, 3, 10, 1029267) LINLITHGOW
